After revising many options, we decided that cooking lessons would be a fantastic way to start our journey...and indeed it was great.I contacted Faim d' Epices via email and Michel swiftly responded to all my queries and arranged our cooking class. If you have any dietary restriction, they will kindly accomodate it so no stress in that matter.As planned, they were picking us up timely at the Hotel to be transported to the training location, a confortable facility surrounded by orange and olive trees. There, we were welcomed by Michel with mint tea and we met the rest of the apprentices.After explaining the activities for the day, we were invited to check out how Nezha, the chef, prepared bread in the traditional way. Later we engaged a worksop on spices. This was a super interesting activity and we had so much fun trying to identify (blinded of course) the wide range of aromas presented.After the workshop we went to our neatly arranged cooking stations, prepared with the tagines, chopping board, knife and other relevant cooking utensils, as well as with the mise en place of all ingredients.Nezha patiently explained the steps to prepare our tagine and encouraged us to reproduce her bread making techniques...Oh boy, this was hilarious for all my friends since i was the only one who does not have any clue on how to cook something else but boiling water for tea.... In spite of all odds, I managed very well! Nezha gave clear instructions on how to chop vegetables, how much spices needed to be added and how to turn the meat for the Lamb Tagine with prunes. We also were taught how to prepare 3 different salads and the popular folded pastry while sipping fresh squeezed orange juice.After we completed our cooking task, we sat outside in the garden to enjoy our fresh made food accompanied with a glass of wine while sharing our experiences of Marocco and its charms.We indeed had a lovely experience and a fun time learning the tricks of cooking a nice traditional meal. We were really pampered and well taken care of. Our words of gratitude to Michel for his wittiness and hosting abilities and to Nezha for her caring dedication to teach us patiently those tricks. Ah! before I forget, at the end they also provide you with the recipes and some spices to put your new learned skills in practice!

A Fantastic day. Without a doubt this was our family's favourite day of our 10 day break in Marrakech. We were collected promptly and arrived at the cookery school to be met by Michel, the very charasmatic chef who runs it. Our children were given a warm welcome and were able to take part in all the activities including bread making and cooking of a delicious tagine with beef, which we, as a group, ate outside accompanied by a lovely glass of wine.A TRIP NOT TO BE MISSED!

Experience worth booking. Cooking was one of the main priorities on our trip to Marrakech and to Morocco in general. Michel, one of the owners of the cooking school, picked us up at our hotel and drove us to the farm- a lovely place surronded by fruit and olive trees. The kitchen stations are quite big and can fit 10 very comfortably- you don't have to worry about sharing a small space or bumping elbows with your cooking partner. The day we went we were cooking beef with candied oranges and pears which ended up being phenomenal. Both the main chef and the owner are constantly helping and assisting so even those with very little cooking skill will be hard pressed to screw up. There are step by step instructions for everything that you make- the bread, main dish, three salads, and dessert so one never feels lost or confused. After you have finished with your meal a small glass of wine is served and everyone takes to the patio to eat the meals prepared and to soak in the fact that coming into the course we knew very little of Moroccan cuisine and leaving we felt like we could easily make the recipes again and again. Upon leaving we were given a small bag of the main spice used in all of the cuisine, as well as the recipes we had made for that day. It was a wonderful experience and one I will not soon forgot. There are many other cooking courses in Marrkech but for a genuinely different and lovely experience I can recommend this one emphatically!!! Should we return to Morocco we will no doubt visit this place again!

LOVED IT!!. Did it with my girlfriend, we had soooooo much fun, the staff are amazing and the Haman we did after was the perfect end to our day.They picked us up from our hotel, drove us to the farm, cooked all day, had a great meal outside, drunk wine, we did not want it to end.

A Delicious Delight. This day was indeed memorable! I actually made bread and took it back to my hotel to show off and share with friends! The class was well planned and timed perfectly to keep me completely engrossed for the day. We were emmersed in learning, encouraged through humor by Michel, and expertly taught. We cooked lamb with prunes stuffed with almonds which looked lovely in the tangine and were taught how to prepare different three salads. I'd take this class once a week if I could!! Loved it!Nancy M. Florida

Great experience. Loved the day. Very clean and well laid out cooking areas. Enjoyed the bread making and sampling all the food we made. Michel was a great host and his team of ladies are all lovely too. We did the mystic spa part too and thought it was a perfect day!

A delicious treat. Our day at Faim d'epice was delightful. We learned to cook a traditional moroccan tagine, bread and crepes and enjoyed every minute of it. Michele and his staff are as exceptional as the food we created. I highly recommend this as a day excursion while staying in Marrakech. We combined it with the Hammam in the afternoon, which rounded out our day cooking with a bit of pampering and relaxation.

A Highlight of Our Trip. Our day at Faim d'Epices was definitely one of our major highlights of Morocco. Our experience with Michel and his team ran so perfectly from our time of booking until even after we returned home from our trip (I won't ruin the surprise here!) The dishes that we cooked on the day were so easy to make with their guidance, but tasted so incredible....and after the class you could easily make them in your own kitchen. We did the package of the cooking class plus the Mythic Oriental Spa treatments (which we also thoroughly enjoyed) and it was amazing how quickly the day went by. Thanks so much Michel and everyone at Faim d'Epices!!! I can recommend this experience enough :)

An absolute must whilst in Marrakech!. As part of a gastro trip to Marrakech we knew we wanted to do a cookery course to learn all about the local cuisine and through searching on trip advisor we took the plunge and booked a day at Faim d'Epices and I can genuinely say that that we cannot wait to go back! We were picked up bang on time from an agreed location near our Riad and joined a mini bus full of people just as excited as we were about what the day was going to bring. We knew we were going to have a great day the moment we met Michel, who was extremely funny and very entertaining. After chatting to all the other people over a very civilised mint tea we took part in a spice test which was so interesting and gave us an insight into all the various spices so we knew what to look out for in the souks and what to avoid! Following this the day was spent making breads, chicken and olive tagine, various salads and pancakes. The entire team's passion, dedication, patience and expert guidance was so appreciated and included the right balance of tuition, guidance and practical and then to sit in the sun eating all our carefully crafted food with some good wine and good company rounded off the day. Once we had all enjoyed our delicious food we were safely deposited back to our Riad. There were so many lovely touches throughout the day and we were sent away with the recipes from the day and Michel even followed up the day by sending us photos from our day and even more recipes. We are already planning our next visit!

An experience not to be missed!. My husband and i had a fantastic time at L'atelier Faim d'Epices. Michel was an excellent host, funny and entertaining and the dishes was the best food that we ate in Morocco.. If you are thinking of booking a class, do! It was the highlight of out time in Marrakesh..

Fun For All. There isn't much I can say about the cooking class that others haven't already said very well. So I'll direct my comments to non-cooking men, a group that includes me. Okay, so your wife wants you to go to cooking class with her and you'd rather be poked in hte eye with a sharp stick. You didn't go all the way to Marrakech to learn to cook. Well, just get over it. This class is fun even if you know nothing about cooking and don't really think you want to. It starts with a blind sniff test of various spices. Out of about twenty samples, I think I got about two right. Heck, I probably wouldn't have gotten more than a half dozen if I'd been able to look at them. But it was fun watching the other people figure them out. One young kid about 12 years old beat me by a mile. Then the cooking starts. You first get a demonstration, then you're led step by step through each process. It's pretty hard to screw it up, really. My bread might not have been as pretty as some others, but it tasted just as good. That and the desserts were my favorite part, since the main dish wasn't really something I'd have picked. But everyone else thought it tasted great. And even I felt a sense of accomplishing something new.So get over those silly hangups and do something your wife wants to do for a change. She'll appreciate it, and you might even like it.

A great day!. As an ex chef I was very interested in this when searching for things to do on my holiday, and I wasn't dissapointed!The pickup from the hotel was bang on time with a friendly driver, and the transfer only took about 20 minutes. we were then greeted by Nezha our cook/teacher for the day then served mint tea by the owner Michel who told us what the day would entail.On our day we prepared beef, pear and candied orange tagine, with local flatbread and all the salads.. and I have to say that it tasted fantastic, and so easy to make.We could not fault the instruction, very clear and concise.. and fun!There was also a 'blind' spice session with Michel that I learned a great deal from, he is very informative on all the spices and their traits, including how to tell real saffron from fake.I would highly recommend this trip to anyone with an interest in moroccan cuisine, you will not be disappointed!

Fabulous Feast. A friend and I took the cooking class featuring tajine of lamb and prunes. We were picked up near our riad and wisked away with six other would-be-chef's to the Faim d'Epices farm where we were greeted by one of the owners, Michel, who served us mint tea and gave us an overview of the day. The initial introduction to Moroccan cuisine was a "spice class". This was great fun, blindly smelling various spices and trying to guess their identities followed by a tutorial of their culinary uses. The school itself was a lovely space, very aesthetic and welcoming. The cooking stations were well equiped and our instructor Nehza was very hands on, frequently checking on us to ensure we were "boxing" and "stretching" our dough correctly. We tasted a few things as we went along (although be sure to eat a big breakfast as you won't eat anything substantial until the afternoon) and at the end of the day we enjoyed the full bounty of our day's work with a sit down lunch on the terrace overlooking the garden. The dishes we learned to make were tasty and ones I feel I could definitely duplicate at home. A nice introduction to Moroccan cuisine in a laid back yet professional environment. A full day, a full belly!

Fantastic!. This course is brilliant! For a start it is great value, it is not a half day at all as we were picked up and 9.30am and returned back to our hotel at 5.00pm. All day you are made to feel so welcome and given fresh juice, wine, mint tea, bread.....so much delicious food and drink that when it came to eating the meal we had cooked - cous cous I was already stuffed! The cooking itself was very informative and interesting, as was learning all about the different spices. I have already recommended this place to friends from home who are visiting Marrakech in the coming weeks and I fully recommend it to you too!

Please go to this cooking school, it is So worth it !. So, a review for the cooking class in Marrakech, sorry this took so long.  Problem is I can't remember names at this point, however, the important part, the cooking, well that will be no problem...We had a blast.  The fella who probably co owns the class, Michel, picked us up at the designated time there at our Riad, so it starts with convenience.We Headed off to get another couple, two sisters from Ireland, it ended up being just the four of us, two buddies on a Blueman bonding trip, and these two ladies, so the space was beyond ample, I'd suggest they could accommodate ten comfortably, and do most of the time, so make your reservations early,The cool thing about this class was that it was taught using good English.  They do German and French, probably Spanish, maybe even Hindi, but not having to work thru an interpreter is helpful.The space is outside of town, so it's relatively quiet, actually quite quiet.  Also very hygienic with clean toilets, soap, towels, etc.The teaching is on par with soup to nuts.  We actually made couscous, from scratch, possible the only time I'll do that !? Not that it was hard, but there are good ready mixes out there, but we all liked having that experience under our belts.We also made breads, and doughs for dessert creeps, those too we're fun, and very tasty !To include with the couscous, actually adding to its flavor as it/they cooked from below, was a medley of veggies, and off to the side, caramelized onions, which really came across more like a controlled substance, adding a wonderful flavor, as well as bouquet, to the finished  meal.Prior to eating we put several cold salads together, one a shredded cucumber with a dressing from orange juice, the other, yikes, this is where it would have paid off to do this review sooner, my 1970's influenced mind can't recollect the specifics of it.  Sorry.Another cool thing about this class was when you would be in between courses,  where there really isn't anything to do other than watch veggies cook, Michel would form a group off to the side, on comfy couches where you would be educated on the nuances of their various spices and herbs, quite a smart thing to do, since other classes I've taken in Morocco simply let you wander off on a smoke break.Lastly, as cool things these guys did that others don't, after we sat outside on their patio and finished off the results of our dicing, slicing, and steaming, they brought us outa very handsome ice cream and strawberry dessert, accompanied by those crepes that we had a part of kneading earlier.  Very un expected, and wonderfully received; nice job !!!At this time of the season they were running a special, tied to a very chic spa there in Marrakech.  So with a full belly we left the class around three, maybe as late a four, and Maurice (Aka) took us to the spa, where he sat and talked with us until the massage folks were ready for us, another nice customer services touch.The spa was wonderful, sure, do I wish I looked better in the tong made of crepe paper, of course, but, with all due respect, I doubt Brad Pitt would even look good in them, and it's not like anyone sees you ???  It should be noted that this wasn't some quickie nooner spa experience, we got a full body scrub using the essence of your choice, black mud, rose oil, choices like those.  Then after a nice sit in sort of a steam/sauna you'd get washed off, then a full hour massage, followed with herbal teas and relax time, this spa is quite nice, it appeared to be run by a French couple with the help of parents.  Very chic, nicely renovated old Riad there in Marrakech.That's it, I do think you should do these, Marrakech has grown up, it isn't the cool place it once was, after all, just too many people can afford cheap scooters now, and with no restrictions as to where they can ride them you're at risk just wandering.  The rug merchants ask way too much for their pieces, and if you don't know those products you're not going to get anything rally worth taking home, but I suppose that is in the eye of the beholder...sorry. Point, take advantage of a fun day, especially if you want to see Marrakech, you won't be sorry.Haj, aka, Salida1048

A super day!!. What a wonderfu way to spend half the day. We learned so much about cooking, and the food was wonderful. There were 6 couples on our course. we enjoyed the time we spent meeting these people and sharing tips for the city. Very professional and worth every penny.
Great day. Choose to do this on our day of departure and it was a great way to finish our holiday, they even dropped us off at the airport! Very enjoyable day!

Cracking people and great value for money. Three of us did the cookery spa package this weekend. It's great. As per all the other reviews Michel is a very good host making all nationalities welcome and involved. The demonstrations and hands on cooking were great and we all learnt how to make bread, crepes, tagines (beef, artichoke and peas), and moroccan salads. Can't be much we don't know about spices now either!My tip would be to have a big breakfast. Despite the early start we didn't eat until gone 3pm and being around food that long and not eating is gastro torture.The SPA add on - i'm becoming a massage addict and have paid more than the price of the whole day for a massage that good so would recommend it highly. Eat before you go and don't expect an early finish - we got back to our Riad 11 hours from the pick up after, for me, the best day of the holiday.

good value and fun. Picked up at the agreed time and taken to the farm where we learnt to make traditional food and were given drinks, tea and wine. Excellent value and relaxed day. well worth trying.

Nice experience. We did the combination cooking+spa total: 1080 dhm pp (100 euro).The cooking: good introduction in Maroccon cuisine and spices. Although host and chef where competent a communication barrier in enlgish was experienced with the chef. The host, Michel, was knowledgable and familiarized us with the local culture and customs. Michel went out of his way to accommodate us.The spa was an unforgettable experience, in a fantastic Ryad in the Medina, performed by well trained staff in a very professional manner.

Highlight of our holiday. I travelled to Marrakesh with my husband and teenage boys. From looking at tripadvisors things to do in Marrakesh, I pre booked the days course through the internet. The reply was really prompt from Michel and we confirmed dates and collection time. What was fantastic was we were to be collected from our hotel, so no worrying for me. We were collected by a lovely man and driven to L'atelier Faim d'Epices. On arrival we were warmly greeted and offered mint tea or coffee whilst waiting for the rest of the group, 11 in total. The room was all on one level, comfortable and light with our cook stations all set up waiting. As everyone arrived we all got chatting easily and Michel was great, making us all instantly relaxed.We went on to learn about spices and tips as to what to look out for in the Medina, as you can imagine there are a few things that are not completely genuine for example, saffron and Argon oil's.We were shown how to make bread, chicken tajine with red olives, salads and Moroccan version of pancakes. After a very full and extremely interesting day of cooking all these lovely things, Michel and his team then offered us some lovely wine, soft drinks and we as a group we enjoyed our labours in a lovely tranquil outside area, which has orange, lemon and olive trees. All in all this is a great trip to do whilst you are away. They speak great English and so made it easier for us to understand.  I then received an e mail from Michel yesterday. He has very kindly sent photo's of us and some more lovely recipes for us to enjoy now we are back in the UK, what a great touch, this is how to look after your clients. Well done to you and your team Michel!

Great experience!. We attended the cooking experience as a group of 6 ladies. It was fun & interactive as the day is split nicely with learning & fun! It is a “chill out” day so if you want a break from the intense heat & bustling streets this is ideal. I wanted to spend some time with my group so it was a good way to be together without being split up in the chaos of the souks.The day can be combined with spa treatment at Mythic Oriental Spa…this is thoroughly recommended (best spa I’ve ever visited). I felt relaxed as soon as I entered & felt the benefit for days!

Great fun learning Tangine cooking. An excellant all day excursion outside of Marrekesh. The driver picked me up on time at a location that was easy to find. Michael was quite the host. One aspect of Morrocan cooking I wanted to learn was spices. The class had 1-2 hours that focused only on spices. Learning the techniques of tangine cooking was also a goal, which was 100% met. All the other students were a lot of fun and the class was very interactive. And after all of this, we enjoyed a wonderful meal, that each student prepared over looking the grove of olive trees. I highly recommend this trip to anyone who enjoys cooking. You'll learn about a number of aspects of cooking that you will be able to use no matter what type of meal you are preparing.

Who knew spices could rock your world!. My 3 girlfriends and I were amazed by our experience with Michel and his team! From the pick up early on Saturday, to the lovely conversation, long lunch, hands on experience and warm sun... it was a true gem! We bought it as a package deal with a local hammam, thus the day was heavenly. I can't wait to come back and take another class with Michel. Michel, Je t'aime!

Absolutely a must while in Marrakech. My wife and I take a ton of cooking classes, this was the best one we've ever taken.Michel and co, were fantastic. Heres why:-Knowledgeable team with good english. This is often the biggest fault in internations coking classes. Even better, they're really fun people. -The spice tasting/review really is informative to better understand what and how to use each ingredient. You learn instead of just carrying out a recipe.-You leave FULL. This was an absolutely delicious, big meal. -Unlike a lot of other cooking classes, you get to make the each dish, instead of breaking into groups.-The recipes the send with you match the class, no hidden ingredients and tricks you'll forget later. We absolutely recommend L'atelier Faim d'Epices, it was our favorite activity in Marrakech. Go!

A moroccan feast & blissful evening at the spa. We did the cooking course & spa combo offered by Faim e'Epices & Mythical Oriental spa. What a fantastic day! We were collected by Michel in the morning and he proved to be an excellent host and a real character. The cooking course was well run and it was easy to keep up. The meal we prepared was delicious & a real treat to sit out in the sun with a glass of wine. It was a very nice touch that we were not only given the recipes from the day but also emailed photographs of us in action. After a day in the kitchen, we were taken to the spa. This was 3 hours of absolute bliss. A must do!
Fantastic. You have to try by yourself. That was something new for me and I couldn t imagine what I seeing Its original

A great day. A really great day in a relaxing atmosphere in lovely surroundings. Michel is a genial host and Nazha, the Morrocan lady who actually does the cooking instruction, is relaxed and helpful in every way. Pick up was right on time, Michel smiled and chatted all the way through the day and gave us very interesting instruction on identifying herbs, spices and oils.A great day and I'd recommend it as a way of getting out of the city and learning how to cook Morrocan cuisine in a fun and relaxing way.

It's worth a day just to get to know about the spices. Just spent a great day cooking a true Moroccan Tagine. Michel is just brilliant keeping the day running. Before you hit the spice markets it's worth spending a day and truly understand the spices and herbs used in Moroccan food. Michel gives an honest account and a little insighton how the spice trade works here in Morocco.The cooking is very relaxing and great to eat, I can recommend it.

Fab first day in Marrakech. We spent our first day in Marrakech at L'atelier Faim d'Epices and it was a a great start to our break. We where a group of 7 and it is an excellent activity for a group of this size. There wasn't one part of the day we didn't like. We where picked up by Michel, spot on time and it was very interesting to to see outside of the city. The food was delicious (even if I do say so myself), I have tried a few of the recipes since returning home and they are as tasty now as they where on the day. I would thoroughly recommend L'atelier Faim d'Epices to anyone who is travelling to Marrakesh. My own personal regret is not taking advantage of the deal they have with the spa.
Great food. We had great time here , we enjoyed our food , the staff was great .will go back there !!!!

Fantastic Experience. Our Riad host booked the cooking class at Faim d'épices for us. It is a top-notch and professionally run operation with a casual and fun approach.Michel, one of the owners, picked us up near our riad and we picked up additional students as we meandered back to the cooking school which is just outside the bustle of Marrakech. Upon our arrival we were served mint tea and coffee while the staff finished up preparations. Michel introduced us to the spices we would be using that day. Each pair of students has their own cooking station with all the necessary ingredients and cooking equipment. I used to work in the food business so I was particularly impressed with the level of organization and the thought put into the flow of the class.We learned how to prepare several dishes from a lovely, Moroccan woman. The directions were clear and easy to follow. After cooking, we all sat outside in the sun to enjoy the delicious fruits of our labor with a glass of wine. After buying some supplies and receiving our printed recipes, we were driven back to our riad.A few weeks later, I received an email with additional recipes AND photos of my husband and I that were taken throughout the day by Michel. There were six couple in our class and there are classes every day of the week. I have no idea how Michel managed to sort and send the photos to all the students. Amazing! Thank you for the photos Michel!

One of the best days we had in morocco. I'd thoroughly recommend this to anyone visiting Marrakech. It was a really fun and interesting day I learnt so much- particularly about spices! The whole day was brilliantly organised and very well executed. The food we made was delicious and I can't wait to make it. (You are given the recipes at the end.) The surroundings of the olive trees were lovely and relaxing and great to be out of the busy city for the day. Michel was great- a big personality and he made the day really fun. I will be recommending this to any of my friends or family visiting Marrakech!

I'd pay the full price to taste the food alone.... We decided to make the best of a rainy day in Marrakesh by learning how to make some typical Moroccan dishes. This turned out to be a great idea and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.We were picked-up at 09.30 in the morning and taken to the outskirts of Marrakesh.The cooking lesson starts with a blind smell test of different spices used in Moroccan cuisine and is great fun. Next you learn how to make bread and swiftly move on to prepare for the tagine (in our case, a beef tagine), which will incorporate many of the spices that you were exposed to during the blind test.For dessert you learn how to make a typical Moroccan type of pancake (which will later on will later on be complemented by some nice locally-made ice creams).Once everything is cooked you'll get to taste it all and more, as the staff will have prepared some additional salads in the meantime.Good points:- they pick you up and drop you off- extremely well priced (550 Dhiram for a full day)- friendly and charismatic host- the whole area is nice and clean (as are the toilets)- 'Cous Cous' the cat!Room for improvement:- it was quite cold when we were there (rainy day in Marrakesh)Ounces of fun...just go!

Bon Appetit Faim d'Espices. The cooking school is a whole day excursion and Faim d'Espices pick you up and return you to your lodgings. We booked the day via email with Michel - easy. What's included for the price: mint tea welcome, introduction to spices used and produce of Marrakech, make your own bread and tanjine, demo on how to make Moroccan salad and pancakes and you then eat you creations with a glass of wine, the salads and pancake and ice-cream for dessert outside. Help is on hand to make sure everyone makes something edible and our lamb and prune tanjine was delicious. Drinks are provided during the day and you are very well looked after and it is an easy going and enjoyable day. Highly recommended!!

A Great Find!. My husband and I booked this excursion based on the great Tripadvisor reviews, and we weren't disappointed! We booked pn very short notice and Michel accomodated us and made the process very easy. Our driver was right on time to pick us up in the medina and drive us out to the beautiful property where the school is. Our teacher, Nezah, met us and made us feel very welcome. The cooking lessons were amazing and I've already made everything since being home. The spice clinic was extremely helpful and informative. Anyone going to Marrakech should definitely make the time for this outing.

A wonderful day in Marrakech!. For photos, see my blog: http://www.eatdreamtravel.com/2012/03/couscous-cumin-and-cooking-class.htmlAfter all the great eating we were doing in Marrakech, we wanted to learn how to make some of the dishes, so we signed up for a cooking class at Faim d'Epices. I was hesitant at first to spend the money (about 55 euros per person), but I'm very glad we did. Michel, a jolly Frenchman and one of the owners of the enterprise, picks you up and takes you to a building outside the city in a grove of olive trees. Then you watch Nehza, a sweet Moroccan chef, demonstrate how to make the circular bread you see everywhere here. Then Michel leads you through a spice class, blindfolding you and seeing who can figure out what spice is which by smell alone. After that, it's off to your own cooking station to make the bread, and then to make the tajine of the day, which in our case was the Berber tajine, featuring vegetables and some beef. Nehza is there every step of the way to help, but you also get to be hands-on, which is great. While the tajines cook, she demonstrates the making of various salads as well as Moroccan crepes. At this point, you are starving and then finally it is time for the meal. You sit outside with your new friends under the olive trees, eating the delicious fruits of your labor. Michel offers you wine, and then just when you can't eat another bite, out comes ice-cream. This is the perfect way to get out of the city, meet people, and learn how to cook Moroccan food! (They also have a package where you combine the cooking class with a half day at a spa/hammam, and it is a good deal, so I wish we had done that, instead of the hammam that we went to...which is a story for another post.)

Highlight of our holiday!!!. Before I chose faim d'epices I researched a lot of cookery schools in marrakech and most of them seemed to be in riads within the medina, and faim d'epices stood out as it was outside of the city, which if you have been to Marrakech before you will know this is a major plus in itself! The whole day from start to finish was fabulous, and the course was much more than just cooking, as Michel teaches you about all the herbs and spices which was very useful for all cooking, not just moroccan! We also watched how to make 3 different moroccan salads, and pancakes, and got to make our own bread which is something ive always wanted to do.Everything was perfectly organised and easy to follow, and after we cooked our tagines we all took them outside to eat on the terrace, followed by the best homemade icecream i've ever had!Before we got taken back to the city Michel gave us the recipes we had used presented beautifully in a glass tube, and some of his own blend of Ras Al Hanout, the spice used for tagines.When i got home from marrakech i had an email from Michel with all the pictures he had taken of myself and my family on the day we were there, you wouldnt get this anywhere else!This day was the highlight of my trip and is excellent value for money, myself and my family would definitely go back again and were gutted we did it on our last day and couldnt go again!

Awesome experience!. This is a must do! We are so glad we took the time to do this. We ordered 2 tajines as soon as we returned home. We love Moroccan food and now we can cook our own! Special thanks to the entire staff!!

Had a lovely day but was drawn out a little.. Had a lovely day, learning about spices and how to cook a tagine. I made my own bread which was excellent. Punctual pick up. Staff friendly and helpful. However, I did feel the day was a little drawn out. We didn't eat lunch until 3pm ish!! And even after that we had yet more tea when really we could have been driven home instead of hanging around. Despite this, the lunch was excellent as you get to eat your own tagine and a glass of wine was included. We were given the recpies from the day and complimentary spices to take home which was a nice touch. It is a long day but I did enjoy it.

A fantastic day out. Michael and his team create a lovely atmosphere in which you learn to cook. Even my husband enjoyed his cooking experience and the tagine for lunch was the best we tasted in Marrakech.

Can't wait to try the recipes at home!. The cooking class was fantastic! Our pick up on right on time, everything went very smoothly, and the staff were extremely nice and happy to have us at the farm. The facilities were top notch and everyone got their own cooking station. I learned all about Moroccan spices, even some tips on how to pick out the best ones (and notice a fake!). Learning how to make the bread was awesome and definitely something I can do at home. We all got to eat the food we made at the end of the course and it was the best meal I had in Morocco. It was a lamb tajine with candied prunes and roasted almonds, three types of Moroccan salads, bread, and Moroccan crepes for dessert. YUM! I even bought a tajine so I can try the recipe at home :)

Fantastic course - highlight of morroco. Really enjoyed learing new cooking techniques and the blind spice test. I'm still embarrassed about buying tumeric instead of saffron! Thanks to everyone at Faimd'Epice! x

Great Day. I really can't add nuch to the glowing reviews already posted. We were picked up as planned by a charming host: Michel. The day was both enjoyable and informative. We combined it with the spa package which worked well. too.

Thoroughly enjoyable day - great fun and learned a lot at the same time. We were picked up from our hotel just outside Marrakech and drove into the hectic bustle of Marrakech's back streets to pick up the rest of the group. We were then taken to Michel's lovely purpose built building situated in Orange and Olive groves. His great team made us feel welcome and he guided us through the tasy cuisine of Morrocco. We each made our own bread, a Berber tagine and pancakes, whilst we were shown how to make accompanying salads and side dishes. Alongside this we had a blind 'test' of our knowledge of spices which was informative as well as being fun. We were in a group of 10 and had a good time with the others as well. All in all in was a great day, excellent value for money (I'd have paid good cash just to hurtle around the back streets of Marrakech - which you'll understand once you've been!)Whilst you're there Michel also takes photos which he then emails on so is fab for couples and a really nice touch!Thanks Michel and team - a great day

Really fun day out. Came here as it was rated number 1 of tripadvisor. Never done a cookery class before. Have signed up to tripadvisor just to rate this place! Really fun day out. Michel, the host, was great fun and very knowledgeable. Learned to make bread, salad, tagine (which type of tagine you make depends on the day you go; we made lamb with prunes). Definitely worth the price. We were given the recipes in a cute little gift wrapped container and a small bag of the farms raas al hanoute. Very personal touch. Only thing I'd say is it's a long day. You're picked up at around 0930 and don't eat the meal (you've made yourself!) until around 1500; so take a snack and some water with you (although they do give you water and freshly squeezed orange juice throughout the day).Recommend this place 100%

Fantastic experience. I went with my Daughter to Marrakech for a girlie break and going to L'atelier Faim d'Epices was definitely a highlight! We thouroughly enjoyed our day it was really informative enjoyable and good value with the highlight being able to eat what we cooked on the terrace with a nice glass of wine in the company of our fellow 'students'.The mix of fun and information was perfect!

Great experience, great atmosphere, would definitely recommend.. Visited in October, 2011: Definitely one of the the best, if not the best highlight of our trip to Marrakesh. Located on a farm just outside Marrakesh, the ambience is just fabulous. We cooked a lamb Tagine with prunes, truly mouth watering! Michel (and his cat, Couscous) ensured a great sense of humor during the experience. Throughout the class, Nezha and Michel went through a number of recipes (salads, bread and desserts). Must visit if you are traveling to Marrakesh. Thanks Michel & Nezha for a great experience!Dr. Yasser Aljabi.

Great food, great people, great day!. We got picked up at 930 in a part of the medina that was easy enough to get to, and were transported to the base in the van with a bit of banter and local info from Michel. We arrived in a beautiful, built for purpose building, mint tea at the ready and chatted to the rest of the group. (I think we were ten in all) We had the spice test, very interesting and a bit of a giggle...Michel is a wonderful host! We learnt about the salads and the bread and got started on our own cooking. The Sunday dish is a Berber tagine made with spices, herbs, veggies and beef, and while that was bubbling we learnt how to, and attempted to, make Moroccan pancakes...divine!!! Once it was all ready we ate al fresco with our new friends and a glass of Moroccan vino. Inmmim!!!We took advantage of the deal on their website which includes a hamamm after the class. Michel took us into the spa so we didn't get lost and it was a lovely experience too. Definately recommend it as it's one of those thing you have to do while you're there!

Unique experience. The day was absolutely brilliant, Staff was just gorgeous and very patient with everyone. Do not miss this wonderful experience - delicious food. We were provided a fun and relaxed cooking environment that is non-intimidating and pitched at all levels. You don't have to be a gourmet cook to enjoy cooking classes.After a good introduction to the array of spices presented by Michel, this time Nezha professionally opened the class. We really enjoyed it and are excited to try some of the recipes.
Great Experience and very friendly and informative.. Great Experience and very friendly and informative.

A little oasis of calm in Marrakech. This cooking course was a lovely all day event, which started with a fun education in the world of spices and continued on to bread making and the art of making a tagine. The team of Michel, Philippe and Nezha were wonderful hosts, ready to laugh and made all of us all feel welcome. A great experience and definitely one we will remember!

The most fun you can have standing up. The best day of a great week! From the momentMichel picked us up to the last moment of the day - a great experience. Fun, eductional, interactive, and great taste both to the senses and the humor. Michel provided the personality extrodinaire and Nezha the epicurious delight. You have your own "kitchen" and like having a personal chef at your side. We learned, we tasted, and we were entertained - can anyone ask for more. If you don't do anything else in Marrakesh you MUST do this!!!!

#Ranked 1 on Tripadvisor for a reason. My girlfriend and I took a class on our second last day in Marrakech. The classes are very well organised and fun. All the staff are very nice, helpful and welcoming and the guy running the show Michel is hilarious. We cooked a lamb tagine with prunes which was the best thing we ate on our whole trip! They also taught us how to cook Moroccan bread and guided us through the different spices used in Moroccan food.Definitely recommend!

Enjoy a full day of learning about Moroccan culture through food. The day begins early when Michel picks you up in the Faim d'Epices van and whisks you into the countryside. He'll entertain you with stories as you drive, and are deposited on the front doorstep of a lovely rosy building specially-built in the olive grove as a learning center for Moroccan food and culture. Sit at the lovely banquettes and chat with the other participants in the day's adventure whilst you are treated to tea or coffee, and the day's schedule is recited. Then, time to cook!We started with "boxing the bread"..making our own Moroccan-style loaves, and as it rose we took a blind spice test. Michel is like a charming French schoolboy with a bit of naughtiness in his ways...he told us (with great humor and charm) how to spot fake saffron, how to discern the scents of paprika and ways of telling different kinds of cinnamon from one another. We then learned how to make salads and tagine, and everything cooked up quite well, even though many of us weren't particularly gifted cooks. Our late lunch was outside by the olive groves...and it was lovely and too much food! Just wonderful!  Michel gave us the recipes and many of us bought spices since they seemed so fresh and high-quality. Many of the guests in my group said it exceeded all expectations.

Fantastic cooking class!!. We booked into this class based on the recommendations on TripAdvisor and definitely were not disappointed. Michel was a wonderful host who picked us up to take us out to the kitchen away from the craziness in Marrakech. We were then greeted with some mint tea and a quick debrief of the day ahead.We then started with a spice workshop which was a great introduction to the flavours that are typically used in Moroccan cooking. We were then taught how to make the round bread that is everywhere in Morocco which is surprisingly easy! Nezha is a fantastic teacher with a lot of patience and also incredibly friendly. We learnt to make the chicken tagine with preserved lemons and olives which tasted delicious! They also showed us how to make some of the traditional Moroccan salads, another type of flat bread (the square one they have at breakfast) and some different cooking techniques as well. It was a great day out and was fantastic to be able to sit down at the end of the day and enjoy an amazing meal which we cooked! The ice cream at the end was also incredibly tasty!Would definitely recommend this to anyone!!!

All the wonderful reviews are true!. My husband and I took the cooking course (and did the spa after, actually) and it made for a perfect day in Marrakesh! The entire staff was lovely, the food was amazing, and it was such a great opportunity to meet some other tourists and talk about our trips to the city. We will certainly be recreating the dishes we learned at home. I can not say enough good things, this was such a fantastic experience!

Great day out of the madness of the Medina. A cheeky Frenchman called Michel smoking a Gauloise arrives late (Moroccan time or French??) to pick us up on our trip out of town to learn more about Moroccan spices and to make bread along with cooking a Chicken Tagine. The others on board include a nice Irish couple and some young Aussie gals, who seem everywhere in Marrakech. The atmosphere is chilled and Michel is charming to all the gals. We arrive at a purpose built site in the middle of an orange grove and olive trees, we are given the usual mint tea and merci, a proper espresso. We do blind smelling of spices, most of which we got right and then onto cooking led by a Moroccan chef, Nadya. She was really friendly and the course was a good combination of demonstration and actual cooking. A relaxed meal in the sun, along with some wine and homemade ice cream for afters ended a lovely day. A must do when in Marrakech.

Exactly as described. This is a great, fun activity which is so relaxed you feel at ease from the pick up in the morning to the drop off at the end of the day. We were picked up bang on time at the selected pick up in the easy to spot people carrier and were whisked off to the Marrakech countryside. Mint tea on arrival and then a bread making demonstration. The blind spice session was interesting and very informative especially if you want to buy some spices back in the souks. Then it was time to make the bread, guided step by step to make the perfect Moroccan bread. Bread made, onto the tagine. Again we were guided so no one fell behind and before you knew it your tagine was bubbling away, aromas galore. Whilst our tagines cooked we were given demonstrations on Moroccan salads and then crepes. Food ready we sat outside and enjoyed our creations with a glass of wine. Then it was time to return to the hustle and bustle of the Medina.

Lovely atmosphere , fun day , something different than shopping in the souks !!. I think I have cooked if I put a ready meal in the oven rather than the microwave so when my friends suggested we go on a cooking course I was a little worried .... then I realised it was exactly what I needed !!My friend booked it all via the website and we paid cash , in dirhams , at the end of the day. Pick up was fine , we were met outside Cafe Argana in the main square. Driver spotted us instantly and called out my friends name so we were reassured it was the right driver. ( The other members of our group arrived in a marked minibus so easy to spot. )It was about a 40 minutes drive to the farm which I really enjoyed. I have been to Marrakech several times and mainly stayed within the medina , so I found it interesting to drive through the outskirts , see the kids all going to school and witness a bit of everyday life away from the main tourist centre. We turned off down a bumpy track and we were soon pulling up outside the farm.First impression was WOW , this looks great ! A beautiful modern , air-conditioned building in a field with olive trees and other varieties. Immediately inside the door is a sofa area and small selection of things to buy. Lovely old Moroccan posters cover the walls and lots of purple accessories .... Michel's favourite colour we think ...We sat and had mint tea while we waited for the rest of the group who arrived 5 minutes later.Michel , the owner and creator who picked the other guests up is , as previously mentioned by other reviewers very twinkly ! He talked us through the day and I couldn't wait to get started !We made bread , a tagine , had a talk on spices with some interesting facts and tips on buying saffron and argan oil , watched a salad demonstration , helped make crepes then sat out in the sun and ate our tagines and bread followed by crepes with fruit and ice cream. Delicious !This cooking school does not claim to teach you how to cook gourmet meals , it is a light hearted introduction to simple Moroccan food and spices. The atmosphere is relaxed and friendly and I had a really good day. If you are looking for something a bit different to do or just want a break from the crazy bustle of Marrakech this is a good choice.I'm off to buy a tagine !

Masterchef in Moroccan Cookery. We thoroughly enjoyed our day with Michele and his staff at the Cookery School. Tony my Husband was a little apprehensive when we were collected from our Riad, but was immediately put at his ease by Michele.The day was very informal, and there were a variety of age group of people on our course. All the recepies were demonstrated to us, and when it was our turn to have a go, we were all helped as much or as little as needed.Our introduction to the wide variety of spices was good fun, and was very informative.Michele's staff were very adept at clearing away the washing up, whilst we were shown another delicious recepie. And of course, at the end of the day we ate what we had cooked, washed down with a lovely glass of wine.We would recommend this day course to anyone, whatever your level of cooking ability, you will easily be able to show off to friends when you get hom.We will certainly be considering returning to do a different recepie day.Regards Tony & Sue Cook

Relaxing and informative day away from hectic Marrakech. Lovely day learning how to make Morracan bread, a tagine, 3 salads and crepes. Relaxing clean venue with a warm welcome and very good tuition. A talk on authentic spices and herbs was also infrormative and fun. We enjoyed our efforts with a glass of wine outside on the terrace. We stayed much longer than anticipated as everyone was chatting and enjioying themselves and there was no hassle to leave. You could but tagines, oils and other items at a very reasonable price but there was no pressure at all to buy, which made a welcome change.

Enjoyable. We spent the day learning to cook a Fish Tagine with Michel and his team. The spice and herb blind tasting was really good fun, and eating our finished meal outside on the terrace with the other 'trainee' chef's - a real mix of nationalities, French, English, Danish and Dutch, was lovely. We even had a glass of Moroccan wine to savour with our meal. We feel confident that we can recreate a Tagine back home in England. This is a good day out away from the hustle and bustle of the city and Michel and the team are a pleasure to spend time with.

Great food, great spice and a great host. Highly recommend the combined offer as both the cookery class and spa were fab. Wouldn't have believed I could cook as a good a tagine as you can taste in Marrakech! The day was great fun and Michel made it fun and engaging for all. The Mythic Oriental Spa topped off a great day. Hidden away , you enter an oasis of calm and, for a couple, you're whisked away for a private, sensual experience that seems miles away from the hustle and bustle outside. Would do both again on our next trip.

FAB-U-LUS. The twinkle in Michel's eye tells you that it's going to be a fun day and you are not disappointed! He, Nezha and the behind the scene team make the whole day seem effortless. The only down side is that now when I am chopping onions my six year old son keeps telling me " that’s not how Michel did it"…..Michel you have created a monster. Thank you for taking such good care of him and all of us.

Highly recommended. A wonderful day that wasn't long enough! Looking forward to the possibilty of 2, 3 - day or week-long courses! And a days experience made even more enjoyable thanks to the charm, excentricity and warmth of Michel, the organiser and his delightful and talented partner who guided us with patience and understanding through the cooking experience.Don't hesitate to take this course even if, as with us, you're only in Marrachech for a couple of days. We combined this cooking class with an evening at the Mythic Oriental Spa where we were well taken care of with the utmost professionalism in an exotic and extremely relaxing environment. A day and an evening of feeding the stomach, the heart and the soul. Skål!!

The best meal we ate in Marrakech. We went to Faim d'Epices for our first full day in Marrakech, and it certainly didn't disappoint. My boyfriend was a bit hesitant about the idea as he is not an experienced cook, but it was fine for all abilities, as they demonstrate every step and supervise you so you can't really do anything wrong. The building and surroundings were lovely, and their resident cat very friendly. We made Moroccan flatbread, tagines (I made a a vegetarian one, others did beef or chicken), msemen, and were shown how to make three different salads which later accompanied the meal, although we did not make these ourselves. We were able to sample the demonstrations along the way, and given real fresh orange juice from their trees, as well as delicious coffee and mint tea. The spice workshop was a great touch too, trying to blindly identify different herbs and spices by smell alone, and told a bit about each one.The atmosphere was welcoming and relaxed, and the final result was definitely worth the preparation. The tagines and pancakes went down very well in the sunshine, especially with a glass of wine. At the end we were given a copy of the recipes, and some spices to take home. We paid about £42 each for this day, which was excellent value - you absolutely would not get anything like this for such a low price in the UK. I don't think they run through the hotter summer months, but if you get a chance to go then I highly recommend that you do so, whatever your cooking ability.

Excellent experience in Marrakech, do not miss!. I saw this as a must do in Marrakech and saw all the positive reviews so decided to take advantage of the cookery class and hammam deal. Was worried it may have been overhyped but we were not disappointed. There was five of us and we had the whole day to ourselves. We thoroughly enjoyed the day, it was relaxing and fun and we had a laugh. We were taught to make the Berbers tagine, Moroccan bread and had a go making Moroccan pancakes. It was very satisfying to end the class enjoying our own cooked food. They prepare a different dish for each day of the week so if you are in Marrakech for several days you may want to enquire beforehand to see what dishes they will teach so you can pick a day when they will cook something you prefer.The chef and Michel were great and it added to the overall experience.

Damn skippy!. Simply, do not miss out, great hosts, fantastic food, relaxed environment, I myself am a distinguished kiwi chef, and even though I have learnt such cookery styles on my travels, this cookery course offers insights into moroccan cuisine which u shant find elsewhere, oh and hey the on the house wine with such delicious food topped it, say hi to cous-cous the kitchen cat from us! book this tour!

Great Day, Relaxing, Enjoyable, Entertaining and Interesting. The cookery course at L'atelier Faim d'Epices was an amazing day out. We booked this solely on the recomendation of fellow tripadvisers before we left for Marrakech. ( I strongly advise to book to avoid disapointment) We got the deal where we were then taken to the Oriental Spa for a Hamman and Massage - which I would also throuroughly recomend.But im here to talk about the cookery course. We had a fantastic time. Everything was taken care of for us - we were picked up from our hotel and whisked away to the country side ( 20mins outside Marrakech)The actual venue was purpose built and looked beautiful - surrounded by a farm and Lemon/Orange(?) trees.I wont spoil it for you - but the course had a few extra bits that made it even better than described. We all had our own work stations - so were all able to individualy do the cooking/chopping/ mixing - instead of having to share the tasks with a partner. And then when you had finsihed one part of the cooking - you are taken for another demonstration while the staff clear and clean your work stations. Perfect!The only recomendation I would make is to eat a big breakfast before you go - as the cooking takes a long time. We didnt end up eating until about 3. ( although we were able to sample some bits and pieces throughout the demos.The team ( especially Michel) are really friendly and made us feel relaxed and welcome.

Absolutely perfect day!. I have just returned to my hotel from the cooking class andI couldn't wait to write my review. The day was absolutely brilliant, Michel was a funny and friendly host, Nezha was just gorgeous and very patient with everyone. Do not miss this wonderful experience - delicious food, excellent company - just perfect.

A Must-Do!. We weren't sure what to expect having never been to a cookery school before, but we had such a great time! Michel slipped effortlessly between English and French for our mixed nationality group, and was hugely engaging in either language! The food is typically Moroccan as one would expect, but with a bit of individual flair - we made a beef tagine with candied oranges and pears - different, but felt very authentic! The teaching is clear and enjoyable - even though I managed to drown my bread with water, it was charmingly rescued!!  As a whole-day activity, it is very good value, and even since we have come home, Michel has emailed us photos which he took during the day. Little touches like this really set it apart from the crowd!

Informative and very well organized cooking class.. Thank you Michel and Nezha for a wonderful insight in the tastes and fragrances of Moroccan cooking. After a fun introduction to the array of spices presented by Michel, Nezha professionally instructed the class. Our class consisted of making and baking our own Moroccan bread, Salades, and then lamb and vegetarian tagines. For desert we prepared Msemen, yummy moroccan pancakes drizzled in local honey. Finally we all sat down to enjoy the feast with a glass of local wine in the sunshine. A delightful day, not to be missed!

A 'must-do' when in Marrakech. Like all the previous reviews, this is a wonderful fun day, out of the hustling Medina. Michel, (the host, owner and driver) is a very knowledgable, friendly guy, who has created a wonderful business for those wanting to learn more about cooking with spices.Worlds away from the centre of Marrakech (although only about 20 mins!), Michel has got his business spot on.He collects you and your fellow 'students' from your hotels and drives you to his place, a newly built workshop amongst his acres of olive growing land.With the aid and patience of his lovely English speaking cooks, the relaxed, fun but resourceful day is then spent learning about spices (their origins, purposes and usage etc), how to make bread, tagines, salads and pancakes.The afternoon is then spent relaxing outside, eating the tagine and bread you've just made with your new friends.The only downside to this trip was that I didn't want to go back to the Medina afterwards!This is a definite must-do if you come to Marrakech, and all at a very reasonable price too.Oh, and by the way, did I mention that (asides from your hands) there wasn't a spot of washing-up we had to do neither?!! C'est parfait!

An entertaining experience and great way to take away with you a bit of Moroccan culture. We opted for the package deal that Faim des Epices had on at the time with the Hammam. This worked out very well as we spent up to late afternoon at the 'farm' and then unwound in the evening back in Marrakech. Overall, it was a great way to end our week in Morocco.We were picked up reasonably early in the morning by Michel, our guide for the day. As the cooking course is well advertised, we were in a small but diverse group of people - this made the day all the more entertaining. After a short drive out of Marrakech, we arrived at the destination, a small bungalow on a plot with olive and various other trees. The building is very nicely done up, well laid out, very clean. We were shown round, given plenty of tea/coffee and then the briefed about the day.The cooking itself is very well organised. Though you cook the bread and main dish only, you get to help out with the desserts and salad. The personal kitchens and demonstration area are ideal, and the chef was extremely friendly giving pointers along the way. Prior to the cooking, you have a spices workshop, which was really interesting. Michel lets you in on some trade secrets, and you learn a lot about the ingredients that we tend to take for granted in our day to day diets. After the cooking is over, you get to enjoy the location and eat outside. We were even treated to some home-prepared ice-cream.Michel was a great guide, and the staff were great all round. You have the chance to buy local produce at the end, but there is no pressure to buy. This, I suppose, is reflected in the price. If you want a hassle-free fun experience you have to fork out that little bit extra. As a nice gesture, you get some spices and the recipes to take home with you!We did have a minor problem with the taste of the olives, but that shouldn't take away from what as a great day out.

A very relaxing and informative day in Marrakech. We had an excellent day with Michel (owner, driver and host) at Faim d’Epices. It all begins with the warm welcome from Michel when he gets out of the minibus to greet you like you are his closest friend. Then it’s a short drive out of the city to the Faim d’Epices, with Michel keeping you entertained along the way with his friendly banter.When you arrive at the destination, it will look like any other place in Marrakech, dusty and brown. But (like a lot of places in the city) when you walk through the door you’ll be charmed by the beautiful interior of the building. This is something we experienced a lot in Marrakech; rough and ready on the outside but the interiors are truly breath-taking.To begin, we are offered traditional mint tea or coffee and given a chance to relax before the cooking course begins. Michel even explained how the mint tea is made.The first thing we learned to make was a traditional Moroccan flat bread; made completely from scratch and cooked on the stove. First we watched the cook make it close up, then we made it ourselves with the guidance of Michel and the cook.While our dough was left to rise for 30 mins, we were given a spice class that explained the various spices used in Moroccan cooking. Some of these spices, herbs and flavours were well known and some not so well known (argan oil, rancid butter, orange blossom, preserved lemons). The spice class was fun and informative.Next, we each made our own fish tagine with lots of veg and herbs and spices. This was the most informative part of the class for me because you actually learnt how to use a tagine for cooking. Tips included chopping the veg the right thickness, layering the items in a particular order and piling the ingredients up high. The tagines were then left to cook for around 45 minutes while we moved on to the next stage.Next we watched 3 different Moroccan salads being made. These were simple to make and full of flavour. We also helped make a delicious Moroccan pastry which is a kind of sweet bread made with lots of thin layers. We tasted these with different types of toppings.Finally whilst our tagines were almost cooked, we finished making our own breads on the stove. Michel warned us that someone always burns their bread… and he was right (not me).The final stage is the feast. Eat your own tagine as well as helpings of the different salads and your own freshly cooked bread. The final meal is very casual and Michel is a very warm host. The meal was served with wine and finished off with a lovely dessert.Overall, this was a lovely day out and we left with a big smile on our faces as well as the knowledge of how to cook with a Tagine.

Pots of fun.... We booked before we travelled based on the reviews on TA and included a local meeting point to be picked up. Unfortunately the day didn't start well as we were left waiting for 45 minutes and were just about to walk away when Michel eventually arrived. Michel drove us out of the city to his cookery studio which is purpose built for up to 18/20 people. After a show round, tea/coffee and the usual getting to know everyone (there were 7 people on the course including us) we proceeded with the day. We started with a bread demonstration, then on to a spice quiz and then started to make bread, our tagine (beef with pears and orange) and learn about Moroccan cookery.The setting for the day is excellent, Michel and his team could not be more helpful and the food you produce is delicious. We ate the food we had cooked outside in the sun which was excellent.All the recipes are included as is transportation to and from Marrakech.Our day didn't start well but we thoroughly enjoyed the day and would recommend the course regardless of your cookery knowledge or skill.

Morocco, Marrakech, Michel.........Magic!. This is a day that tantalises everyone of your senses. The tastes are wonderful, the smells are evocative, the sounds are of laughter and you will love the experience of making wonderful food and then eating it. Added to this is the cabaret................Michel. A warm and wonderful individual who does not give you just a day out learning to cook lovely things and an understanding of spices, what you get is a lasting memory for years to come. We loved it. Thank you everyone for such a lovely day.
Good day out. Just so happened that We were the only ones booked for the day.. We enjoyed the experience of hands on cooking and it was a great relaxing and enjoyable day

You must do this. Beside Jamea Fana/Medina, this was the next best thing I did in Marrakesh. I took the combination of the cooking class and the Spa with high expectations, after reading reviews on TripAdvisor, and still it managed to exceed all my expectation at a great value. Michel is a guy who has made his mission to have fun and make sure you have fun too and share his joys with you and he does a great job doing it. Remember this is not only a cooking class. It is having the best and cleanest (remember, you made it) five course local meal in Morocco, in a wonderful place. Not to mention he will pick you up and drop you at your spa appointment, so all is easy and fun. At the end you know how to make the best Tajine, make bread, appetizer, learn about spices and ingredients, in addition to having an unforgettable meal in a wonderful ambiance, with great company of people and staff.

Brilliant way to spend a day in Marrakech. Michel has had great reviews for this experience and he really deserves it. It was brilliant to learn to cook such a variety of Moroccan food, and to eat it in the sun on the terrace. Really good value for the whole day.

Fantastic cooking class - highly recommend!. We had a really great time at the cooking class at Faim d'Epices. Spending the day in a beautiful setting learning the traditional way of making cous cous, vegetables, breads and salads! Very easy to follow along and a great chef to teach us! Michel is a wonderful host and we got to all enjoy our dishes together afterwards out in the sunshine surrounded by olive trees - perfect! Really recommend the Spa package, was just what we needed after a 'hard days' cooking....and eating, as the massage was really good and the Spa was relaxing escape from the busy streets of the Medina! Lovely touches were a cooking certificate which we received afterwards and extra recipes to try out at home! Fantastic day and learnt lots - thank you!

Fantastic Honeymoon activity!. This was a great experience for me and my partner when visiting Marrakech on our honeymoon. Michel is lovely and makes the whole experience such fun. Even as a couple with a large group of other people we still had a wonderful time. I would highly recommend this for anyone visiting Marrakech.

An awesome day out of the city, highly recommended. We did the cooking course and Spa day combo and it was the highlight of the trip.Michel was amazingly friendly and hospitable, he went out of his way to make sure we had a great time in Marrakech.. The cooking course was fun, informative and in a great setting. The evening Spa was a luxurious bonus and again, the staff were just so friendly and nice.Highly recommended, not just for the activities but also to spend time with Michel and learn more about Marrakech.Do it!

Fantastic honeymoon trip!. Myself and my new wife attended this course on our honeymoon in Marrakech. We both found this a very entertaining and educational experience, one that we will never forget! The hosts of the course were very friendly and were willing to answer any question we asked. We were also with a group of other English tourists who were excellent company! As we were on our honeymoon Michel gave us a tagine as a gift, a very kind gesture. I would definitely reccomend this course to anyone visiting Marrakech!

Absolutely Amazing!! A must do in Marrakech. I had the most amazing day doing this cooking course with Michael. I had read the reviews on trip advisor, expected it to be good and it still surprised me how much fun we had on this day! I really enjoyed making the tagine and bread and we were also taught how to prepare salads and crepes. Then we sat on the verandah and enjoyed our beautiful tagine with a glass of wine, finished off with spiced ice cream and crepes.... yum!!!! The attention to detail and care from Michael was beyond words, providing us with recipes and a spices goody-bag. I was also shocked to find that after I returned back to London I had received an email from him with photos from the day and extra recipes. If you are going to Marrakech then you must do this day!! The highlight of my trip and a beautiful sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of the city!!

Unbelievable Day!. This was the highlight of my trip to Marrakech. Michel and his staff were wonderful! My friends and I did the cooking/spa package. We learned about different spices, how to prepare a traditional Moroccan meal, and were able to enjoy the fruits of our labor. It was such a beautiful day and then to add to the beauty of the day, we had the best spa experience. A full belly and a relaxed body, I couldn't ask for anything more.

Great experience. If you are a foodie like us, you should definitely book this course, even if you are not.Michel picked us up near our hotel and drove us to his beautiful cooking studio. It was great to experience the spices workshop, prepare the Moroccan bread and tajine. We learned a lot, to use at home about spices and cooking skills. Now we will grate our tomatoes if we want to have a sauce, instead of peeling them first :-)We found Michel and the Moroccan chef very welcoming, and heartwarming.He even dropped us off at a supermarket, as they were hard to find in Marrakesh.
Fantastic day out. An enjoyable and interesting day activity. Did the combined spa and cookery class. A whole day of fun. Michel has found his vocation: a wonderful host. Highly recommended.

A fantastic cooking experience. We had a wonderful time at Faim d'Epices. Such a creative and personalized experience in a really relaxing environment on the farm. Beautiful way to spend a day, we had a great meal and I was very happy to learn the Moroccan way of cooking from a wonderful Moroccan chef! The owner was very passionate, knowledgeable guy who clearly loves what he does. I can highly recommend the experience to others!As far as my personal experience, I went with eight people including family members, and it was a very good activity for a larger group. We were all able to interact and be included without any of the difficulty or embarrassment that can sometimes happen when you're traveling en masse.

Great cooking class- value for money. Great fun this cooking class ! Being a bit experienced in cooking courses I can tell you that this class was the most fun, enriching and versatile. Blindfolded we learned to recognize the scent of different herbs, we were taught how to make bread, pancakes, salads and a very tasty lamb tajine. Appealing to everyone, experienced cook or beginning amateur. A well-trained teacher, charming host, delicious recipes: this course has it all. In between the cooking we had a chat, a drink and a laugh. The piece de resistance was eating our selfmade dinner outdoors while enjoying the beautiful scenery. Accessible to people who are interested in local food, who want to broaden their culinary horizon or who are just looking for a fun way to spend their day. Highly recommended !

Great experience. Great day of cooking, learning and relaxation. Collected on time from our Riad by the friendly Michel then on arrival we were offered a choice of mint tea or coffee. We had the mint tea which was excellent and refreshing. The course was excellent, I knew nothing about the spices used in Moroccan dishes or how to make a lamb tagine, flat bread or Moroccan salads and more. By way of cooking what you learn in the course and then eating what you have created was an enriching experience. One that we look forward to sharing when we cook for our friends. After the course we went to the Hammam (this was booked with L'atelier) we thoroughly enjoyed the experience and the relaxing massage. Overall a great day out!

Definitely worth the time. Difficult to add to the previous comments of others. The manager Michel is a great host, with a good sense of humor and Nazah, the cook, could be Marrakesh's answer to Nigela Lawson - constantly smiling!

east meets west through food - really fun. Michel and his team were superb. We were whisked away by van from the Palais Bahai in the heart of the medina by a mad Frenchman into the nearby Moroccan countryside for an unforgettable experience. After sniffing our way through a rigorous sampling of local spices wearing opaque purple sunglasses, we were placed in front of propane burner tables lined with cute prep bowls of pre-chopped spices, vegetables and a hunk of raw chicken. Following the instructions of our charming and beautiful Moroccan chef, we punched bread dough and cooked it, watched salad preparation and turned our raw ingredients into a spectacular tajine. Enjoying the fruits of our labour on outdoor tables in the sun in the olive orchard with a glass of wine and our loved ones, life couldn't be better.The timing and logistics of the event went like clockwork. Beautifully planned and executed - with love.A great way to plug into the culture and have a lot of fun. Most highly recommended.

Great day - try it for yourself. After reading good reviews of faim d'epices on tripadvisor I decided to contact michel about availability for cooking a vegetarian meal. He replied and said the dates I had suggested were free. He also mentioned the mystical spa. He told me up front of the prices and said there was no obligation to go to the spa. But I thought it would make a great day out for my daughter (28yrs ) and myself.We were collected from the medina in marrekesh in the morning by michel in a minibus clearly marked with faim d'epices on the sides. There was a young couple in the van when we got in and then we picked up another young couple on the way. By the time we got to the farm, we had introduced ourselves and was chatting happily together.The building was clean and bright, although a little chilly indoors. Michel did put heaters on which helped and once we started cooking we warmed up.We started by having mint tea and a chat about what was going to be happening throughout the day. We met couscous the cat. I liked the lovely clean white apron and now wish I'd bought one.The cookery session itself was easy to follow and michel wandered around chatting to us and assisting if we needed it. He also took photos too, which he emailed to us with more recipes to try. The spice blind test was interesting. And I enjoyed making the couscous. ( the stuff ive tried in the uk, I've not liked ) but I liked mine. We was also given a certificate with the recipe of the food we made that day. A nice souvenir. We sat and ate our food outside in the sunshine. Some had wine and we all had delicious homemade icecream. Michel sat with us and we all chatted and relaxed.It was later than planned when we set off for the spa. But it was all well worth it as its a beautiful place and we were made to feel welcome and comfortable. The hamman and massage was lovely and relaxing. The only thing I can think of which wasn't positive, was that we were not told until after the spa and massage that we would not be taken back to town by michel. We got lost and it took ages to find our way back in the dark and we wasn't as relaxed as we should have been when we got back to the riad. one couple had to find a taxi to get back to ther hotel which wasn't in the medina.I read a negative review about a hard sell to get people to buy products. It cant have been at faim d'epices as michel pointed over at a small corner of the room and said " there are things to buy if you would like to". And that was more or less it. My daughter bought a tassel and as michel didn't have any change he said to pay for it at the spa. Which we did.But the cookery day was a fun experience and I would definitely recommend it. Thanks to all the staff and michel.We also want to say hi to the other 2 couples and thank them for being part of making the day such fun. Wendy and Laura

fantastic day. Had a fantastic day. Well organised, lovely staff, some great cooking techniques to learn and such a gourmet meal to enjoy at the end. The pick up and drop off made it very easy. Highly recommended - I dragged my husband along and he even loved it too!

very good class lots of fun. We love to take cooking classes in the cities we visit. You get to relive the experience every time you make the receipes. The class was easy to follow the receipes great lots of variety and all in all a great way to spend the day. Michel was so welcoming and the instructor was great. Try it you will enjoy.The hammam Mystic Oriental Spa, is awesome, very clean gorgeous decoration and fabulouos treatments we ended up going three times during our stay. do the combination you will not be sorry.
Learned to cook Tagine Poulet. Nice day, took too long before we got to spa but really enjoyed the cooking class and meal together

Experience not to be missed. I booked this experience for my daughter's birthday as part of a special offer including a spa experience later in the day. We were not disappointed. Michel the owner was friendly and welcoming from the moment he picked us up from our hotel. When we arrived at the farm, we were offered (excellent) coffee and tea, and the format of the day was outlined. We started with a bread making demonstration from the school's cook Nezha, folowed by a spice workshop. The workshop was particularly interesting and we learned a great deal. Michel has a detailed knowledge of morrocan spices and had lots of useful tips for buying good quality spices. We then made our own bread and went on to make a traditional tagine. The tagine recipe that day used beef, but as my daughter is vegetarian, they provided vegetables to make a traditional berber tagine. We were shown how to make a selection of salads, and after baking our bread, we ate the delicious lunch on the terrace at the back of the workshop building.
