The class was run by a Moroccan woman who was nice but unfortunately wasn't able to explain things very well in English. I am curious by nature and was asking lots of questions and not really understanding the explanations, so I ended up losing interest about halfway through the class. The food we prepared was good, but I had better in simple restaurants in Marrakech. My biggest complaints are that there was no visit of a local market (which I understood was included) which could have added a slight degree of authenticity to the experience, and that there was a VERY hard sell later -- quite a bit of pressure on us to buy spices from their boutique and to sign up for some kind of spa which I think they own. Only when I made it very clear that we weren't at all interested did they stop what was bordering on harassment.

Had a great time!. Michel was very nice and friendly from the first minute, and things only got better as the day went along. His place is cosy, well designed and had a very welcoming atmosphere, the staff were fantastic and were very patient with us. It was fun learning how to make Morroccan food and the best part was we had to eat everything! We also had some fresh orange juice from the farm, Michel's homemade ice cream and the amazing salad made by the staff - all enjoyed with a few glasses of wine and some great conversation. Michel even gave us a small bag of their special spice mix and sent by email all the photos he took during the course. Would definitely recommend to anyone!

A Fantastic day - Not to be missed!. Our day with Michel and his team was an amazing experience. From the moment Michel picked us up from our hotel, I knew he would make it a special day.His character/personality alone made it a great experience. Michel is such a fun, friendly and charismatic guy, it really adds something extra to the good quality of the cookery course.I have to say the trip to the farm was a little further than I had imagined, but that may have been because we were the awkward customers staying outside of the centre?! Having said that, I would've been happy to travel twice the distance to get there after the day we had.The location is fantastic - very peaceful.The chef giving the lesson didn't speak english, but was very patient, and with Michel there to translate throughout it worked fantastically. The lesson was very thorough, giving an experience of a full three course Moroccan meal. Traditional Moroccan bread, A trio of Moroccan salads to start, Lamb & Prune Tagine for main, and traditional Moroccan pancake for desert.The food was delicious, which was surprising seeing as I cooked the majority of what I was eating! This just proves the quality of the lesson we were given!We were given our recipes at the end, and we've since received an email from Michel including extra recipes we can try, plus some photos he took us of during the day, which I think is a lovely touch! It all shows the personal touches Michel makes which made us feel so very welcome.Cannot thank Michel enough and could not recommend this any higher!Thanks Michel,From Tom & Amy from Somerset, England.

A great calm from the busy city. My boyfriend and I went here as a combo with the Mythical Spa and it was a brilliant experience; not something we would normally want to do. The set up and contact was prompt and easy, got picked up by a super friendly Michel and taken to a converted farm house come kitchen. Everything was really lovely, no pushing from place to place. We were able to chill out on the sofas and take our time. After our terrible guessing of spices were taken shown a whole host of recipes for Tajine, breads and other traditional dishes. All of which were very easy to follow and do again -although not tried it just yet! Michel gave us copies of the recipes and plenty of mint tea so sup on. He was great to talk to and couldn't do more for us. Thank you!!

Great cooking lessons and a relaxing dinner!. We where picked up at the hotel by Michel, a very relaxt and funny frenchman. We didn't know what to expect but it was great. Just 15 minutes outside of Marrakesch in a quiet and green area. We (me and my girlfriend) were with an English couple and an American woman. Michel spoke perfect English so the language was no problem. We learn't how to make bread, salades and tagine with lamb and prumes. Also we got a lesson in spices and how to recognize them. The best part was ofcourse the eating part, with a nice glass of wine!We had a great time and when we come back to Marrakesch we will defintly try one of the other coocking classes that are being given there!Greating from the Dutch couple (from near Maastricht)!Rens en Anne

A lovely day all round.... My Mum and I went to the cooking school in August. It was well run and good fun. The owners were very hands on and eager to answer any questions. Our pick up from the hotel was perfectly on time. Maybe don't make too many arrangements (unless you are booking the hammam combo) for striaght after the class as with the relaxed atmosphere and wine during lunch you may not make it back to your riad by 14.30 as specified. The food was yummy and there were no problems with accommodating our special requests regarding the menu.One nice touch was to be sent menus and photos of ourselves cooking by email a couple of days after the class. Would recommend it to anybody who is interested in learning about Morocca cooking and just wants a fun day away from the souks.

Driver turned up an hour early and drove off without us.. The day before we'd arranged for the driver to collect us from near our riad. He said he'd collect us at 10.20am. When we called him at 10.30am to query where he was he said he'd turned up at 9.30am and that he waiting in his bus and then went. He didn’t call us or come to the riad and didn’t inform us the he had changed to pickup time to 9.30am. The drive said that it was too late for him to turn around and collect us. We ended up going to La Maison Arabe Cooking Workshops instead which was a wonderful cooking workshop which included a tour of the spice market among the souks.

Must-do... This was a fantastic day. I have nothing bad to say about my day at L'Atelier....perfect ratio of 'students' to hosts. A great mixture of actual cooking with demonstrations.. A fun spice test at the beginning and a lovely touch at the end were the home made ice creams. The venue was great and Michel and co were funny helpful and welcomig. Fantastic!

AMAZING A MUST DO. My fiance and I did a cooking class here- we happened to be the only ones due to some cancellations- we had an amazing time! Michel was so friendly and so was his staff! We loved it! He picked us up and dropped us off at the recommended spa which was just as good. Perfect day we had thanks to Michel and his staff and also for the lovely spa that was recommended through his site!We will be trying out Lamb and Prunes dish at home soon! Thanks Michel!I would defiantly do this again!

If you can think of something bad to say, I'll argue with you! It's perfect!. The best day you'll have in Marrakech. Fact.Michel is a perfect host firstly, and his communication before hand is spot on. He'll answer any questions you have by email before you even arrive. He is French, but speaks almost flawless English. The location is a few miles out of the city, away from the noise and set on a peaceful farm, overlooking the garden where they grow there own vegetables, olives, lemons and recently planted orange trees. They get around the distance issue, by offering you free transportation to and from the cookery school.You'll learn to cook tagines, make breads, pancakes, salads... and teste your senses on a spices workshop - learning about their uses, smells and importantly, how to tell the good from the bad when buying.For me, the location was idyllic, all of the staff were friendly and attentive, the food was great, the learning experience useful, the spice workshop was fun and we were well looked after. Drinks always available. We took home the recipes we had learnt that day, and when we got home, Michel had emailed us a handful of other recipes, as well as some candid photos taken of us during the class.TIP - We took up an offer, to go to a spa after the class at a discounted rate with a company they had formed a friendship with. It was well worth it. We had a superb day from start to finish.

A Must Do While In Marrakech. One of the best ways to spend the day in Morocco.Michel and his two Moroccan cooks made everything very easy and enjoyable.The venue was amazing and would highly recommend this to anyone that goes to Morocco. The food, the cooks and Michel where all unbelievable, will be going back next time we visit. Cant wait to cook tajine back in Melbourne.

Enjoyable Day. My husband David and I most certaily enjoyed are last day in Marrakech with Michel and the two excellant teachers of Moroccan food, Mouna and Nezha. Who were very patient with us, while we mastered the bread making and lemon chicken and olive Tagine. We also found it interesting learning about the different spices and there uses. To finish the day by eating the rewards of the cooking, with a nice glass of wine, was indeed very pleasant. We thoroughly recomend any one who enjoys food and good company to take time to experience this day, as you will enjoy it.

A must-do activity for any trip to Marrakech!. My sister found this cooking class online for a last minute two day trip to Marrakech. She easily booked it online by emailing Michele, and we were pleasantly surprised when we received such a quick, accommodating response (after traveling a bit you become accustomed to slow responses). After reading all the fantastic reviews on here we were very excited, and the class lived up to all of the expectations. Michele picks yo up in a van from your hotel (very convenient) and then drives you to the nice location outside of the city. At first we were nervous that we wouldn't be able to find the van or that he wouldn't know who we were, but the van was clearly marked and he came right on time so that was not a problem at all. The cooking class itself was great, and I will definitely use the recipes I learned and that Michele kindly sent us. I really would recommend this to anyone going to Marrakech, even for a short trip!

Fab day and we really learnt stuff!. Michel and team were very hospitable and catered totally to the fact that I had two small children with me - 9 and 7. They're well-behaved kids but it does mean that the cooks have to help more than usual and be a bit more patient with the pace - which they did very well. They loved the spice identification game and have made Daddy do it at home since - with much sneezing! The food was lovely, the day was thoroughly enjoyable and our efforts at replicating the recipes since we returned home have been very successful so the lessons even worked! I would thoroughly recommend.

Tres magnifique. Michel picked us up from our hotel in Marrakech on time and with a smile, checked if we wanted wine with lunch so he could drop by supermarket on way, and had jovial chat all the way there. We were scheduled in to make "Beef, pear and candied orange tagine" and it did not disappoint. There were 5 of us on the course (2 booked at last minute and didn't eat beef so Michel switched theirs to chicken without querying or worrying) and we went through the processes of making bread, the tagine, various salads and their presentation. We had "blind" sniff tests on loads of different herbs and spices so we would be able to recognise them by smell as well as sight (helpful for souk shopping later on). The ladies who did the lessons were very helpful and extremely proficient in the kitchen with Michel translating over their shoulders. We finished off by devouring all the food we made followed by handcrafted ice-cream. Michel then helpfully dropped us around the corner from our hammam so we didn’t have to go through the souks to find it. I couldn’t have had a better experience. One criticism would be that we should have been told not to eat breakfast beforehand as we had to be rolled out the door at the end of the day. Merci beaucoup Michel and ladies.

Pleasantly Surprised. I was a bit skeptical when my friend signed us up for a cooking class in Marrakech. However, I was pleasantly surprised and thoroughly enjoyed the experience at Faim d'Epices . Our group (of 5) was picked up on time and comfortably transported to the farm. Michel and the rest of the staff were very affable and made the experience delightful. The cooking lessons were fun and reasonable enough to be duplicated on return home. We even had emails with added recipes and pictures sent to us after we left. If you want to do something unique during your trip to Morocco that you can take home and share with others, this is the course for you!

A must-do in Marrakech!. After being stood up by another cooking school, I called L'atelier Faim d'Epices in desperate hope of booking onto a class the next day and ended up getting so much more than I expected!!The orginal dish of the day was meat but, during booking, when I told Michel (the owner) I am a fishteria, he was totally flexible and said he'll change it to a fish tagine straight away. Prompt pick up on the day by a clearly branded van (so you don't need to keep looking around 'trying' to spot the right person) and comfortable transfer to a very nice out-of-town location for the class. The decor and view from the place is amazing and a delight to just being there even if not doing anything else! Rather than being cramped in a little kitchen, the area is spacious, tastefully decorated with moroccan lamps and paintings, and looking out into the open garden! What luxury it was to be able to cook in such an environment! We learnt to make bread, tagine, pancakes hands-on and watched demonstration of making 3 salads (which we later ate with our meal). Michel was such an animated character and created a great atmosphere, while the teachers were patient and professional. The flow of the class was really well managed as well with the doing (actual cooking), watching (demo) and learning (spice workshop) nicely arranged so you are never doing the same thing for an extended period of time. After cooking, we all sat down to eat looking out to the garden and chatting away with Michel and the other participants. Michel also gave us a little tour of the garden where they grow all the vegetables they use in the class (guaranteed organic and fresh!) and showed us the olive trees (which supplied the olive oil in the class!). This is more an enjoyable day out than merely a cooking class, the whole experience was fantastic and I would recommend to it to anyone even if you have no desire to become the next masterchef!

Amazing!!! Best thing I did in Marrakech!!!. The day started, very prompt pick-up and good transportation. Michel is very friendly and informative. I asked many questions about the area as well and about the souqs and he was very helpful. The class was awesome for all ages, I am 22 and I loved it. My class only had 2 people in it which was amazing most places would not run unless they had a minimum of 4 people or more so I was extremely happy with that. I also had to change dates of my class at the last minute due to a friend only being able to visit me on a certain day so I was very pleased that it was no hassle for him and had a very prompt responses to any questions i had. I learnt soo much - more than I would compared to watching masterchef or something. I learnt all about spices and recognizing them and how to make them from scratch and which ones to combine, we learnt how to make bread, 3 salads (which I happened to also have at a restaurant that night), a desert, and a main meal (for me was a berbere tagine). Their teaching methods are really good, i can remember exactly how to make everything and the correct method. The facilities are amazing - purposely built for the cooking school, situated just outside marrakech next to a farm so all produce is fresh from the farm. I have taken a cooking class in Thailand a year and a half ago and I thought that was good, but this class was the best, great value for money and well worth it, if i ever return to marrakech i will definately take up another class.

Fantastic! Highly Recommend!. I had a great day with Michel and his staff. Everyone is really friendly and very knowledgeable about Moroccan food and culture. The lesson continues even after you have been there: Michel has sent me follow up emails for new recipes for Tajines and Moroccan salads --- talk about value for money! I highly recommend taking the time to have a lesson with Michel and his staff

Delicious Food and Great time!. My husband and I took Michel's cooking class during our short stay in Marrakech. I am so glad we decided to do this sort of "experiencing" of the culture - rather than just walking around and touring all day in the HOT sun! After arriving at the cooking class location and farm, we had a nice mint tea and became acquainted with our other classmates - who were all a delight! We then enjoyed the spice course (very helpful for me as a somewhat novice cook) and learned how to make the bread. Next, we had a terrific time making the chicken lemon tajine. I appreciated that the instructors put effort into their demonstrations and gave us one -on-one instruction to make sure that we were cooking everything correctly. They really did a great job of showing us a meal that, while absolutely delicious and sophisticated, could definitely be made at home. Michel makes sure that you have all the recipes before you leave as well. He is a genuinely nice person, a great host and makes sure you have fun while cooking! We savored our meal with a glass of wine and our new friends before returning to our riad. We highly recommend this experience!

THE best Marrakesh experience. We had the most fantastic day with Michel and his staff. We were slightly apprehensive about having to meet someone in a busy square in Marrakesh but the whole thing went incredibly smoothly. Their people carrier was clearly marked with the company's name and we were warmly greeted by Michel and took the journey to their cookery school outside of Marrakesh.I was very excited and had very high expectation for the experience and it exceeded all of them! We were given more than was advertised and expected and it felt like all the staff took that extra step to make the experience as enjoyable as possible!There was a perfect balance between relaxation, demonstration and practical work on our own. We had the best experience of our stay at Faim d'Epices and as for value for money .... well it was incredible! Since our stay we have been in email contact with Michel and he has sent us extra recipes and pictures from our experience and for £45 per person it really was worth every penny AND MORE!!

Moroccan cookery delight. My friend and I visited the cookery school we were picked upand taken back by Michell who was a delight. He was passionate about his job and his tales of the Medina and the souks were interesting and informative. He made us feel very relaxed as did the other staff . We really enjoyed the spice lesson and then came the cooking. We made bread on the stove and then a lamb tangine followed by Moroccan pancakes. The great thing about this course is you get to eat everything, plus the lovely salads made by the lady chef. Washed down with wine and juice, and traditional tea. This was then followed by our pancakes and home made ice cream. Such an enjoyable day would definately recommend this day. Good value for money and something very different.

Cooking at it's best !. We've just got back from a great experience at this really friendly, professionally run, authentic and very tasteful day. We took our two children (well, 18 and 22) who weren't that enthusiastic to start off with but even they enjoyed it ! Michel the host picked us up promptly from our hotel, a pleasure to be with all day. Firstly we were taught how to make traditional bread and then a session on the various spices used. We then got into the cooking, individual stations well spaced out and around the chef, Mouna who really knew her stuff ! We made traditional bread and a chicken tagine, it was great fun doing this and even better when we sat down with wine to try out our own cooked food. Michel was at hand all the time, engaging in conversation and talking about where the spices come from. All in all a very enjoyable experience and one not to be missed. My partner researched many other places and this definitely lived up to then reputation. Worth every penny (or Dirham), ended with some refreshing mint tea, which complimented the fresh orange earlier. When we left we were given a recipe scroll in a lovely glass phial and the promise of more recipes by email. Can't wait to try this at home, even our daughter who's a can't cook won't cook type of person was converted ! Thanks a million

Lots of laughter and good food!. I've always been interested in food, so the most natural thing when coming to Marrakesh was to sign up for a local food lesson. This would also give me the opportunity to see some of the surroundings since we were only staying for a weekend.We got picked up by the minivan not far from the riad where we were staying. Michel, one of the owners would stay with us from the very start all through the day, making sure we had everything we could ever need, and with a charming French accent he would also act as translator. We were to make the famous chicken tajine with pickled lemon and red olives.The drive was quick, their house is situated 15 to 20 minutes outside Marrakesh, in a huge and beautiful garden surrounded by olive trees. This atmosphere really changes from down town Marrakesh (Medina), and really gave me the taste for discovering more of the Moroccan country side.The class room has been well planned, and everyone got their very own cooking table.Overlooking the olive garden we started to cook; Moroccan bread, 3 different salads and of course the Chicken tajine.My dish was eatable, I'd probably need plenty more time to master the Moroccan cooking. See their cooking in itself doesn't look too difficult, looking that is. Both our teachers, when showing us how to work the dough, chop the onion or water the chicken just seemed to have magic hands. In Moroccan homes, one's never allowed to touch the food with the left hand for hygienic reasons, they hardly ever use a cutting board, but prefer to hold the onion in one hand, chopping with the other... To sum up, I was amazed by their cooking techniques and next time I'm back in Marrakesh I'm definitely signing up for the couscous!Thank you Michel and the whole staff for a wonderful day, I really enjoyed every minute!

Fantastic day of Moroccan food and spices!. We travelled to Marrakech in May this year and booked onto Michel's cookery course as were interested in learning more about the distinctive and flavoursome cuisine of Morocco. We were given a very warm welcome from Michel and his staff on arrival at Faim d'Epices. The cooking facilities are great, very well designed with lots of space and beautiful views over- looking Michel's produce growing in the land outside.The half day course was a real pleasure, Michel was very knowledgeable and taught us a great deal about Moroccan dishes and the specific spices which characterise the food's authentic flavour, We made a lovely Tagine and a wonderful selection of Moroccan salads together with fresh Moroccan bread which was a delight. We all enjoyed tasting the fruits of our labour afterwards on the sunny terrace with a lovely glass of wine and the great company of Michel. It is obvious that Michel is hugely passionate about Morocco and its wonderful cuisine, his enthusiasm really did become infectious by the end of the day! would recommend this cookery course to anyone thinking of visiting Marrakesh, a fantastic day had by all!

Fun class. Recently did this class while on holiday in Marrakech with a group of six other friends. There were also 5 other travellers doing the course at the same time.We really enjoyed the class - we got to make our own bread and tajine, and also got demonstrations of how to make different salads. The introduction to spices was really helpful and there was a good mix of demonstration/making your own. We really enjoyed ourselves - the staff were lovely! It did run quite a bit later than the website indicated (it said 2.30pm and it was really 4.30pm by the time we got back) so bear that in mind when planning the day

Good cookery couse with a nice set up. We were recommended this course by our riad owner. We chatted with Michel- the driver and one of the owners and he explained it has only been up and running a few months but that things are going well and trip advisor has helped a lot!The course is 550dirham (about £45) per person. We were picked up at 9.30 from our riad and drove out of town for about thirty minutes to this little farm in the middle of nowhere. the kitchen was set up nicely with four individual stations set up around the demo station (there was four of us on the course in total). First off we had a talk about different spices and had to identify some by smell. We then watched one of the cooks prepare some bread which we then had to do ourselves at our station. Whilst the bread was resting, we began making our tagine. The cook didn't speak much English but enough for us to understand and Michel translated where necessary.Once our tagine was cooking and bubbling away, we watched the cook prepare two morrocan salads. After a bit more tagine cooking and cooking our bread in a pan, we helped make the dessert.We then ate out on the patio with a glass of wine (included in the price). I enjoyed my tagine but we did the beef day and I think it could have done with another hour or so to tenderise the beef further. the flavour was good though and the salads and bread and dessert were tasty. The different dishes done each day are available online. I might suggest the chicken day as this would need less cooking and therefore be more tender.The little shop there had pots and little tagines for very good prices compared with the souks and tourist shops.The other people on the course had brought their little boy with them and Michel and the cooks let him join in with the cooking and gave him a chef's hat and a little gift. I thought this was a very nice thing to do.We were also very grateful that we were on the course as it was the day the bomb exploded in the main square and if we hadn't been on the course, we almost certainly would have been in the square at the time.A few days later we were in Gueliz when Michel saw us and came over to say hello. He had remembered our names and enquired how our trip was going. I thought this was very nice of him.I would definitely recommend this cooking course and I wish Michel every luck with his venture

Great experience and delicious food!. I visited Marrakech for the first time last week and was eager to learn more about the sensational cuisine on offer. Michel's course was perfect for my needs. First of all, I found Michel a great host and his facility very well presented. His two chefs were obviously well trained in the art of Moroccan cooking and provided very informative coaching when cooking my chicken & olive tajine complete with salads and breads. To top it off my food was delicious!! Would definitely recommend this and thought it was good value.

very relaxing, understandable cooking lesson. Only 15 minutes away from the Medina you'll find this new building were we had our maroccoan cooking lesson. Not being a cook myself the 2, very friendly, morrocoan girls learned us how to prepare a tajine of veal with fresh peas , msemen and different salades. The owner Michel was a very nice and pleasant guy and told us a lot about all kind of things in Marocco. Certainly we will make a maroccoan dish in the netherlands for our friends and the recepy ( what was given us by Michel ) will certainly help us a lot. A very, very relaxing and nice experience with nice and friendly people and enough space to do this with a group of friends.

One of the best experiences while in Marrakesh!. Michel picked us up at the hotel and brought us to a new facility that was beautifully decorated. The ladies instructing us in lamb tagine with prunes were delightful. Food was delicious and lots of fun to prepare. Not to mention we could add whatever spices we wanted so that everyone enjoyed their meal.

Forget the others, choose the best and most ethical cookery class in Marrakech!. From the booking process to the tasting of our prepared meal, Amal's was a joy to be associated with.These guys are tucked away in the Ville Nouvelle, and the host Jihad did everything possible to make us feel welcome and comfortable.We arrived in the morning, were shown through the ingredients, introduced to some of the women on Amal's training programme and chatted with other wannabe cooks attending.The head chef was knowledgeable, fun and caring. Everyone got involved, had an opportunity to cook their own dish, and left with the confidence to replicate in their own kitchen.ALL proceeds go to the organisation, it is very reputable (I did my research) and is a much better way to spend your holiday money than a fancy high-end cookery class. Plus it's only 250 DAM, what a bargain :)Anyway, enough from me. Go and book yourself a place, you will have an amazing time.

Excellent cooking school experience. Had the pleasure of enjoying the morning cooking class at this worthwhile charity in Marrakech. The class itself ran from 1000-1300, followed by a meal. The organisation of the session was excellent with good communication. You picked what you cooked ahead of time and were given recipe cards afterwards so it could be replicated at home. The cooking class itself was led by a local chef and translated into English by their communications officer who spoke impeccable English and catered for all levels of cooking prowess to produce traditional tagines. It was followed by a tour of the facility and some more information about how the organisation helps people. Highly recommended experience for a very good charity which helps local women develop skills and find sustainable work.

Perfect!. The food was excellent! No less than delicius. Also the staff was very kind, and the armosphere relaxing. Neither my husband or I could eat it all, because there were so much food, but still it was really cheap. so we paid a lot in tips. It is for a good cause !!

Home made Moroccan dining. Was introduced to Amal by a friend. Small cosy restaurant with homemade local food you can enjoy . The place is run by women and supported by a foundation so they have a cause . Prices are very reasonable . Food is tasty. Make sure you go there on your trip to Marrakech.
Food. Lovely food and very friendly staff. Interesting orginasation that Will help women from being raped.

A great experience . We were recommended to attend the cooking classes from a friend who didn't have enough time in her trip to book. It was such a great experience with delicious food, lovely people and in a cute garden setting. I recommend this to anyone who likes cooking and finding out about Moroccan food. If cooking isn't your thing then just drop by for something to eat, the food is amazing!

Definitely giving hope to women in need!. The center itself is a little out of the way near quite a busy hospital in Ville Nouvelle. It was a little difficult to find but we managed to get there in the end. We researched a little into the what the center was all about and fell in love with the aims and goals of Amal (Hope in Arabic) and what they were trying to achieve.We really enjoyed everything. The fact we were mixed in with different visitors and got to choose our own dishes to cook. Learning traditional techniques and cooking methods along with the hands on aspects of getting to do it all. Finally eating the finished product was a fantastic end to a fantastic day!Nothing particular to bring bar a camera and your best cooking skills. Definitely a couple of hours for a visit but you could spend all day there watching the ladies work and hearing their histories.Well worth going out of the way to support such an amazing and worthy cause. We will go back next time we visit Marrakesh.

Great food. Great and inexpensive food, as if you were eating in a Moroccan family's kitchen. There is no menu, but a plat du jour. only negative point is that the desserts were not moroccan but italian (a bit off)! But otherwise the food and staff are perfect!

First class cookery class. . Went to this place as was only 250 dirhams each against 600 for other places. Started at 10am and we are around 12.45. Got a taxi there as about a 30 minute walk from our Riad. The lady who welcomed us spoke perfect English and was so lovely. I booked by email and they replied quickly. My partner and I cooked the lemon and olive tagine. You had a choice of vegetable or lamb though too. You did the whole process yourself with the spices and other ingredients. You then placed on hot coals and let cook. During this time you were given a tour and explanation of the centre and how it started. Then you eat your dinner. Wow it was tasty ! I couldn't recommend this enough. But book in advance !!

Great fun, really good cause.. We booked to do a tagine cookery class before we came to Marrakesh. All of the ladies at this place were so welcoming and lovely. The cooking course was great fun and well organised. The tagine we made was amazing and we got to take the recipe home. We had a tour of the building as well and were informed about the non profit organisation which is a really good cause.
Cooking with kids. We made Cous cous and others did beef Tagine. Amazing - better than expected and for a superb cause. Also bought sweet pastries. ❤️💙💜💚 love love love this place.

Lovely people, great holiday activity. We booked this cookery class in advance of our trip to Marrakech and it really exceeded all of our expectations. Amal seems a great project. We were warmly welcomed, the cookery was interesting and fun. The results were delicious and we enjoyed sitting in the restaurant eating our tagines and chatting to others on the course and our lovely translator, a volunteer at the project. We then ordered coffee and lovely desserts from the restaurant cooked by women training at Amal. Would thoroughly recommend this to anyone traveling to Marrakech

Great Experience. A friend of mine learned of Amal by reading reviews on tripadvisor. A group of girlfriends and I participated in a cooking glass here, and it was a great experience. Oumaima was a great hostess and she took the time to show us around and explain the mission of Amal. The cooking classes at Amal help to raise money for their women's center which trains women that, for various reasons, need to start over again and helps them find jobs. During the class, Oumaima went through all of the spices and explained a little about them. My group prepared the chicken tajine and it turned out great! Probably one of the best meals, if not the best, we had while in Morocco.

Wonderful experience. Visited the Amal centre last week to do a cooking course with my Mum. Oumaima was a great host, talking us through all the prep and cookery lesson as well as giving us a guided tour and telling us about the charity and what they do for the women of Marrakech, which is incredibly needed. Thanks you so much for a great and yummy day!

Amazing place, inspirational people. My boyfriend and I visited this place in June for one of their 2 hour cooking courses. I can't express how much we enjoyed it; the place as a whole and the people were so inspirational. It was great to learn how to make a traditional Moroccan dish but this was made even more special knowing the story behind the organisation. One of the ladies in our group had even booked to go twice in her one week holiday because she was so taken aback by their work. An amazing afternoon and was great to do the workshop in a group and meet people from all over the world. One of our highlights from our trip and we would 10000% recommend!

Good cause, but not an activity with young children.. My 7-yr-old boy likes to cook and so I took him together with my 5-year-old boy to the cooking class. There was hardly any cooking to do. Just chopped up an onion, put it in the tangine, put a couple pieces of meat on top and sprinkled some spices and that's all. Then we had to wait for close to two hours for it to get cooked. I wish I had known about the whole process. I would not have brought my children to the class. It was just hard to keep them entertained for two hours in the heat. Good place and good people though.

Nice price - nice food - nice people . Very kind service , delicious Moroccan food and very nice prices . 6 main dishes , 2 desserts 2 bottles of water and drinks 350 dh ( 35€) and all these for good cause . Thank you !

Delicious food for a great cause. Awwah!. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco. We learned the components of the different types of tagine (fish, beef, chicken) and made it ourselves. Above all, you learn and contribute to this remarkable center that is empowering local women via a culinary and management program. A short petit taxi ride away from the medina. Michelle Obama was visiting Marrakech the same day and we were really hoping that she would stop by this award-winning group since their goals of education for girls and women were completely aligned.Pearls for your visit:1) Make friends in your cooking class. You all make different kinds of tagines and it is fun to taste each others'2) Buy Moroccan patisserie in the small shop after the class. These were some of the most delicious that we had tasted in our trip3) If you can plan ahead, bring some small kitchen supplies for the women in the kitchen. They will love it!4) OK to bring your family. Nothing is as family bonding as cooking tagine together.Visit the Amal women and take the cooking class - you will not regret it!

Great fun and delicious food. The food is delicious and the staff are all really friendly and enthusiastic. All the ingredients are fresh and it's a very worthwhile experience, especially for such a great cause. Everyone was involved and it's a great way to meet other people travelling in Marrakech.

Money well spent on a worthy cause.. My husband and I just returned from our cooking class/lunch at Amal and it was amazing. We got to cook and prepare our own Tagine, while learning about the ins and outs of this amazing organization. Oumaima was a wonderful guide and the rest of the women there were very welcoming as well. It cost us 200 dirham each, which covered the meal and class. Anything else is extra, such as water, dessert, etc. We were originally told 2 hours, but it lasted three, which was fine as we were not on a schedule. Not all taxi drivers know where to go, so plan ahead!We would highly recommend you add this to your list of must dos on your trip to Marrakech! It is definitely a nice change from the hustle and bustle of the medina and square.

Good food, good cause!. Such an inspirational visit. The staff and students are awesome and the tangine class was really fun. Be aware that this class takes 3.5 hrs, the space is very warm, and you may need to ask for water -- we were a bit tired by the end, but our tangine was delicious and we had a great time.

Amazing organization, unforgettable experience. The cooking class at Amal Women's Centre was one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco! One of the first things we did in Morocco, our cooking class was led by a lovely former student and Oumaima, the communications director who acted as a translator. Throughout the class Oumaima explained everything (why we used certain spices, how the tagine cooks, how to properly stoke the coals, etc), making the experience engaging and memorable. As the tagines cooked, Oumaima gave us a tour of the centre and we mingled with the other class participants, who seemed as impressed as we were by experience. It was amazing to hear some of the women share with us what the program has done for them so far, and to hear the success stories of women who have completed the program. Oumaima told us that the program has been so successful it is expanding this coming year to a second centre where she will be a director - I wish them all the best and can't wait to see where this organization goes! Hopefully Michelle Obama and the girls will pay Amal a visit on their upcoming trip to Morocco!Amal is also a great place to have lunch even without doing the cooking class, so I highly recommend paying a visit to support this organization and enjoy some seriously good Moroccan food. If you have the time though, at around $25 CAD for a class, a meal, recipe card, and a fantastic experience - Amal can't be beat. It's only about 30 min from the medina, and an even quicker taxi ride. Thanks again to everyone at Amal for an amazing afternoon, and for all the good work you do!
Wow!!!!!!. Friendly, great space, great cause and great food!!! Our little one loved it. Not too far from medina and new town.

Fantastic charity and experience!. Everyone should do this! Not only do you learn how to cook authentic Moroccan food, but you get to see first hand how an inspiring and innovative charity is changing the lives of women in Marrakesh. Great value and one of the highlights of my trip to Morocco.

Best thing we did all holiday. I would definitely recommend the cooking class at Amal, I went with a friend and we both really enjoyed ourselves. We were given a tour and allowed to have a go at making some filo pastry although we were all rubbish. It was a lovely environment and we felt really comfortable, met some nice people who were also in the class. We made the bastila although couldn't finish it all- it was very filling! we were very impressed with the skills of everyone we met there. It was by far the best thing we did all holiday, nice break from the souks and we were fed! It was INCREDIBLE value for money as well, you can also just eat at the restaurant here which has been recommended by others that we met in Marrakech. Thank you for having us!

More than just a 'cooking class'. We came here one morning to do some cooking :) We were introduced to the establishment which has won many awards for their help empowering women in marrakech. Their work mainly is around allowing women in bad situations to be trained to work again whilst doing cooking classes and being a restaurant!It was eye opening and refreshing. The food was delicious - the only thing we had to say was that the ladies helping us cook did take over a little. The cooking itself was not very difficult and it was what we came to do! So letting us crack on would have been nice. Otherwise great!

Very good cooking class. This establishment run by a non-profit organisation provides a very good cooking class. We were part of a class of 16 and they handled the number well providing everyone with hands on experience as well as clear information about what was going on with the 10 dishes we cooked and ate.

Highlight of our trip. We had the a wonderful morning learning how to cook tagine in a class of 8. The food was delicious and learning about all the components of the flavour was fantastic. While the food was cooking we had some tea and Oumaima told us all about the charity and the work they do. It was so inspirational and the obvious passion that she has for her job really affected me. She told us lots of success stories and if was great to meet some of the women going through the training. If this wasn't a charity the cooking class would be great but being able to play a small part in their continuing success made the morning really special.When the food was ready we all sat round a table together and enjoyed the fruits of our labours with some delicious Moroccan bread and fresh fruit juices. The class including lunch was only 200dh (under £15) and I think that it was exceptional value for money. I can't recommend this highly enough!

Cookery Class. Group of 4 life long friends booked our morning cookery class in advance on-line. We cooked 3 traditional tajines between the four of us - there were a total of 11 people in our group from UK, Poland, New Zealand and Canada. Aided by Oumaima's translation skills (& enthusiasm) we prepared, cooked and enjoyed eating our dishes over a period of 3/4 hours. Whilst we waited for our tajines to cook we were offered refreshments and a tour/insight into the operation of the amal. This truly is a most worthwhile cause and I would urge any visitor to Marrakech to pop along; participate in a cookery class or enjoy one of their excellent lunches.Carol, Julie, Jill & Wendy

Best part of our trip. A secluded cool garden meeting wonderful staff and other travellers from around the world. What an experience, I have cooked a Tagine before but now I know how to do it correctly, can't wait to try this at home.Such a great charity, doing such a special job here, and so lovely to be a part of that and learn along the way.

Tasty, fun and inspiring!. We had a lovely half day at Amal, it was great learning how to cook the famous Moroccan tajine while making new friends and sharing stories with people from all corners of the world. The host was amazing and energetic and her genuine passion to help the disadvantaged women that the centre support was very contagious. I really recommend this place!

Learn to cook traditional Moroccan tajine & pastilla while making new friends. We pre-booked our cooking lesson prior to arriving in Marrakech & we're really glad we did! Located in the new town, Amal is essentially a restaurant where women are trained in all areas of catering from cooking to cleaning to taking orders to front of house service. The women come from different backgrounds & are under privileged or deprived due to personal circumstances, & Amal provides them with education & training to enable them with confidence to find employment & become self-reliant. The restaurant has experienced chefs who train & oversee the women. There were six of us who arrived for the lesson & we were greeted by Oumaima, a bubbly, vivacious lady who was our trainer / translator. She provided a explanation of the organisation & their aim before we started cooking. Working in pairs, we made 3 dishes - my wife & I made a chicken pastilla, the others made a lamb tagine & chicken tagine. The lesson was fun & really enjoyable with a tea break in the middle of it where we were given mint tea & taken on a tour of the site and introduced to the apprentice staff. Once everything was cooked, we shared what we'd made which was truly scrumptious! Our lesson was for 2 hours but we ended up staying there for most of the day making new friends. There are plenty of other places you can go to for a cooking demo/lesson but I doubt they provide the opportunity for you to contribute to such a worthwhile cause and have lots of fun in in the process.We left with our dummies full, knowledge bound & souls enriched, with take away souvenirs including recipe cards & aprons we wore. A must do experience for all ages. Thank you Oumaima and your lovely team for making this one of the highlights of our visit to Marrakech. Azad & Saira

Moroccan cooking. What an amazing experience! Not only did I learn to make a delicious tagine, I also got to learn about what this wonderful organisation is doing for the the less fortunate women of Morocco. A must for Marrakech!

Great food, fantastic cause. We had a fabulous time at the cooking class. The work they do for women is amazing and needs your support so get along and experience their hospitality and donate to the cause. You will love eating what you cook, meet some great people and leave feeling you have made a contribution. A well spent 3.5 hours.
Cooking class. Really enjoyed this morning spent cooking then eating a lovely tagine all for a superb charity that do great work, well recommended..

Rewarding Experience Plus Good Food. 9 of us enjoyed this experience recently. We learned about the impressive Co-op and also learned how to prepare three different Tagines. The gift shop/bakery surprised us with gluten free chocolate cookies that were AWESOME.

Great experience. We had an amazing time at the cooking class - even though it was really full (17 of us) we still got a lot of attention and made a really tasty tagine. The price was completely worth it, especially as it included the food we ate. A much better deal than what you can find at riads or in the souks. Plus Amal's is a great cause! Would highly recommend coming to Amals for lunch or the cooking class :)

A fun and engaging experience - a must!. Recently returned from a trip to Marrakech where I visited the Amal Women’s Training Centre and spent a really fun and informative morning taking part in one of their cooking classes. Before travelling to Marrakech I came across the classes and was really keen to visit as it seemed like a really good cause. All communication was really efficient and when I arrived it was well organised and informative. The cooking stations were set up outside in their courtyard where we were split into smaller teams based on our selected dishes however it had been well organised so it allowed the group as a whole to see how other dishes were prepared too and interact with others. It was a really informative session but most of all great fun, we were introduced to the different spices and which ones complimented each other based on the dish, we then prepared our tagines, everyone in the group was given the opportunity to get their hands dirty and contribute to preparing the tagines. Once the tagines were prepared and cooked over the coal stoves we were provided with delicious mint tea and given more information on the project and their social media engagement campaign. After the tagines were ready we all sat as a group to eat the delicious dishes and you are also given a recipe card to take away with you for your selected dish. This is a great way to get an introduction to the tagine dishes whilst you are visiting Marrakech and based in a lovely garden and courtyard. I definitely recommend this cooking class and I would return here in the future for lunch it was such a lovely experience. I recommend to book in advance especially if you are on a short stay or strict schedule so you get the availability you are after.

A delightful morning. A group of 11, in Marrakesh to help me celebrate a special birthday, descended on Amal for a morning cooking lesson. It was really well organised and explained. The setting in the shade of the courtyard was lovely. It was informative, but above all it was tremendous fun. We couldn't believe how delicious our tajines were when it came to lunch time. Thanks Amal for a highlight of our trip.

Absolute Must Visit & Dine. First, the food is great, the atmosphere is lovely (garden setting), and the service at the restaurant is impeccable. Now that we've got that out of the way, I want to rave about what a fantastic place this is and how important it is that you make a visit for lunch or dinner (or cooking class). We had the opportunity to learn more about the school while we were visiting, which was great because we were traveling with our 17 year old daughter who was making her first trip to Africa, as well as her first trip to a primarily muslim country. The person giving us the overview of the facility was a beautiful young woman who is fluent in several languages, plays on the national volleyball team and could not possibly have been a better ambassador for her country and the mission of the Amal Association. My daughter was so fascinated with the facility and the woman that provided the overview, that she talked about it for a day afterward, and I have heard her talking to her friends about the experience. This was so much more than a great lunch -- it gave us a window into the soul of a great country and was a real trip highlight. If your schedule permits, you really must go.

A must go!. We came for lunch in our last day in Marrakech with the main purpose of celebrating and contributing to the great work the Amal Center has done (and will do) for women. What we got was so much more. The food was absolutely delicious, service was quick, and all volunteers of the center were extremely kind. Nora, the owner, was not only present, she was fully involved in taking orders, chatting with customers, and helping clean tables. I highly recommend a visit to the Amal Center-you will leave feeling full of hope...and delicious food!

Wonderful Food and Lovely Setting. We were so glad we were able to have lunch at this cooperative and meet the women being trained here. Reservations are a good idea as seating is limited. They really are appreciative and gracious on any patronage. Recommend for lunch.
Great class and fabulous food. A fabulous experience cooking great Moroccan recipes here in the courtyard at Amal. This is a fantastic set up to help train disadvantaged women with culinary skills.

Amazing food, amazing people!. We had an awesome time taking their cooking class! The ladies who showed us how it's done were so nice and a lot of fun. Making a tagine over the fire was really cool and we even got to pick orange blossoms straight from the trees to go in our mint tea. We enjoyed learning more about the inspirational things the centre does to help women and would highly recommend a visit, whether it be for the cooking class or just a wonderful lunch! Definitely one of the best experiences of our trip to Morocco.

Awesome place!. My girlfriend and I only discovered this place after searching for things to do in Marrakech during bad weather though we're so glad we went! A fantastic organisation run by some very inspirational women. Learnt everything there is to know about cooking any type of tagine and was all for a good cause. This should be a must for anyone visiting Marrakech regardless of the weather!

Good Cause... A great project for disadvantaged ladies. Unfortunately the class was overbooked which meant everything dragged out and took longer than it should, diminishing the experience somewhat. More cooking stations would have been better as we spent a lot of time watching other people repeat the same chopping of vegetables etc. This said, the tagine turned out well (very tasty) and it was in a pleasant friendly setting.

Amazing women of Marrakesh!. We visited the center on Feb.23(my friend booked it thru internet 2weeks prior our visit).we used the carriage going there and it was easy to find.We were welcomed warmly by the ladies and sat in our reserved tables.we all had fruit cocktail drinks and it was so delicious&very fresh.We all enjoyed our yummy starters which are fish&soup.4 of us had fish tagines&the other one had chicken.I enjoyed my fish main but it was a big serving i couldn't finish the whole serving!i had cream pastilla for pudding with strawberries ohhh it was lush.The manager was very kind to show us how the ladies do all the cooking in their kitchen at the back!they are all fantastic!keep it up ladies&goodluck.We will come back again!

So Much Fun. What a great organization and cause! Additionally, the cooking class was so informational and fun. We made a vegetable tagine, and we loved that the class was outdoors. We also enjoyed sampling the food they make there at the restaurant--the mint lemonade is SO GOOD!

A Marrakech MUST!. Just book it! You get to learn how to cook a traditional Marrakech dish (and watch others cook some too) you then get to eat it :) But more than that you get to support a great cause of giving women from rough backgrounds a chance of a better life. Here they learn how to cook and work in a commercial restaurant environment and if successful at passing all of the tests they get a real job an a chance at independence and stability. They get literacy classes, life coaching classes and a confidence boost which means they finally look at themselves as equal members of the society with a future and a place in the world. Amal is a charity wholly funded by their own activities so the cooking classes help you get to grips with a new skill while funding a really worthy cause. This is also a very popular restaurant (in the top 3 of places to eat according to trip advisor) so once we cooked our tajines we got to sit on the terrace and eat it and watch as tourists and locals alike pour in through the main gate for their daily lunch. the place was packed within minutes! A true testament to the quality of the food and the fame of the organisation! I will say it again - JUST BOOK IT!

Just go there!. We attended a cooking lesson and can absolutely recommend it! We were a nice group and made all kinds of dishes (so you can see how other dishes are prepared, not just the one you're making for yourself). You learn some basic knowledge and enjoy your delicious self-made Tajine! It is not that hard to cook though, so the cooking is not the "best part" of this experience. What is, however, is to support the work of this great NGO. The Amal association supports women in need, trains them and finds them jobs so they can build a self-sufficient independent life. Having some problems with the little role of emancipation of women in Marocco, this was a great opportunity for us to give some support to this cause! Also we had the chance to see and speak to some of the trainees, and maybe have a different look on things...

Good fun & for a great cause . We had a great time at Amal. There were 6 of us in the class and we had chosen to make a lamb tagine. The actual cooking part didn't take long- we prepped and then left the tagines to cook slowly on a charcoal burner and were then shown the kitchens and learnt more about what they do here. It is all for a great cause and the food (which we shared with the others in our group) was really delicious- one of the best tagines we had during our trip! It was around £14 each which we were happy with.

Good experience!. We really enjoyed our cooking class experience at Amal! Making the dish (we made vegetable tajine) doesn't take very long (except for the actual cooking), but this also leaves time to learn about the excellent initiative that Amal is. As the different participants at the course made different tajines, we also got to try and taste the differences between them. Very good!

AMAZING WORK. I really enjoyed my class today with Amal Center... Such an empowering movement they have going on there. The food was amazing and Ouimama (site manager) was very accommodating to all the tastes buds and restrictions in my group!! Class went a bit over but we started late due to folks arriving late. Most places would cut your time short, they did not! There is so much passion and hope in this place. It's a feel good class knowing you are helping empower women!! 100% recommend it!!! I've taken cooking classes all over the world and this one is in my top 5. I will be back as I plan on taking my daughter upon our next visit!! Must do. Support local causes!

Great cause and lovely staff. The restaurant is set up for a great cause and helps women in vulnerable positions. The menu doesn't have a wide choice but an eclectic menu shows of the skills of the women taking part in the project. A great place to go to discover more about Moroccan community.

GREAT experience for our 3 families! Such fun & delicious food. What a wonderful way to spend the morning/lunchtime. We visited the Amal Women's Training Center for a cooking course, and learned how to make 4 different tagines. Our group ranged in age from 8-48 and it fit all of our needs. Relaxed, authentic, and educational not to mention delicious. Our kids loved using the little bellows to keep the tagine fires hot, and the communal table was such a great way to meet other folks and share the fruit of our morning's efforts. We LOVE what Amal's doing for the community and hope to see them expand further. Great job, you guys! Thanks so much for everything.

Very special place. Amal means hope, and you can certainly hope for a good meal here. But it is behind the scenes where this place becomes very special. The Centre trains women to step out of whatever past they have had and will give them 6 months of training to work in the catering world. In the male world of Morocco this is priceless. The centre links with childcare provision for its trainees, again a priceless commodity.The morning cookery class is (early 2016) 200 dirhams, about £14, $20, €17 in very round figures, and is limited to 12 participants. The ingredients come laid out and each participant has hands on experience of chopping, cutting, sprinkling, pouring and arranging. On the day I was there it was a tagine session, beef, lamb and chicken. The ingredients all looked very fresh and appetising. The dishes were duly prepared under the keen eye of one of their women chefs and narrated by another of the team. Once prepared the tagines were cooked on traditional charcoal 'braziers' and finally served and eaten. The session includes a mint tea break, other drinks and desserts come extra.There are a plethora of cookery classes in Morocco, this one is simple, understandable, photographable, and well overseen by the Amal team.The restaurant serves a revolving menu so their trainees have the opportunity to learn a wide ranging repertoire. Each day there is more than enough choice for the hungry traveller.Highly recommended for its food, the course and its ethos.

Great place and great food with excellent service!. A friend of ours recommended this place for lunch and preordered a special dish I forgot the name of. The dish was just amazing and the fresh juices topped it of to a perfect lunch with extraordinary service.Highly recommended!

Best lunch in Marrakech. Amazing food and a great cause. Really enjoyed the tour and learning about the work the association is doing. Everyone was very friendly and the food was the best we've had during our stay. Would definitely recommend, especially the chocolate lava dessert which was incredible!

Delicious food and a great cause. We visited this very popular restaurant for lunch twice during our week in Marrakech and would have returned again if we had the time. The food is excellent and it is a great cause to support. Don't miss it.

Cooking course. We had such a fantastic time at Amal Women's Training Centre. The course was delivered in a clear and informative way. Nora made us feel so welcome and was really passionate about the centre and the work she was doing with the trainees, and what a wonderful cause it is. We had a really fun morning, met some other lovely people and learnt how to cook some beautiful food. We wish you every success in the future and will definitely be coming back when we visit Marrakech again! Laura and Richard, Derbyshire, England
Go, have fun and support them. This is an amazing place. The cookery course was great fun and suitable for any skill level, the resulting Tagine was delicious. Very friendly.

Excellent food. This is a great place to go for lunch. The food is delicious and the service is wonderful. I highly recommend supporting this restaurant and training centre for woman from disadvantaged backgrounds.

The best experience in Marrakech!. We did a cooking class here on our final day, and it was the best experience we had in Marrakech. We were met by Ouimaima, the communications director, who is passionate about the work at Amal and beautiful, funny, welcoming. Totally a dynamic person!The cooking class was great fun, and we learned about the fabulous training going on for disadvantaged women at Amal. Such an inspirational organization. We had such fun cooking the Tangine chicken....everything is set out for you and it is easy, fun, plus you get a cool bookmark recipe at the end. Most importantly, you find out about this great organization and help in your own way. I brought back aprons as souvenirs, and embroidered bags. Don't miss it! Great fun, inspirational beyond words.

A must visit. Amal has an amazing mission and through their cooking classes and philanthropic restaurant is able to change the lives of Marrakechi women. It was easy to schedule the class online and we enjoyed the full experience (takes about three hours including eating lunch). It was all very lovely. I would recommend pairing this with a visit to Jardin Majorelle.

Wonderful experience. This was an overwhelmingly positive experience. The cooking class was great fun and the recipes were easy to follow. Obviously you get to cook what you eat too so lunch is sorted! Better than any of this, however, is the fact that you get to support the amazing work of the Amal organisation which supports disadvantaged women in Marrakech to work their way out of poverty. This is just such a great way to give a little back to this wonderful city and to spend a really rewarding and delicious half day with positive and friendly people. A real winner!

Not much cooking. Whilst I fully support the organisation and every thing they do to support and empower women the cooking class was a let down. I was expecting to do a lot more than dice an onion and sprinkle a few spices. We then sat around chatting for 1.5 hrs while the tagine cooked.

Cookery class organised as part of a hen weekend in Marrakesh. This was an inspirational morning that I found very moving. I am full of admiration for the work that is going in this centre- it is quite incredible what can be prepared in such a small kitchen.........and then we got to do it ourselves. So, even better we could then eat our own prepared tagines. I would highly recommend a morning cookery class just to be amongst these inspirational women, their chef and the leaders of the centre.

Book it now!. The cookery class was great fun and the company was good. The best thing however was the inspirational Oumaima who talked us through the purpose and aims of Amal with such passion and commitment. Her dedication to improving the lives of women gave us a lot to think about. Our beef tagine was delicious and the chicken one cooked by others looked great. Take a morning to learn something new and enjoy the resulting lunch with new friends. Highly recommended!

Delightful Morning. AMAL WOMAN'S TRAINING CENTER COOKING CLASS AND THEIR RESTAURANT, is a wonderful experience. I had a meal here before registering two friends and myself for a cooking class. Enjoyed both immensely. It is a lovely little villa on a side street in Gueliz. Very quiet, and pleasant garden. The class was fun, and very reasonably priced. We enjoyed the meal we cooked. I've eaten here before with friends. It is a modest restaurant, with good food and excellent service. It definitely deserves a 5 star in its category.

Great cuisine for a great cause. We absolutely loved this place: great cuisine with fresh ingredients - the couscous was to die for -, nice outside terrace, friendly staff, very good value for money and all, for a great cause (chek the restaurant's website for the full story).

Great day !. My wife and I signed up for the cookery course, and we are so glad that we did. We were shown round the centre, and were then taught how to cook a chicken tagine with preserved lemon and olives - very hands-on - and thereafter the best bit - we were able to eat what we had cooked. It was delicious ! Everyone there was very friendly and committed to carrying out the great work they do. I would recommend this to anyone. In addition to running a cookery course, the centre is also open as a restaurant in it's own right, and the food being served looked fantastic.Keep up the good work !

One of the best things we did on holiday. This was a really great experience. Definitely recommend!We arrived a little early so sat in he lovely shaded courtyard outside. To start we were shown round the facility and given an introduction to the charity which was really interesting. You can ask as many questions as you like and they'll be happy to answer. Then it was time to make our own tagine! This was really fun. The chef didn't speak much English but a volunteer stayed with us the whole time to help translate and take lots of photos. It was great to learn to cook am authentic dish with a local Morrocan.As our tagine was cooking we got to drink mint tea in the shady courtyard. And then we were presented with our tagine with bread made fresh that morning. It was delicious! We also got a free recipe bookmark each to take home so we can recreate our dish. It was such a great experience.

Great facility, average cooking course. The work done to support struggling women at the Amal centre is really great. However, the cooking course just felt a little simple, probably because tagines are so simple to cook. Perhaps some other dishes could be involved too?

Couscous, the proper way. Our group of 9 had a fantastic cooking lesson at this school. We could chose 3 dishes and one of them was couscous. It was fascinating to watch it prepared the right way. We were all able to participate in the chopping and cooking (but didn't have to) and the end result was a delicious lunch for us all.The school is part of a program to help women who have fallen on hard times (divorced, single mothers, etc) learn job skills to support themselves. It's a wonderful program and a great cooking school.

Don't miss this gem. I have just spent a most enjoyable four hours learning how to cook a good tagine at Amal. This is an opportunity not to be missed! For a small fee of 200dh you get a full 'hands on' experience and then enjoy the results when cooking is complete.Amal is a worthy cause and does a fantastic job teaching the ladies how to cook, serve, speak different languages, build their confidence and then find them jobs in the local community. You can help them by taking a lesson or just going to the restaurant for a meal to see for yourself why it is rated no.3 here in TripAdvisor and I guarantee you will return. Definitely one of the best Marrakech experiences.

Achieving Excellence in Every Way. The Amal Women's Training centre is wearing many hats and achieving many things - its a training centre - it is a cooking school for visitors - it is a restaurant for lunch and on every level it is achieving excellence.I was very excited to find this centre on the internet prior to my visit to Marrakech and booked for a cooking class. The communication I had with the centre whilst preparing for my trip with outstanding, they offered tips for travel to their location and a clear outline of what to expect from my trip. When my travelling companion cancelled they were more than accommodating with new arrangements and continued to reply to my enquiries in a timely and polite manner.When I visited the actual centre for my class it was not as easy to find as I had hoped and the local taxis don't seem to be aware of its location but I got there in the end and was received with great welcome into the beautiful quiet and clean Amal Centre.First we were provided with a short tour around the centre and details about it purpose as a Non Governmental Organisation / Non-Profit / Charity. As a centre who provides education and training as well as counselling and financial support to small groups of disadvantaged women over a 6 month period with a view to giving them the skills and confidence to find work and self-sufficiency after graduation - essentially saving the women and their children from lives of poverty and destitution. An excellent project that is achieving excellent results in real-time and also gaining recognition and winning awards in the social forum. Outstanding.The cooking classes and restaurant are the main means to sustain their development. So I was booked in for a cooking class on the Saturday and a lunch visit on the Sunday - trying to get a feel for the whole place.The cooking class was great fun and the highlight of my trip to Marrakech. A group effort really, with everyone watching the others take instruction and build their recipe, rather than couples heading off to corners with their dishes. With three different dishes being requested it did take quite some time to prepare and there were short periods of waiting but the group I was with were chatty and good craic was had throughout the morning. Chicken and Beef Tagines were prepared and put to the stoves using traditional bellows to puff up the fire. In the meantime I tackled the Chicken Pastillia - filo pastry parcel of sweet and savoury goodness!! There was no rush or impatience from the staff, even when it came time to open for their lunch time crowd we were welcomed to sit together and enjoy the fruits of our labour on the outdoor patio. Mint tea and deserts were inevitably ordered as the morning turned into afternoon. And at the close a number of the class - who had never met before today - made groups that headed off to visit the Majorelle Gardens (YSL gardens) not far away. This was certainly a fun way to meet people and take on new cooking skills. A lot of details about the Moroccan traditions, spices and tips on preparation. A super open air class, using lovely fresh ingredients in a spotlessly clean setting. Totally exceeded my expectations for the bargain price of booking. An ideal option for the solo traveller like myself, or a couple or larger group. enjoyable for all.And lunch the next day? - still got lost trying to find the place - how silly am I?? - Was much quieter and more relaxed on the Sunday lunch time. Was provided with a varied and tasty sounding menu from which I chose the breaded fish and molten chocolate cake to follow. Both were really wonderful dishes, I love fish and this was delicious and presented well. Not a big chocolate fan, but the molten chocolate cake was made to look exactly like a burnt rock oozing dark lava and was very so very soft and delicious. Mint Tea, of course. And then able to sit reading my book undisturbed until it was time (unfortunately) to leave for the airport....But not without first buying an arm full of gifts for my friends back home!! Beautifully embroidered aprons, napkins and sturdy cotton shopping bags were available at very reasonable prices - all with the centre logo and all profits to support the centre of course - easy to pack and each one a lovely gift.The bargain price of the lunch here for the quality of the food on offer in a quality, clean setting is in itself a single most important reason for every traveller in Marrakech to visit here. How could anyone want to pass up these prices in the lovely bright and relaxed Gueliz district?? Add to that, the proceeds are going towards a wonderful organisation who works in the local community and uses local produce.. its a win/win... If I am in the city again I would try to have my lunch here most days, its just too good value to miss and on my way out, grab some pastries to go and I have my afternoon snack already on hand!!As for the cooking class, if there had of been an availability for me to do another one on the Sunday I would have booked in a heartbeat. Again, bargain prices for top level experiences. OVERALL - the Amal Women's Training Centre and Restaurant - an absolute must see. Satisfaction Guaranteed. Great Value for Money. A Feel Good Visit on every level - great food, great people and a great sense of having contributed to a worthwhile cause - for a cup of coffee and a quick visit, for a quick grab of a bag of super pastries, for a full lunch date or a morning learning cooking - Go Here. Feel The Welcome. Feel Good in Marrakech.

Didn't make it, but they were lovely nonetheless. Disclaimer: we didn't manage to visit. They were closed in the month of August. But when we contacted them, they were very friendly and lovely about it. I appreciate the courtesy - which we found all over Marrakech - and wanted to thank them for it. If we ever come back, we'll make it a point to visit.

Excellent experience and fabulous food. We booked a cooking class here during our recent trip to Marrakech. It was only my husband and myself along with another couple from Germany who were doing the cooking class this day. It was a wonderful experience! Of course we learned more about the work that this great NGO is doing for women in Morocco, and got to see them working on the day's menu up close. And then we got to work with one of the lovely staff to make our own tangines. The experience was fabulous, and the food that we got to eat was absolutely delicious, by no small stretch the tastiest meal we had in Marrakech. The spices were so fresh and perfectly balanced in our lamb tagine, it was perfect and we can't wait to try to recreate it at home! Absolutely go for lunch even if you don't want to do the cooking class, but if you're looking for a cooking class while in town you should certainly do the one here, it's an excellent value for an excellent cause and the result is out of this world good.

Fantastic, well run course.. Love this place, well organised and immaculate ...great course with clear instructions and friendly teacher.Definitely recommend and such good value, not least a fascinating and successful young charity. Thanks to Kara and Jamila for a great morning. Wonderful food not to say the least.

A genuine linitiative in Marrakech. I was one of five attending the cooking class. Oumaima gave us a very good history and tour of the facility which is a restaurant, training centre and cooking school. We could all pick a dish we wanted to make in advance (see website) and it was hands on with the assistance of a staff member. We cooked the tagines on coals and used bellows to get the fire going. All the trainees were busy making food and sweets for the day and were all very pleasant and obviously enjoyed their training. We were given delicious mint tea and later once our tagines were cooked we sat and enjoyed the ample portions with their homemade bread. I bought some of the little Moroccan pastries which were all delicious and each quite different. The cooking school is excellent value at 200dirhams. We were not rushed even though the restaurant opened for lunch when we were there. There are other cooking classes in Marrakech but I would go here again as it helps a very worthy cause of training disadvanted women who are either widows, divorced or single mothers of between 18-40 and helps them to get a job once their six month training is finished.

Air-conditioned, clean restaurant, great servers and The food - EXTRAORDINARY!!. Amal is the only place I ate salad in Morocco. Being a brit, I was careful with my food and drink whist on holiday in Marrakech as I did not want to get ill. Amal restaurant prepares food in a unique way. The lovely Oumaima (who is the communications officer there) gave me an impromptu tour, when I went and said Hello and advised me, the ladies who are working at this charity learn to prepare food to international standards of cleanliness. I was allowed to take photos (see photos attached) and I found it very funny when the ladies were saying, we just finished serving Lunch and so the kitchen is very messy right now!
