I felt it was the cleanest restaurant kitchen I had seen (and believe me, this is so very true! having stuck my head round pretty much every restaurant kitchen I could, including the one at our hotel too- I have mild ocd, related to cleanliness, hygiene mainly) and I was genuinely thrilled to meet these lovely ladies whom were working at this great women's charity in order to better their lives.Lunch is served 12-3, almost daily, check their website (link above) and dinner bookings I believe can only be made for large parties of 20+. I am actually so thrilled with my experience there and having learnt about what they stand for, next time I'm in Morocco, I intend to book out the place for dinner and take some lovely local's I met this time round - this way I get to treat them as well as give my hard earned £'s to a worthy charity.As well as other souvenirs, they sell apron's, tea towels and strong shopping bags - all of which I bought to support the charity. Very reasonably priced. If you go on holiday to Marrakech, I really think Amal is a must, you must visit. Not only are you supporting a amazing charity by spending your money here but the food - wow!! The food was absolutely delicious. What amazing quality and the desserts were to die for - just yummy! It is a shame we were only in Morocco for 4 days, I could easily go to eat lunch there everyday...and next time we go, that's just what I intend to do!A comment for the Amal team - Thank you for having us, please keep up the good work. May you prosper and do well in your aim to help and empower more local women. I'd love it if you also opened up for dinner. Yup you will certainly have my custom on a daily basis. I hope to return later this year, when it's cooler. Thank you for serving us, by far, the best meal I ate in your beautiful country.

Magnificent Experience. We had a wonderful experience with the cooking class, the center is a MUST see and eat of Marrakech. The flavor of the food we cooked stick to my mind during my entire staying in Morocco, it was delicious, we have already cooked in México the dishes that we learned at the center, which where of traditional Moroccan weddings as we've been told. Our spanish translator was a lovely girl, Iman, she made the experience even better by teaching us about her culture.

Family Cooking CLass & Lunch!. We loved the cooking class our daughters got to experience while visiting Marrakech! Their instructor Jelima was an amazing instructor and so sweet with our girls! Also, Mohammed the Chef was fabulous and so generous with all of the tastings he provided us during the course of our class! The following week we made sure to come back for lunch and enjoyed seeing everyone again, meeting all of the other diners, and enjoying our delicious meals!We recommend the Amal Women's Traoining Center and Moroccan Restaurant to any and everyone who is visiting Marrakech whether it be for your first time or you've been to the city before!Thanks for a phenomenal time and if we're ever in Marrakech again you will definitely be seeing our family again!

Fun experience. My friend and I had a class and it was fun. The group kind of encouraged participation because a lot of it was done by the instructor but other than that it was a great learning experience and we were happy with our dishes ;) really delicious and the staff was so kind and helpful! I wish we had time to go back for lunch another day but we didn't.Great initiative - best of luck!

A Great Experience in Marrakech. My partner and I took a cooking course at Amal and it was fantastic. The restaurant/ cooking school is located in lovely neighbourhood in the new town, and so it was a great excuse to escape the hectic-tourist filled medina. Our teacher was very patient with us, and the young woman translating fun to chat to. The food (a beef and prune tajine) was delicious. I would love to go back to the restaurant to eat more. The whole atmosphere was very friendly, and this was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.

My Compliments To The Chef!!!. On arrival you get a tour on what the place is about, very interesting. Then you get cooking the tagine of your choice, I went for the Chicken Citrone and due to the excellent teaching it was bloody lovely!!!! Highly recommended :-)

A Rewarding Experience. The Amal Women's Center is a great place and program. Taking a cooking class here was an excellent experience as the staff and trainees were extremely welcoming, hospitable and knowledgeable. Not only do you get to learn how to cook a traditional Moroccan dish, but you also learn about the Amal training program, and the women involved with the program. Not too mention the food you prepare is a delicious (and extremely filling) treat at the end of class. You get to eat in the beautiful courtyard, and feel like you are n your own Moroccan oasis. Definitely recommend a visit to Amal Women's Center.

Learnt so much. From beginning to end this was a truly wonderful experience. From shopping in the souks, to preparing the food which we would later eat, this was amazing. Getting to prepare and eat Moroccan cuisine and sit down with your fellow classmates was very enjoyable. Every person involved in helping us were very helpful throughout.

An authentic Morrocan cooking experience. I am now a convert to cookery classes when on holiday ! This was a wonderful day (10am to 4pm) due to the attention and guidance from Gemma and Cecile and the wonderful dynamic experience of cooking alongside Morrocan women. the first hour or so was spent in the souks buying produce for our meal and this was both a great experience and educational, giving an insight into products that would be difficult to gain as a tourist passing through alone.We were a group of 12, the only two Brits in a group of Dutch and German, but great conversation and laughter was had throughout the day. The kitchen is in the -open-to-the-sky centre of a riad hidden away in the Medina and which provides an amazing experience. We even took some of our produce through the streets to a local baker to have it baked in his ovens.Between us all and with the insistent guidance of our local cooks, we created a feast of salads, fish, two types of briouates, cous cous and cookies. We then thoroughly enjoyed eating it all, washed down by some local wine. Thank you Gemma and to all the ladies in the kitchen.

Highlight of our trip!. My only wish is that we had done this sooner in our vacation. It truly is an amazing experience from the people you will meet in the souks with Gemma, to the fresh ingredients, her sous chefs, and the actual making and eating of the meal. From start to finish it was a wonderful adventure. My 7 year old daughter loved being a mini-chef and walking the treats to be baked down at the baker. My oldest (15 years) and middle (12 years) love to cook at home, so to do it here themselves and enjoy new foods & fresh ingredients was a real treat. The souks are overwhelming at first when on your own. Gemma, the owner, teaches so much about the shops and how to navigate them. She introduces you to the people she regularly shops with. In the days following, they would recognize us and we would stop in for a visit. The information is priceless, as is the experience. Gemma and her sous chefs make this experience.Gemma is also very accommodating. We have a daughter with serious allergies that has to avoid many types of food. Gemma got the list of allergens ahead of time and made a complete menu from appetizers through desert that the whole family could enjoy. We never had to worry, which was a welcome relief from the rest of the trip since it was very challenging to make sure everything she ate was safe.Overall, it was the highlight of our trip. I think our kids will always remember the experience as well. Thank you all!

Birthday Treat. This was one of our favorite couple experiences on our vacation. After taking one excursion and two different training courses, this was by far my favorite and more enjoyable time. In my opinion you still have the cultural experience but also a superior quality product in comparison to other training course vendors. Also, while shopping and meeting the different retailers helps in reducing buyer’s remorse.The owner and operator was very open to signing my girlfriend happy birthday. Big Thanks!

One of the best parts of our trip!. My husband and I spent a day with Gemma, the two chefs in the kitchen and another lovely couple. We started the day with Gemma handing us a shopping bag, a grocery list, and a wallet of money. This was unexpected as we were told we were responsible to get the items on our shopping list. What a wonderful experience though in the souks, with her help, we shopped as a couple getting ingredients for the meal we were about to cook. Once we had all of our ingredients we headed to her home where we met a Moroccan chef and her sous chef. We had the best time cooking vegetarian Moroccan dishes and then enjoyed them as a group with wine and tea. I was even able to walk the tray of biscuits to the local baker and returned an hour later to pick them up. Incredible experience! Gemma was wonderful as were the chefs. One of the best parts of our trip to Morocco!!!

Great experience and introduction to Moroccan food.. A great way to spend a day in the Medina. Enjoyed walking through the souk and shopping for ingredients for the meal with Gemma. There were multiple courses and the seven of us pitched in preparing the various courses. Highly recommend

A fun and interesting way to learn to cook Moroccan food. I read about Souk Cuisine on Tripadvisor when looking at 'what to do' in Marrakech. I e mailed the owner, Gemma who responded within a couple of days, with all the info. I needed to make a booking. My husband (who considers beans on toast is a cookery challenge) and I were so pleased we had booked this very unique event. We met as per instructions, Gemma and one of her friends, and with 13 other eager cookery students visited the Souk. We were given a shopping list of ingredients needed to cook a typical meal. .The cooking was in a kitchen open to the sky. Tuition was given by experts, that is local women who use the recipes on a daily basis for their families. The ladies spoke very little English, however even if you don't speak French fluently, everyone understood the instructions given. Gemma was on hand at all times to supply the water and encouragement.After all was baked in ovens or cooked on the stove, we sat together and ate our delicious dishes and biscuits.This full day event has inspired my non-cooking husband to be more adventurous when taking the kitchen cooking challenge. I also picked up tips how to use spices and easy food preparation know - howsThis day was also a great way to meet others from all over the world- USA, Australia, Sweden, Austria, France, Germany, Holland, Belgium, (apologies if I've left anyone out).Don't forget your camera. Aprons are supplied so no worries about food splashes on clothes.Also a big thank you to Gemma for guiding us to find a taxi to return to our hotel. Without your help we would have easy lost our way.

Simply WOW. There might be many many cooking courses in Marrakech, but certainly none of them will give you such an experience!Not only will you receive super interesting background information on Moroccan culture and food, how to haggle for the right price (if there ever is something like a "right price") and about different spices, their taste, production and influence on your body. After buying all necessary ingredients on the market, you will be welcomed into the home of a bunch of lovely Moroccan women who teach you how to make traditional Moroccan food such as Tajine, salads, dips, pastry, fish and meat and much much much more ... But be aware - you better strictly follow the recipe! ;)No where in Marrakech was the food - nor the company - that good!We are more than amazed and thankful that we had the chance to get to know the real Moroccan hospitality while eating such amazing food and learning sooooo much!Would recommend it to anyone visiting Marrakech and will certainly come back on a second visit!Once again, a virtual thank you to our lovely host and guide Gemma! :)

One of our favorite experiences in Marrakech!. We were not sure to book it at the beginning because of the price, but it was totally worth it! The whole experience of walking through the different souks, choosing the ingredients, meeting people from different countries and learning marroccan recipes from local people was amazing.There were also several ladies there helping us with the preparation and cooking of the dishes itself, which made it possible to cook so many different things plates in a short time.

Awesome way to find your feet in Marrakech, while enjoying fantastic food & hospitality. We met the owner of Souk Cuisine Gemma in the morning and were given shopping bags and lists, then were toured around the winding alleys of Djemaa El-Fna, such a great way to learn the maze of market stalls & shops which can be quite difficult to navigate by yourselves for the first time. She gave great advice not only on food, but about the Moroccan way of life and how to get by in the craziness of the square. We walked, talked and shopped for an hour or so, filling our bags with the most beautiful of produce,fresh spices and the freshest chicken we have ever seen! After bartering with the locals we headed back to her kitchen ( which was amazing ) where we met our 2 chefs who would be guiding us along side Gemma to prepare our delicious lunch. We drank tea while the chefs prepared our ingredients then got to work cooking some of the most tasty fresh food we have ever experienced!We sat and ate tajines, veggies and all types of other delights, then talked over a herb infused tea which was nothing like we have had before.I cannot recommend this tour highly enough, it was one of the best ways to get to know the surrounds and an overall wonderful time that will be remembered forever.Thank you Gemma and the Souk Cuisine team!!

Such a highlight of our trip.. What a great experience. The food cooked was delicious and Gemma and the Moroccan women were fantastic, but for me the best thing about Souk Cuisine is the chance to shop in the markets of the souk amongst the locals. It was so interesting and such a fun and rewarding experience. I also loved taking some of the courses to the local baker to be baked, what an experience. Would definitely recommend.

Great introduction to marrakesh. Great day, buying ingredients and cooking in a group (we were 12), taught by Moroccan women alongside Dutch owner..great fun, learn a lot about food and prices!, and a communal meal together...ask to see the communal bread ovens.Like 'great Moroccan bake off' but better!Might seem expensive by one measure but opens up unseen bits of Marrakesh & a good long day 10-4

I cooked The best lunch in marrakech !!!!!. From 10 am to 3 ish pm we were immersed in the possibility that we were going to produce amazing food. 4 enthusiastic , but very amateur cooks shopped for vegetables, fish, olives, herbs,then a visit to a spice shop, everything so well explained, off to the courtyard of a lovely riad, stainless tables, everything set up beautifully, recipe booklets handed out, a group of smiley, helpful Moroccan woman chefs gave us instruction, and we set about our tasks. We all worked on different recipes,shared what we were doing... At the end of the cooking, we all sat down to eat our efforts. I have to say it truly was the best lunch we had in a week in marrakech. I would recommend this to everyone .

fantastic experience and lovely food. Myself and a group of my family and friends enjoyed a day exploring the souks, shopping for ingredients and cooking with Gemma and her team. We had a couple of veterinarians with us which were well catered for - we made a wide selection of different meals and side dishes as a team and then sat down and ate them together at the end of the class. We really loved exploring the souks an buying our ingredients. we learnt a lot and found it very interesting. Everyone there was so lovely and friendly. Everyone from our group had a fantastic time

Great fun, great food!. Despite having wandered the souks for hours in the preceding days, seeing them with Gemma as our guide was fascinating. We went down alleys we would never have visited, bought from stalls we would have overlooked and went through doors we wouldn't even have seen. Then back to the lovely Riad for some simple yet delicious food. All our questions were answered with expertise. Followed by a great meal with like minded people. Leave yourself some digesting time afterwards if you plan to shop afterwards!
Great introduction to Marrakech!. This was a great introduction to the souks and to Moroccan cuisine--the highlight of our vacation! Additionally, the meal we made was the best food of our trip!

Great way to see the souks, learn to cook and meet new friends. This was a wonderful way to get to know the souks and an introduction to Moroccan cooking. We did the class on our first full day in Marrakech which worked out really well. Gemma and her assistant Cecile split us into 2 groups before taking us round the souks to buy the ingredients for our feast. This was an education in itself, especially the visit to the spice shop and buying chicken from the chicken and rabbit butcher! Once we'd bought our ingredients it was back to the Riad for refreshing lemon verbena tea and a break before the cooking started. A few reviews have said that they didn't really get to cook and they just prepped veg. Well, seeing as preparation is most of cooking, that is no surprise, but everyone in the class of 11 got stuck in and we all got to cook as well as prepare the dishes. Activities like this depend on participation and the more you put in the more you get out of it. The ladies who were our tutors for the day were great fun and showed us exactly what we needed to do, with Gemma overseeing and explaining in detail. Once the food was cooked we sat down to an amazingly delicious feast and we rolled out about 4.30pm. This was a great way to spend the day and as a bonus we made new friends too. Thank you Gemma, Cecile and all the ladies.

Amazing, Fun and Cultural Cooking Class. Souk Cuisine is a wonderful cultural and culinary experience in the Medina (old part) section of Marrakech.In addition to being a "cooking class", it's really an immersive cultural outing. You start by meeting the owner Gemme (an ex-pat from Holland) and going to shop for all of the ingredients that you'll be using.From learning about the spice market, to which are the best conserved lemons to choose and what to order from the butcher, you come away with a real experience of shopping on a daily basis in the market.Then you go back to Gemme's lovely home where together with her and her team of local chefs, you prepare all of the ingredients into an amazing lunch.Oh my goodness it was awesome. We did it with our two daughters (17 and 18) and they had a great time as well.I highly recommend this for anyone from individuals to families. Thank you Gemme for everything!!!

Amazing experience. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Marrakech. We were tarvelling with four boys aged 13- 24 and needed to sort the agenda to keep them happy. Therefore I booked a session witn Souk Cuisine and it was a complete success. It started with shopping for the ingredients in the souk. Two people were given a shopping bag, a shopping list and some money and the. We set off witn Gemma supervising and diercting us through the maze of the souk. As there were no sardines available that day the boys were able to buy chicken - live chicken! We could watch the whole process of choosing a chicken, witnessing it being killed and prepared right before our eyes. Very different from your Supermarket "grab a pack of chicken" experience. The shopping tour was also a good brush up of our French skills. Then we went to the riad which housed the kitchen and in the courtyard of a very pretty riad we prepared our lunch supervised by four lovely Marroccan ladies. Salads, tangines, chicken (baked at the local bakery - we had to carry the trays there and pick them up again) followed by mint tea and a variety of sweets. Sooo delicious and great fun. Gemma and her team did a great job and we had the best time.

A great introduction to Moroccan food. We did Souk Cuisine on our second full day in Marrakech and it was a great time to do it; we'd had enough time to see the souks but could also still benefit from Gemma's wealth of knowledge about them. Gemma was a knowledgable guide, explaining many things we may otherwise have never noticed. The class itself was full of new experiences and included selecting our own live chicken to turn into tagine. We came away with lots of new information, a full stomach, some great recipes and some cookies. Great!

Fun day at the Souk and cooking. We did a fun day of shopping the bazaars and cooking with Gemma at the Souk Cuisine school. It was great having someone show us the traditional way of shopping (this was also an education in holistic medicines and spices). It was hands on and then a delicious lunch. There were 6 of us and another group of 5 so a total of 11 people which was easily manageable in the large open space. The Riad it is housed in was a hidden gem!

Cuisine & Culture. I booked a day with Souk Cuisine for my 2nd day in Marrakech & what a joy it was.My group met outside the Cafe de France & we were given shopping lists, shopping bags & little purses containing money. We were shown around the souks and enjoyed the tour from a local's perspective. The shopping experience was great fun & it was a great way to interact with other cook school buddies & locals. On my tour there were mostly Dutch & Belgians & despite any language barriers they were a super friendly bunch & we all got along well.Once the shopping was done, we started to cook in the Riad. It was brilliantly set up & very interactive. Over the course of the afternoon we made a surprising number of traditional dishes with the delightful Souk Cuisine ladies keeping us right.A particular highlight for me was taking food to the local oven to be baked. A great experience.When the food was ready we all ate together & enjoyed a glass of wine.The cooking was suitable for all levels & thoroughly enjoyable. I would recommend Souk Cuisine if you're looking for something a little different. Friendly, inexpensive, well run & super fun. You won't be disappointed.

Top culinary delight. My partner and I thoroughly enjoyed this fantastic cooking experience! Definitely something to try if you covet a break from the bustle of Marrakech.Upon meeting at a mutual destination the group was split and lead round the daily food markets to source ingredients from a pre-set 'shopping list' that we would be cooking later. This was a true highlight for us as we were shown the 'real' side of the Marrakech food markets and encouraged to engage with the locals, with tips and tricks on 'good' prices. There were 14 of us altogether which Gemma told us is about average. After walking round, ticking off the list for about 1.5hours we walked to the Souk kitchen to prepare our feast.The kitchen is housed within a beautiful Riad and we were greeted in French by warm, bubbly chefs. We worked as a team to prepare our lunch and there were a number of 'stations' to choose from. Gemma and the all-female chefs were on hand to show us the best way to prepare certain foods in line with the recipes. We all contributed and patiently waited for the dishes to cook, whilst presented with tasty snacks and appetisers. When we did sit down to our feast it was delicious!What a great afternoon spent cooking local dishes, learning new culinary methods and chatting with new, interesting people. Gemma is a lovely, warm host who happily answered all of our questions, considered any dietary requirements and made sure we got the most from the experience. Very good value for money too, loved it.

Best experience in Marrakesh. The cooking course was, by far, the best experience I had in Marrakesh. (That might be, because the city itself is rather unspectacular.) It was interesting to buy all the indigence on the market, cooking was of course nice as well. You get an insight into Moroccan cooking techniques - and the food was the best I had on the whole trip.

Fantastic experience. I'm very glad we decided to spend the day with Souk Cuisine. We both had a lot of fun and learnt a few things along the way.The first thing I'd say is that I recommend doing this early in your trip. The souks can be a bit daunting and this is a great way to ease yourself into it. Having a guide who is explaining everything as you go along makes it a lot more interesting too.You start the day with your shopping list, bags, and a purse provided by Gemma. You then have to get all your ingredients (being directed of course). Thankfully food is a fixed price so you don't have to worry about haggling or being overcharged. I found the spice souk particularly interesting, being showed how to tell the difference between real and fake saffron.Once you have all your ingredients you head to the kitchen for tea and a sit down before the cooking starts. There are different stations and you will usually get one dish to cook at each station. This means that you probably only directly have a hand in one or two dishes, but you can watch the other stations to get an idea of how the other dishes are done (hint: there's a lot of chopping veg in Moroccan food). I think it works better that way because all the food is ready at the same time and it's not overwhelming. Gemma and her team of Moroccan ladies are always on hand to help.Once the main meals are cooking, the cookies are made and delivered to the local baker to be collected later.Everybody then sits down to eat. It's nice that Souk Cuisine caters for everybody's tastes and will adjust the menu accordingly.Overall I'd strongly recommend Gemma and Souk Cuisine. It makes a huge difference to the day going round the souks in the morning, it's far more than just a cooking class. That being said, if you want an advanced cooking class there might be better options, but if you want a fun day, a trip round the souks, to learn about the food and have a chance to make one or two dishes (and eat them of course!) then this is your best option.Thanks very much Gemma and her crew :)

One of my favourite experiences in Marrakech . We started the day in the souk picking up all of our ingredients and learning a little about them and the locals along the way. Having only been in Marrakech for a day or so, it was the perfect introduction to the Medina.The group was around 15 in total but we were split into smaller groups each with our own guide to make navigating the souk easier.Back in the kitchen, Gemma and her team had us whip up a feast of authentic dishes which catered for all tastes and levels of culinary skills. I learnt some great tips and the food we cooked/ate was delicious. Can't recommend this activity highly enough.

An unforgettable experience in and out of the kitchen!. Gemma has clearly thought out the perfect way to not only teach you how to cook amazing Moroccan dishes, but she has created a style of learning that has you interact with the locals by having you shop for food and even having certain items baked by local bakers down the street from her class. It takes the experience to another level which was appreciated by our entire group. She created a menu that catered to our likes, but even introduced items that she trusted we would like, and she didn't disappoint! I was in charge of making fish (I dont normally care for fish) that I was so proud of and found absolutely delicious! Put your trust in Gemma, she will provide you with an experience that you will not forget and will stay with you when you are in your own kitchen at home.

Great experience in Marrakech. If you’re hoping for an advanced culinary experience then maybe Souk cuisine isn’t for you. However, for anyone looking for a simple introduction to Moroccan food, a chance to explore the exciting (but somewhat daunting) markets with a guiding hand, and a welcome break from the hustle of the city then Souk cuisine is perfect. We cooked a mixture of cold salads and kefta tagine in a small peaceful riad and took marinated sardines and home-made biscuits to the local bakery. It was a really nice way to spend the afternoon to relax, meet some lovely people and of course, enjoy the delicious food. Overall a very pleasant way to spend the day in Marrakech- highly recommended!

Amazing !! . This was the first cooking class myself & my partner had done & it was so so good. Meeting Gemma was great. We had a very small group of 6. & we each got given a list of Ingredients we needed to purchase from the souls. As Gemma took us around she told us a lot of interesting information & mixing with the locals was really fun. We went back to where she lived & two Moroccan women who were Chiefs, helped us cook all our dishes. It was an extremely enjoyable experience & we each got given a little recipe book of the food we had made that we could take home with us. When it was all cooked we all sat down with wine & enjoyed the lovely food we had made. I would recommend this to anyone that hasn't tried a cooking class.I'd give this 6 stars if I could!!

Great Experience. We had a very enjoyable time during this class. The shopping for the ingredients in the medina was very fun as was mixing with the locals, learning about Moroccan spices, and seeing the community bakery. We made mostly salads, and a tajine and some pastries all of which were excellent. The cooks are local Moroccan ladies who speak no English so this made for some fun sign language as we tried to follow the directions. All in all a lovely day, and the wine served with the meal was lovely.

I would do it again. My sister and I thoroughly enjoyed ourselves during the entire experience. It was probably one of our favorite things we did while in Marrakesh. Gemma was very nice and understanding when it came to my two small children. She let my "princess" make the cookies. The class was an intimate size. We had a bad souq tour before and found we learned more about the souk from the cooking class than in an actual tour of the souk. A wonderful experience and if I am ever back in Marrakesh, I would do it again.

A gem. Having done many cookery classes the ones I enjoy best are the ones where you get into it and get your hands dirty rather than spending hours on demos. This offers exactly that. The group met in the main square and Gemma set us the task of shopping for the ingredients needed in the souks. The group consisted of 3 New Zealand girls, 2 Germans and us (2 Brits). We all bonded really quickly and with a shared task we all got down to business. After around an hour we found our way to Gemma's riad and after a short rest we cracked on with cooking. We were all set a task and helped by the two local ladies who were hard task masters, making sure everything was done properly. There were no real demos but it was easy to pick up what you needed to do and to join in with others when they were on task which interested you. Between us we made around 10 dishes and then once they were ready (we used the oven belonging to the local baker) we sat down to enjoy the fruits of our labour. This excursion was just what I hoped it to be, fun, informal, interesting and laid back. I'd 100% recommend it.

If only you could give 6 stars.. Amazing experience. I want to do a cooking class in every foreign country I go to - and I hope they are all like this. My wife and I learned so much. Getting to go to the souks first to buy all our stuff was so much fun and so helpful and educational. Gemma was the perfect host. It was great doing this on our first day because for the next two days that we were there we had so much of a better understanding of where we were and how to get to where we wanted to go. After buying everything from all the shops and learning about how the locals buy stuff we went back to the kitchen and cooked. My wife and I both love to cook and it is so enlightening learning the way that other cultures cook. New ingredients, new smells, new techniques - amazing. After cooking we all sat down with our new friends and had wine and the food we had just prepared.A perfect day, and there was still time afterwards to do other stuff.Highly recommend.

One of the best cooking classes I have done!. The difference between this cooking course and many others, is that Gemma starts you in the market. She has her list of ingredients and bags, and leads you to the different markets to purchase each of the ingredients. She has a great relationship with a lot of the shopkeepers who are excited to chat with us and educate us on their products. The shopping is followed by cooking the courses in her kitchen with two Moroccan dadas (cooks). Once all the food was cooked, we all sat down and enjoyed one of the best meals I had in Morocco. Thank you, Gemma and her crew, for giving us one of the best days we had in Marrakesh.

An enjoyable day in the market and in the kitchen. An fun and informative day in the market and in the kitchen with Gemma. We started in the market buying all the ingredients for our recipes for the day (don't forget - the uglier the lemons, the better) - if you want a true Moroccan cooking experience then you should definitely start by shopping for the ingredients, and it was great fun. Then to the kitchens where we were all given our recipes and tasks to complete. My wife and daughter loved it, and even for a complete non-cook like me, the ladies were on hand to help me and I managed to turn out a decent enough dish. There were seven of us with Gemma that day - probably would have been a bit of a squeeze with any more but seven was perfect. Tonight at home we are having Moroccan chicken using some of the delicious spices from the shop in the Spice Market recommended by Gemma,

Loved it. Really fantastic day out with my boyfriend. I cook a lot and thought the recipes we perfect for a novice or experienced cook. Starts in the morning with the group meeting in the square. The fantastic Gemma leads you around the souk to the local food vendors in a fun and educational venture. You then go back to her lovely home and cook with two amazing local chefs. We made 7 courses with the duties split amongst the group. Traditional Moroccan salads, tagine, fish etc. Once the meal is cooked everyone sits together to eat and drink wine. Total blast and highly recommend!!

Fantastic experience that will allow you to cook great food at home. We had a fantastic time in Marrakech and this was one of the most memorable bits.From buying the ingredients to learning how to cook with them we found it all interesting , relaxed and very tasty.

Great way to learn about Moroccan cuisine. It was a really enjoyable day. After meeting in the main square Gemma took us to the souks to buy the ingredients. It was really worthwhile experience and we learnt a lot especially about the spices and their medicinal uses and the trip to the bakery was fun. We then went to Gemma's house where we cooked up 7 different dishes. We were with two other groups both from Holland so it was also a great way to interact with other visitors to Marrakech. A great day and would thoroughly recommend to anyone visiting Marrakech. We have also tried out the recipes again at home!

A worthwhile experience from a wonderful woman!. A great experience and mini adventure, starting with the market trip. I met Gemma outside the café with a group that included a couple from Portugal and a lovely group of ladies from Florida and Alaska! Gemma was really fantastic and incredibly friendly and knowledgeable. You will find out about some of the secrets of the Souks which you would find difficult to discover alone. The shopping for ingredients was a lot of fun and the cooking creates a great camaraderie with so many tasty dishes. Highly recommended! Stephen :)

Must do. Myself my husband and our 13 year old daughter went on this course in April 2015, when I booked I felt quite guilty as I was using a day of my families holiday doing something I want to do instead of riding the water slides in our hotel / water park but it ended up being our daughters highlight !! The tutor Gemma has an excellent manner and my daughter struggled with her confidence in a kitchen with other unfamiliar people, instead of getting involved as I usually would I ignored my daughters complaints that she couldn't do a, b, c and Gemma instinctively stepped in and nurtured her enough but not too much which empowered her, my husband never cooks but his dish was the best in my opinion and he had fun too, you are helped to source your ingredients and local ladies help you to cook, the food is delicious and the company was good too, I recommend this course for any level of Cook , the atmosphere was very relaxed and we were encouraged to stay as long as we liked to finish the food and wine supplied the only reason I have not given 5 stars is the tutor was 10 minutes late and she said she would have souk cuisine shopping bags but they were regular bags so not so easy to identify but overall an excellent experience and good value for money

Fabulous. If you are interested in food and finding out how the locals live in Marrakesh, then this is for you! If you do it at the start of your trip you will also get some great tips on where to eat for the rest of your visit.
It was the best things we did in Marrakesh. We loved it!

A highlight of our trip. Really enjoyed this experience, starting with the market trip. It was great to get to meet some of Gemma's favorite vendors, gather our ingredients, and end up at her kitchen to make so many wonderful dishes. We had a fun and enthusiastic group, and we chopped our way to a fabulous lunch of Moroccan salads, two tajines, and cookies that we sent to the local communal oven to be baked. Everything was delicious and I learned a lot. Highly recommended.

Great day!. I loved this day with Gemma. From meeting her in the square and being given your purse and shopping list to going through the souks shopping for all the ingredients to make some truly Moroccan dishes. The ladies working with Gemma were also all very lovely and helpful, and I had a fantastic time learning different techniques and things I would have never tried before. I also really enjoyed going to the spice shop! The food we ate at the end of the dy was delicious too.

Great day. This is a brilliant way to start your stay in Marrakech. Meeting Gemma and touring through the Souk to purchase the ingredients for the meal you will prepare later is a great introduction to the City. The experience will also suit seasoned visitors to Marrakech as there is the opportunity to find out much more about daily life. We are looking forward to trying out our new skills and recipes on unsuspecting friends! Really good value too.

One day cooking course. Really worth doing and good fun, first you meet in the square to do your food shopping which in itself is an experience! Then you go back to a really fun place to cook & then devour your culinary work! Fab

A marrakesh highlight . I had a great day with Gemma and the ladies in March. The day starts in the souks which is a real bonus as you get the act like a local and learn from Gemma's friendly store people. They are very willing to share their knowledge of spices, meats, olives etc. The rest of the day is spent learning the trade secrets and techniques of Moroccan cooking in a beautiful home. You leave with many tips & recipes to share with friends at home. I'm excited to show this off upon my return. I recommend to non-foodies & foodies alike. It's a small group and you're able to be as involved or not as you wish. Thank you Gemma.

Great fun and delicious food. This was one of the best experiences during our trip to Marrakech. We met Gemma in the morning and explored the Souks together. While shopping the groceries for our meal, she showed us many interesting places and gave really good advice - things we might have overlooked otherwise! Afterwards we went to a lovely little house, to prepare the different dishes together with two moroccan women. We were a Group of 6, which was just the perfect size. Sure there's a lot of chopping and preparation involved (makes it authentic in my opinion) and you're not going to become a master Chef with this course (which shouldn't be the aim anyway) - but it's great fun, super delicious food and good insights into Moroccan cuisine and culture!

A fun Event suitable for all. Myself + 3 friends booked onto Souk Cuisine to have an introduction to cooking Moroccan style. We meet Gemma at 10:00 just off the main square, are armed with a shopping list, bag, purse and into the souk we go. Gemma knows the stall holders, everything seems so much easier when you have a guide. An hour later and we have bought spices, vegetables, meat, fish and been into the local bakers (would never have attempted this on our own).Down a side street and through a tiny door (Alice in Wonderland style) we are in the Gemmas' kitchen. Two local ladies will oversee and check out our purchases whilst we have a cup of tea, ingredients. We are each set up at a station with a booklet of recipes. Hot and cold salads, tagines and fish dishes are all to be prepared. The chefs watch and guide us as we prepare the dishes. Items to be baked are taken on the trays back into the Souk to the bakers where for a few dhiram we can use his oven. Tagines are bubbling on our stoves and when everything is ready we sit round a table and are all able to eat our creations, washed down with a glass of wine.A very enjoyable experience and I'd recommend this to anyone who wants a taster of the shopping and cook experience.

Great way to spend the day.. My friend and I booked this cookery class a few months in advance for December.We met our host, Gemma, and 4 other enthusiastic participants in the main square in the morning and our adventure began right there.Our journey to the raid, where we were to cook an amazing feast, took us through the streets of the souks on a shopping expedition, a herb & spice lesson and a peak in to the daily life of the locals in the medina.Before we had even picked up a cooking utensil I had: learnt how to differentiate between quality saffron and what I have in my cupboard back home, met a famous chef whom Jamie Oliver had cooked with, visited the communal oven of the medina and discovered that genies live in your kitchen sink!The cooking lesson was fun and taught me a few new skills (grating tomatoes!) and the food we ate at the end was probably the best meal I had that week. If you like cooking and you would like to see the souks as a local - I would definitely recommend this to you. Gemma is a fountain of local knowledge so I would also advise that you do this class at the beginning of your trip, as it will give you more confidence in navigating and negotiating in the souks afterwards.

Best Marrakesh experience!. This was definitely the best experience I've had in Marrakesh. Gemma is an excellent host and offers great insights in the local cuisine as well as the culture.The cooking class includes a trip to te local market where you have to buy your ingredients from your shopping list with money provided.After that you head to the workshop area and you cook a wonderful, authentic lunch, assisted by Moroccan women - they give great tips about seasoning and preparing local dishes!) and Gemma. After cooking, you sit back with some local wine, whilel enjoying your delicious home made Moroccan lunch.The best part: you get to take home all the recipes. Already tried them back home and they are really easy to make yourself.

Something different & fun. We (a group of 6), booked a course with Gemma during our visit to Marrakech this month. We very much enjoyed our tour of the souk, buying our ingredients and experiencing 'local' Marrakech. Gemma's kitchen was great and we were joined by two local women to help us. We had a long list of things to prepare and cook which we enjoyed with wine after cooking. My only criticism would be that for some of the group they did not really get to 'cook'. One of our group just chopped vegetables for salads and any cooking of ingredients was done by one of then helpers but this was probably due to our group size. It would have been fun to have rotated a bit or even had a go at cooking a little of everything. It was an enjoyable day and a really good activity to add variety to our trip to Marrakech. I would recommend booking a cooking course when in Marrakech.

Wonderful activity. My husband and I joined by four other people. We loved the guided tour of the souk as we crossed stuff our collective shopping list. We learned about the spices and met local vendors. Our took close to 2 hours to get our ingredients. Gemma took us to get house. It's beautiful. We were aided by two excellent chefs. They guided us and helped us prepare an amazing four course meal. The group all spoke English well and we had a delightful lunch conversation. It was a great easy to see Marrakech.

Very enjoyable. We had a lovely day with Gemma. Five in our group, we enjoyed being able to ask lots of questions in the market when buying our purchases and really enjoyed the trip to the baker. We made several dishes, all delicious, we enjoyed the salads and the beef tagine and sardine tagine. Gemma bought some of the things we asked about on the market for us to try with lunch. A great day, we chose it as a market introduction, food shopping and cooking day - we weren't disappointed. Thanks Gemma for a thoroughly enjoyable day.

A brilliant day of cooking and eating and a whole lot more .... Having been disappointed at the few excursions that would take 1 person, I stumbled across this gem. I've always enjoyed Moroccan cooking and I even own a Tagine, so the opportunity to learn from the locals was perfect.The owner, a Dutch lady called Gemma, runs a well organised set-up that gives you a hands-on experience of buying, preparing and cooking Moroccan cuisine.We met at the Cafe de France on the edge of the Jemaa al-Fna square and after introductions and a brief run-down of the day's activities, our party of 4 was each given a shopping bag, shopping list and envelope of local money before heading of into the souk. We shopped for sardines, chicken, vegetables, bread and spices. The visit to the spice shop was particularly enjoyable as the young owner told us all about the medicinal properties of various spices and let us taste some too. The brightly coloured tubs of spice were amazing, and I'd never seen so much saffron in one place - and this was the real thing.Armed with our 'comestibles', we headed back to Gemma's riad, in one of the alleyways of the souk, where we met two women "dadas" (wedding and festival chefs), who were there to help with the preparation and pass on their knowledge to us.I prepared two dishes: Baked Sardines with Chermoula; and Chribas, a sweet biscuit. Other dishes were Moroccan Salad, Courgette Salad, Carrot Salad with Almonds and Raisins, Sweet Pumpkin Salad, Zaahlouk, Chicken with Chermoula, and Vegetable Tagine. We spent a couple of hours preparing the dishes and the those that needed cooking were taken to the local bakery.While the food was cooking, we sat together with a few glasses of wine eating snacks and chatting about the day we had. The whole day was rounded off with our home-cooked "banquet" and more wine.A wonderful day with a wonderfully generous host. If you enjoy cooking, this is the excursion for you - but book early to avoid disappointment.

Wonderful day of cooking. Gemma was a flexible and gracious hostess and a good cook and teacher too. There were six clients so we all were able to help with any dish we chose after shopping in the souks. We cooked in Gemma's house that has a very practical and beautiful set up for cooking and enjoying the meal. We managed to make several salads, a fish dish, a chicken dish, a (wonderful!) couscous dish and moroccan cookies. We enjoyed our meal (and company) so much, that we stayed until all day!

Souk Cuisine - 5*. Our lovely host, Gemma- who has been in Marrakech for 9 years, took us on a bespoke tour of the souqs. Along the way we bought our ingredients for our 4 course lunch and even had time to stop in the spice shop to discover raw indigo.Our four fellow chefs, who were Dutch, endeavoured to speak in English where they could! The day was wonderful experience with local knowledge and experience that was priceless.

A great experience! Don't miss this!. This was a perfect introduction to the souk on our first full day in Marrakech. Four of us booked and were joined by a Dutch couple.Gemma met us in the main square and took us all around the souk, where each couple was tasked with collecting ingredients on an extensive shopping list (we were supplied with shopping bags and purses). We toured the souk buying meat, fish, vegetables, fruit, spices, herbs and dry goods before walking to Gemma's well equipped kitchen in her home in the medina.There we were shown how to prepare a really substantial range of dishes under the tuition of Gamma's Moroccan chefs and taking some of the dishes to the local baker to be cooked before sitting down to enjoy our work.It was a really terrific day, hugely enjoyable, truly useful and amazingly good value. Do not miss this!Thank you Gemma!
Marrakech Souk. Madness! Assault on the senses that has to be experienced. Get for sprices, leather & food. Worth booking a guide as they know where the taxis are!

We loved it.. We had a great day with Souk Cuisine. Met Gemma without any problems in the main square and within a few moments were in the souks with our shopping lists trying and buying. After an hour or two we went back to Gemma's house where mint tea and snacks were waiting. We then spent a couple of hours making various dishes alongside two Morroccan ladies before sitting down to try all our work with a couple of glasses of wine. Very interesting way to spend a day and I would like to say it was the best tagine of our trip but it was just narrowly pipped by the one we ate in the mountains the next day cooked over a wood fire in a Berber house. But it was exceptionally good. Came away with a recipe booklet and definitely intend to recreate some of the dishes at home.My one reservation with the day is that it might not be for you if you are looking for a cookery course type experience. The dishes were shared between the team and the amount and complexity of actual cooking depended on your role in the team. Probably more chopping than cooking but lots of fun all the same.For us it was a perfect experience as we were more interested in the food of Morrocco than improving our cooking skills. It was our favourite day in Marrakech. Thank you Gemma!

Great day. My partner and I had such a great day with Souk Cuisine. It was a different experience. We found it really informative and fabulous value for money. Gemma happily answered all questions. Most importantly, the food and the company was top notch. Can't wait to get home to try the recipes in our new tagine :-)

The Times lied.... There is hardly a word of the Times' recommendation that didn't set me up for disappointment:"The half-day workshop starts with a visit to the Rahba Kedima market to forage for quince, argan oil and other Moroccan ingredients. Classes convene in the courtyard of an old riad, where budding chefs learn how to make dishes like lamb tagine and raisin couscous, culminating in a four-course lunch on the terrace, served with mint tea and wine (40 euros)."They have apparently migrated from the courtyard of an old riad to the kitchen of a modest house. They have downsized from a four-course feast to a medley of salads and appetizers, and they have traded in the lamb couscous for processed sardines (really). We didn't so much cook as we chopped up some vegetables for some wonderful Moroccan women to season and cook for us - and as much as I appreciated their cooking, 90 euros seemed a lot to pay to play mommy's little kitchen helper and eat a meal that costs less than 5 euros to make.I should note, too, that the "visit to the Rahba Kedima" (2.5 hours) made me very uncomfortable. Our host played the role of expert on the locals while remaining complicit as members of the group took photos of people without asking for permission. It seemed as if half our tour consisted of vendors getting justifiably annoyed with close-ups they had never consented to and our gracious guide trying to persuade them to be photographed ("Come on, just a few, for her..."). The cultural insensitivity reached a peak when she joked that the group (in which I was the only man) was reminiscent of a harem, a comment I found especially inappropriate given my ethnicity.It seems that some of the one-star reviewers missed out on the experience. I envy them.

Amazing - book it at the start of your holiday. Excellent combination of shopping for ingredients in the souks, then cooking and eating the dishes. Wish we'd done it right at the start of our holiday as it gave us a much better insight into how to negotiate the souks. The food was absolutely delicious and it was so lovely to work with Moroccan women, I may never chop an onion in the same way! Really can't recommend it enough and we felt it was excellent value for money.

Cooking and Culture--not to be missed. Two adults signed up for the one-day cooking class. There were six of us in the group. The class began with a tour through the souks where each couple had a shopping list. We learned about spices, food preparation techniques. We even selected our chicken still alive. We toured the communal ovens. Back at the workshop, we cooked, with the help of two sous-chefs, a complete dinner. We enjoyed the meal with Moroccan wine. The day was a wonderful introduction to a new culture. Gemma is a star!

A good day in Marrakesh. We were met in the main square by Gemma and taken shopping in the souks to purchase the food we were later to prepare , cook and eat.With our purchases we proceeded to a Riad in which was set up a kitchen with work stations.We were introduced to the support Chefs and then set to work preparing a whole range of Moroccan dishes.The experience was great from state to finish and we thoroughly recommend Gemma and her team.10 out of 10.

Our most memorable Marrakech adventure. The riad where we stayed recommended Souk Cuisine. I booked well in advance, as I heard they can fill up fast and we were a group of 5. Traveling with our 16 year old daughter and her two friends, we wanted to have a fun experience with Moroccan cooking. I liked the Souk Cuisine package because it also involved food shopping in the souks beforehand. We met Gemma in the Jemaa el Fna Square and got right to work. The full group was 11, so we split into two subgroups to shop. Our family went with Gemma, armed with shopping bags, shopping lists and wallets with local currency. What a fun and educational experience we had! We visited the olive vendor, the preserved lemon vendor, the fruit and vegetable market, the bakery, the spice shop and more. Perhaps the craziest was when one of the girls agreed to choose the chickens, not realizing they would be live chickens. Fully loaded down, we headed to a local riad where there were metal tables set up for workspaces. We split up amongst the tables and worked on different parts of the meal. The other guests focused on making the vegetable and chicken tagines. Our group worked on the various vegetable salads. There were 3 or 4 Moroccan women helping out. Certainly there was a lot of chopping, but that is the nature of a lot of Moroccan cooking. Guests could help as much or as little as they chose, stopping for breaks to munch on olives and bread, and have a glass of the ubiquitous mint tea. I chopped a lot of tomatoes, parsley, cilantro, onion and carrots. The girls worked on courgettes, shredded cucumbers, squeezing oranges and slicing eggplants. My daughter spent a lot of time frying all the eggplants, so much so that she and her friends came up with an eggplant frying dance. When all the food was done we made our way to the rooftop and enjoyed a leisurely meal. Since returning home I have already recreated the eggplant dish (which will taste better when tomatoes come in season). I’ll even try a tagine soon, although I am a bit “tagined out”. This was probably one of our favorite activities and I would definitely recommend it.

Excellent Insight into Moroccan Culture & Cuisine. I reviewed several cooking class options in Marrakech and Souk stuck out because it seemed like a more authentic experience (smaller groups, included shopping in the market and wasn't at a Western hotel). Gemma (who founded and owns the company) met us in the morning, gave out shopping lists & money and took us into the market to buy all the ingredients for our multi-course lunch. This was my favorite part and where I learned most about Moroccan culture. Gemma does an excellent job of explaining how Moroccans live their lives as you make your way through the various alleys and squares. For example, I would never have known that in each area's bakery, its common for Moroccans to bring in their own dough or anything else they want to cook in the wood burning oven (we took our chicken and sardines there to cook while we prepared other dishes). After everything on our list was checked off, we headed back to her Riad where Souk is on the ground floor and where sunlight poured into the kitchen from an open roof. We each took a station and began preparing the many dishes we were excited to eat. Two Moroccan women were there to step in for anyone needing extra help. Since we had informed her that my boyfriend was vegetarian prior to the trip, she ensured that there were plenty of options for him. When all was done, we sat down to the most delicious meal I had in Morocco and Gemma was generous with wine and company. She went out of her way to accommodate us and I would recommend this as a must-do to anyone I knew heading to Marrakech. Truly wonderful and enriching experience.

Great way to spend a day in Marrakech!. My husband and I just spent the day with Gemma and her team and enjoyed every minute. Wandering the souks looking for ingredients, we learned what to look for in the best preserved lemons, saffron and ras el hanout (head of the shop) and countless other typical Moroccan products. Best of all, we marched our trays to the local communal wood-fired oven and 30 min later retrieved pans of perfectly cooked fish - all on the honor system with the guys who run the bakery. Totally charming & unexpected. Best of all, we sat down a few hours later on a sunny terrace to share the meal with a dozen new acquaintances from all over the world who we'd shared a lot of laughs with over the day. Truly special!

The most enjoyable experience of our holiday. My boyfriend and I booked onto Gemma's cooking course in late December and right from the start we had a fantastic time. We all met Gemma in the Djemma el Fna square where we then split into groups and armed with a shopping list, headed into the souks to buy the day's ingredients. We were (thankfully!) accompanied by Gemma who helped us work out which were the best ingredients as well as explaining all the various culinary curiosities which we passed along the way. Shopping done, we then headed to the Riad where we were to start our cooking course which was very conveniently situated at around 2 mins walk from where we were. We were warmly welcomed into the immaculate Riad where tables and cooking equipment had been laid out in preparation. We had some mint tea as recipe books were distributed in our various languages so that we could preview what we were about to cook. Dividing into groups and each making different things (around 11 dishes in total including a range of traditional salads, a tagine and dessert), we spent a very pleasurable couple of hours under the watchful eye and guidance of the very friendly Morroccan cooks. At any time, we were free to sit back down and relax with some bread, olives and tea/water or go up to the roof terrace. We all rotated and Gemma encouraged us to have a go at making different dishes before we all went upstairs to the sunny roof terrace to eat our creations with wine and good conversation. Gemma made a point of talking personally to every person and the atmosphere was relaxed and friendly. We are keen to try to recreate these meals at home using the recipe book and cannot recommend this highly enough.

Amazing activity in Marrakech. I loved this cooking class! It was one of the best things we did in Marrakech. It was so nice to buy our own ingredients and then be able to make delicious local dishes out of them. After the shopping was done we split into teams to make salads, tagines, biscuits and other treats. The chef's watched over us but we were really made to feel like we were the ones cooking and it was very rewarding to sit on the beautiful roof terrace sipping Moroccan wine and eating the food we had made. Gemma was lovely and made a point of chatting personally to all of us.This course was a very fun introduction to the souks and Moroccan food.

Excellent cookingcourse!. We were a bunch of friends taking this cookingclass and Gemma and her assistant Iris met us in front of Cafe de France. We went shopping in the souk for all kinds of ingredients - spices, vegetables, fish, poultry, bread - which was a lot of fun and good learning about Moroccan culture! We then went to Gemmas Riad and prepared all the food we had bought. Everything was very professional and went very smooth, much thanks to Aisha - the Moroccan chef - she had it all under control! We had a very enjoyable day in the company of Gemma and her staff and the food that we cooked was absolutely delicious! We got to eat as much as we could with some good moroccan rose-wine. I absolutely rcommend souk cuisine!

SO disappointed.... This cooking course was the first thing my sister and I booked in Marrakech. We were SO excited to take the class, and I reserved the spots a month in advance. When I sent the confirmation e-mail, I included all kinds of information, including my credit card number to keep our places. A few days before, when I wrote for directions on where to meet Gemma, I was told that my reservation had been cancelled...because I had not given them my hotel information. I was really upset! I didn't give them my hotel info because I booked the CLASS before I booked a place to stay!! They were not at all apologetic, and were actually rather rude about the cancelled reservation. I still want to take a cooking class in Morocco, but it certainly will not be with Souk Cuisine!

Should have read the other reviews first.... We thought this cooking course looked so interesting that it was the first thing we booked in Morocco! We included our credit card information, etc. However, a day before the class was supposed to start and following an email that we wrote them asking about meeting place, we found out (to our surprise) that we were not included in the reservation. Why? Because we hadn't included our hotel information during the original booking. Reading the other reviews on here, it seem their management style has always been flaky. Unfortunately, we had planned our trip around being available on that cooking day. We should have been smarter and booked with a different organization.

Best cooking class in Morocco!. As everyone else has said Gemma is really knowledgable and organizes a great experience from the souks to the kitchen. If you want to learn about Moroccan cuisine and culinary culture take this class, you won't regret it!

A must when in Marrakech. This was a fantastic day starting in the souks, we met Gemma in the main square where we were given a shopping list, bags and money. We then perused the various stalls including mint (of course), spice, vegetables and bakery. Meanwhile Gemma explained the uses for various ingredients and also the best places to source them. For us, this was the best way to see the souks at their best, meandering around alleys we wouldn't have stumbled across if it weren't for grocery shopping. With the shopping done, we arrived to a beautiful kitchen, and enjoyed some mint tea and nibbles while we decided which dish we would cook. The group (six of us in total) got to work with two very knowledgable Moroccan women chefs showing us the ropes, there were no food blenders, or shortcuts here, everything was done by hand, and all the tastier for it. Within an hour or two we sat down to eat a three course lunch with Moroccan wine, finishing off with cookies and mint tea. The day was very relaxed, Gemma made us all feel very welcome, translating for the various languages in the group, and everyone had the chance to get involved. We are looking forward to recreating the food at home.

A Great Day with Food Moroccan Style. Firstly, this is a must do activity in Marrakech with Souk Cuisine. It started off with shopping for our ingredients in the souks. It was a great experience, Gemma showing us how to look for the best quality ingredients and shop like a local. We arrived at our cooking location and snacks and moroccan tea was awaiting us. We all teamed up to make different dishes at our own stations. Gemma and her team were very helpful, teaching us to slice and cook the moroccan way. After a couple of hours of fun we had salads, tagine, and dessert that tasted delicious. We also had wine and another kind of moroccan tea to have with the dessert. We all had the receipe booklet to take away with us. If you are a food lover and/or cook then definetly fit this into to your holiday itinery. It was worth every penny!

Perhaps my favorite Morocco experience. Gemma and her staff at Souk Cuisine were recommended by our wonderful Riad (Riad L'Orangerie). Our group of 9 family and friends were taken shopping in the souk markets led by the intrepid Gemma who provided money pouches and market bags for our shopping. We haggled for olives, sardines, fruits, and vegetables under her watchful eye, and found areas of the souks that we had completely missed in our prior wanderings. We learned that a "supermarket" is a small shop that looks like many of the other souks, and that her local neighborhood grocery store was a small 3 ft x 3 ft window in the wall where the shop owner handed out what she wanted after knocking for it to open. We returned to a lovely Riad where the open-air lobby was completely outfitted with worktables, equipment, and helpful staff. She provided each of us with a cookbook, and we set to work making the most wonderful meal you can imagine. Every detail had been carefully considered, so that we and the other participants could participate as much as we wanted, but her staff was there to help as needed so that we completed the meal in a timely (and delicious) fashion. We then retired upstairs with some snacks and wine to wait for the final products to be brought for eating. Don't miss this experience!

Fun Experience. I booked this cooking class with my sister-in-law and a friend as a "girls" thing as our kids were out doing the quad adventure. It was a fun and interesting experience. Gemma and Lindy met us in front of Cafe France - it was a pretty big group, thus we split into 2 to do our shopping. Armed with a list, our shopping bags and a wallet Lindy was our souk guide, showing us the spice market, the veggie market and the grocery store as well. The class was held at a Riad nearby where refreshments awaited us. Stations were set up for all the students and we pretty much just jumped in and prepared the recipe assigned to us. We had Gemma and a few ladies assist us in our chopping, frying, mixing and cooking. It was interesting to walk around and check out what each station was preparing. After a couple of hours, a lovely spread of various salads, tagine, couscous, and dessert was ready for us to sample. Water and wine was provided too. It is a fun way to learn Moroccan Cuisine as well as meet a great group of food lovers & wannabe cooks.

Souk Cuisine - wonderful birthday present. I booked the Souk Cuisine day for my partner’s 30th while we were in Marrakech. The whole thing was excellent – from Gemma and the others who ran the whole day, to the food. We were a group of approx 14 people, split into 3, for the souk shopping. We had a list, some money, a shopping bag or 2 and a guide. Our guide was Samir, a friend of Gemma’s who works in one of the spice shops. We learnt so much from him! The souk shopping was brilliant, a great way to find your way, learn about haggling and shop like a local. Then it was on to the Riad (very close by) for some water and a sit down. We then spent time preparing all of the food at different stations for different dishes. We also had a copy of the recipes from the day to take home with us. And then of course we ate it all! The food was wonderful, and knowing we had cooked it was great. It was also lovely to spend the day with other people, getting to know them and relaxing. Would thoroughly recommend, great value for money

Great experience and wonderful food!. Myself and my girlfriend did this on our second day in Marrakech with four other like-minded people, which I thought was a perfect number. We started by shopping for ingredients in the souks. This was fun and it enabled the group to bond. It was also very informative, and we were introduced to all the spices and told about all the key ingredients involved in Moroccan cuisine. We also visited a small bakery to buy our bread. And for us it was great to explore and get involved without worrying about getting lost or jumped on and expected to part with all our money. We went back to a very beautiful riad that was a welcomed cool oasis from the heat of the city. The kitchen area was beautiful and well equipped. We cooked a variety of traditional dishes between us, learning some very interesting techniques along the way, all under the guidance and watchful eye of the two dada chefs. It finished with a sit down with wine and good chat with what turned out to be some of the best food we experienced in Morocco. Everything was superb and it exceeded our expectations.

A must!. One of the best activities we've done during our 4-day stay in Marrakech was the cooking workshop at Souk Cuisine. First Gemma and her colleagues will take you into the souks to shop for all the ingredients needed, which is a very fun and interesting experience. It's a great way to learn more about the local lifestyle. Back in the riad we prepared various dishes, under supervision of Gemma and very skilled Morroccan cooks. And of course the best part was tasting the delicious food we've cooked. We have received a recipe booklet with all dishes, so we will definitely try it at home as well. If you want a fun and tasty experience in Marrakech, a workshop at Souk Cuisine is a must!

Enjoyable, informative day of Morrocan cooking. I often take cooking classes when traveling abroad as a way of bringing the experience home and meeting like-minded travelers. This class was one of the best I have taken. The 5.5 hour day began with shopping for ingrediants in the medina, with guidance from staff members. We then proceeded to a well equipped kitchen and prepared a varied meal of Morrocan dishes with instruction from local home cooks. Snacks and drinks were provided. The day culminated with a lunch of our creation. Non-cooking spouses were welcome to partake in the meal.

Wonderful introduction to Moroccand food!. I am so glad that we took our cooking lesson on the first day of our trip to Morocco! Gemma took us to the the souks in the Medina to buy all of our ingredients before class started and we learned how to shop as well as cook! The dishes we made were delicious, and it will be a coutinued joy to make at home the beautiful and tasty recipes she gave to us. If you are a foodie DO THIS! it was really a great experience!

Could not have been better - an excellent value. My husband and sister and I recently spend a fun and richly informative day with Gemma and her crew learning genuine Moroccan cooking. On our next trip to Morocco we will spend at least three days with her deepening our experience. She has Hotel school and catering background and loves to cook. We were 12 people, mostly Dutch who graciously spoke English with us. We met at the Cafe de France and broke into two groups of 6 each with a knowledgeable and gracious guide to go shopping for ingredients in the souks. This was a fascinating experience in itself that would not have been possible without such a guide. It was two hours of shopping before we arrived with our "loot" at the Riad where we were to have our lesson. There were fully equiped work stations for all of us and stoves in the sunny courtyard of the Riad There were two Moroccan women who, with Gemma, guided us in the preparation - which we did ourselves - of several cooked salads starters with three main courses and lovely light as air cookies for dessert. About 2 1/2 hours later,we all went up to the roof top dining area to enjoy our feast. Gemma provided wine and by the end we had enjoyed four bottles of excellent Moroccan rose. We much enjoyed getting to know our fellow travelers over late lunch. One Dutch couple had even been to a small town on the coast of California where my husband and I had our first date - Bolinas. Would highly recommend this experience.

An experience I have never forgotten. I am rather late in posting this review but a number of years back I booked a cooking class in Marrakesh called Souk Cuisine. I did all of the things that are described in the other reviews and the shopping experience and visit to the bakery were fantastic insights to what it would be like to live in this charming place. The spices and herbs I bought I still have some of them and I can still order more from the man in the store who had an extensive knowledge of his trade. If you are travelling on your own it is a great way to meet others and the women in our group came from various countries which made a lovely dinner party at the end of all of our hard work cooking. Thank you to the wonderful lady who hosts this Moroccan experience, it is one of the best things I have ever done and if I visit Marrakesh again I would love to come and see how the business has progressed and grown. I would highly recommend this as an activity that stays with you for years to come! ps please take no notice of the review date...I visited Souk cuisine about 5 years ago. x

Brilliant. Best cookery course I have been on in a long time. Superb souk tour.Such a charming guide-Gemma. Food sublime. Did this on the first day and it was like meeting Marrakech personally, shaking her hand and spending the day in her kitchen.From then on the town was as familiar as my backyard

Great Day Out. On a recent trip to Morocca 3 friends and I did this cooking school. We all had an amazing time and the food that we learnt to cook was amazing. The whole day is really nice you start off by going through the markets and purchasing the ingredients you require. You get to see and experience going to a butcher, the fruit and veg markets, the local supermaket and also the bakery. Going into these places and learning about the way of the locals is a really amazing and unique experience.When you arrive at the cooking school it is absolutely amazing it is in her home and has an open roof. The school is very well set up and cooking with the locals is a really fun and enjoyable experience.Make sure you do this on your visit not only is it a great experience and lots of fun but you really don't need dinner afterwards.

A fun cooking experience. We booked this cookery day following a recommendation from friends. We were only in Marrakech for a few days so I would recommend booking in advance. This was all very easy to do via email before you arrive. You start the day in the main square where it was very easy to meet everyone, before being taken into the souks armed with your shopping list, purses and bags (all included in the cost of the trip so you don't need to bring lots of change!)The group was broken down into 2 smaller groups so it was very easy to hear our guide and you didn't feel too on show in the markets (although you obviously still are!). I hadn't realised before this that you don't haggle for food in the markets so this makes the experience much easier and enjoyable and you can spend the time really finding out about the foods and where it comes from. The shopping takes approximately 2 hours but it is really good fun and you learn as you go, as well as seeing different areas of the souk. After picking up some bread (fresh from the bakers oven!) You then go to the Riad to start the course. The only downside I would say is that you don't each make every single dish as you do on some courses, but this does mean that the group is able to make more as it is shared across more people. You each get a recipe book to take away with you and you're split up to cover separate dishes, however you can happily walk between the different tables to pick up tips as you go. The local ladies who help you are quite strict so be prepared to follow sharp instructions, but the outcome is definitely worth it!You end the day with lunch on the roof terrace (weather allowing) and a few glasses of wine. A really worthwhile day and a fun excursion as part of a quick city break!

Excellent hands-on cooking class!!!. I found this cooking class, when I was preparing for my trip to Marrakesh with my mom. I always take a cooking class while traveling abroad, because this is the best way to learn about another culture. Since my mom doesn't speak English very well and Gemma, the owner, is Dutch this was a perfect option for us. We were met at the Jemaa el Fna with shopping bags and lists of the stuff that we had to buy in the Souk. I've done more cooking classes, but none where you actually buy your ingredients yourself on the local market. Great experience and great fun. We had a small group of six, so after shopping and learning about the ingredients we went to Gemma's house, in the middle of the Souk. There two helpers waited for us and started prepping the food, while we enjoyed some tea or drinks. After that, it was hands on and start cooking. Chopping large amounts of fresh herbs, vegetables, onions, garlic, etc. We made a perfect meatball tagine with egg and had so much fun mixing the meat mixture, making meatballs and a lot more. After that, we also had to make typical Morrocan biscuits for desert, so more opportunities to get our hands dirty. After all the cooking was done, Gemma set the table and we all enjoyed a perfectly cooked lunch that was more than enough to last us for dinner as well. It was by far the best food I've had while I was in Marrakesh and when I go back to this beautifull city, I will certainly take another cooking class at Souk Cuisine.

Fab class. As a group of 20-something girls we went to Gemma's class with an open mind, and we had the most incredible time! We loved the tour of the Souk, which is great as you can feel intimidated as girls in Marrakech.
