Gemma was totally aware and catered to our dietary requirements and we ended up making an amazing fish tagine after a series of salads. I totally recommend this class and as 45 euros, is definitely a great price!

Morrocan cooking course. I'd researched this on TA and decided prior that I liked the idea of buying the ingrediants in the morning. This was invaluable as initally walking around the Souks was quite intimidating so I felt more comfortable being able to stop and look at things properly. Gemma was really helpful and was able to give a lot of local knowledge and she even took us to a local communal bread oven which was great. She explained what some of the Morrocan delicacies were which from looking at some of these alone we would never have known!The cooking course itself was excellent. We were welcomed into Gemma's beautiful Riad where we cooked several Morrocan dishes and were given a recipe booklet to take with us too to try at home.The course was approx 5 hours which was a perfect amount of time. We were not rushed around the Souks and Gemma was extremely patient with all our questions! She even assisted in us purchasing some herbs and spices to take home with us.I would highly recommend this course. It was nice and relaxed and informal and I will definately try and cook some of these recipes at home.

Well organized and fun!. Gemma, the owner, provides a fun and satisfying shopping and cooking experience. One of her shopping assistants, Samir, is a kind and gracious young man who later helped my companion and I purchase some spices from the shop he works in. As to the class itself, it was great to meet and interact with folks from all over the globe, as well as prepare and share a fantastic meal.

Another way to discover Morroco. Making the market to buy the foods you need to prepare a typical morrocan lunch was another way to discover marrakech, the people and they way of life. I really enjoyed this experience.

Amazing Culinary Experience. This was definitely one of the highlights of my group's trip. Marrakech offers several options for cooking classes, but I don't think any of them offer an experience such of this.We met Gemma in the main square (Jemaa el Fna) without any trouble, and we immediately started on our journey shopping in the souk for our ingredients. As we walked through the markets (which Gemma navigated with ease), she taught us not only where to purchase our ingredients, but also where to purchase the best items that were of interested to us (i.e. fabric) and where/what to eat. There will be no need for you to purchase a souk tour is you book this cooking class. It's a souk tour and cooking class all in one!Now on to the cooking, the riad kitchen is small, but comfortable. Aisha and the other cook whose name escapes me greeted us with lovely smiles. Although they did not speak English, Gemma translated and they were super friendly, laughing and joking with us. My group had a wide range of cooking levels, and we all loved this. We each focused on different dishes and we all loved the experience. The zaalouk is something all of us still talk about!OH! I'd be remiss if I didn't talk about my experience in booking the class. Gemma was very responsive and provided me all the information I need. She even catered to my requests for a private class and a specific menu. We all left with smalls on our faces and some wonderful recipe books. This is a must-do in Marrakech. :)

Great experience. Gemma is a fantastic host and guides you through the souks to buy the food and then takes you back to the Riad in the souks to prepare and cook a delicious meal. We loved this experience, Gemma is very friendly, funny and helpful. We would highly recommend this course and it was one of the highlights of our holiday.

Cooking Classes with "local Gemma". Best thing was shopping at the souks whe Gemma get's you in touch wih the locals and shows she's very well integrated in the Marrakech society. Thewokshop in itself was very basic. No room for own interpretation and creativity. Nonetheless a great expercience. Try the recipe as soon you get home and relive Marrakech!

Informative, fun, clean, beautiful food- a treat!. Gemma's course offers you the chance to really get into the nitty gritty of buying in the souks and you come away with a good understanding of the various spices, ingredients and local prices. Cooking in her riad was lovely- low key, no pressure, but a chance to have a go at everything, then eat a scrumptious meal on the roof terrace. I highly recommend this to anyone, singles, families with teenagers and couples. don't forget the 500dh includes a massive lunch so you won't need to spend much more on food that day!

A taste of Morroccan cooking. The workshop consisted of a guided 2 hour walk through the Medina to find ingredients for our cookery course followed by a 2 hour class in a riad located within 2 minutes from the souks. Really enjoyed the class and got to have the food we cooked. Really really tasty and we learnt a lot from the experience. My favourite dish was the chermoula sandwiched between sardine fillets which we had to take to a stall nearby to have cooked in a wood burning fire. Awesome!!!

A very good experience. Definitely worth doing. It was a good way to experience real Marrakesh life, shopping in the souks for food and then cooking it following a Moroccan recipe. It was enjoyable exploring the souks with someone who knows their way around them!!!

Bring home skills. An hour in the souks shopping, learning about spices, food and culture; then great fun cooking salads, tagines, cookies and more with other friendly travellers. Very well organized, delicious.
Just Great. Had a great days cooking at souk cuisine and can recommend it, give it a go you will love it
cheap and tasty. excellent. If you want to try real morrocan food then here you go. totally inexpensive and so so tasty.

Real Moroccan cuisine. Great course, you actually learn from Moroccan women how to cook certain dishes. All delicious, in a beautiful place, good value for money. And you get to buy your ingredients in the souk yourself.

A really fun and informative day. The soukhs in Marrakech can be very overwhelming and doing a day like this really helps to put you at ease and teaches you loads. Gemma was very knowledgable and taught us loads about all sorts of things while we were walking around buying the ingredients. The actual cooking part is done in her beautiful home, and dont worry if you arent a very experienced cook as the recipes are very easy and Gemma is great at keeping an eye out if you are doing something wrong! We enjoyed the delicous lunch at the end and will definately be trying out some of the dishes in our own homes.
Great School. I had a great day at this cooking school it is in a small Riad and in the medina area.you do your own shoping and is reat fun.

Terrific Experience - none of the downsides mentioned by others!. We had a terrific experience with Souk Cuisine. We were two friends travelling, and our Souk Cuisine cooking class had just 2 other participants so we were a small group of 4 + Gemma. The 2 others were an Aussie couple about our age, so it was great chatting with them during shopping and cooking to get to know them better.I deliberately selected Souk Cuisine because I wanted the experience of shopping for ingredients in the market, and I'm so glad I did, because I really would have felt that we would have missed out on a critical part of the cooking process! We each had a shopping list and a coin purse with a little money and Gemma took us around to her preferred vendors in the souks to purchase the ingredients. Shopping took about 2 hours.Because we were a small group, instead of cooking in a riad I believe we cooked in the downstairs kitchen of Gemma's home. There was plenty of space and natural sunlight from the open courtyard, but it was lovely to be out of the heat. Others have mentioned that due to the (large) size of their groups they were each isolated to individual tasks and didn't get to learn how to make the other dishes. However, given the small size of our group, we each divided up the dishes and were responsible for a set of dishes, but during the preparation there was enough downtime (while waiting for things to cook, pans to heat up, etc) that it was quite easy to keep an eye on / ask questions of / watch the others in the group to see what they were working on!We cooked for about 2 hours, then sat down to enjoy our lunch. I was so glad that Gemma chose some unique dishes -- instead of typical tagines and couscous, we had a really special dish ("seffa") involving buttered steamed vermicelli noodles and a hidden stewed/curried chicken surprise "buried" in the middle. All in all - my friend and I agreed that this was the highlight of our 5 days in Morocco.

Interesting, fun, DELICIOUS. I did the Souk Cuisine cooking course with some friends in October 2011 and it was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco. Gemma, the lady who runs the course, is lovely and gives you some great tips about choosing ingredients and shopping in the souks. The souk kitchen is located in the central courtyard of a local riad and is a lovely environment in which to prepare the meal. With the help of the local women we learned how to make a wide selection of dishes, all of which were absolutely delicious, then we sat together on the roof terrace to enjoy them. As well as being great fun and very informative, the course is also a great way to meet other people travelling in Morocco and I would highly recommend it to anyone travelling alone or in a small group.

A must do for anyone who loves cooking!. My wife and I found this event on the trip advisor's most recommended for Marrakech and were not disappointed. Booking a few weeks in advance is recommended as numbers are limited to keep the day a personal experience.We were greeted by Gemma in the main square and were introduced to the other five participants that day. About an hour's guided shopping in the Souk followed with a shopping list, bag and money wallet in hand. Everything was clearly explained by Gemma, and we bartered with the stall holders for produce under her very welcome guidance.With all the ingredients bought we went back to her riad to prepare a series of delicious dishes. This is very much a team activity, supported by two experienced sous chefs. Drinks were provided throughout.I'm quite an experienced amateur cook, but picked up several new ideas and techniques on the day. Can't wait to try these at home.Lunch was delicious and of course consisted of the fruits of our collective efforts.Excellent value for money and a fantastic day out. Thanks Gemma.

WONDERFUL DAY !. I visited Marrakech for a few days in May 2011 with my daughter and as a surprise for her, booked a cooking course at Souk Cuisine. We met Gemma (the Dutch lady who operates the course and resident in Marrakech for about 5 years) met us and 4 other participants at 10 am and then proceeded to take us round the local markets - armed with 2 x purses, 2 x shopping list and shopping baskets. Under her guidance we had to source and purchase the ingredients for our meals and this was great fun. She gave us a lot of local knowledge and showed us markets we hadn't found before ! After visits to spice shops, fishmonger, veg markets, bakery etc etc (which all in all took us about 1.5/2 hrs we then went on to her beautiful home right in the heart of the medina. Six preparation places were laid out in her courtyard kitchen (with sun streaming down from the roof terrace !) and under the guidance of her lovely Moroccan cook (whose recipes we followed) we prepared an abundance of great dishes - various veg salads (carrot, aubergine, cucumber, courgettes, etc etc) with monkfish tagine and briouettes (like little samosas) with fish & vermicelli filling). Also some little cakes were make (shortbread type) which were delicious !!! We all had a hand in the various dishes - and finally sat down to a lovely meal with wine and/or water !All the food was exceptionally tasty and delicious - and we all felt very proud of our achievements as the whole experience was very "hands on" with only guidance from our hosts !We took so many photos and I will post some on this site (when I get round to downloading them from my camera as only got back 2 days ago!). We would thoroughly recommend Souk Cuisine to anybody interested in experiencing traditional Moroccan cooking - we did it all !! I have since tried one or two of the dishes we prepared with great success (we all had a booklet with the recipes).Well done Gemma - and thanks for a great experience !

Great Day - so glad we did this!. My boyfriend and I did this just over 2 weeks ago - had a great day. As others have mentioned, we were given a shopping list and had to go and get our own food. All the market sellers knew Gemma so when they realised we were with her didn't really bother us at all - it was so nice to go round and be able to look and touch things a bit more without being bothered and really fascinating talking to some of the sellers without them trying to sell stuff to you.There were 10 of us in the group so we went to a Riad hired for the day - it was a beautiful place!! As some people mention, you are mainly preparing and chopping up food but we did get to cook it ourselves.We then went onto the roof top and ate all the food, again very relaxing and a nice break from all the hussle and bustle. We finished around 4pm (started at 10am).Would definitely recommend!

Worth the trip. Our day spent with Gemma at Souk Cuisine was worth the trip to Marrakech. There are many wonderful thing to see and do in Marrakech, but shopping for food and cooking is at the top of our list.

Wasn't Impressed w/ Communication. I read about their program and was eager to set something up for our trip. I emailed to get information on their availability. Unfortunately they didn't have any space during our stay. We could have provided a group of 10 so I was a little disappointed that they couldn't suggest a way to make it work for us either with an earlier or later time. I even asked about getting just the 2 of us in and got a belated response without much care. I personally was a bit apprehensive about traveling to Marrakesh and found that there are some amazing people there, i just don't think this group was representative of that spirit.

Honestly, a bit disappointing. I recently did the cooking course with Gemma. There were 6 of us in total - that group size was good, we were all english speakers & had a good laugh together. The trip around the souk was good, the spice shop in particular was very interesting. The lunch we had was delicious, and plenty of it, I couldn't fault it at all. My problem, I'm very sorry to say, was I found Gemma unenthusiastic and not very chatty at all. The cooking wasn't great. I love my food & I love to cook but as other people have said you just end up chopping a pile of vegetables. There was no introduction to the dishes, what we were trying to make and how it was supposed to look or taste. But the food in the end was very tasty and there were 2 moroccan ladies there to make sure everything got done. The day was fine, but I came away disappointed and if someone asked me to recommend it I'd suggest looking into a different course.

Brilliant introduction to Marrakech. I'm not a person who 'enjoys' cooking, it's usually just something that has to happen so that I can eat decent meals, but my better half certainly does enjoy it, and so I booked us onto Gemma's cookery day. I booked it for the first day we had in Marrakech, as I figured that being guided around the souks to collect the ingredients would be a slightly gentler introduction to the place than just plunging headlong into the madness.And I was right. Having Gemma discuss the pros and cons of the souks, and how to deal with the market holders and give guidelines on prices of foods was the perfect way to overcome some of the culture shock of a first time visitor to Morocco. Plus, most of the stallholders must have recognised the colourful shopping bags we had and realised we were on the 'Souk Cuisine' gathering walk though the stalls. One herb stallholder even referred to Gemma as 'Madame Plastique' as she would be a frequent visitor with her colourful plastic bags and collection of tourists in tow.The actual gathering, preparing, cooking and eating was brilliantly managed and I think everyone in our rather large group felt really at ease with the day. The preparation and cooking took place in the courtyard of a Riad which was a lovely little area, and then the eating took place upstairs on the terrace in the sun. For a day in the middle of winter it was just perfect; nice food, interesting conversation with a mix of nationalities and glorious sunshine!

This was one of the best days we had in Marrakech!. We booked the cookery course at Souk Cuisine back in September, due to popularity Gemma gets booked up quickly.We met outside Hotel Du France in the square and then went into the markets to buy the food and spices. We went to the part of the market where the locals go, also the areas featured in Jamie Oliver's programe. We then went back to Gemma's riad, which is down a very small alley. It is beautiful inside. We all helped cook various recipes, with the help of morrocan women who cannot speak a word of english but have no trouble telling us off when we make mistakes! We really had fun doing the cooking including the boys, they are not normally to be found in the kitchen! We all then sat down and ate the feast that we had cooked, we were so full we could not eat for the rest of the day! We would really reccomend booking a course with Souk Cuisine to anyone wanting to experience traditional morrocan cooking. The food was the best we had tasted the whole time we were in Marrakech.

The course was a good experience but didn't really live up to my expectations. The course was a good experience but didn't really live up to my expectations. After a trip to the market we started cooking at the riad, as there were only 2 people on the course (4 of them didn't turn up) I thought this would be a good opportunity to have more instruction from the teacher. Unfortunately this was not the case and I felt that we were pretty much following the recipes from the booklet. The Moroccon lady who helped us out did not interact very much and it was up to me to ask her questions about what we were doing. It's a shame we didn't get to cook more dishes and see how other dishes are prepared. It would have been more beneficial if the ingredients were already prepared (ie onions/veg already chopped - I think we all know how to do this!) so we could concentrate more on the actual cooking techniques.

Fun cooking experience!. My family of four had a fun experience with souk cuisine.( 18 year old daughter and 20 year old son) There was a total of six people in our cooking group. We went to the souk and bought and picked out our food. Lyndell did an excellent job as guide and facilitator of this experience. We learned a lot of interesting things as we shopped. The recipes were fun and easy to make and really delicious. What a wonderful experience. I would definitely recommend souk cuisine if you are visiting Marrakesh.

Authentic Moroccan cooking made easy and fun!. Book early to get into this excellent cooking class. Starting with the market is a great introduction to Marrakech and Moroccan shopping. We had alot of fun and a great group of people to learn with. The staff were excellent and full of great tips. The food was delicious and even more special because it was made by us. Cooking for all levels, you don't have to be a MasterChef.
Fantastic. What a wonderful day we had. The tour was well organised and the food prepared (by us) was tasty..no in fact it was delicious. It was easily the best day out in Marrakeck

Too Many people & made to feel like a YTS student. Learned very little. My daughter & I booked on this course which took out one day of a 3 day trip, but we felt it would be worth it as the course received good reviews & having done previous courses in Thailand we were expecting great things. Sadly that was not the case. The biggest issue was that they seemed to overpack the course with 15 people (didn't like the fact that they lied about the large number either. They said some people from the hotel wanted to join & as we were using their premises it was unfair to say no. But none of the people were actually staying there, so it was a bit of a cover up to get as much money as they could, in my opinion).Having so many people made the trip around the market painful. It took over 2 hours & we seemed to spend forever waiting around for someone who had wandered off. I had lost the will to live before we even got to the kitchen!.On previous courses the prep is done & you learn how to cook the recipes. Not the case here - I felt like a sous chef. All we did was prepare vegetables! I had to chop over 15 onions & a poor girl that was on the course had to peel about 100 tomatoes bless her! What are you learning about Moroccan cookery from that? The Moroccan ladies were also stressed & grumpy. They were not at all welcoming or friendly & made you feel like a YTS student & kept saying 'chop more, chop more'!! They were very unpleasant tutting & shaking their heads - what was all that about I am on holiday for goodness sake, not in catering! I wanted to learn how to make the chicken & lemon tagine but they took it off into the kitchen & produced it when it was cooked so I haven't got a clue how they did that.The food at the end was delicious & it was nice to eat it on the roof top terrace, but because of the number it massively ran over & we were rushed & couldn't eat our meal as we had transport arranged back.It is a real shame as this course has great potential, but they need to make some fundemental changes. They really need to limit the number strictly. With 15 in the kitchen & pans of bolining oil it is an accident waiting to happen. Also the tap was overflowing & a marble floor was swimming in water & very dangerous (but then health & safety simply doesn't seem to be an issue here!).

15 people and learnt nothing about cooking. This is not a cooking course. It is however a very good tour of the souks and an enjoyable lunch. There were 15 people on the course, which in my opinion was far too many. Their website says 2 to 12 people, which would have been far better. It felt like they had just crammed in extra people to make more money and we all suffered as a result. The tour of the souks is very good and most enjoyable. We then went to a Riad to supposedly learn to cook. In fact there were so many of us that we were each given the job of chopping and preparing 1 or 2 vegetables whilst the Moroccan ladies did the cooking. They were the only unhappy looking people I meet during our 6 days in Marrakesh. They seemed very stressed and did not show us anything. If we tried to ask we got no where. I did not learn anything new at all about how to cook. The meal was served on the terrace and was excellent. We were only given 2 bottles of wine for 15. Eventually a third one did arrive. The other guests were great fun. It was a very good tour of the souks and lunch. It was not a cooking course. If you want to learn to cook I don’t think this day is for you. We learnt more about cooking on the Berber Tours trip (which was brilliant).

so bad. I tried to meet souk cuisinetwice in the Jemaa el Fna, and both times she flaked out. She gave me her cell phone number to coordinate better, but she then kept her cell phone off the entire time during my stay. On my last night in Morocco, she showed up in my riad to apologize and reschedule -- but I had a flight in the morning, and it was too late. Lots of attractions in Marrakech close for lunch -- between 12 and 2 or so -- so don't spend your morning waiting for to show up, because she won't.
Fun. Really enjoyed cooking class and the food that was made. Great experience all around.

Trip Highlight!. We decided to sign up for Souk Cuisine early on in our trip and what a difference it made. We had been exploring the city ourselves, but after spending the day with Gemma in the markets and with her wonderful staff back at Chambres des Amis, it showed us Marrakech in a whole new light. We had a great group of about 8 and even considered signing up for an additional day! Best money spent all week.

What a great day....do this if you have time and enjoy food.. Won't repeat the format of the day but what a great and different experience to have. I would highly recommend Gemma's Souk Cuisine as she seems to have hit a good format with the shopping first and then the cooking and eating. Loved taking and collecting my fish dish to/from the local bakery! We were really lucky as we were only 4 and so it seemed a much more personel experience. Can't wait to try to replicate the recipies again!

Book now - superb day!. We had already been for a week to marrakesh in september and returned again in december for another week. This cooking day is superb and even if you are only there for a few days we reccomend this as an unmissable thing to do. You don´t need to be a master chef, I certainly am not!What I would say is its not just a cooking course, You start off in the BIG SQUARE and are each given tasks, 2 people have shopping lists, 2 people money and 2 people shopping bags and you go into the souks to buy the ingredients and learn, it gives you a great insight into negotiating the souks and places to shop. Then you go back to the riad and cook and eat, we had a superb day and after returned to some of the shops and took home delicious spices and the best chilli sauce known.For xmas I gave friends spices and some of the recipees we learnt and new years eve we had a morrocan evening where we cooked what we had learnt for friends.I bought a Tagine and now cook on my terrace on my gas bbq morrocan delightsBook now, its a superb Day!!!

Fun experience - combining Souk trip and cooking. Would definitely recommend, first you buy your ingredients, which is a lot of fun and you learn a lot about the Souk, then you cook a range of traditional dishes. Great fun and good value.

The Best Experience of our Marrakech Visit. We've taken cooking classes all over the globe, but none have compared with Souk Cuisine. It starts with a "trail by fire" of shopping in the hurried markets—Gemma gives you money for ingredients, but insists you get local prices—then finishes with a relaxed and educational cooking experience in her home. The meal we prepared was epic and made for a very memorable day. We can't recommend this enough.

Amazing experience!!!. I strongly recommend this activity if you are keen to learn about the local culture. The morning in the souks was very informative with lots of fun and memorable moments. We cooked in a very charming area which makes the whole experience even better. The food was absolutely great and we could taste it with a delicious Moroccan wine - and have a chat with the group. Gemma planned everything very well and gave valuable tips about Marrakech and the funny negotiations we make all the time in Morocco. This is definitely a great value for money!!

Great Value, Great Curltural Indoctrination and Fun!!. Our day with Souk Cuisine was a great value, especially when you consider $50 per person paid for a whole day of instruction(10am to 3:30/4pm). Spending the am in the Souk (market) to buy ingredients meant learning a few key Arabic words, learning Souk etiquette (don't over handle the produce!!!), being invited behind the counters of several small shops, briefly meeting your entree (chickens) just before they went under the knife, and getting an indepth guide to dramatic piles of aromatic spices. It was a great indoctrination into Moroccan culture while sharing the experience with a small group of tourists from places arund the globe. Very interesting! Gemma and the other cook who worked with us (sorry I forgot her name) did an amazing job guiding us and accommodating our various cooking abilities and different needs (vegetarians). I'm glad we booked the Souk Cuisine for the beginning of our stay in Morocco, because we felt so much more comfortable and capable shopping in the Souk during the rest of our stay. My husband and I both considered this a highlight of our visit! And we'd do it again, and again! Did I mention the beautiful sunlit kitchen Gemma uses that is situated in the central courtyard. Kitchens in Morocco aren't usually I believe placed int he cental courtyard, but its location made the experience very special and makes sense for Gemma who receives her clients/cooks in a kitchen. Book ahead-or you may miss out on a fantastic day!

A great day in Marrakech. Our day spent with Souk Cuisine was informative, enjoyable and relaxed. We found Gemma to be totally professional, she was attentive to her clients without being overbearing, had an excellent rapport with local stall holders, had planned the day well for the number of clients and was very good company too.Our group comprised 5 or 6 different nationalities, ranging in age from early 20's to late 50's and with various dietary needs and yet everyone really enjoyed the experience.The shopping trip was a highlight for me, we went in small groups to purchase herbs,veg, spices,chicken, fish, bread etc. Normally I hate organised activities and would sooner die than go on a tour or have a guide BUT some of these stalls I would never have even noticed if I had been on my own, especially the bakery which was a huge clay oven where local residents were taking their food to be cooked, ladies with sesame seeds to toast or bread to bake. The bread came straight out of the oven in to our bag!Buying the chicken live was a new experience!!! Maybe one I will not repeat!!As others have said, this is not a highly technical class or a master class, it is a superb day out in excellent company, the meal we cooked was the best food we had in Marrakech and we now have recipes that we will use over and over. I would highly recommend Souk Cuisine.

Highly informative - a good day!. This was a very full (10am to almost 4pm - possibly as our group was quite large) and informative day - this is not just about cooking but a comprehensive guided tour of parts of the souks that you would not have access to. Do not approach it as a technical cooking course in which you will learn skills but rather as a fun day out with food, this also makes it excellent for non-cooks. All in all good fun, very enlightening and also great value.

Fantastic Day with Gemma. I recently spent two weeks in Morrocco, and was fortunate to have booked a day with Gemma and Souk Cuisine.The entire day was well planned and managed, as otehrs have mentioned - the day started with a shopping trip which was great fun and very informative. Then back to Gemma's beautiful Riad. With the help of her staff we (6 of us) produced the best meal that I had in Morrocco.Gemma is a sophisticated, intelligent and charming woman. The entire groups had a fantastic time. Highly recommended.

a fabulously informative and enjoyable experience. Gemma was very pleasant, organised and completely in control of what was happening, and it was one of the best experiences I had in Morocco. It was great fun buying our ingredients in the souks, meeting the shop-owners, and then cooking it all. The group we were with were great, there was 6 of us and we all got along so well. The result was amazing, I don't think any of us could believe we had managed to make such a feast (with a little help!). Gemma provided us with wine, and it was great to know that we were armed with the ability to cook a few dishes when we got home. I would thoroughly recommend this cookery class.

a must in morroco. Just got back from 4 days in Marrakech and spent our last day at Souk Cuisine. I must say it was one of the best days of our holiday! Interesting, sociable, entertaining, delicious, calming and educational are the best words to describe our day. As I'm sure you've already heard from previous reviews, we spent the first part of the day in the markets buying the ingredients for our meal. Led by Remi, we learnt many extraordinary things about the markets that would ordinarily escape most tourists. The experience proved to be a more relaxed way to investigate these usually daunting souks by having a guide.When we returned to the riad just a short stroll from the square, we were given a small book of recipes in our own language and each one was explained. After choosing which preparation station to work at, we all happily got on prearing our dishes under the watchful eye of Aisha and Remi. Everything was very well organised and where time was tight, Aisha stepped in to assist. Several hours later after busily chopping, frying, folding etc the food went into the ovens and dishes and lunch was served. I can only say that it was the best meal we had during our stay in Marrakech (not just because we cooked it).Overall a brilliant day. Ignore negative comments from previous reviews, they must be from petty-minded people who lack the ability to socailly assess different situations and people.

YUMMMMMMMY. This was truly an authentic experience! SHOPPING:We all met at the market from where we started out the shopping tour. The 13 of us where split in 2 groups given a shopping list, a bag and some money. We were in the group with Gemma and she provided great advise what to look out for when buying the ingredients. I am very sure that you have never done this kind of food shopping living in North America or Europe. Unlike anything else you buy here in Marakesh you do not have to discuss the price but you sure discuss the quality of the product :-)COOKING:Gemma led us to a nice riad where a few tables where set up waiting for us to cut our the produce we just had purchased. So after a good rinse the cutting started. We were split up in groups again according to the recipes that were provide: Moroccan salads, tagine, couscous, cookies as desert. Gemma with the help of 3 Moroccan ladies made sure we cut everything the "right" way and we used the right herbs to make it all perfect. The smell and colors was unbelievable!EATING:In the end we got to eat all our new creations - I must say - this was better than in any restaurant I have been to in Marrakesh. This must have been the fluffiest and moistest couscous I have ever eaten! Every thing was just great. We can highly recommend this cooking class. Even my husband, who is not to interested in cooking had a great time. We published a few picture under flickr, key word: Gemma van de burgt, souk cuisine.

A Very Interesting Culinary Experience.. I feel I must defend Ms. Gemma Van De Burght. My partner and I attended Souk Cuisine for a day last month, and found it a really enjoyable experience. Gemma is a very well-organised, efficent lady and is of a fairly quiet disposition. She has a limited amount of time to have clients prepare and cook ingredients, and I'm positive she has all planned very precisely - she's been doing this for a few years and her ways work for her. It was quite a serene experience, and we all were allocated different tasks as there'd not be enough hours in the day for one-to-one tutoring. If you want that, it'd be exorbitant - it's just a "taster" ( pardon the pun ) of what Moroccan cooking is about, we didn't expect to emerge experts. To be honest, we've been to Morocco several times and eat French, Italian and Chinese food when there as we don't particularily like Moroccan food, but we went to Gemma's course with open minds, willing to sample all the food, and we did. It was a relaxing day away from the madness just outside in the markets, and my partner and I always appreciate being able to enter other people's houses when abroad, simply to enjoy the difference in how others live. No-one yet has mentioned the most magical thing : the house has a pair of resident sparrows who flit about the courtyard ( i.e. kitchen ) and who nest and bring up young there every year. We think it was a lovely day, and well-worth the money, just to do something a little bit out-of-the-ordinary. By the way, we asked if we might take a few photos rather than just assuming this was acceptable, and were granted permission graciously.

Great food, not great class. As part of our culinary tour of Morocco, we wanted to learn a bit more about Moroccan cuisine, and so decided to take some cooking classes. This was the second one we took, and the menu was far more ambitious than the introductory class we had taken earlier in the week. I should note also that I am a very experienced cook, and unlike another reviewer, found myself nearly alone in the over-40 demographic.As mentioned before, we met up and did the shopping in the souks, which for me was the best part of the class. It should be noted that the owner who usually leads the class was out sick, and another woman was filling in for her, so she may not have been entirely up to speed on everything. For example, we spent an entertaining half hour in a spice shop, where the shopkeeper put on a great show and explained many things, but then it turned out that there were no spices on our shopping list! There was also no explanation as to why we chose one merchant over another, which would have been useful information for when we ventured out on our own. The class itself was held in a tiny riad in the souks, which meant it was a tiny space, with very little elbow room. In my case, I had to weave my way around several people to the only sink every time I wanted to wash my hands, something you do frequently when cooking. There was also a lack of hot water and soap, which made it very hard to get olive oil and butter off my hands. Knives were of excellent quality, but not as sharp as they could have been. Organizationally speaking, the class has several issues: we were six students; there were six workstations. What was not clear was that by choosing your workstation (some were higher than other, I am tall, I chose based on height), you chose the dish (or dishes) you would be working on. No overview, just trying to guess the dish you had “chosen” by comparing the pile of recipes thrust into your hands with the ingredients in front of you. Our side of the room ended up spending over an hour peeling tomatoes, coring carrots and chopping zuchinni, while the people across the room were whipping up spicy sauces and marinades, working with chicken and fish and exotic ingredients. The cook spoke very little French, and none of us spoke Arabic, so it was not always easy to communicate. And we had to ask for nearly everything we needed: dishes, plates, pots, matches, oil, missing ingredients, etc. There was no demonstration: you were simply to follow the printed recipe given to you. And the recipes weren’t that well written. Which meant that any time anyone didn’t do something right, the cook would gruffly grab it out of their hands and do it for them. I would have liked a bit more explanation of what was going on: an overview of the menu, the structure of the class, certain techniques. For example, what is the advantage of steaming vermicelli over boiling it? Also, having different people do different dishes—and having the cook do so much on her own without explanation—meant that none of us had an overview: I personally never saw the chicken between the market and my dinner plate.Once the main dishes were cooking, we could relax a bit and work together making cookies and rolling pastries; by this time we had bonded like schoolchildren who had been chided for their behavior all too often. We had no problem with taking pictures, and indeed, everyone did it.In the end, we did have a fantastic meal: several salads, a hearty appetizer and a main dish that leaft us groaning (we barely touched it, we were so full). An excellent wine was offered with the meal. And we still had cookies to eat and take home. But I had a bitter taste in my mouth from our treatment at the hands of a grumpy cook.

Good food, patronizing owner. I start with the good things:- shopping in the souks was very interesting, we've seen things I wouldn't see if walking alone,- the food we made was delicious! - the lady working for Gemma, Aisha, was very good at what she was doing, and showed us many small tricks to ease our work in the kitchen.Now things I hated:- I'm 32, which made me 20 years younger then the next person, and a target for Gemma's patronizing. Each time she saw me using my camera she would jump me and remind me not to take photos of people. As if it was my first time abroad, and as if I was at all interested in taking photos of someone!- when we arrived at the kitchen, I took out my camcorder, placed it in a corner standing on a tripod, pointed it at the exact spot I was standing in order to be able to film myself making food, and let it stand turned off while Gemma was explaining things. This made her go totally bananas!!! At first she tried to make the other clients (all Europeans) to admit they minded it, but of course they didn't. Then she exploded, screaming how abused she feels! I could understand this reaction if I was actually filming her, or somebody else, but I wasn't! I was going to film myself only, and I was going to start filming after she stopped talking. I mean, I'm an adult, and a lawyer, and I know it is against the law to film people without their consent! But the lady was behaving like crazy! I had to put away my camera, and I don't have a single photo or film from the whole day! If I wasn't there with someone, I'd probably just walked out the door, feeling abused myself! But the whole episode made me feel so angry it totally spoiled the day! That is the reason I do not recommended this cookery school - you do make good food, but if you're under 50, you're treated as a naughty child!

A must!. We were in Marrakech on our honeymoon and took this cooking class our second day in town - it was enlightening, fun, and definitely the most delicious meal we had! It was also the best way to get a proper introduction to the souks (the markets) and not just feel like a harassed tourist! Gemma, the dutch woman who runs Souk Cuisine, took us around the souks not only to get us to pick up the groceries ourselves (very fun indeed!) but also to explain some of the ins and outs of Moroccan cuisine and market life - she finally explained to us what all those wierd and wonderful things we'd seen were (argan oil, preserved lemons, rancid butter, black soap, amlou - a paste not so different from peanut butter made from nuts and honey), and helped us to communicate when things got tricky (it did actually take us a good 2 hours to get the shopping done, most of it because of trying to ask someone for 500 grams of flour when you have no language in common!). After all that, with the help of a shy but stern Moroccan woman, we got to cooking in a gorgeous courtyard of a traditional home right around the corner from the spice market. We ended up after a few hours with an amazing meal of moroccan tomato salad, carrot salad (the best!), a smoky eggplant dip, a mini moroccan version of a samosa filled with prawns, vermicelli and calamari, a swordfish tagine, and if you can imagine there was any space left, sesame cookies as well. I have to say, I think it was one of the most impressive and delicious meals we had during our stay! I would highly recommend this not only to people who love food and cooking like we do, but also to anyone simply looking to do something a bit off the tourist track, if you want a little peek into traditional Moroccan culture, meet other like minded would-be cooks and learn something that you can take back with you as a great reminder of your trip! (Also very good for impressing friends back home!)

The perfect to master the Moroccan cuisine. Souk Cuisine is a cooking school. At the beginning of the day you start shopping for ingredients in the Medina. During this tour the owner of the school tells you all sorts of interesting facts that otherwise remain hidden, like the pit where they cook up to twenty scheep or the bakery where people bring their dough for baking. When all the groceries are bought, you start cooking under the experienced eye of three humorous Moroccan women, who teach you all the secrets of the Moroccan cuisine. Afterwards you eat all the dishes on the sunny rooftop of her house (or on the rooftop of hotel Chambres des Amis). This course is a must for everybody who loves food!

Really fun experience. We had a fun experience doing this cooking. My husband (not a cook) loved it. It was out in the countryside and lovely. It was very well organized. They really know what they are doing. The final products were delicious and we hope to make these dishes at home.

Frank and Kathleen. This was a wonderful experience.The chefs were friendly and helpful.They were not only very good cooks but also good and patiient teachers.The location was wonderful and gave us an authentic experience of Moroccan life and culture.
Merci!. This was a wonderful introduction to the souks and the cuisine of Marrakech with chef Tarik, culminating in an excellent dinner.

A cooking class in the countryside...highly recommended!. We went on a Friday, with reservation made on Thursday afternoon. Choice was based on TripAdvisor review, no regrets and highly recommend this one.It was more than a cooking class:- multiple tea sessions - spice introduction- prep and partial cooking of multiple dishes - bread and goat cheese, latter was super soft and fluffy, nothing like the ones I've had in Canada- walk around the rural village- really nice fruit/vegetable juice to go with meal- a graduation ceremony! What a surprise!All in all it was more than four hours and you get to take away the recipes via an email, so no need to take notes.Wine would have made this an even better meal ;)

Must do when in Marrakech. We spent a delightful day with Chef Tarik and his wonderful support team in a very "hands on" cooking class - where we learned how to make a variety of tagines and how to cook couscous properly. His instructions on how to use Moroccan spices was particularly welcome. These spices, which are for sale and have been prepared by local village women, make lovely gifts. It was great to see Chef Tarik's organic garden and to know that everything that we made and enjoyed eating was so fresh and healthy. Highly recommend this as a day's outing as Chef Tarik is very knowledgeable, informative and engaging. In addition the rural garden setting is quite lovely and relaxing and you won't want to leave.

Cooking class in Marrakech. Good class. But felt the chef was exasperated with us. The knives need to be sharper for a real chef's experience. I felt inept trying to cut and peel vegetables with tools that were not the best.

50th Birthday celebrations. We were collected promptly at 09.30 from our riad for our day of morrocan cookery at Atelier de cuisine...prior to making the booking I did a considerable amount of research as to which would be the right course for our group...this was part of my 50th birthday celebrations so I had booked for 10 of us ( sadly 2 of the group were unwell and didn't make it) The reason I chose this course was the fact that it took place at an organic farm in a Berber village approximately 35 mins outside of Marrakech...and also for the content of the course, it covered so many different elements!!We were greeted at the entrance by Chef Tarik and taken to a beautiful spot in the gardens to drink tea together...this was so humbling! then shown how to make this amazing traditional tea and given some history behind its meaning.After tea we donned our aprons and hats for a tour of the stunning vegetable gardens, and were then shown to our cooking stations ( all outdoors in the gardens) we had two chef's one at each station and we all participated in preparing three different targines, cous cous and three morrocan salad starters...which was very informative and great fun too.Whilst the food was cooking we went over the outside bread oven where one of the local ladies baked fresh bread that was served with homemade olive oil and fresh goats cheese....utterly delicious.This was followed by a short walk around the Berber village...a wonderful experience to really see how the locals live.Upon our return all of the salads and targines we had prepared earlier were served to us in a beautiful tent...the food was incredible, probably one of the best meals you will eat in Marrakech...along with a lovely tasty beetroot juice.This was followed by a delicious dessert...I was concerned that the left over food would go to waste but was reassured it would all be eaten by the staff and shared with the locals too.Chef Tarik organised a beautiful birthday cake with sparklers and all the team singing happy birthday to finish up our feast.....We then returned to garden for more tea and our certificates.I can only begin to tell you what a truly amazing day this was...we had an absolute ball...it was informative, fun, humbling, educational and full of delicious food, what more could you want?! oh yes and set in the most beautiful gardens too!!One of my friends said it will go down in her top five things she has ever done!! I totally agree...I would recommend this special day to everyone!!!

BRILLIANT!!!. This was a surprise day that my sister had organised, It was the last day of the trip and we definitely saved the best till last. A truly wonderful experience with amazing passionate staff. Would highly recommend!! Thanks for such an awesome day!

Moroccan cuisine . Learnt to make lamb, chicken and vegetable Tagine and couscous and Moroccan salads. Great teacher makes it very enjoyable. Beautiful setting great to see where they get their ingredients in the farm and how they make their bread. It was all delicious and hope I'll make them at home. Tarik gave us all certs at the end which I'm sure we will hang in our kitchen. Will definitely come back to learn more. Everyone was lovely and great at showing and explaining about spices and ingredients.

Fantastic experience. It was a great pleasure and fun cooking with Chef Tarik team. All experience was fun, interactive and results are delicious. Best food i had in Morocco. Cheff tough us about local mint tea, tagins and some small appetizers easy to cook at home. I would love to do some of it on my own trying his precipice.

Highlight of our trip to Marrakech. Myself and three others went to Atelier De Cuisine Chef Tarik Orty-Ct during a five day trip to Marrakech and this was hands down our best experience of our visit. Throughout the day there are various workshops including tea-making with the 'tea master', a spice workshop, a look at the making of traditional Berber bread and then the actual practical cooking portion of the day. We made several tangines and three types of salad which we then ate in a beautiful tent in the garden/farm. We also had the chance to walk around the village which is beautiful and has amazing views of the city and the Atlas mountains. The staff really do go out of their way to welcome you and to create a relaxing and pleasant atmosphere. Chef Youssef was absolutely amazing - he was very friendly and is an extremely talented and skilled chef. One of the members of our party is vegetarian and another is vegan and the staff were very accommodating to this - Chef Youssef even made a vegan cake which is the first time he ever attempted it (it was really delicious!).As you can probably tell I really can't rate this place enough! You need to experience it to really understand how wonderful this establishment is. On our return to the city we spent the car journey discussing how enjoyable the day was and how we would definitely return to do another class when we return to the wonderful country of Morocco.
Great cooking class. We enjoyed a wonderful day in this gorgeous open-air kitchen!! The food was delicious and we learned a lot. Great!

Great cooking experience in a wonderful setting. I am glad I chose this place out of the many options in Marrakech. For people who are really Interested in cooking, who appreciate organic produce and who are interested in getting a glimpse into Moroccan traditions then this is the place to do your cooking course at. What I found particularly great and what differentiates this place from other places is that you cook 3 different ( not just one!) tajines, 3 salads and couscous. Chef Joussef was lovely and patient, and although the other people who were supposed to be on that course change their date they still did the course for just me instead of cancelling on me which I greatly appreciate.You even pick your own fresh organic veggies right off the garden.I can highly recommend this course and want to thank you again for this wonderful experience!

Excellent Experience!. My wife and I had a wonderful time while learning how to cook some of our favorite dishes from Morocco. The staff is friendly and knowledgable and the location is exquisite. We weren't entirely certain that we would enjoy a 'learn to cook' class but we had a wonderful time and would recommend it to anyone.

A great day of cooking. If you're looking for an alternative to the hustle & bustle of souks this is it. The staff were amazingly accommodating particularly Hazam the village tea maker. It was a great experience and found the skills that we learnt are still being used at home today. We enjoyed picking the vegetables from the garden for our tajines.The driver conveniently picked us up from our accommodation and drove us the 45 minute trip to the village. It was such an authentic Moroccan setting, a bio organic farm in a local village nestled withing the desert. Upon our arrival, we were given a tour of the farm and an outline of the days activities. We soon began our spice lesson then were taught how to brew an authentic Moroccan mint tea, the best we had during our whole trip. We were impressed to learn that we had our own private chef/tutor, for the whole day. He was a lovely man with a great sense of humour and a lot of knowledge and skills. From there, we were escorted to the farm where we picked fresh produce to use in our dishes. We made three tajines and three salads and even learnt some unique skills for garnishing. While our dishes were slowing cooking on the hot coal fires, we were taken for a walk around the village where we got to experience first hand the simplicity of life lived in the local area. It was very calming to be away from the business of the city for the day. On our arrival back to the farm, the dishes we had made were eloquently presented to us in a traditional dining area. We were so proud of what we had made, it truly tasted like authentic Moroccan cuisine. We would recommend this cooking class to anyone interested in learning how to cook Moroccan food. It was one of the most enjoyable experiences during our whole holiday. A perfect surprise that we accidental stumbled upon. Do yourself a favour and give it a go :)

A great activity for something different when touring Morocco. Can't say enough about how fun this cooking class was. Chaf Tarik and his staff made it easy for us to learn about the Moroccan cruise we had been enjoying on our trip to Morocco. We found this to be a nice change from souks, medinas and architecture! We chopped and stirred as we learned which spices are traditional for of the Tajines we made. We saw how the pots sit on coals to slow cook the delicious stews. We learned that the knob on the top of the Tajine pot does not get too hot to touch. We learned to make a few of our favorite Moroccan vegetable salads. We enjoyed eating what we had made for our lunch. The organic gardens at the school are lovely. While our Tajines cooked we walked through the neighborhood around the school and saw up close the traditional mud brick buildings, this walk provide a nice glimpse of local traditional life. Chef Tarik followed up with us after the class by emailing their recipes to us so we can make the Tajines at home and share our love of Moroccan food with our family and friends. Thank you everyone at the school for a really fun experience! A bonus is the clean restrooms!This is a really great activity and recommend it to anyone, it is just a short ride from Marrakesh!

Exceptional. This was an exceptional, once in a lifetime experience! I had so much fun. Small class of two. We made 3 types of tagines and learned the traditions associated with Moroccan Mint Tea. The food was great and the hands on experience was awesome. (Chef Tarik's Tagine was actually the best I had over 2 weeks in Morocco.) I dont know what i liked more - sitting and eating the amazing food we made or learning the traditions and recipes involved in Moroccan food. The tour of the village was also fun and very informative. Chef Tarik and his crew were just exceptional. I could go on and on about this experience... I'd certainly do it again.
Memorable Tagine Cooking Class with Tarik. What a memorable cooking class experience in the Berber village with Chef Tarik. A must while in Morocco!

The keys to Moroccan cooking!. We learned the 3 different combinations of spices that, combined with the fresh from the garden ingredients, made for delicious tagines and salads. It was fun, well presented, and hands-on and we had a lovely lunch - beautifully presented - of the food we had just prepared. A "taste" of Morocco worth the time.

So fun!! . What an awesome cooking class! You learn to make mint tea, Moroccan salads, and three tagines. You first pick all your fresh vegetables from their organic garden then you prepare/cook your food. The staff were all so welcoming and helpful I did this with my mom and she also had a wonderful day. It's a nice break from the Marrakech hustle and bustle as its out of the city. They have a driver that picks you up from your hotel/riad which is super convenient.

Berber Banquet Blast. We loved learning about the food of Morocco with Chef Tarik. He is an excellent teacher and chef. It was easy and fun to follow his instructions and the food we made was so tasty! We especially loved the atmosphere and leaning about his life growing up in a Berber village.

A hight of our trip in Marrakech. We are family of 4 with 2 children. The farm arrange an driver picks us up on time and when we arrive the farm, we know it will be a prefect day. Wonderful setting and nice course design. The chef and tea master are so great and friendly. I am very glad I choose this course over others.

Amazing experience. Everything, from our arrival at the farm until we left, was perfect. The staff was very friendly and the cooking class was fun and delicious. We enjoyed every minute of it. Thank you for this amazing day!

Amazing. Excellent experience! Really nice stuff and awesome food! If you wanna do something especial and different, i'll totally recomend it! I'm really glad for had done it! It is completely worth it

Wonderful Experience!. The cooking and touring at Atelier De Cuisine was fantastic! We had such a great time learning about/cooking Moroccan specialties, viewing the garden, and exploring the village. We learned all about the tea ceremony, how to cook Moroccan bread in a clay oven, and three different tagines (lamb, chicken, vegetable). All the ingredients were unbelievably fresh, right from the garden! Highly recommended experience. Truly Authentic and memorable!

Relaxing and delicious cookingclass. We had a cookingclass with a group of 5 girls. We were welcomed by chef Tarik, chef Youssouf and teamaker Hassan in a beautiful garden outside of Marrakech (30 min - pick-up included - we were picked up at 9.30 and brought back around 15.00h). Moroccan cuisine is typically slow food. Everything is prepared with a lot of love and attention, from the tea, to the selection of herbs to the salads and tajines and the bread. Because of the slow pace and the beautiful surrounding of the garden, we experienced the cooking class as a very relaxing activity (though of course we were put to work by the chefs;-)). The food was delicious! We would definitely recommend this cooking class!

Beautiful day on Chef Tarik's organic farm - learning about food and much much more.... Our taxi arrived at 10am on the dot, and off we went... A winding drive 30km away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech, lies Chef Tarik's organic farm.Behind the tall gates, lies an oasis. Nestled in the dappled shade of olive trees grow neat little lines of beetroot, artichoke, carrots, eggplants, courgettes, herbs and more... But for Chef Tarik, it's about far more than just about growing fresh organic produce. The farm employees locals from the village, providing them with not only a source of income but also hospitality and catering training, whilst also introducing tourists to the history and cultures surrounding Moroccan food and tea. The day began learning about the ceremony of tea making - the making of which is just as important as the drinking! Our group was just four people, so we were introduced to Chef Tarik and his lovely team and learnt what the day had in store. Next up was a crash course in spices. The base to all tagines: salt, pepper, olive oil. Then just add other specific spices to create bases for different meats, vegetables and so ons. Then on to the cooking, three tagines and many salads to accompany them. The pace was great - never rushing but also not slow enough to allow us to get bored. We then moved on to the bread oven, where a local Berber woman was cooking fresh loaves for us to try (accompanied by goats cheese and olive oil, yum!). After a wander around the tiny village it was time for lunch. And what a feast... The highlight was definitely the lamb tagine with apricots and almonds, as well as the smoky eggplant salad. As a Muslim country there's no alcohol served; their wine comes in the form of a home grown beetroot and apple juice which was divine. And then came dessert - bananas baked in the fire with a spiced syrup and a yoghurt and orange jelly pot. We were easily defeated by the mountains of food, but the leftovers are distributed amongst staff and local families so rest assured nothing goes to waste here. Then it was time once again for tea - the same pot brewed three hours earlier only this time with added thyme to act as a digestif. Chef Tarik's organic oasis is the perfect remedy to the crazy city of Marrakech; food to feed the heart and soul... We learnt so much more than just how to cook. Thank you Tarik and team!
Great Experience. We had an amazing time. It was a group of four of us and the cooking class was so much fun and we learned how to cook as well. Well done :)

Our favorite Marrakech activity!. We loved learning to cook Moroccan salads, tagines and learning the proper way to make Moroccan mint tea! Chef Tarik and his staff were fun, knowledgable & the food was amazing! They even made a surprise birthday cake for me. We're looking forward to using the recipes he emailed us at home.

Kudos to chef Tarik. Situated in a charming Berber village, Chef Tarik Orty-Ct's coking class is a wonderful introduction not only to Moroccan cuisine but to the culture that made it famous. Upon arrival, each guest is greeted by a ceremonial tea service followed by an introduction to the quintisential spices of. Moroccan. Following this is a hands on cooking class with Chef Tarik himself. We learned to make several tagines as well as a variety of the famous Moroccan salads. Then on to the bread baking demonstration. Delicious piping hot bread was served along with local olive oil. While our tagines cooked, we took a little walk in the village and returned to a wonderful lunch. A fabulous day indeed! . One that we will not soon forget.
Perfect. No more to say, it was really perfect: the place, the chief Tarik, the weather, the lesson. Good time with friends.

A great experience!. Just back to our Riad after a great day cooking. Great chefs teaching, a great atmosphere and so much great food. The setting was just perfect. Can't wait to go buy some spices and get cooking back home. Definitely recommend!

Cooking class with Chef Tarik. My friends and I enjoyed our cooking class with Chef Tarik last week. He taught us how to make mint tea, lamb, chicken and vegetable tagine and several salads. He also discussed cooking techniques and herbs. We took a walk through the surrounding area while our food was cooking and ate our meal when we returned. We learned and lot and thought Chef Tarik and his crew were very interesting, professional and friendly. I highly recommend the class!

Professional cooking lesson in a panoramique area with biological products. Nice authentic ,quiet place and cooking lessons with the chef Tarik.We learnt a lot of the maroccan culture and the passion of the owner for preparing the food with original moroccan ingredients.Highly recommended to visit this place,nice staff,and best educated in the English language.

A great relaxing way to learn Moroccan cuisine.. This place is set in a village an hour outside of Marrakesh main city. Worry not, though, they provide a pick up and drop off service, included in the price. Only thing is I did not know that and spent an hour worrying if I was being driven to an unknown place in a foreign country. When you arrive, a warm welcome is followed by a lesson in tea tradition and making the tea.We understand the role of each spice in Moroccan cuisine and then go on to pick our own veggies and start chopping to make our tagines. The chef was helpful but not overbearing. He shared the nuances of handling a tagine and we did not have to worry about the writing of recipes as he e-mailed them later and we could focus only on how he was doing things.We made 3 tagines and 3 salads which was quite enough for the 4 hours.Chef is very experienced and friendly and let us take the lead. The lunch was eating the tagines we made and the table was laid sumptuously, while we went for a walk in the village.The last thing was the award certificate in cooking, which all of us enjoyed !!The drive back to the hotel was mostly sleeping from so much eating !!

Fun, Food, and Culture!. The cooking class is located in a village 28 km from Marrakesh. Our "class" consisted of only our family. The chefs made us feel at home, like cooking with friends. The recipes were simple but very tasty and bountiful. The food comes from the school's organic garden/farm and surrounding village. We learned a great deal about the culture of the Berber people. A small shop is available to purchase spices, pots, etc. The price of the class was reasonable, but payment must be made in cash. Overall it was a terrific experience with great food, great fun, and great learning!
cuisine chef Tarik. It was a very plaesant stay with you and your kind staf. Eating our nice self cooked food and make a little walk while we were waiting for the tagines.

Extraordinary Culinary and Cultural Experience. Thank you to Chef Tarik and the entire staff at Atelier de cuisine. The chef's Moroccan roots combined with his international culinary experience are the key ingredients of the extraordinary 4 hour experience we had with him today. Our afternoon included learning about the social purpose of tea and the spice combinations in tagines followed by real hands-on preparation of 4 tagines, 2 salads, and couscous (including instruction on slicing and dicing) and bread-making. We had a private feast that was more elegant and delicious than any Michelin rated restaurant I've ever been too. And, the session ended with a "special dessert."I'd highly recommend that you build Atelier de cuisine into your itinerary. It was the highlight of our trip...and we did ALOT of cool things all coordinated by Heritage Tours Private Travel
Bob. Really awesome They're great guysAnd great food Really good experience overall Local food and village also fantastic

great cooking class on the farm. great class outside at the organic farm/garden. we picked veggies, prepped them, spiced and cooked in the traditional tangine pots!! Awesome! Tarik and staff shared Moroccan traditions as well as taught us about traditional spices, specific Moroccan dishes that were excellent! I would highly recommend this for anyone interested in morrocan cuisine.

Cooking fun for all. The chefs and team were amazingly friendly and patient. They worked well with a wide variety of cooking talent levels. The food was delicious and the pace of the day reflected our wishes.

Wonderful day with Chef Tarik!. In early January, my husband, Stephen, I and our friends, Lynn and Bill, did a cooking class with Chef Tarik and his associates. We were thrilled with the experience! First, the setting is really lovely and we enjoyed seeing the gardens. Secondly, both Tarik and all of the staff were friendly and helpful as we learned and prepared our lunch. We also enjoyed taking a walk through the village and learning more about village life. When we returned from our walk, our table was set beautifully and our food served expertly. Finally, we are all professors so we were particularly touched by the little graduation ceremony with our certificates and gifts. All of us counted our cooking class as one of the highlights of our great trip to Morocco.

Moroccan Cooking Class with Chef Tarik. The mixture wonderful smells, fresh and home grown food food, and talented yet patient guidance from a wonderful Chef and staff, made this one of the most memorable days of our two weeks in Morocco. Well organized and presented. Getting to have a fabulous meal of multiple dishes we learned to prepare ourselves was icing on the cake. Walking through the Berber village while our food cooked was an added bonus. Highly recommended by all four of us in the group.

Cuisine at "Chef Tarik". We had a lovely half-day in his garden, together with another family. Everything was very good organized! Learned to make tea by Hassan, made three "Tagine", a couple of sallads, visited the village and had a great lunch together. This event we recommend warmly!

Do it!. This was one of my most memorable experiences on my trip to Morocco. It happened to be Thanksgiving the night my friends and I took the class. And it was a great meal! I really liked the structure of the class, from arriving and meeting the staff, to learning the tea making process, and of course the preparations of the tagines and couscous. It's very hands on. The chef demonstrates what needs to be done and you go for it! While the meal is cooking, we had a bread demonstration. It was hard not to eat all of it while it's coming out of the clay oven. It's a really worth while experience!

Great Experience in a Beautiful Setting. This experience is truly unique. We learned how to make traditional Moroccan tea, learned about the spices, learned how to make traditional Moroccan salads and tagines, and had a chance to walk the grounds to see the animals and learn about the self-sustainability of the farm. The staff was incredibly nice, knowledgable, and eager to help. We had people of all knowledge levels in the class, and they were able to make everyone feel good and go at a pace that suited everyone.Would highly recommend this experience to anyone, even those who don't like cooking.

Winter break 2015. We had so much fun with chef Tarik! What a fun afternoon we had learning how to cook Moroccan food! We also had the pleasure of eating it too! I highly recommend his activity if you plan on visiting Marrakech!!

Good fun and great food. We did the food tour with chef Tarik. It was great ! First we walked over the market square and through the soukhs to discover all kind of typical Maroccan food. Started with a fresh orange jus, and then tried different dades and other dried fruits, nuts, pastries, olives, herbs and spices, snails, special herb tea, and also visited a communal oven, where we sampled the fresh bread.Then Tarik took us to a restaurant where we had a marvelous diner. We started with two types of soup followed by eight different starters. Then it was time for the four main dishes, couscous, beef, chicken and lamb. As desert we had fresh fruit, and we finished with Maroccan tea with pastries. A great way to try this many different dishes.It was one of the best activities we did during our trip in Marocco. Highly recommended.

Cooking in Morocco!. My daughters, 17 & 21, and I had a wonderful experience. We learned how to make desserts, tea, tanginess, salads and more in a beautiful setting. The staff was helpful, fun and friendly. The setting is beautiful

Great food, great fun!. All of the chefs were super friendly and they helped us make some amazing food! We learned a lot and had a great time. I would definitely recommend the experience to anyone visiting Morocco!

Excellent and entertaining afternoon with Chef Tarik. My wife and I enjoyed a fun afternoon in the quiet garden of Chef Tarik, a setting that perfectly compliments the fresh flavors of Moroccan food. The experience of cooking was matched by the fun we had eating the dishes we cooked. The entire experience was well-organized and worth the short trip out of Marrakech. Highly recommended!

Amazing day at the garden!!. When in Marrakech, a visit to Chef Tarik's garden and learning Moroccan cuisine is a must! Chef Tarik and his team put a lot of thought in order to provide their guests with a perfect day at the garden learning about traditional tea preparation, herbs and spices, cooking tagines and visiting the Berber village. The lamb tagine with apricots and dates is the best thing I've ever tasted in Marrakech! I also felt grateful upon knowing that this garden helps support the Berber community in the area. Thank you for giving us such a wonderful experience Atelier de Cuisine!

A beautiful culinary day on the farm. Chef Tarik is a professional. Our day at Tarik's organic farm and cooking school during a recent foodie tour to Morocco with Geoff Jansz, was special. We arrived to see colourful rugs and stools set up under the olive trees. A beautiful setting! First a tea making demonstration and tasting followed by our hands on cooking class in the outdoors. Chef Tarik has a wonderful team of staff who supported him and our class of would-be chefs. Everything ran very smoothly. We witnessed a bread making demonstration in an outdoor rustic oven. This was followed by eating the warm bread accompanied by goats cheese and olives. A wander around the small village and then a magnificent Moroccan lunch which we had helped in preparing. A magic day! Thankyou Tarik.

Best way to learn Moroccan cuisine!!. We had the opportunity to take this class with Chef Tarik. When compared to other classes offered by Moroccans I can tell you this is the way to do it!!!! You are driven to a remote area (by a driver who picks you up!) and taken to an Eco friendly organic farm. This is where Chef Tarik and his crew welcome you to an opening in the field arranged with traditional Moroccan pillows and tables. This is where you sit together and have tea made the traditional way. You are taken then to a bellowing tent where you cook 5 different cuisines!! It's an unbelievable experience. Make sure to bring ur camera... There are SO many moments worth capturing you will not regret choosing This!
Unmatched experience of Moroccan cuisine and culture!. This was an amazing day-- tea preparation, tag ones, bread making-- an unforgettable travel experience. A must on your itinerary.

Disappointing. Earlier this month we spend a week in Marrakech. Everything regarding our trip was pre book online after checking recommendations on Tripadvisor. We booked airport transfers, a food tour, a day tour to Ait Bin Haddou, Spa and dinner at MK masion, our Riad and this cooking class and apart from the cooking class it all more than lived up to our expectations and would be something we wouldn't, hesitate to recommend to others. On the plus side the setting for the class was lovely and a nice break from busy Marrakesh, the staff was very polite.The whole experience was however much too formal and programmed with no deviance from the rushed schedule. There were not much actual cooking experience. Most things where prepared in advance. We got to chop a few things and learned to make a tomato rose! We were also allowed to add the spices and pull a turnip but under very close supervision. The cooking station was too low and the small slicing knife very blunt but then we weren't there for very long! There were no written instructions but we were promised that chef Tarik would send all the recipes to our mail but date we still haven't received anything from him.There was plenty of food at the following lunch but it wasn't nearly as tasty as the Morrocan meals we had at our Riad. To summerise the whole expirence should be more relaxed and hands on. It is also very expensive as we paid more for this than a five star meal experience at MK maison.
You should try. We have been very pleased by the experience we had at atelier de cuisine.It was nice to see how the tajine were prepared and cooked.The diner was excellent!Thanks Chef Tarik

Real Moroccan highlight. Everything about this experience was spot on: the location, well away from the bustling city, the relationship it had with the village community, the organic, small farm and the kind and interesting people. We had a wonderful day at the end of our holiday and it will be one of our best memories from Morocco. Tarik was extremely helpful, friendly and professional.

An experience to savor. We totally enjoyed the cooking experience here with Chef Tarik and his staff. The tours, explanations, tastes and lessons were all remarkable. It was so much fun to learn how to cook this excellent food, and then enjoy the meal. We just returned home and can't wait to begin cooking the Moroccan delicacies. Definitely try this experience. You won't be disappointed.

A relaxed and most enjoyable Moroccan cooking experience!. Our cooking class with Chef Tarik was a great escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech in very pleasant surroundings. Everything was very well planned and organized including the prompt pick up from our riad in Marrakech, the welcoming tea making ceremony, tour of the kitchen garden, instructional and informative "hands on" outdoor cooking lesson,a pleasant stroll around the village and a wonderful feast of Moroccan food to sample and savour all our cooking efforts.All the staff were very friendly and hospitable, the set up of the cooking class very clean and well organized and great attention to detail in all activities. All participants in the class were cared for and assisted with all tasks required. A highly recommended and thoroughly enjoyable day in a peaceful,rural garden setting. Thank you Tarik and all your team.

An absolute highlight!. Chef Tarik is a gracious host, and his gardens are a genuine paradise amidst the rural region outside Marrakech. We enjoyed VERY MUCH the setup, the instructions, the service and above all the excellent food that we have prepared. It was a real FEAST! Everyone is organic and fresh.Can't wait to be back.
Surprise ....... Continuation of entry that was TTarik. It was this outdoor twist on a standard cooking class that made it a different category.
