Lovely to escape the hussle and bussle of the city and go to a green oasis a short drive away. Host was very welcoming and engaging. Small class sizes made it feel friendly. Learnt about Moroccan tea, bread, spices and best of all the food. Excited to try cooking some of it at home and they give you a tagine pot so no excuses!
Loved it!. We had a great time at the cooking school. Who knew I could cook Moroccan food and it would be so good! I'm inspired to do it on my own when I return home.

Great fun and an exceptional Teacher. My girfriend and I had great fun during this course and learnt a hell of a lot from a wonderful teacher. Would highly recommend this to everyone who loves food and a bit of cooking!

Excellent!. Superbly explained, even for the novice cooks, by the friendly and knowledgeable staff, this was a wonderful way to spend a morning preparing your own tasty lunch. The setting is so lovely too. Totally recommend!

Cook Like a Moroccan. What a professional way to learn how to make and eat a Moroccan meal with a proven Dada. Watch the dada prepare the ingredients on a monitor and do the same. Other chefs will keep an eye on you to make sure your meal will be just like a pro.

Brilliant . Have to agree with the majority of the reviews. Great half day learning some authentic recipes. Mohammed Nahir, the instructor, was really helpful and spoke flawless English. Fantastic value for money

Highlight of my trip to Marrakech!. This is hands down the best cooking class I have ever taken. If you are at all deciding whether or not to do it, DO IT! There is a beautiful setup, knowledgable and friendly staff, and you'll be impressed at your culinary skills at the end.

Over the top fantastic!. I have taken cooking classes in schools around the world and to say La Maison Arabe is the best of the best is an understatement! This is not just a class... it is a true Moroccan experience not to be missed. Incredible!

Wonderful!. My husband and our 4 adult children enjoyed a wonderful morning at the workshop, we where picked up from our hotel and taken to the workshop just outside Marrakech. The kitchen was awesome! Very modern. We cooked and learnt just enough for it to be interesting and informative without being a task and tiresome. And at the end they gave us a tagine!

Wow, wow- book now!!!. What a brilliant day- my hesitant boyfriend and I were absolutely blown away by this course. Professional- interesting and full of excellent little touches! Was a was our interpreter and she was charming, funny and informative- keeping the day flowing beautifully! The staff make the day- from learning to make bread to making little biscuits- they were excellent! The recipes are easy to follow and there is a gorgeous gift at the end from the Dada! Best thing we did in Marrakech!

Expensive but can't really complain. For me, this tagine cooking class was a welcome break from being aroundMoroccan men, for all the assistants and cooks were female and the mainguide spoke excellent English and, unlike most Moroccan men I'd had as"guides" and "drivers," the female staff at this cooking school were all very, very cooperative and sensitive to my interests. I wondered why a cooking class cost around US $200 until I saw the very modern setup with spotless gas stoves and the TV monitor simulcast showing the two cooks demonstrating every step of preparing the recipes, while the English speaking guide stayed at my elbow assisting me. The lamb and fig tagine that resulted was a darn sight better than any of the mediocre tagines I'd had at hotel restaurants in Morocco to that point. I'm home now and I will try out the little tagine pot they gifted me with as soon as I get a chance to.

more than a workshop!unmissable!. From start to finish this was an incredible afternoon. Mohammed our guide was excellent as were all of the chefs and assistants. I recommend this class to anyone who enjoys cooking! Thank you to maison Arabe for a wonderful informative afternoon!!

Very enjoyable cooking class. The setting was super, located at a golf resort in the outskirts of Marrakesh. We met at the riad La Maison Arabe and were transferred to the resort in mini buses.The host was very informative and friendly. The kitchen was very modern and perfectly set up and the lesson very well prepared and everything well organized.We really loved it.

A cooking class beyond the ordinary. This culinary class is held at a country club outside of the medina. Beautiful grounds filled with trees, plants, flowers and all the herbs used in the dishes we prepared and the tea we drank. The kitchen itself was beyond professional. I cannot imagine it is not used for television demonstrations.I'm guessing there were 16 of us that day arranged in a u-shape with the chef in front demonstrating and also shown on closed circuit TV. Each of us had our own station with a TV screen, sink, two burners, and all the necessary implements. The chef was excellent and there were several assistants who helped those who wanted extra hands (like my husband.) We prepared two salads and a wonderful tagine (the best we ate in Morocco--probably because we could add extra spices ). We finished the day sitting under an arbor in the garden eating our creations and drinking 3 selections of wine with our new and interesting friends from all over the world. An excellent experience and highly recommended. We wrapped up the day at a Hammam for a scrub and massage.

One of the Most Enjoyable Cooking Classes. I have taken many cooking classes around the world and I must say this was one of the best. While you wait at the gorgeous hotel, you are served tea and cookies. The vans actually leave at 10 (being on time is surprising in Morocco) and take you to their country club. Here they have a traditional oven where you make bread and are taught how to serve tea.The best part of this class was that it was not just directions but an explanation of both the history and influences of the cuisine and why each step is done. They also encourage everyone everyone to ask questions.When the cooking starts, everyone gets their own personal cooking station and makes their own tagine and salads to their liking. The stations are the most high tech and organized I have ever seen (see pictures). Each station has a screen to see what the chef in front is preparing and helpers come around. When its time for the meal, you all sit down for a delicious filling lunch. As you leave, they give you a very small tagine as a gift. This is the best non-historic thing to do in Marrakech.

Excellent cooking class in superb setting with top notch facilities. We were picked up at our hotel and ferried to La Maison Arabe (hotel), and then served mint tea and petit fours whilst we waited for our fellow cooks. We were then whisked off to another venue, sadly with little direction as what was happening, and then the minibus pulled up to a rather inauspicious door. When it was opened, it revealed the most idyllic garden and driveway. We drove up and were warmly greeted, watered and sat in the shaded sunshine where we were talked through thoroughly the agenda for the day, before being taken through to the most wonderful kitchen. A central station stands in front of a horse-shoe shaped classroom of the most decadent nature, and each of us had our very own workstation with hob, sink and everything we could possibly need, including... a television screen in front of us, showing exactly what was being demonstrated up at the front. As we were talked through every stage of the recipes, assistants cleared and mopped as we went, and miraculously appeared with ingredients at the perfect moment. We ate our wares in a lovely group table at the end - everyone had produced the same dishes, yet they were all slightly different! Really great instruction, good level of detail, and a wonderful setting - a Moroccan must do!

Simply brilliant. I often get bored after a couple of days sitting by the pool and take myself off to a local cookery school.However, nothing had prepared me for the amazing setting and high quality of the bespoke kitchen - with individual work stations and video link so you can follow what the chef is doing step by step.I went of my own but by the end of the meal everyone was chatting like friends and you get to cook everything that you made. At the end we got given a tagine so we can put into practice all we learned when we returned home which was a lovely thought.Rick Stein's cookery school in Padstow is the nearest major centre of this kind near me but it wasn't a patch on this course and three or four times the cost of the Marakesh experience. I would fly back just to do a week's cookery school !

The best food we had in Morocco... And we cooked it!. La Maison Arabe run a tremendous cooking class. We were in the 10am class and were transported to their second premises on the outskirts of town. The gardens were laden with fresh herbs and it was wonderfully serene. We started off with a quick overview of food in Morocco and important ingredients, before making flat breads in the large outdoor oven, along with fresh tea.We then moved into the kitchen and made a chicken and preserved lemon tagine with two Moroccan salads. It was hands down the most delicious food we ate in Morocco! They also gave us a small tagine each for completing the course. The staff were brilliant and warm and we can't recommend the class enough.

AMAZING, ENLIGHTENING BRILLIANTLY PRESENTED COOKING WORKSHOP. We loved Morocco and this Cooking Workshop at La Maison Arabe was one of the highlights of our trip.We were very fortunate to have been taught by Mr. Mohammed NAHIR and his staff, in a very relaxed atmosphere showing us step by step the wonders of Moroccan Cuisine.After a private shuttle bus ride, we were taken to a small estate with beautiful gardens and a very professional kitchen. Everyone had their own station. All of it decorated with a lot of taste. The food was delicious and the experience extraordinary. Highly recommended.

Absolutely brilliant experience and surroundings. Did the lunchtime 10-2.30pm cooking workshop at the Maison Arabe. Brilliant edge of town country club location. Gardens and host were brilliant. Introductory talk about Morrocan food, accompanied by fresh bread making and mint tea. Then cooking in a purpose built studio with great instruction and help. Then we got to eat the food in the garden under a sun screen. Thoroughly recommended. Everything worked well and experience was great.

Cook like a Marrakechi!. Nine of us took this class and it did not disappoint. La Maison Arabe has a professional cooking class set up that allowed each of us to have our own work station. The space was very clean, but also decorated beautifully. While there, we also toured their herb garden, which had a wonderful variety of herbs and we got to participate in baking bread in a traditional outdoor oven. The entire class was led by women. Wafa was our guide for the day and during the meal, which was delicious, We made chicken tagine with two sides. If you like to cook, I highly recommend this class. It is a wonderful experience. And you even get a small tagine as a departing gift.

Fantastic foodie experience!. If you're a foodie, do this. We were taken in a shuttle bus to a small estate just on the edge of the old town. Pretty place with a nice kitchen garden.The class was taught in English, and the introduction (history and for-interest stuff) and the instruction were both brilliant! It's definitely necessary to like cooking, as it's a reasonably quick pace, but you don't have to be a particularly gifted chef to get involved. Really good fun for half a day's activity, and we practised what we learnt the evening we got home!

Wonderful Cooking Class. It seemed like a great idea to take a short cooking class in Marrakech -- and this far exceeded our expectations. The staff gave an excellent overview of Moroccan cooking in good English (a rarity in Marrakech in our experience) and then we rolled up our sleeves. First was "helping" cook flat bread by placing it in the domed oven. Then a demo of how to make cookies (which baked for desert). Then each person when to their own station to prepare and cook tajine -- food cooked over a flame in little clay dishes with conical covers with vents to let out steam. The ingredients were there for us, and we sliced and diced and mashed and added the ingredients to the tajine in order at the proper time. (Oh -- and to cut up a salad.) Each station was modern, well-equipped, and came with a large screen to see what the instructor was doing on the cooking stage via close-up camera. We were impressed with the sophistication of the facility and how well organized it was. Once done we ate our hot meal as a lunch with drinks at an extra cost. It was a far greater experience than we imagined and we can't recommend it enough as something different and interesting to do in Marrakech.

A fascinating experience !. The Cooking Workshops at La Maison Arabe, Marrakesh, Morrocco, is a fascinating 4 hour, hands on, workshop.Guides and lady-chefs are incredibly kind and professional. The classroom is a real professional kitchen, with a personal working station for each student.Groups are small, and the guides have time to teach each student personally.At the end of the workshop you eat what you have cooked, with lovely wines and desserts.Amazing !!!

Great fun in a fabulous venue. I've been thinking about doing this cookery course at La Maison for a few years. At last I signed up for a fun afternoon in a beautiful location on the outskirts of Marrakech. La Maison has a club about 15 minutes from their main riad hotel in the centre of the city. It's available for hotel guests with beautiful gardens and a huge swimming pool. This is where the purpose built cookery school is located. The cookery course is well organised and the teachers are very good at what they do. We laughed a lot and learned how to make authentic Moroccan dishes. It's not cheap but it's well worth taking an afternoon out of your trip to squeeze this experience into your schedule.

Tomato Peel Roses - A New Party Trick. I went with a friend, a fellow self-proclaimed "foodie." We had a fantastic experience learning how to make chicken tagine, zalouk salad (an eggplant dish), taktuka salad (green peppers and tomato). The dadas knew just when to step in and save your dish and were quick to compliment when it was all going just right. Even the dishes that were not on the menu to be prepared (such as a the bread) had a hands-on element. The cooking workshops are on the outskirts of Marrakesh in a beautiful garden/country club. After preparing your dishes, you are invited to sit outside, drink wine, and chat with your fellow chefs (you are too busy to socialize while cooking!) before being served your meal in the fresh air and sunshine. We developed a passion for cooking classes over the course of the afternoon and picked up a new party trick: tomato peel roses.

Luxurious cooking in a 5* Maison. Thanks Mohammed for the full afternoon cooking and teaching me about Morroco. I have really enjoyed learning about spices, making and eating my vegeterian cuscus.I booked the 3.5 hrs long class at the reception a day ahead. As it was noone else booked for that time, and instead of cancelling on me, i received a one to one private class with a professional chef lady (sorry forgot her name) and Mohammed the translator. The attention i received and the location was 5* -worth all the money (600 dh). This was not just a cooking class- Mohammed will tell you all about the country, the people and how to make a Moroccan mint tea. They give you mineral water & tea while you there. The amount i cooked was too much(starter, main and bread) so the hotel staff packed the leftovers in a nice tagine in a nice posh bag to take away. If you the first to book you got to choose what you/the group cooks as main.

Great insight into Moroccan spices and cooking.. The attending chefs (Dada's) were very helpful with explanations and assistance. The kitchen facilities were of the highest standard with great detail attention to detail. We were not rushed and found it very enjoyable.After cooking the meal we sat outside in a lovely garden setting and ate our masterpieces.

Fun for Foodie Family!. My husband, daughter, and I did the cooking class and loved it! We learned a few authentic recipes in a beautiful kitchen, each of us at our own station, with attentive teachers giving us tips. We enjoyed the entire day--watching bread-making, mint-tea brewing, and learning some background of the foods of Morocco. Great experience.

Learning, Cooking, and Tasting in Morocco. In Nov. 2014, my husband and I traveled to Morocco. Travel Explorations provided us with some memorable experiences that I would recommend. This was one. We learned about the tea service in a beautiful garden setting, made our own chicken tagine at individual stations with professional help, and then ate our creations with wine and dessert. Finally, each of us were given our own recipe booklet and individual tagine. What a delightful time this was recommended by Alecia Cohen to help us understand and enjoy the foods of Morocco.

Fab cookery course but outside of this great Riad just be aware. Had a wonderful time on the cookery course, we were not staying in the riad (but really wished we had!). We were two women friends travelling and just something to be wary of (still not sure whether this was a tourist trap or not). We left the medina close to closing (around 9.00pm) and, as usual, had lost our way. We entered a square where one of the stallholders, who were clearing up, shouted 'they are closing the gates'. Feeling a little panicky we were unsure what to do, go back or try to get out before gates shut. A young guy (about 18) said 'Quickly, follow me, which we gratefully did. He led us through the maze to the outside of the medina. He was very pleasant and chatted as he led us along. Outside we thanked him and offered him the equivalent of around a £10 tip as a token of our thanks. At this point things turned nasty. 'You want me to call my friends round, this amount is an insult! The end result, we paid him around £40. I feel embarrassed about this amount. On reflection we should have stood our ground but in a foreign country, in an area we didn't know we felt threatened into paying this. Just be wary, I am sure, on reflection, that it was all set up from 'The gates are closing'.

Best part of my vsit to Marrakech. If you enjoy food, you should do this course/day out.Start's off with the tea ceremony and bread baking, the history of cooking in Marrakech is disseminated during this introduction to the day, and this is followed by meeting the head chef and preparing three morrocan dishes, which you get to eat at the end of the day.There's plenty of time for photos and the like, and needless to say, the meal at the end (which we'd cooked ourselves) was very delicious.

Well-organized, excellent cooking workshop. I've taking cooking workshops elsewhere in the world. This is one of the best I've attended. The set-up is top-notch: a workstation with a sink, granite counter, gas burner and a monitor to view the chef at the top station, in case you aren't near the front. The chef gave a wonderful lecture about Moroccan food tradition, the cuisine's origins, demonstrated the spices and was available all the time for assistance, as was his co-chef, who was not an English speaker but did speak French. We had ample time to cook a tagine, bake bread, make two salads and eat all at lunch. We also had a demonstration of the art of Moroccan mint tea. There was a tour of a spice shop (rather a bit chi-chi and not like a souk spice stall, but still interesting) and the community bread oven, which was amazing to see. They were roasting nuts, but bread was waiting to go into the brick oven. The workshop is a kitchen in a small, boutique hotel of 26 rooms and done in the traditional Moroccan style. The dining area surrounds a lovely pool in a large interior courtyard.

Worth the time, take a half day course you will learn a lot and enjoy it as well. We took the half day course and after a short trip from the Hotel Arab (which is worth a look on its own very impressive) we arrived in a large garden area with a very well presented kitchen which had lots of individual stations and even Tv screens by each workstation as well as a personal assistant.We learnt about bread making and the correct process for making tea outside in the garden which was very informative, more than you might imagine.The course taught us to make two starters and a Chicken tagine which were all very impressive as you get to eat what you cook. Several instructors and most languages are accommodated.A good Q&A session and lots and lots of information which you will find useful.Really enjoyable day and it might sound a bit pricy when you look but trust me it was worth it.

Enjoyable cooking class . We enjoyed the cooking class at the Maison Arabe hotel. It was a nice way of discovering more about Moroccan cuisine and we came away with some good tips & a good chance of being able to re-create an authentic tagine & moroccan salads at home. You spend about 30 mins on the introduction sat in the gardens before going to visit a local bakery & to learn more about spices. The 'dada' leads the cooking in the high tech kitchen where everyone has an separate 'work station'. Occasionally the pace was a little too quick for us & the approach was a bit more 'do for us' rather than teach us to do but we definitely learned a lot & had a great morning. We enjoyed eating the food afterwards as well!

Fabulous cooking course in beautiful surroundings . My partner and two others booked the cookery course after hearing a recommendation from someone in our hotel. The course was at the Riad's country club and we spent the morning in the herb garden learning about ingredients and watching the traditional bread baking process. The cookery course was in a beautiful kitchen and was extremely informative as well as fun. Our instructors spoke excellent English and everything was explained clearly without being boring. We were even given tagines at the end so that we can recreate the dishes at home, a wonderful way to spend a morning in Marrakech.

Cooking class a bit on the pricey side. The cooking classes are held in beautiful clean kitchens just near the hotel's dining and pool area. Its a beautiful hotel, with top facilities and equipment. The 'Instructor' (not to be mistaken with the chef) is friendly and speaks multiple languages but at times can 'babysit' a bit too much... especially if you consider yourself as someone who can cook, for e.g I was cooking a vegetarian Targine and my veggies came pre-washed, pre-chopped... I get maybe it was to save time but we were waiting at the dining tables drinking water whilst they were getting organised in the kitchen. Think they were running late in the kitchen that day but I would have preferred to be hands on rather than sitting around waiting. You also go to a nearby bakery to see how they cook bread, then to a spice shop... and also learn how to make and pour Moroccan Mint Tea. It was all pretty basic stuff. At the end you get a mini Targine but for the price, a glass wine or a packet of spice would have added just that bit more value. Otherwise, it was intimate with only 4 of us that day, and they did take us very last minute so I would recommend.

A fun experience. We gathered for the trip to the beautiful gardens on the outskirts of town where the class was held. The class was conducted in English but help was also given in French and Italian. Taught was the preparation of a simple lemon chicken tangine, as well as a salad and an aubergine dish. Each student had a counter top, sink and gas burners. Ingredients were mostly readied for use by the staff. When the meal was complete we ate the results.

The best thing we did in Marrakech!. This cooking class was absolutely fantastic. We were shown how to make a variety of Moroccan dishes, including tagines, salads, bread and coconut cookies and able to eat all of them. The lesson itself was very well run and all the facilities were impeccable. It was also great to have a look round a 5* Hotel after we had finished eating. Although the course is quite pricey, it is well worth it as we had such a good time!

FABULOUS EXPERIENCE!!. The cooking class at La Maison Arabe is SUCH a fun experience! It is the most beautiful and modern cooking class you can imagine. Each student has his/her own tv monitor, stove, sink, knives, etc. After an overview of Moroccan cuisine, we made several Moroccan dishes and got hands-on instruction and explanations. The food we made was delicious and was eaten in the most gorgeous garden setting!! The instructors were wonderful and everyone in the class bonded and had a great time together. We highly recommend this. It was one of the most fun experiences we had during our 11 day visit to Morocco!!

wonderful experience. this is not normally my thing but i have to say i had a brilliant time,there are two locations for this workshop and i have seen both and they are wonderful, our workshop was in the hotel in the city in the lovely setting of the restaurant and courtyard pool area you prepare a starter and main course (you can customize it to your taste) are given background information on the ingredients, make some bread, have tea and after all sit down for a meal (in this fabulous location) which you have prepared . if you think of the cost of the meal taken in to account this is a very reasonable costed activity for your holiday. the kitchen is fantastic modern and very clean with everyone having their own preparation area including an individual tv screen at each cooking point to help with the demonstration. the other location is on the outskirts of the city in a hidden oasis of a walled garden and pool area ( not small by any imagination) . this is a popular workshop so book up early, we were staying in the hotel and saw many people arrive and were in aw at the location, enjoy .

What's in a tagine and other Moroccan Cooking Secrets.. Moroccan cuisine is graced with a spice profile that is different from its european or north american counterparts. From the first moment that the cover is lifted from a tagine and the aromas of turmeric , saffron, and cumin drift out, if you are a cook, or just a lover of food, you want to know how it is made. There is no better place to begin to explore the preparation of Moroccan food than the cooking school at La Maison Arabe. It has a well deserved reputation of being one of, if not the best, schools in Marrakech. Certainly I would say, having experienced many cooking schools, it is the best equipped that I have ever seen. Each student has their own station which includes a television screen, a 2 burner cooktop, a sink and a large prep area. Our chef and instructress for the day, Dada Ayada, spoke only Arabic or French and since we had only limited French the cooking workshops manager, Wafaa Amagui, acted as interpreter and also gave us a preliminary but detailed introduction to Moroccan cuisine, its methods and spice profile. While we did not prepare a couscous dish we received sufficient description that I am confident we could prepare one successfully. Our morning started with a visit to a spice vendor where we learned about the various unusual spices and their combinations and had an opportunity to make purchases. Afterwards we visited a traditional fire driven brick and stone oven bakery, not one where baked items could be purchased, but rather one where items which had been prepared in neighborhood homes were brought to be baked. The rest of our morning was spent "hands on" under the watchful eyes of both instructor and interpreter preparing a Berber vegetable tagine and a chicken tagine with preserved lemons and olives, taktuka, a tomato and pepper salad, zalouk an egplant salad, and khohz, the traditional round Moroccan bread. We learned about the intricate process of making perfect mint tea, pouring it from on high to aerate and cool, into traditional glass cups. Feeling very accomplished, with anticipation and great delight, we sat down to the lovely lunch that we had just cooked, seated at a poolside table, and toasted the success of our experience with Moroccan wines which had been chosen to complement what we had prepared.

I don't cook at home but had a blast in this class. So for all you boyfriends/husbands reading this review, you should accompany your significant other to this class. It was a lot of fun and the dishes I created actually tasted pretty good (even my wife said so). They do a great job leading the class so you don't have to be an expert. The off site location is really nice with an extra large kitchen. Each person gets their own station. The other nice part of this type of activity is that you get to meet people from around the world and have a meal together. Helps reduce the tourist "bubble" on a trip. Highly recommend.

Perfect and fun. very professional teaching kitchen set up. Everyone had their own work station and 3 staff to help us. We all cooked the chicken Tagine from scratch but almost as good was the stuff we learnt about Morocco, it's people, spices, food etc. you get to eat your own Tagine in the adjacent restaurant too. One of the must do's in Marrakesh.

Best coking class I've done. We had a great time at this cooking class. The instructor was fantastic and you felt he was really passionate about sharing Moroccan cuisine with you. The kitchen was so professionally set up and all the cooks and assistants we so much fun. Everyone cooked their own Tagine amoung other things and you really learnt a lot about spice combos and tequniques. We even made bread and took it to the local baker to bake! Would highly reccomend ... Have some great memories and knowledge to take back home from Morroco from this. ps: the food we cooked was delicious!

Le Maison Arabe made us feel we were great chef. The classroom where we had our class was very well equipped with tv screens where we could watch closely what Dada was doing. The instructions were very clear plus I appreciate that there was someone watching what we were doing to ensure that we were following the instructions and to help us when needed.I wished they gave us the aprons instead of the tajines as they are hard to pack. My sister's broke on her way back to the US. We could have been the walking advertisement of the maison if we had those aprons on. I also wished we could buy the coscoulaires, the tray for the teapot and whatever utensil we used during class. We do not know how to pick a good one.

Fabulous Cooking Class. Ten of us went for this wonderful Moroccan cooking class and the whole workshop was just perfect. The kitchen was very well equiped. We had our own sink, stove and cooking utensil. We also had individual TV screen to see how the Dada was doing. We had the teacher/interpreter and two other assistants who are constantly checking on what we are doing. They prepared a table for us and we all ate what we prepared. They gave a certificate at the end of the class and a Tajine cookware as souvenir. The tajine cookware was fragile and bulky to carry in our suitcase.I would strongly suggest that they give us the apron we used as the souvenir. it is light to carry in our suitcase and a great advertising for the cooking class too.

Another fantastic cooking workshop!!. I have booked 2 workshops with La Maison Arabe over the past 2 years and loved both of them!! The first one we were only 7 people so we got to use the cooking classroom at the Riad inside the Medina. The ladies were wonderful and the class was so much fun!!This year we were 14 so we had to use their space outside the city at their Country Club which is about 15 minutes away in the Palmiarie. We had a blast. Their vans met us to take the group out and we were greeted by the smiling faces of the ladies and another fun and informative class!! The food was delicious and everyone had a BLAST!We got to help make bread, learn to make mint tea, and of course the salads and tagine were all great. They give you a little tagine gift to take home and your 'diploma'! adorable.You can choose your menu which I didn't realize so next year we will switch it up and do some lamb! They accommodated our vegetarians and gluten free people wonderfully also which was fantastic.Our group decided to make a day of it and we brought our suits to hang by the pool and the gardens for the rest of the afternoon. They charge 200MAD per person for this but we loved it after full bellies from lunch! (*btw Moroccan swimming pools are FREEEEZing across the board. at least in October but we got in anyway. fyi!)Plus it is a real value for all the experience and the great fun you have.Highly Highly recommend this cooking course!
Cooking Class at La Maison Arabe. Just Fantastic! Would choose the off-site school vs the on-site option as it has more space and the opportunity to see old-fashioned bread-baking by a Berber woman

The best cooking class EVER!. On my 50th birthday we decided to book a cooking class at Maison Arabe and we were not disappointed. The staff were fabulous and the venue truly beautiful . Our 6 year old daughter loved every moment and it was a birthday event we shall never forget. Oh and our chicken tagines were delicious even if we do say so ourselves! PS the restaurant is also fantastic having tried it the night before

WOW - one of the best cooking classes we've ever taken. This actually blew me away. We loved it! We met at the hotel and were bused to their cooking school and gardens. We helped make bread in the outdoor oven, learned about their tea ceremony and cooked GREAT food in their state of the art cooking school. The best experience we had in Marrakech! Fast paced, fun and funny, completely worth it!

I was looking forward to this and it didn't disappoint. We were first given a walk around the lush raised herb beds in the garden, then shown the traditional oven for baking bread and roasting foods to be used in the meal. Wafaa was an outstanding hostess and Madada demonstrated the cooking techniques. We each prepared the meal we would eat. A monitor over the preparation area allowed you to see what was being demonstrated. We each had a two burner cook top with a tagine and a frying pan. With the assistance of the circulating helpers we prepared two salads, a chicken tagine with lemon and olives, coconut cookies and a pastille for dessert. Wine is available if one wanted it. We were given the recipes and a bit of the background about the many influences on Moroccan foods. There were about 16 in the class and it was fun, congenial and so good. As we departed each guest was given a small tote bag with a single serve size tagine. Be prepared to bring it home well cushioned in your suitcase.

Informative and fun.. If you like cooking, I highly recommend this workshop. The instructor gives a great overview of Moroccan cuisine and the dishes you create are quite good. It was very fun interacting with other travelers and the take home tagine dish was the cherry on top.

Fantastic way to depend a morning. We loved the riad for a start. We started with an introduction and were led into a fantastic custom build kitchen complete with overhead screens so we could see what the Dada was demonstrating. 3 hours later we had bread, drunk mint tea, made 2 salads and a chicken tagine each. We ate this lovely lunch in the peace of the riad and complimented it with wine parings. Lovely helpful staff , very professionally run cookery class

Inspirational. Go on holiday and go on a half day cookery course you must be joking! Well that's just what we did, fantastic time. We were told to turn up at 9.45 at la Maison Arab so we did. We were shown into a courtyard given mint tea and told that the transport would soon be there to take us to the country club. Well we were transported to a fab location where we met our master chefs. We were given an overview of what we were going to do and then we were taken off for tea and to see how they made bread. Well the tea of course was mint both it and the bread were delicious. So far so good. Now down to the real hard work. The kitchen layout was something way beyond my expectations, ultra modern with a dozen work stations all fully equipped complete with flat screen TV focused on the chef. They explained about herbs and seasoning and where you need it help is given, ace.Well you eat what you cook and where you eat is lovely. I have to say that mine was excellent so was everybody else's. If you get the chance do it. Thanks to the team it was great. John
A very professional and informative show. I've been to a few cooking schools in different parts of the world. This one ranks with the best - professional, informative and presented with aplomb.

Enjoyable cooking class. This cooking class was a fun. Both Mohammed and Aida were very nice and helpful. The kitchen was spotless and perfect and we enjoyed our selfmade food in a perfect location! What else can you ask for?

Very good workshop - but not on time.... Very professional workshop in a beautiful surrounding - a blooming garden outside the city walls. We enjoyed the instructions and the actual cooking process. The nice ladies had prepared everything beforehand so we could start right away with chopping, mixing and tasting at work stations with were high-end and spotlessly clean.The workshop, the instructions, the lunch and the give-aways (your own little tajine) would have made for five points, but unfortunatly the class started an hour late (after the hotel especially stressed that clients needed to be on time and we rushed to get there early!). We were "parked" in the courtyard of the Riad for more than 50 minutes - a complimentary mint tea would have been nice...

Fantastic Experience!. As I love Moroccan food, one of my goals was to take a cooking class during our 11-day stay in Morocco. Much to my surprise, my husband and the other couple we traveled with wanted to do the same. While our tour operator thought he could find an informal (less expensive?) class offered by a riad, I was hoping all along that we would go to La Maison Arabe because of its reputation. All four of us thoroughly enjoyed our experience.This is really a topnotch program, with excellent facilities and teachers. The day began outdoors at the oven where traditional bread was being baked. We learned about Moroccan tea and the many spices used in Moroccan cooking. Once inside the kitchen where we all had our own cooktops and supplies, we made two Moroccan salads and lamb tagine. Once done, we ate what we prepared for lunch in the delightful company of our classmates from South Africa, England and Italy.

Ode to Michele. Cooking lesson with a twist, the host was hilarious, kept us entertained through out the day.The actual cooking session was brilliant after cooking our meal we all sat down to eat our 3 course meal with wine. Definitely worth checking out.

What a treat!!. So fun!! WEnt to the "country club" setting of Maison Arabe and started with mint tea while they showed us how to make bread. Then went indoors to our private cooking stations and made 3 dishes - including chicken with preseved lemons and olives. My kids, husband and I all had a blast and then ate our creations for lunch!! Loved this!!

Local Cooking. This school is very well run. Had a cooking discussion, a spice review, followed by actual hands on cooking with an instructor and two assistants. We made two salads and a tagine with bread. Then had a lovely lunch with those in the class each of us eating what we had prepared.
Great time. My husband took the course and he enjoyed whole experience very much. Even though I didn't take the lesson, I enjoyed watching everyone's cooking and having meal my husband cooked.

A perfect cooking experience. Traveling a lot we always love to try the local food – why only stick to what you know when you can learn new.This was the first place where we (me, my wife and our daughter) tried a cooking class abroad was Maison Arabe and this was a very good experience.The cooking class included introduction to the local spices, vegetables and chicken. The kitchen is big, cosy and equipped with hob and sink for every working station. The chief instructor was standing at the end of the long table around which we had our working stations. It was possible to see all that she was doing as a flat screen was used as monitor.We prepared three courses with the main course Chicken tagine as the most important. The instructions were easy to follow and understand and the result perfect.After having prepared all the courses and enjoyed looking and hearing the chief instructor the complete group was seated together and our own food was served in the fantastic area around the small pool.Having a diploma and a tourist tagine was not necessary and we had to leave behind the three small tagines at the hotel when leaving Marrakech. All in all I can warmly recommend this attraction.

Must do in marrakech. This is a really fun and interesting way to spend a morning or afternoon in marrakech. We were greeted poolside at the beautiful hotel by Mohammed. He spoke to us about the various moroccan dishes and the ingredients that are used. He also had lots of information regarding the medicinal or healing properties of spices. We then went to the hotels spice shop to smell the various spices we would be using during cooking.After this we went to the most beautiful kitchen which was equipped with everything we needed and each work station also has a tv screen so that we can see everything that Mohammed is doing. Firstly we made bread to accompany our meal and then we moved on to prepare an egg plant starter and a chicken tagine main course. They had very helpful assistants with us also to help us along. There were 6 in our group and we had a great time and Mohammed's knowledge is excellent. After finishing our cooking class we sat poolside again and were served all the food we had prepared. After dinner we got a beautiful desert and to top the day off we each got a beautiful taginne to take home with us and a list of recipes to try at home.This is a must do thing in marrakech. It is suitable for all ages. I myself am 28 and really enjoyed it and the other members of the group were of various age groups.Thank you for a great day again Mohammed.

Fun and informative.. Very engaging host who talked knowledgeably about the subject supported by helpful cooking assistants. Really pleasant way to spend a morning and definitely worth the money. Learned a lot and even got a tagine with a small cookbook to help us at home. Helped us appreciate the food for the rest of the trip. Highly recommended.
Perfect experience if you like to cook. Wife and I had a great time and enjoyed the flavour of our cooking. Would definitely recommend....if you like to experience genuine Moroccon cuisine...

Amazing - a highlight of our holiday. This really was a fantastic cookery course & certainly THE highlight of our holiday. Anyone who just likes cooking or food would enjoy this. We were taken by shuttle bus to the most idyllic setting. The herb gardens were so peaceful & calm & we enjoyed tea & bread in these stunning surroundings. The large spacious kitchen was beautiful & very well set up. The staff were fun & friendly & really made the course. It was fun eating our food in the shaded gardens with our pre-ordered "wine pairing."

Fantastic Cookery Course!. Highlight of our trip to Marrakech! Did the half day course, excellent information and local knowledge, beautiful setting, plenty of assistance with the cooking and as a result, lovely food at the end! You get a little tagine pot at the end along with the recipes. There were 4 of us, then another 4 doing the course, so it was an excellent group size and we all ate together at the end. Would highly recommend, worth every penny

La Maison dArabe cooking school. Easily the best experience of our Marrakesh trip. Highly recommend this to anyone who wants an authentic taste of Moroccan food.great background to principle of Moroccan food. Fantastic kitchen individual workstation per person complete with individual sinks and mini cok tops. Completely set up with knives and spices dishes and main ingredients all laid out. Good fun introduction to our half day workshop. Got to help flatten out the bread before cooking it in outdoor communal oven, enjoyed the ritual of Mint tea. Great fun trying to make roses out of our tomatoes. Completed and enjoyed the chicken tagine and Moroccan salads we cooked and shared at the end of our session. Ps. Really enjoyed the experience of identifying - all the different spices which were also available for purchase as were the cute pottery bowls.

20th June 2014. We booked a day course at this wonderful school to learn a little about the food and culture of the people of Marrakech and couldn't have chosen better. There was 15 people in our group and everybody was warm and friendly...we spent a little time going through the spices and then about the traditions of the foods we were about to cook. When we moved into the kitchen it was well equipped with enough staff to go between pupils...after preparing the meals we moved back outside and all ate together. The surrounding were beautiful after a leisurely lunch we were taken back to our hotel to mull over the recipes given at the end of the day. A fabulous day out.

Great day. The cooking facilities are great, Teheran hosts friendly and knowledgable and the morning well though out in terms of teaching reusable techniques and explaining basic principles of Moroccan cooking. We made tagine and salads that I still make from time to time in the uk. It was nice to have a formal sit down meal and chat with the other students and we all felt a bit more connected to the cuisine.The take home pack was fantastic with recipe cards, a clay tagine and spice. Couldn't fault the course and would recommend to friends visiting the city.
Wonderful. We had such a lovely time! I would definitely recommend this cooking class. We have been on many tours/attractions and this was our favorite!

Amazing experience. We went to the cooking class not knowing what to expect and we ended up having an amazing time! The facilities were great, really modern and clean. The instructions weren't too hard to follow, and the staff ensured everyone had a good time. Well worth the money.

Wonderful day. We spent a morning at the cookery class here. I was not sure what to expect and was vaguely worried that there would not be other guys for my teenage son. but it was a very mixed and friendly group, about 10 of us, and we all had a ball. Starting with garden herbs, into bread making and the mint tea ceremony we learnt a lot before we were let loose on our own tagine. Gently helped by the Dada and her colleagues everyone cooked a delicious lunch and learnt even more along the way. Great introduction to Moroccan food and one of our favourite holiday days. They were very clued up and helpful with my son who has a nut allergy. Highly recommended.

Highlight of our trip. Marrakech is a city of hidden beauty, and the location of the cooking school is no different....a 2 acre garden oasis 10 minutes outside of town. The staff takes care of everything- shuttle to and from the venue- very easy. The day is perfectly planned- a great combination of learning, listening and doing. The facility is very modern, clean and beautiful and the careful instruction makes everyone feel like a great chef. The instructor spoke fluent English and was very insightful about Moroccan food. Its a great opportunity to socialize with your other classmates and enjoy a great lunch in a beautiful and relaxed setting. This was the highlight of our trip for sure.

Great Experience. Had a fantastic day, one of the best experiences on my many travels. It was fun and exciting. Very professional, kitchen and cooking stations were of a very high standard. Well worth the money( approx. £44). Once the food was cooked we all sat down outside to eat. I paid extra to have a glass of wine (taster) with each course. Excellent.Thanks to Dada and the rest of the staff you were great.Jay

Excellent fun!. This was really enjoyable, a small group of us only about 8 people, so a good class size. Wonderful teachers, made it fun and you learnt a traditional dish whilst also shown how to make the local tea. At the end you all sit and eat what you have cooked in the gardens. Also a bit of time away from the hustle & bustle of Marrakech. Perfect!

A Marrakech must!. Our day at the Maison Arabe Cooking School was an absolute delight. We were not sure how it would go as we started with a lesson on how to make bread and Moroccan mint tea. It was informative but a bit formal. Well...it did not take long for the tone to change. Our Dada ( Moroccan Chef), her Manager and assistant all started to laugh and entertain as well as teach us about Moroccan cuisine. The entire class, including lunch afterwards, takes only about 4 hours but we learned a lot about spices and techniques. The cooking school is located outside the Medina but a shuttle takes you to and from Maison Arabe. The kitchen was high tech with monitors at each cooking station. The equipment was new and everything was clean and well planned for our class. They are well prepared and able to accommodate about 16 guests.We thought the price was reasonable and well worth a day of educational fun. My husband even enjoyed himself and now assists me with cooking with my tagine!La Maison Arabe Cooking class was one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco.

Great cooking class in English in Marrakech. We took this cooking class on our last day in Marrakech - and it was amazing! We had rang up that morning - they were not planning to run an afternoon class - but they decided to anyways, and it was just for the two of us!This wasn't some amateur cooking class put together by a riad owner or a maid - they run these all the time and even have a purpose built cooking class kitchen to accommodate a big group. There are TV screens at each workstation to see what the chef instructor is doing, and the whole room is air conditioned so a very comfortable experience indeed.We learned how to make Moroccan salads and a chicken lemon tagine. We then got to eat our creations - as well as a dessert from the kitchen - in their tranquil restaurant at the Maison Arabe hotel where the cookery school is located.At 600 Dirhams per person it isn't a cheap experience for a 3 hour class and a meal, but we really enjoyed it, the teacher was great, the class kitchen was professional, clean, and well set up.

Brilliant cookery workshop. We had a great time as a family at the Maison Arabe cookery workshop. Our kids joined in making bread at the start and the staff could not have been more helpful with them through the cooking itself. The food actually tasted great as well. That may have been helped by the tasting wine menu as well. Eating macaroons fresh from the oven in a herb garden in Marrakech - life's memories are made of these moments.

A fantastic experience. For my wife's 30th birthday we spent the day learning how to make a traditional Moroccan tagine in a beautiful setting. The staff were fun, friendly and knowledgeable and made the experience very memorable. Needles to say the food was delicious. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys food and would like to get a flavour of Moroccan food.

Cookery Class Experience in Marrakech. A fantastic experience with a great group of just 9 of us. We learnt a lot, had lots of laughs, and enjoyed eating our meal together. Really good kitchen area in a beautiful setting. Can highly recommend doing this.

A must for any foodies!. I would highly recommend this activity to anyone who is looking for a memorable introduction to Moroccan cuisine and traditions. There was more to the day than simply learning how to create delicious chicken tagine, tomato roses or aubergine and pepper salads. The facilities were spacious, stylish and well equipped. The team led by Wafaa were efficient and professional, yet they also created a friendly and informal atmosphere, with their jokes and anecdotes about cooking and eating in Morocco. During the morning we sampled typical foods such as freshly baked flat breads dipped in olive oil, a creamy pastry and watched Moroccan tea being made (not how you'd expect!) Sitting in the beautiful tranquil gardens, eating what we had cooked for lunch, rounded off a very enjoyable morning. And the gift tagine we received at the end was a nice touch!Reviewed by Suzette M

Wonderful!. Took our boys, ages, 11 and 13 to this class and we all had a wonderful time!! Once you arrive at the hotel, they take you to the 'country club' location that is a beauttufl garden with the cooking facitlies on-site. The facitilies were very professional and the staff was wonderful. The meals were very tasty and complex enough to feel like it was worth the time and money. Would highly recommend!!

Best thing we did in Marrakech. My husband and I did the cooking class when we stayed in Marrakech in mid February. The cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe was seriously the best thing we did in Marrakech - the setting was just stunning, set within a beautiful, peaceful garden. Our host and the Dada (cook) were super friendly and helpful (and funny). To top it off, at the end of the class we got to eat a really delicious meal (prepared ourselves!) while sitting in the lovely garden in the sun. The cooking was in a fantastic kitchen studio, with independent working stations and small flat screen TVs that allowed us to see what the Dada was doing up close. It was also nice that it wasn't a huge class - there were only 7 of us doing the class when we did, which was really nice as it felt like we each had individual attention. The class was well pitched - not too tricky, but not too easy either - and the food selection was great. I also really enjoyed the lessons on how to make mint tea, bake bread, and about the important spices in Moroccan cooking. It was just a really pleasant way to spend the day - definitely recommended.

An Absolute must. If you have any interest in cooking whatsoever or just want to make your own Moroccan meal, this class is an absolute must. The staff is so warm it feels as if they are inviting you into their own kitchen. The workshop takes place on a quiet country club that is so peaceful, and a vibrant kitchen features more than a dozen state of the art cooking stations for you to prepare your very own meal. Not only does the day end with a fabulous meal, you will also learn much about Moroccan culture and food and get to interact with locals. Taking this class transformed my understanding and appreciation for this beautiful country.

Pleasant surprise and well worth while. I am naturally cynical and was expecting a fairly pedestrian affair for what seemed quite a lot of money (600 dhiram per person). It turned out to be a wonderful venue set in the peaceful gardens of the Maison Arabe country club with an amazing kitchen setup individual cook stations for about 20.Our 14 and 9 year old girls had no problem with the prep and cooking work, and everyone had a great time. Was a memorable and worthwhile experience.

Brilliant. This was a top notch class as it was a lot of fun and very informative. You are taught a lot in a short time. They make learning very easy and you will leave confident in cooking some basic but very tasty Moroccan meals. Enjoying your final product in the beautiful courtyard was a perfect end to a great day.

Excellent & Fun. Gifted the course as a birthday present, I went with Mari to the Maison Arabe and took a course on Moroccan cooking. Led by Mohammed Nahir, we learnt much about couscous, spices and other ingredients in traditional Moroccan cuisine. A visit to a nearby spice shop helped us to visualize and usually by smell determine which spice was which. Before starting into cooking we stopped at the community baking oven, since many have no ovens in their homes, dough is prepared at home and brought here to be baked. Very interesting.Back at the workshop kitchens, each of us had an individual workspace consisting of two burners, a half-sink and all the ingredients to make a chicken Tagine and two salads in the course. Of course, we had a glass of wine to help with the cooking process. Mohammed was very clear and Ida with Fatima showed us how to prepare the ingredients , whether to dice or chop or julienne and prepare our dishes. We started by each learning to knead dough for the bread to accompany the meal, as we then set out to prepare the Tagine and salads.Great fun, very informative and the best part was when we finished we sat outside in an interior patio overlooking the pool and each of us enjoyed the meal we had just made, accompanied by excellent Moroccan wines. What a treat! I would highly recommend this half-day cooking workshop for anyone, cook or not. You'll have fun and finish with an excellent meal, one that you made.

Professional Cooking Class and Great Fun. We booked a cooking class for 9 of us, and were all pleased with the class! As well as learning to cook, you are given a background of their food (principles and ingredients of Morrocon food). You even get a tour of the local bakery! The class itself is very professional as they have a workstation kitted out with screens so even if you are not right next to the teacher you can see everything that is being done. All the staff were very friendly and helpful, and most importantly encouraging along the way about our progress! We learnt to make traditional bread (everyone just gets a go at the kneading to feel the texture of the dough), see the tea ceremony, and got to make a tagine and 2 salads for ourselves, as well a garnish of a rose out of tomato peel! The food was delicious and is nice that we get to sit down together and enjoy our culinary skills! You get given the recipes to take away, but as we sat over lunch talking about buying tagines so we can reproduce it at home, it was a great surprise to learn that you get given one at the end so there is no excuse not to bring the Moroccan flavours home! Great way to spend half a day whilst in Marrakech!

A little break. Brilliant enjoyable and opens your eyes to a different way to cook.All the staff were great and you end up eating a great meal cooked by yourself! Place is in great location, clean neat and even has great audio visuals.We were all cooking and singing and is great for all ages. Le Maison does do things well.Only downside is that they need to give you bigger tagines as gifts as the ones given are not big enough even for one person.

Very fun and enjoyable. I took the cooking class just few days ago mid Jan 2014. It was a great and fun experience. Quality cooking class, very professional ! They make it a very pleasant course atmosphere and we learnt to cook tagine. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to learn to cook Tagine

Thoroughly enjoyable and highly recommended!. I took a cookery class at Maison Arabe in December 2013. The morning began with our very welcoming and knowledgeable host Mohammed explaining the main principles and ingredients of Moroccan cookery. He then took us to a local public bread oven and on to a boutique shop where he explained further about Moroccan spices. We then returned to the Maison Arabe and entered the class kitchen to cook. Fatiha, our wonderful chef, first mixed some dough to make Moroccan bread, and all of the class had a chance to knead it. This was a lovely way to be put at ease with the other classmates! We were all then led through the process of cooking our own chicken and preserved lemon tagines and two Moroccan salads. All of the ingredients were provided and some already part-prepared to save time, but aside from this you do actually do most of the preparation and cooking of the dishes. Both Fatiha and Mohammed were really friendly, entertaining and helpful, explaining everything step by step and answering any questions we had. At the end of the class, all the classmates got to sit down together to enjoy lunch of the tagines and bread we had made. We were given the recipes to take away, and after lunch we were all also given a gift of a small tagine, which was a lovely touch. Mohammed was also true to his word and emailed me the recipes for the dishes when I realised I had lost them on returning to the UK. I would highly recommend this class as a really interesting, informative and fun activity to add to your trip to Marrakech, regardless of cooking ability or whether you are travelling as a couple, family, with friends or alone. I don't think you'll be disappointed!

Highly polished cooking class. I can't speak highly enough of the cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe, the whole day was a smooth and faultless experience. The setting is beautiful, at a "country club" on the outskirts of town with an olive tree grove and herb gardens. The kitchen is a purpose built building with such a lovely feel, high quality appliances and modern touches such as screens to watch the demonstrations. The staff are funny,gentle and warm and do their very best to ensure the food you produce will taste delicious! After cooking the group eats their meals ( with matched wines if you like) outside in the sunshine in the beautiful garden. We met some lovely people and enjoyed socializing over our Chicken and preserved lemon tajine and Moroccan salad.This workshop is all class and it's the small details that makes it so fabulous. If I ever come back to Marrakech I will be sure to visit the lovely ladies at La Maison Arabe cooking school again!

Outstanding, family fun and educational. A must!. One of the criticisms I have of this activity is that the Maison Arabe does not market it well enough. We were expecting something of quality given the status of La Maison Arabe, but this cooking experience is at the same level or above many of the cooking schools I have attended in Europe. First of all you meet up in the hotel lobby (we were not staying there) and the drive you to a beautiful country estate with wonderful gardens including herbs and vegetables. We went with our 3 teenage boys who absolutely loved the experience. With us was a wonderful American family with boys as well which made the whole experience even more fun.First explanation was seated in the gazebo in the middle of the garden explaining how the correct Moroccan mint tea is serves. We also saw them cooking bread which we tasted with olive oil.Back in the cooking pavilion we were extremely surprised at the quality of everything. Separate coking stations with a TV monitor in from of you to have a detailed view of what the cook was doing. The explanations were wonderful and the food we ended up cooking and eating outside in a beautiful setting was delicious. Special salads and delicious chicken tagine. The whole thing took a good 3 hours and worth every minute.We bought the cookbook and were given a small tagine as a gift.If you want to learn about Moroccan cooking, understand their spices, have fun and a delicious meal this is THE place. At 60 Euros per person we felt it was excellent value too.A must in Marakech!

Amazing experience. Hi, we visited the course 3 days ago and loved the experience! You will be taken outside the city to a private garden. We prepared the bread, had a mint tea and then we moved to kitchen itself - equiped very professional, with flat screens (you could easily follow the cooking process) and prepared a chicken tajine and 2 morroccan starters. The time flies when you are there! I love the cooking book I bought right there and got the recipes to remember. One of the best activities in Morocco - if you like the food and cook, just book it!

Sensational!. This was, without doubt, one of the most memorable and fantastic experiences of my trip to Marrakesh.It was such a well organised, professional - but very friendly and entertaining - cooking class. Some friends and I had been to another cooking class that morning which was such an undewhelming and disappointing experience that we felt quite deflated before arriving at La Maison Arabe. Luckily for us La Maison Arabe was as fabulous as the morning session had been hideous. And both classes were about the same cost!The 'teachers' were knowledgeable, entertaining and kind and everyone in the session felt supported and encouraged by them. We learnt an amazing amount about Moroccan food and culture and I now feel very confident in tackling the cuisine at home. There was a great sense of generosity from our hosts who gave us gifts of tagine dishes so we could continue cooking at home. We had a tour of the kitchen garden and drank the best mint tea I had tried in Morocco. It was prepared according to traditional methods, using the best quality tea and herbs, grown and picked in their own garden.The class was very satisfying, the food we cooked was amazing and the technology supporting the general execution of the workshop very impressive.Highly recommended!

Excellent experience!. I took my children (teens) to a cooking class at La Maison Arabe - We LOVED IT!They have a perfect setup for classes and, perhaps just luck, our little group of 10 was so fun!The menu was great - chicken with preserved lemon, cooked in a tagine, aubergine and tomato confit-ish dish in the pan - and the results outstanding! Our "teacher" spoke perfect english and explained everything very well- not just the prep/cooking process, but how food fits in to the daily life. Would absolutely recommend this to anyone!

High quality set up. The riad now hosts most of its cooking workshops in its country club in a purpose built, high tech kitchen. The riad transports you to the country club. YOu make you own tagine and salads and it is then served to you. You can pay extra and have wine while you are cooking and more wine with your meal. It was a very pleasant experience; the best thing we did in Marrakech. Expensive but worth it and they gave each of us a tagine to take home. This is suitable for coupes, friends and families where the kids like cooking and can manage a cooks knife! Enjoy.

Highlight of Morrocan cuisine experience. We spent a lovely afternoon at the cooking workshop of Maison Arabe. A minibus took us from the hotel to the fabulous workshop location with its own veggie and herb garden. After a lovely welcome by the host, we were given a fragrant and delicious mint tee with freshly baked bread. Thereafter, the cooking part started, led by a lively and engaging woman who brought across the warm hospitality of the country and had us prepare an AMAZING chicken tajine with preserved lemon. After dinner, we were served a yummy dessert. It was an amazing experience that all of us enjoyed very much.

Fun, informative class in a beautiful setting.. Our dada Fatiha and Wafa the workshop leader were both outstanding. The class is very well organised and located in the gorgeous Maison Arabe hotel. Each of us had our own fully equipped workstation and tv screen to watch the dada at work. The material given was clear and the techniques easy to follow. I was also happy to learn more about Moroccan culture, bread making and spices. The food we made together was delicious -we loved it so much we came back and took a second class. I feel quite confident I could re-create these dishes at home. Thank you Dada and Wafa for a truly wonderful experience.

Highlight of our trip. We were bowled over by the slick organization of this class. We were lucky that we were the only two people who had booked the afternoon class and so got personal attention throughout. The class leader Mohamed is actually a Professor of English at the University, so no language problems ! After a 30-minute whirlwind lecture on the basics of Moroccan cuisine (how to make an authentic couscous, tagine, pastille and a bit about the use of spices), you are taken to the hotel's spice and cookware shop for a run through the various spices (we returned to the shop next day to buy some of their beautifully displayed ceramics). Then it's on to the cooking - after learning how to knead dough, we were taken step-by-step though making a chicken tagine and two salads with the support of a chef and assistant. The teaching kitchen was immaculately set up and with all mod cons, although, because we were such a small group, we had no need of the video screens in front of each workstation. Mid-way through the class, we were refreshed with tisane and biscuits. At the end of the class, we were invited to sit down at a restaurant table in the courtyard outside the classroom to eat our meal, The setting is spectacularly verdant and beautiful around a pool. The food was delicious - although my wife thought there was too much pepper in the aubergine salad, I pointed out that she could hardly complain as she had cooked It herself ! The cost of the class was 600 dirham per person (about £45) but as this includes the cost of the meal, it is excellent value. I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in cooking and delicious food.

Loved it - great way to learn more about Morocco. The whole arrangement fabulous - gorgeous hotel, fantastic kitchen set up. Very knowledgeable leader providing info about Moroccan cuisine and culinary history. Terrific "dada" or chef leading the way. Great food, fun atmosphere - topped off by a delicious lunch. FANTASTIC way to spend a few hours in Marrakech.

Excellent Moroccan Focused Cooking Class. My girlfriend and I really enjoyed this class. The Maison Arabe is a truly stunning hotel (even the Queen of Denmark stayed there). The class is held in a part of the hotel dedicated only to cooking workshops.You will learn to cook authentic moroccan dishes (aubergine salad, chicken with apricots, chicken with preserved lemons, etc.). The staff was very friendly. Made us also visit bread furnace (which serves the whole neighborhood) and taught how to make moroccan mint tea. We truly enjoyed this class and would recommend it to our friends.

A fantastic afternoon in a unique class. We have taken many cooking classes around the world and found the cooking workshop at Maison Arabe unique in that we each had a cooking station with a computer screen. Mohammed started by giving the 6 of us a background in Moroccan food and spices and took us to the riad's spice shop to show us the 35 ingredients that go into ras el hanout, a primary Moroccan spice mixture. Since we were the first to sign up for the class months ago, we were able to choose my husband's favorite, lamb tagine, for the entree. We also got to make bread and learn to make tomato rose garnishes to decorate the two salads that we made. We chose to have the wine pairing with our early dinner which I would recommend. The Maison Arabe is a beautiful example of a Moroccan riad and we wished that we could have stayed there as well but we were on a 2 week small group tour and were not able to select our accommodations.

Informative and tasty!. Learnt to make a great tagine and saw a local bakery in action. The class could have been a little cheaper but gets five stars for being so instructive abd helping us to make such tasty food!

Cooking School at La Maison Arabe. This was an incredible experience, Wafaa was an excellent instructor and together with our own personal dada (chef) it was one of the hi-lites of my time here in Marrakech. What I found so great was that this was an experience, right from the moment we arrived when we were given some traditional breakfast foods to sample while Wafaa gave us some insights into Moroccan cuisine. This is a hands-on school, be ready to prepare and cook on your own burner in front of you. They have a very intimate setting, their kitchen faces the inner courtyard, next to the pool where water trickles out of the lion's heads, it's very peaceful and serene. I particularly enjoyed hearing why we were preparing the food the way we were, why we saved the lemon rinds, why we made the traditional mint tea the way we did, why we added certain spices to specific dishes, how they bake their bread, By the end of our cooking lesson we sat down next to the trickling water and were served the food we'd prepared, it was a moment, and the food was delicious, i could not believe that I had made it. Would I come again, absolutely, would I recommend this to my friends, absolutely.

Excellent class, great food, great teaching. We asked at our hotel about cookery classes and they booked us into the class here at La Maison Arabe.The class was great - there were 8 of us so there was plenty of attention. We had a dada from the kitchen and our host Wafa who hosted the class.The explanations were very easy to follow, the items we cooked were fantastic and we finished with a tagine to bring home.I'd highly recommend this to anyone wanting to experience the full Marrakech experience and find out more about the food and cooking :)

cooking a tasty authentic meal experience. My husband and I are not the greatest cooks but having already read on trip adviser this experience was even better than other people had described.We had such fun and the whole thing was very well organised. We met the lady cook and her assistant (who has been making dough for over 30 years) we had our own cooking space each and the teaching wa clear and fun. We were taken around the town to see a real bakers communal oven and also to visit a friendly herb shop with no pressure to sell us anything. We made 3 courses and then ate them in beautiful surroundings.Bliss. We were given a little tageine to take home free as well.This is an absolute must do when you visit Marrakech but book early and you wont be dissapointed.

Great morning in the kitchen. SInce I was staying at La Maison Arabe, it seemed silly not to do the cooking course while I was there. I booked via email a few months in advance, which was probably a good idea since the courses that week seemed quite full.The course begins with a talk about Moroccan cooking and a sampling of some of the breakfast dishes from the hotel (the pancakes are excellent), followed by mint tea. We then went around the corner to see a baker and to visit the hotel gift shop for a talk through some spices. If the course could be improved, I think this is where it would be... a more interesting visit to a spice shop in the souks would be far better, although is perhaps a little too time consuming given that it's only a half day course.Once the cooking gets started, the staff are very helpful in ensuring that everybody is keeping up with the pace. While it wasn't the most complicated of recipes, there was plenty to keep you occupied... the tomato peeling and rose making were probably the most challenging part.The small tagine you get as a gift at the end is a nice touch, although a little difficult to pack in to your luggage! I think the Maison Arabe branded aprons would have been a better choice.

Great Marrakesh Experience. This class was the perfect balance of just the right level of detail on spices and technique, hands-on work, and a lovely meal. Mohammed and Fatima are very obviously passionate about Moroccan food and keep the energy level high in a very beautiful facility. The process was fun and the outcome was great. It was a relaxing break from the buzz of Marrakesh.

Amazing !. This was so fun and interesting, the teacher Fatima is lovely. Works at your pace and makes you feel relaxed. The food was wonderful, the recipes given after are easy to understand. A little present once you've finished was sweet.
Brilliant!. Lovely experience completely worth every penny. Tried out all the recipes as soon as I got home. Fatiha was an amazing teacher completely put us at ease great day!

The best food I ate in Marrakesh!. We were instructed by the Dada (chef) and had an English interpreter as well. The cookery school is well set up and very clean, with screens showing the Dada's work station so you can copy exactly what she is doing. The interpreter gave us an interesting introduction to Moroccan food and another chef prepared some breakfast pancakes for us before we cooked - they were delicious. They catered for my vegetarianism - I made a vegetable tagine while the rest of the group made chicken and lemon tagines. We also made some delicious warm salads and side dishes, and bread. The experience also included a trip to the nearby bakery to have our bread cooked, and a visit to the hotel spice shop. At each place, the interpreter explained everything clearly and concisely. After cooking, we ate our food. It was the best meal (as a vegetarian) that I had in my 10 day trip, and we enjoyed it so much that we returned a couple of times to eat here. We were also given a tagine dish at the end, and a leaflet containing all of our recipes to try again at home.

Take the class!. I took two cooking classes in Marrakech and absolutely loved this class. The staff were very friendly and easy-going. Mohammed (the teacher) was amazing and very knowledgeable...giving many tips and extra recipes. In addition to answering my questions via email upon my return to New York. If you are in Marrakech and are not sure which class to take with the many choices and different fees, take this one! And after your class, stop by the Hammam. I totally want to move to Morocco, I had a great trip.~Amma
Delicious!. We loved this class. It was interesting, easy to follow and really fun! I really would recommend this to anyone looking for something a bit different to do

Enjoyable experience while in Marrakech. A great course to experience. The kitchen is well set up, with individual stoves and sinks, and tv screens to view the leader cooking. A couple of things to note:- it is advertised that the person who makes the first reservation selects what you cook, this is actually incorrect- they instruct you to save all your questions and ask them at the end...which seems ridiculous when you have a question on a particular ingredient or techniqueThe staff were friendly (as long as you didn't want to ask a question) and the workshop is held in a great setting, by the La Maison Arabe hotel pool.

So much fun!. This was truly one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco. The chef, Fatima, and translator, Mohammed, helped us prepare a wonderful meal in a beautiful professional kitchen which included individual work stations with TV monitors to watch Fatima. It was right off the pool in a nice hotel. I agree with something another poster said, "it was my best meal in Morocco because it was prepared by me" Eating at the pool side tables and meeting your fellow students was also fun.

YUM!!. My husband and I took this class with our friend during our recent visit and the class was excellent!! The food was great (if I do say so myself since I did cook it) and the staff explained everything very well, demonstrated and was helpful. Loved going to see the community bread oven, and the spice shop.

The best part of our visit in Marrakech. Our friend recommended this cooking workshop. Our 13 y.o. son enjoys cooking so we sign up.The class was well organized and the instructor was very informativeThe facility was excellent and the other attendees were a delightful group.We learned how to make Tangie and we are excited to try it out when we return home!
