Highlight of our trip. This cookery course was fantastic, and was the best part of our trip to Morocco. The course was hosted by a chef and a translator/chef. It was really interesting, we had the basics of Moroccan cookery explained and we were talked through the main spices used. We then spent the afternoon cooking a delicious chicken tagine and a couple of side dishes. The food was fantastic, the afternoon was great fun and we couldn't have had a better few hours.

Lots of fun. Thanks to Wafaa and Latiha for a fun morning. I'm no cook but I enjoyed it a lot. We made a lemon chicken tagine from scratch and two salads, and then enjoyed our food in the beautiful hotel courtyard by the pool. A highlight for me was going around the corner to visit a master baker who receives dough from different families and then he bakes their bread. It was interesting to see everyone's baked bread waiting to be picked up.

Go for Chicken tagine. Wafaa and Fatiha , two young ladies taking in charge the cooking class was greatthey just show you step by step how to prepare this delicious tagineat the end we tasted what we did prepare and was YAMIII

Simply fantastic!. I wod recommend this to anyone! We spent the morning cooking tagines and Moroccan salads (don't worry if you are a veggie or have any dietary requirements here, they will cater for this), learning about the food history and even visiting the local underground bakery. You finish by eating your creations and I would highly recommend the wine pairing you can do as well which was reasonably priced. Without a doubt the cookery school manageress and the Dada really made this special. The Dada in particular was so funny and kept us all laughing while we cooked. You eat in the lovely Riad's surroundings and you are given a tagine to take home with you. A fantastic way to spend a morning.

Fun cooking class - one of my best meals in Marrakesh, made by me!. We took a half day cooking class here and it was a blast. Our guide first explained the principles of Moroccan cooking (couscous that takes 3 hours, not 5 min to make) and took us to see a communal bakery. Then we got into the kitchen where we each have our own cooking station. We made lemon chicken tagine, sounds basic but actually has a nice balance of many flavors. After having many delicious tagines this one is still my favorite! We also made appetizers like one with eggplant and tomato and one with roasted giant sweet peppers. I loved that meal but maybe it tasted better because I had to work for it :p definitely recommend it! They also have us tagine pots as gifts at the end :)

Fabulous!. The prompt response to my reservation augered well for what turned out to be a very professionally run cooking workshop at this beautiful riad just outside the medina. The well structured class was delivered in a well planned kitchen with individual cooking stations, television screens to see detailed steps and everything provided. There was no running around trying to identify ingredients or find utensils, there were no hidden costs. We visited a nearby bakery (just a few steps outside the cooking school) and the riad's spice shop, there was no pressure to buy anything, just absorb and observe. The Bada was patient and there was plenty of help available for anyone needing a few tips or a gas jet adjusted. A great few hours, terrific recipes and I totally commend it to you!

The highlight of our Marrakech trip. We found this activity in the top 10 rankings on Trip Advisor and we totally agree with all previous comments. We paid 600 dirham per person which may seem expensive for a cookery class but it is excellent value for money for the experience. All of our group were English speaking and both instructors were perfectly fluent. We started with a trip back in time learning about the history of Moroccan food and its basic principles and influences. To follow we paid a visit to a local bakery and the hotel gift shop where we went through all the difference spices involved in Moroccan cooking. We then walked back to the hotel and into the professionally kitted out kitchens fitted with TVs to guide. We helped make traditional bread before making 2 Moroccan starters and a chicken tagine! Once completed we were taken to the restaurant where we were then served our creations. Probably the nicest tagine we had all week! Before we left we also were given a surprise gift! The hotel was a beautiful setting and both instructors were fantastic and made the day extra special. Get it booked!

Moroccan Cookery School. From arrival to the end of the half day course it was thoroughly enjoyable. The two ladies running the course were informative, friendly and good company.The classes are small and held in a most wonderful hotel. If you like cooking and are in Marrakech I wouldn't miss it.As the courses are small I suggest you book early.The cost of the course was wonderful value for money.

Warm, Welcoming Introduction to Moroccan Cooking. I scheduled this cooking class on my recent visit to Marrakech based on trip advisor reviews, and I wasn't disappointed!The registration process was easy on-line, with quick response from the Riad. My 12 year old daughter and I attended the afternoon session and made the Tangine chicken. When we arrived we were seated at a table and the Chef talked about Moroccan cooking, spices, how to make couscous, and history. We then went to a communal baking oven and then the spice shop. Then back to the Riad for 2 hours of cooking.The nice thing about this cooking class is that each person has their own work space, with a TV screen in front, so it's easy to watch the demonstration. Two people ran the class, one doing the demo, one assisting the class. They were wonderful with my daughter who does know her way around the kitchen.Easy to follow instructions, ingredients at our side, we had an amazing time learning how to use the Tangine. Once we were done,,we were escorted to the dining room where we enjoyed eating what we made. We had a wonderful time, and actually tried to get into another class, but they were full. So book early and enjoy!

What Moroccan Cuisine Should Be. After being in Morocco for several days across three cities, I had been a little unimpressed with the cuisine because everything had just started to taste alike. When I arrived at the cooking class, I was a bit disappointed to hear that we would be cooking a tagine because the idea seemed pretty basic. But wow! The attention to detail and combination of spices was incredible! I was very satisfied with the outcome of the efforts and after consuming the savory meal, wished that all of my tagine experiences in Morocco had been as delectable as that! The hosts are very dynamic and make you feel welcome and competent (even if you don't have much culinary experience). They were also very accommodating, happily switching my chicken tagine for a vegetarian one, even after we had already started preparations. The kitchen is just as pictured and each person is provided with their own station, oils, and spices. You are even given a gift upon completion of your time together. Well worth it!

Chop chop top chef!. A dozen of us invaded Le Maison Arabe's cooking school kitchen. The morning/lunch program included a short visit to a neighborhood community bakery, a short review of Moroccan spices, and a fabulous 2+ hours of instruction filled with cultural insight, history, laughs, and so so Moroccan wine :-) A great time was had by all thanks to the team of dada umma Fatima and English literature instructor turned social network foodie entrpreneur Mohammed.We prepared lemon and olive chicken tajine, eggplant and tomato sides. My key take away was the key spices that go into the ras el hanout seasoning mix along with insights into traditional Moroccan culinary folklore. We spent nearly two hours consuming our top chef tajine creations with more laughs around the hotel's poolside patio. Highly recommend the experience.

fantastic experience. The cooking course was a great contribution to a long weekend in Marakech, we learned cooking, but also more about the local culture with a visit to a shop to learn more about spices and a local bakery. The food we cooked was delicious. I have just bough a tagine myself and am going to try out the recipies at home. I can highly recommend it.

Cooking Class. We have just returned from Marrakech 12-16 March - we didnt stay at this hotel although we were shown around briefly.We went to experience their cooking class... It was well worth it, very professionally run, & great fun - Marakech is all about experinces and this is a great one to have. we cooked a chicken Tagine, 2 starters, enjoyed tradional mint tea and pastries, you get to eat your tagine - so we opted for the afternoon class and could eat the tagine as dinner. it worked out really well. I highly recommend it.. you even get your own tagine for one to take home :)

A great experience. Maison Arabe provides a beautiful setting for this enjoyable class.  Organisation was very professional.   My wife and I shared the class with 8 others, and everyone seemed to have fun.Wafaa who hosted the event and the dada (chef - Fatima) were superb.  They created an atmosphere that had everyone smiling and enjoying themselves.  The pace and energy level was very well done and everyone got a good result from their cooking.During our ~10 to ~1400 morning session, we each cooked chicken/lemon tagine, aubergine/tomato salad and roasted pepper salad.  We also watched the dada make bread and helped a little, and learned how to make mint tea.We visited a nearby baker/bread oven to see how Moroccan bread is cooked and also a spice shop to learn about spices used in Moroccan cooking.The kitchen facilities are very good, with tv screens to see the dada's workstation.  For lunch we each ate our work beside the riad pool in the centre of the hotel, sharing a nice time with fellow students.  The dishes tasted very good.We left with a small gift each to take home and with smiles on our faces.If you are in Marakech, and have any interest in cooking, you'll really enjoy this class.

Confident enough to try this at home!. Wonderful, friendly experience. Shared class with 7 Italian ladies and we 3 Brits and everyone was catered for and a lot of fun was had too. We all took turns to knead the dough, saw how they make the Mint tea and visited the local bakery, complete with moped parked inside! The kitchen facilities are excellent and Wadaa and the Dada are excellent hosts. We had a morning course then got to eat our prepared meal for lunch - and couldn't manage a big dinner that evening.Returning home I've used the recipes given to prepare the same meal and the family loved it!

A great Moroccan experience in the centre of the Medina.. All the staff are Friendly, helpful and welcoming. They also speak good English, which was refreshing as Marakesh is very local speaking, which we didn't speak. I embarked on a 3 hour cooking course and learnt how to cook local food which was a great experience, especially as you eat your food after. I was not staying in the hotel, however, when I return I would choose the Maison Arab. This beautiful authentic clean hotel is very central to the Medina but also tucked away off the busy streets.

Excellent cooking lesson and an enjoyable experience. The course is 3 hours (10am until 1:00pm) followed by eating the food you have cooked. The session includes a visit to a local bakery and to a spice shop (very close to the hotel).The surprise was that the lesson takes place in a purpose built training kitchen just off the central square of the hotel, near the pool. It is very professionally set up and well run.

Fun , informational and tasty!. The cooking workshop is a well-designed program which includes learning about Moroccan spices, breads, tea, as well as cooking your own lunch of a Tajine and two veggie side dishes. The kitchen is especially outfitted for the workshop where each person (max of 10) has their own station. No worries if you have previous cooking experience or not. It was a lot of fun for both me and my husband. The session also includes a quick visit to a bakery around the corner as well as a spice shop. The class started at 10am and we finished eating the lunch we prepared on the riad's beautiful terrace at 2pm.

Great way to get out of the souks. We loved this experience. Besides getting us out of the souks and away from negotiation wonderland, it taught us some useful skills for duplicating some of the wonderful dishes we had been enjoying. This class is great for beginners as well as more experienced cooks. Enjoying what you have cooked afterwards, in a lovely setting, is well worth the price.

Cooking Class at Ateliers de cusine de La maison Arabe, Marrakech. I Want to say Thank you to our cooking class manager Wafa and the staff for the wonderfull Cooking Class at Ateliers de cusine de La maison Arabe, Marrakech.I learned how to cook Chicken Tagine, Peppers Salad and Zalouk Salad and visited a lokal baker and a local spice shop to learn more about how the bread is abken and how to use spices, The maroccan cook and Wafa were so kind and friendly and gave information about Moroccan culture and its relevance to the food. After making the food we sat at in the beautiful riad where the food was served and Wafa joined me and my two English cooking Calss fellow-students.It was very enjoyable and I can recomend this cookuing class to everyone interested in Maroccon cooking.Britt Sallingboe

A must do in Marrakech. 5 friends and i booked this course. From inital contact La Maison Arabe and its staff gave fantastic service. It's great value for money, all the tools, tuition, food etc is included. Wafa and the Dada lady where brilliant. I loved the visit to the moroccan bread oven. The course is really interesting showing you how to make many dishes, I found the course to be at the perfect pace. Eating our rewarding lunch around the pool was a highlight of the trip. Later on in the evening we went to the jazz bar for drinks which i would recommend.

Brilliant. We were recommended this activity by friends and we are so glad we did it. We were on the course with one other lovely lady and the three of us had a fantastic day. We were taught how to cook a chicken tagine with an egg plant salad and pepper salad. We had great fun doing it and thankfully we did really well too as you get to eat together in the sun after. The set up is really good and the ladies teaching us were lovely. They take you to see how the local bread is distributed to the families and they also take you to there shop to explain the different spices. I would recommend this to anybody as it is really lovely to do something different and the hotel is beautiful.

Nice activity to try. We signed up for the cooking course and enjoyed the activity. Like other people said, the food we made was delicious and we learned how to make a variety of moroccan dishes. My concern was halfway into the course, the chef gave instructions too quickly, and moved on to step 5, while I was still working on step 1! (I'm not that slow, I'm just not a professional!!) I asked him to slow down, which he did, but he seemed a little irritated. I would have expected him to do one or two steps, and check everyone was okay before moving on... Maybe he was having a bad day? Overall it was fine, the food was delicious and it was a great experience.

Top experience. We did an afternoon cooking class here, and it is highly recommended as one of the most do things when you visit Marrakech. Right from the introduction, the spice lesson to the cooking and eating our own dish by the pool of the Riad, everything was just excellent. We were a group of family and friends (7 people) and we had a great time. The price (€ 60) is very reasonable considering you get a full afternoon experience, plus a lovely dinner and meal (depending how well you cook obviously).

a highlight of our trip. My husband and I took this class together and completely enjoyed ourselves from beginning to end. The class lasts about 4 to 41/2 hours and includes dinner, so I think it's worth the money. We enjoyed making and eating our meal, learning about how the food is prepared (not just a recipe) and it was fun to meet others with the same interest. We made three different classic Moroccan dishes and also watched them make bread. It definitely made me feel more comfortable about trying Moroccan dishes at home. I believe they do different dishes in the morning and afternoon sessions, so ask what they plan to do if you care.

Unbeatable surroundings, and a very enjoyable class.. We thoroughly enjoyed it. The teachers were awesome, and they really knew how to teach us. Even though it's pricy, We would recommend it to anyone interested in Moroccan cuisine.

Great way to spend a half day. We had a brilliant time doing this cooking school. I would highly recommend it. Don't rely on google maps to get you there tho. I think the hotel should add blow by blow walking directions to hotel from bus station/the closest gate.

Fun morning in cooking school. At first it seemed like a big time commitment to do a cooking class, but we were rewarded! The class kitchen is first rate. Both teachers were helpful and knowledgeable. We made a chicken tagine, pepper salad and eggplant salad. At the end they even gave us each a tagine, which we wrapped and carried home. I would recommend this class and the experience to learn how tagine cooking works in a beautiful location.

Fun and professional. My friend is very much into cooking and she wanted to have a proper cooking class while in Marrakech. I joined her. More out of friendship. And ended up loving every minute that I spent at the cooking class of "La Maison Arabe"! First of all, it was educational, as you get a short introduction into Moroccan cooking traditions and spices. Then you pass on the cooking experience, where everyone gets his own cooking space with a TV screen in front, that shows what in happening in the pan of your teacher, in our case it was Fatiha, who was simply wonderful. Every day there are 2 cooking classes - morning and afternoon. And the recipies of those classes are different. So you can spend the whole day there. They teach you to cook 2 appetizers and 1 main dish (vegetarian for vegetarians) and 1 dessert, which you eat at the end of the cooking class. The reciepies are real, not the ones that you just read or hear and realize that you'd never be able to cook it yourself. So even if you are not a great cook, but love good food, you will love a cooking class at "La maison Arabe"!
Well worth it!!!. The chef and interpreter were fantastic. The food we cooked was superb and the best we ate in Marrakech. We didn't want the course to end!

Fantastic and fun!!. We had seen the reviews and thought we were too late too book but managed to get in to the class due to another couple not appearing and so glad we did!! A great afternoon of interactive cooking. We made a beautiful chicken and lemon tagine each an were taught little cooking tricks. At the end of the class we sat down with our fellow attendees and ate our delicious meals. We were each given a gift of a traditional tagine to take home plus the recipes for that day plus the opportunity to email our chef for additional recipes. Class was fun and a great experience in beautiful surroundings.

Excellent experience!. We took a cookery course one afternoon with our two teenage children (16 & 14) and it was one of the highlights of our trip. Everyone loved it, we made bread, an aubergine dip and then a chicken and lemon tagine, and finally ate it of course! Everything was well explained, the chef took us to a spice shop to explain the different spices first, and then gave excellent instruction throughout the afternoon.

Wonderful way to spend a morning, learn something and have lunch!. We were greeted so nicely from the moment we arrived and looked after by Wafa throughout the worshop, in a very nice setting. We learnt some history, how to make some salads, a tagine and bread. The kitchen was very well equipped and immaculately clean and we each had our own work station. We also have individual screens so we can see clearly what the chef is doing.We visted a bread over and the Maison Arabe shop to see how Moroccan tea is made and learn about spices. We returned to Maison Arabe to eat our lunch that we had cooked and were offered the desert. It was simply delicious and I can't wait to try it out at home!It was a really nice experience and Wafa and our chef were really great and explained things so well to us! Thank you both so much!

Great experience and break from busy souks. We did the afternoon cooking class. The food was excellent. they gave us a gift bag at end with a complimentary tagine pot - great end to a busy week in Marrakech

Cooking doesn't get tougher than this (actually it's just good fun, Masterchef fans). Pros: Modern facilities, great location, excellent host, mini tagine to take away, eat what you make, no pressure to buy things from spice shopCons: A little fast-paced at times, be prepared to eat with your group, pricier than others (but worth it I think)Moroccan cooking, at its best, is divine. So to be let into the secrets of how it's done - though, honestly, it's all fairly simple stuff - is great fun. I'd wanted to do a cookery class for a while and spent ages assessing different courses via Tripadvisor and other sources. I settled on La Maison Arabe and I'm so glad that I did as it was good fun and the facilities were top notch too. You eat what you make, so you'll need to put your heart into it for a decent lunch! You'll also eat with the rest of your group, so if you're not a conversational type then this might not be the thing for you. But I think it's a nice way to chat to others while away. As educational as the class is, it can get a bit fast paced from time to time. If you fall behind there'll be some help to get you back on track though. The host spoke perfet English to help everything along, including historical food references and functional cooking tips. The "dada" (cook) spoke little to no English, but her gesturing and actions were all that was needed. On our course we made bread (the dada did all the hard stuff though), cooked a chicken tagine and made some side salads (hot and cold). There was also a desert - but that was assembled by the kitchen to serve. Between bread making and cooking there's a visit to the spice shop (a private shop, not a market stall) for a tea-making experience, and later a visit to the communal bakery (no daytime fire during Ramadan, of course). It's a full experience that'd be good for friends, couples or groups. Not one for kids though.Take a bit of extra cash along and browse the wine list at lunch. It's hard to come by the red and white stuff in Morocco for the most part, so it felt like an extra treat on top of the cooking treat. I'd happily do it again, assuming it was a different set of courses on the menu.

A fun food adventure. Four aussie ladies visited La Maison Arabe last week (Sep 2012) to participate in one of the best cooking workshops we have experienced that became one of our favourite afternoons in Marrakesh. The half day cooking workshop was conducted by the expert, enthusiastic and patient chef Mohammad whose english was impeccable and knowledge of Morioccan cuisine and culture was extensive. He was ably assisted by the very capable Moroccan bread cook. I am sure we amused her with some of our techniques!! We cooked an aubergine dish, a grilled green pepper salad, prepared and cooked a chicken tajine with olives and visited the hotel's retail outlet to learn how to make mint tea and to identify some exotic spices. Not only did we get to eat our own delicious creations, but we were also treated to a delicious dessert. At the end of our feast we received some recipes and a little gift. A highly recommended and rewarding experience. Wahdiah Hopper

Not to be missed!. This was an amazing few hours and excellent value for money. I urge anyone with a slight interest in cooking, Moroccan cuisine or new experiences to try this. The riad itself is an amazing place and we were warmly welcomed with water by the pool and as a group of about 10, told a brief & interesting history of Morocco. The cookery class itself was great fun and easy to follow (you don't need to be a good cook!). We all had a go at making bread, then our own individual salads and tajine. The two instructors were energetic, helpful and entertaining! The course included a visit to the local bakery to see how the bread is baked, as well as to the hotel spice shop, where we got to see & smell more spices than I knew existed. We were also shown the authentic way Moroccan mint tea, as well as sampling it during a nice rest. Once the cooking was done, we sat down to eat & thoroughly enjoy what we had produced! We were given the recipes to take away, as well as a small tajine which is functional as well as decorational. The only slight downside was getting a taxi afterwards. Although the hotel was helpful in getting us a taxi, the drivers were very hard to bargain with & wanted a much higher price than it should be (maybe because they knew we had just come out of one of the luxury riads and/or maybe there is a cartel going on?) However, this didn't spoil what was a wonderful experience and a must do during a visit to Marrakech!

Great Cooking School. My husband and I visited Marrakesh this summer and we really enjoyed our unique experience at La Maison Arabe. We began our afternoon with some coffee and discussed the basics of Moroccan style cooking with our cooking guide, Mohammed. Then we ventured into the kitchen and began preparing an excellent lemon tagine. The chef was encouraging and easy to understand. I would highly recomment this school. Cindy & Steves Rodriguez

Great experience, though a bit expensive if by yourself. This was a thoroughly enjoyable experience, with everything arranged very clearly and comfortably. After a brief overview about Moroccan cuisine, we prepared our food and also visited a local bakery and spice merchant (where, contrary to previous reports, I felt absolutely no pressure whatsoever to buy anything, but rather found it to be a useful introduction to some of the key spices used for Moroccan food).We were with one other couple, which halved the price of the class. It would have been quite expensive to do as a couple (let alone solo) unless you are looking for in-depth personal coaching, so you might wish to inquire about the number of other people enrolled in the class before committing to it.

Great way to spend a day!. The two of us (25 and 24) attended the cookery course at La Maison Arabe during mid-August 2012. We thoroughly recommend it!We did the course along with another English couple (only 4 of us in the class). The kitchen was high-tech with tv screens at each station showing what the lead-chef was doing. The leader of the group was fluent in English and was very knowledgable. The kitchen was air conditioned and clean and the food that we prepared and cooked was great! It was served to us at a table in the main restaurant of the hotel - which also looked very plush! As part of the workshop, we:-Helped make Moroccan bread-Cooked a Moroccan aubergine dish-Made a Moroccan green pepper salad-Prepared and cooked a chicken tajine-Visited the hotel's boutique to learn how to make saffron tea and to learn about spices-Visited a traditional Moroccan bakery-Had a pastilla (with ice cream)Water was also served regularly.As a 'present' at the end of the day, we were all given a gift bag with a traditional tajine inside.We would recommend the day to anybody. We had come across slightly cheaper cooking courses but the setting alone made this good value for money, considering that a tajine meal in our own Riad was costing 15euros. To know that we had prepared the meal and had learnt how to cook the same at home was great - especially as the recipes were also given to us.A great break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech!

A fantastic morning of cooking!. This was one of my favourite days from my trip to morroco, it was fun, well organised and informative. This riad is very discrete and is quite hard to find, even though only 10 minutes from the main square but once we got there it was great. We were part of a group of 8 and we received a high level of service from when we arrived. Water was served immediately when we arrived and were told the schedule and the history of the hotel and area. We then visited a spice shop where they explained all of the spices. I bought some of these which were reasonably priced and we did not feel obliged to buy anything, this is because we chose to. We were given the recipes we were going to cook to take home and the kitchen was extremely well kitted out. The dada made bread with us, we then went on to make our own chicken tagine and salad. Later we were served the food we made in the restaurant and also had dessert, although we did not make this. We both really enjoyed ourselves, I cook regularly but my boyfriend doesnt and he still really enjoyed this experience.The free tagine was a lovely touch to end the class and we finished by visiting the communities local bread oven! I would definetely recommend this cooking experience.

Loved it.... Our family of 4 (including two boys ages 17 and 12) took the class mid-August and loved it. Educational, good ratio of staff-to-guests, immaculate facility. I do not consider any of us to be experienced chefs, but surprisingly the food that we cooked was outstanding. I attribute that to the quality of the provided ingredients, the chosen recipes and the staff. The kids had a great time too. Highly recommended, especially as a way to beat the mid-day heat of Marrakech in August. A little bit pricey, but worth it, in my opinion.

Great fun and very well organised.. The cooking class at La Maison Arab is fun, well organised and a great way to spend a morning. It's ideal for people with some cooking skills but would not inspire anyone who was already familiar with Moroccan cooking. The host and the dada were very welcoming and provide lots of encouragement. You will learn how to cook a nice Moroccan tagine and salads and then get the pleasure of eating your own work afterwards. The only downside for me was the visit to the hotel shop which seemed like an unnecessary sales opportunity. Highly recommended.

Wonderful experience. After visiting the sights and the medina of Marrakech, the cooking class is a good choice if you want to do something different. The chef received us in the beautiful courtyard of the large Riad, where he explained about Moroccan food, culture, different flavours and preparations. After that, we went to the kitchen where we were taught how to prepare different dishes such as bread, eggplant and pepper salad and a chicken tajine. When I mentioned that I am a vegetarian, the cook took me apart and let me prepare a vegetable tajine instead. We were also shown how to prepare saffron tea, an alternative to the mint tea served everywhere. All in all, a great experience and we even received a tajine to take home.

Brilliant - well worth it. We did this class on Friday and it was super. The hotel is amazing to start with and the cooking class kitchen is great - kitted out with everything you need. You make bread, a tagine, two side dishes and then they prepare a dessert for you.Its on the more expensive side at 600 dirhams but I enjoyed every minute. They also give you a little tagine to take home with you, a nice touch.

Fun, delicious, original.. My husband and I immediately fell in love with the delicious local cuisine and so jumped at the idea of a cooking class. The kitchen space was beautifuland clean and everything was well organized. The yummy dishes we preparedwere served to us later as our lunch. We highly recommend this cooking class as a way of bringing home a bit of Morocco with you, if like us you don't have space in your luggage for a beautiful carpet!

Fun and original in superb kitchen :-). The cooking class was very nice refreshment of our stay in Marakech - we loved visiting the local bakery, cooking own Tajine in a nice atmosphere of La Maison Arabe hotel. Very nicely spent morning :-) If you are foodie person - you should try :-)

La Maison Arabe Cooking Class. The school provides a great overview of Moroccan food and spices. It is wonderfully set up with TV's at each station and hands on instruction. The instructor, Mohammed, sets the stage nicely with background on the food and takes you to a spice shop where you sip mint tea while experiencing the uses and aroma of the spices. Following that you visit a communal bakery before going back to the hotel to start cooking. It was fun learning to cook in a tangine. The setting around the beautiful swimming pool was spectacular and the best part, getting to eat the meal you prepared yourself which I must say was one of the best we had in Morocco. We ordered a bottle of wine and relaxed by the pool with our meal. It was a wonderful afternoon with perfect weather and a charming host.!

Relaxing, informative & fun cooking class!. The cooking class with Mohammed Nahir was amazing - he took lots of time to explain every step of the recipes, but also interesting background info as well. The meal we made was so delicious, and the setting at La Maison Arabe was beautiful - pretty much a perfect experience!

Great tutors, locations and food!. My partner and I are both big foodies and love cooking so it was always part of our plan while visiting Marrakech to take a Moroccan cooking class. We had an idea of which one we would do (from Lonely Planet guide) but found it was all booked up for the week we were in town, so we looked online and found this one. I was cautious at first as this particular course was quite a bit more expensive than the other half day courses we looked at. In retrospect, we don't regret one bit! It really is a fantastic place to learn to cook.We were welcomed into Le Maison Arabe and guided through the beautifully decorated hotel to the pool-side dining area, where we met our teacher, Mohammed (poly-lingual). We sat down for 30-40 minutes while he explained the basic concepts to Moroccan cooking and guided us through the recipes we'd be cooking. Next Mohammed took us into the kitchen (fully kitted out for 10 students - although it was just the two of us in our session - low season), we cooked along with the chef as they showed us how to prepare each part of the dish (chicken tagine with aubergine starter). After we'd finished we were seated next to the pool again and served our food with 3 fantastic Moroccan wines. At the end we were given recipes cards and a terracotta tagine each to take home.I can't recommend this course highly enough. If you're willing to spend a little more money than you would at some of the other schools then this is definitely the one for you.

So much Fun. One day we took a cooking class at la Maison Arabe, and it's was just so much fun. The young women translator - her name was Wafa-was very informative and patient with us. we all cooked a wonderful chicken tagine, then sat down poolside and enjoyed our meal with delicious Moroccan wine. It was all too wonderful.

Fun, delicious, original.. My husband and I immediately fell in love with the delicious local cuisine and so jumped at the idea of a cooking class. The kitchen space was beautifuland clean and everything was well organized. The yummy dishes we preparedwere served to us later as our lunch. We highly recommend this cooking class as a way of bringing home a bit of Morocco with you, if like us you don't have space

Great food and cookery classes too. One of the highlights of our holiday was a half-day cookery school at La Maison Arabe, a hotel and restaurant in the Marrakech medina. The instruction was excellent, the introduction to Moroccan spices and cooking Moroccan salads, tagines and pastillas was enlightening and we got to eat what we cooked!

A great way to learn about Moroccan Cooking. Fantastic cooking school, with great hosts. Learnt how to make tagines - vegetable and chicken, plus salads and bread. Delicious food, interesting information and a great environment to spend a few hours. Would recommend!

Lovely Mohammed. What an amazing class with Mohammed! I had seen great reviews of him from previous posts and we were thrilled to arrive and find him as our teacher. The recipes and instruction were wonderful - I'm making my first tagine this evening for guests and hope to do as well as I did at the school - fingers crossed:)
Nice place. We enjoyed an afternoon while visiting the city, the location was good and the atmosphere was nice.

Hand's on perfection. We had 3 hours cooking class with Wafaa and Fatiha
there are amazing
we learned how to cook a tagine, how toi make moroccan bread
just love it

cookery class. We did the cookery class as a family.Part of it was good and we did learn some about Moroccan cooking but a large part was done "on routine" without much personal enthusiasm from the Dada. Most interesting was a visit to the local owen where women from the neighbourhood take their bread to bake. Less interesting was the visit to the spice store, in particular since every visit to the Medina also is a time when you either visit or fiercly avoid getting dragged into spice shops....

Great food, great experience and great value. My Partner and I did this last week on Friday and thoroughly enjoyed it. The day begins at 10am and finishes at 2. Cost is 600 dirham/ 55 euro / £46. The workshop starts with a brief history of Moroccan food followed by a bread making demo where everyone has a go a kneading the dough, then off to the communal bakery then the hotels own spice shop for a cup of Saffron T and soft sales pitch/ spice lecture. This is pretty interesting and unlike everywhere else in Marrakech you don’t feel pressured into buying anything, at the time I thought it was pretty expensive and if you want to buy spices to bring home I’m sure you can get better value by haggling in the spice section of the Souk, we didn’t bring any home due to Easyjet luggage limits but I’ve just paid £4 for a pinch of Saffron in Waitrose and wish I had now. After spice demo you head back to kitchen to start cooking, we did a chicken tagine with side dishes of aubergine and tomato mash and a pepper salad. My only criticism of the course was the cheap blunt knives but we coped.You finish cooking about 1pm and sit down by the side of pool where you are served what you have made plus you also get bread and a nice desert even though I cooked it, it was one of the best meals I had out there.Great cooking course and enjoyable lunch would definitely recommend.
Yum delicious. Good food a fun place in the souk to visit -eat -meet friends while you are Souking!

needless to go. we took a cooking lesson at this place and were disappointed by the lack of interest : imagine a dozen of people gathered in a small place and the only thing that we were taught was a moroccan salad with tomatoes and cucumber, chicken with lemon and an orange salad ...I could have done it by myself for free, while it cost me 80 euro!!!!

Delightful Setting. The pool side restaurant at the Maison Arabe is a beautiful outdoor setting, which is best enjoyed during daytime, to fully appreciate its attractiveness. Prices are reasonable, service excellent, and the food is quite good, though not outstanding.
cookery lesson. riad atmosphere warm and welcoming, cookery lesson good, trip to spice shop half way through slightly wierd but otherwise very enjoyable
Comfortable and Calm. Good food, nice ambience. Good service. Mixed menu of local dishes and international favorites.

Great cooking class!. Worth every penny. The setting is awesome, like a TV set. Food is great, you prepare several dishes, all typical from Morroco. The visit to the local bread bakery was our favorite part. We made some friends in this lovely setting while eating our meals.

Must Do. A half day of how to cook a Tagine, a moroccan salad and a visit of spice market
love it

The one you must visit. Perfect setting, perfect drinks, best meal we had in Marrakech. Ate outside by the pool under the open sky -- seriously this is what you pictured when you thought about the "glamorous" Marrakech. Also a hotel, cooking school & spa -- I would book myself into everything they offer next time!

A knowledgable staff, quality product/equipment and relaxed atmosphere make the culinary class a must do.. One of the things my husband and I love about traveling is the opportunity to taste authentic local cuisine. The cooking class at La Maison Arabe was all that we’d hoped for. Our instructor, Mohammed, began our lesson with a culinary history of the region before we began cooking, then patiently took us through the steps of making a delicious starter and tagine. He and his staff had a sense of humor, making the experience relaxed as well as informative. With our cooking completed, we were served our meals in the lovely restaurant by an attentive waiter. It was a great afternoon and one we can highly recommend.
Great Place to vist. We were very impressed this time with the attentiveness of this place...
Great Place. Lot to experience here, it was very nice place and great staff

Fun and education in the most beautiful riad. I took a group here which our tour operator arranged not knowing quite what to expect. What a novel but ingenious way to spend a morning; getting the basics of Moroccan cooking with hands on experience and expert guidance in an outstanding riad.The hotel itself it amazing, an utterly beautiful riad; peaceful, sumptuous with outstanding décor and ambience. We all wanted to stay and not return to our downmarket hotel!

Great class. One of the reasons I wanted to visit Morocco was because of its cuisine so I decided to learn some of the basics in Moroccan cooking during my stay. I found the class in Maison Arabe through the internet but had my hotel book it for me when I had arrived in Marrakech.Mohammed, our teacher, was very friendly and spoke perfect English. His knowledge of Moroccan dishes was wast and it was interesting to listen to him go through the countries culinary history. When we left, he wrote down his email address and told us we were welcome to contact him if we had any questions about the food or other dishes. I did contact him shortly after I arrived back home in Iceland and asked for a tagine recipe and his answer was waiting in my Inbox the very next day!There were six of us in the class, three couples. And it was very relaxed and great fun. At the end of the class we all sat down in the restaurant and ate our own cooking and enjoyed a glass of wine and each others company. I highly recommend this class to any one that wants to learn the basics in Moroccan cooking!

Excellent cookery experience. Having had a wonderful meal in the morrocan restaurant we wanted to learn how to cook similar dishes ourself. The course was very informative and Mohammedkindly e-mailed us more recipes to try at home. The facilities were really good and the surroundings to enjoy your meal after cooking it was very nice.

Wonderful Moroccan Culinary Experience!. Delightful, hands-on way to savor the local crusine. Chicken tangine to the creation of a flower made from a tomato. I am a far cry from a kitchen wizard but with the expert guidance from Mohammed even I was able to create a delicious lunch! Beautiful surroundings and fellow students from around the world....a definite 'must-do' while visiting beautiful Marrakech!

Fun, informative and good quality. We enjoyed the experience from start to finish! Beautiful surroundings, delicious food and great hosts, who made the experience such fun. Oh! And we learnt many things too. My friend and I are quite experienced cooks but were able to learn and ask many things about Morrocan cuisine that we found useful and fascinating!
Hammam. My first Hammam ever (and massage) Thoroughly loved every minute! Go the full treatment

Fantastic experience and nice break away from the busy-ness!. Mohammed was an excellent cookery teacher who guided us alongside the dada chef - we created a very tasty lunch in beautiful relaxed surroundings. It was great to visit a spice shop and have everything explained to us about it. Mohammed is also very knowledgable about the city and is keen to offer a few tips on places to go or avoid. Highly recommend this as something a bit different, giving you fresh local cookery knowledge to take home with you

Wonderful experience but.... Although my daughters and I thoroughly enjoyed our half day at the cooking school, the experience was somewhat tainted by the spice shop they took us to. We were not required to buy anything, but I thought that it would be a good idea to buy from the source the cooking school endorsed. The saffron I bought was not pure- it is mixed with some other material. So- as a word to the wise- enjoy the cooking lesson- it was really fun and instructive, but don't buy spices from the place they take you!
Great afternoon cookery lesson. We spent the afternoon learning to do tajine and then had it as an early dinner. great fun

Delightful way to spend a half day. From other reviews it seems the menu stays fairly consistent. The food was delicious and the staff was incredibly skilled and knowledgeable. What I didn't see mentioned was the very posh cooking stations - all set up with ingredients, equipment etc...for each student including a stove, sink, and trash can for each student. I've been to many cooking classes where at certain points you have to wait your turn, juggle with limited space, or watch others cooking one communal dish on the stove. With this set up it was a real pleasure to be 100% engaged in cooking my own meal from start to finish.I did this as part of a business trip. It was a fantastic change of pace and delightfully slow paced way to learn a bit more about the culture and history of Marrakesh through its food.

Fun, informative and tasty. Lovely cooking school - we took a brief tour of the herb shops and then we made lunch for ourselves. I came away with tons of recipes and a mini-tagine! Great way to spend the morning.

Great cookery course. Wow - if you do just one thing besides walk through the souks in Marrakech, go and learn how to cook Moroccan style at La Maison Arabe. We had a great time, thoroughly enjoyed the experience and felt very well guided through the whole process. We even got to eat our own creations which was very nice too. We bought a tagine to try it all out now we are home. For the price a really really good experience.
yummy!!. A great experience. Learned breab, tea, two salads and. A. Prewerved lenon chicken tangine. Really fun way to have a break from craziness of the souks! Highly recommend it.
Excelent. Had a great time and well worth doing!! We got the full experience and learnt so much.
Brilliant. The chap running it answered loads of questions about Morocco apart form foodie ones.

A perfect way to spend an afternoon - a highlight of our fabulous trip to Morocco. We were thrilled with our last minute decision to take a cooking class on our first day in Marrakech - it exceeded our expectations. Muhammad, our chef, was charming and full of local insights which proved to be invaluable. The class commenced with a visit to the local spice shop. We enjoyed it so much we went back every during our Marrekech stay. Muhammad and his assistant Ida guided us through the spices and flavors of Morocco with fish/veggie tagine, eggplant with garlic/tomato, traditional moroccan bread and dessert which, after cooking, we enjoyed outside on the veranda overlooking the hotel pool and accompanied by a moroccan musician playing lovely music. The setting was serene and the food sublime ... honestly, the best meal we had in Morocco. We even learned the art of making Moroccan tea. An unforgettable experience and one I look forward to repeating. Don't miss it!

A must do for foodies in Marrakech!. As many of the other posters here have found, this half day cooking class was a highlight of a recent visit to this magical city. The facilities, which are located within a beautiful hotel complex, are excellent and the day is expertly run. I cannot recommend this experience highly enough...but leave a little bit of room in your luggage as you're presented with a goodie bag at the end!
fab food!!!. Beautifully set restaurant...quite pricey...but hey, it was worth it!!

You Must Do this!!. FANTASTIC morning with the team and thanks to all for an informative and fun half-day. Had this recommended to us before we left and I am telling everyone now!!We live in London and did a Jamie Oliver course the week before. Jamie, pick your game up Mate- you can learn from these guys!Make sure you do the walk with them to the Spice shop. It is optional but very good!

Fun afternoon. The cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe was great fun and also gave a good insight into Moroccan cuisine. They have excellent facilities – everyone has their tiny little kitchen and is cooking for himself. It can’t get more hands on. But it’s not hard work at all – most things are already prepared – it’s like being a TV chef, except for the cameras. And best of it you can try and eat everything at the end. The total time was about two and half hours for a brief introduction, a visit to the spice’s shop, and of course cooking. In the end, we spent another couple of hours enjoying the “fruits of our labour” in a very nice and cozy atmosphere. If you are a foodie – and if you’re in Marrakech chances are good that you are – plan an afternoon for a cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe! You won’t regret it.
Crash course in tagine preparation. We signed up for the 4 hour course - learned some of the "tricks" of the Moroccan chefs and enjoyed a feast of our efforts at the end!
Fun cooking class!. How fun it was to learn how to make tagine and couscous at this fun hotel. The instructor is amazing.

THE MOST WONDERFUL MORNING WITH MOHAMMED. My daughter who is 21 and I went to this wonderful cookery school. First we had a little talk by Mohammed about Moroccan cookery. He then took us on an outing to a spice shop and a bakery where we saw the local residents bring their prepared bread for baking. The talk in the spice shop was really interesting and gave us a full insight into the spices and herbs used. We returned to the cookery school. This was beautifully laid out. Each student, 9 in all, had a stove, sink and work station. We prepared chicken with lemons and olives. Such fun and a pleasure to do. With this we prepared 2 moroccan cooked salads with a tomato cut into a flower. I never thought I could do such tasty and well displayed foods. After we finished, the hotel had laid a beautiful table for us to eat the food. My daughter and I are vegetarian so we couldn't eat the food we prepared but promptly a vegetable couscous was brought to us. The chef had also prepared a filo pastry desert to round off our meal. At the end we were given copies of the recipes. I had such great fun and whilst this course was not cheap, it was most enjoyable and worth every penny. I would highly recommend it.
lovely spot for food. beautiful riad and restaurant in the heart of the medina
Cooking Class a must!!!!!. We did the cooking class. Made the most amazing Tagine. Got taken to a spice stall and taugh about the different spices.Lots of fun and great expereince

I learned so much in 4 hours! The food was amazing!. We stayed four nights at the La Maison Arabe riad, and on our free day I decided to enroll in their cooking class.Two ladies taught the class, the "dada" a very charming and inspiring chef, and her assistant, made for an unforgettable day!The atelier or the school offers twelve students a hands-on opportunity to make three very popular Moroccon dishes. Tagine, and two salads. Each student has his/her own cooking station.After we had an introduction to the history of Moroccan cuisine, we walked over to a spice shop or herborist. We also took a little trip to the communal bakery and saw how they bake everybody's bread! We then returned to the riad to start cooking. The ingredients are very fresh, and are all provided. The instruction was excellent and detailed. The instructors made sure everyone succeeded in making an excellent tagine and salads.We sat down at a lovely table to enjoy our accomplishments, and we laughed, and enjoyed the lovely food and company.Haven't had so much fun in a long time! Highly recommend this atelier. The food was divine, and I'm proud to say I made it!
Learn to cook a Moroccan meal!. This is a fantastic cooking workshop where you really do learn how to prepare a Moroccan meal. The explanation is clear and the experience is very "hands on."

Fun even for those afraid of kitchens. My wife had to convince me to join her at this cooking class, as she knows I don't like cooking and will create any excuse to stay out of the kitchen. That said, I could not have been more surprised at how much fun I had and how much I learned. The chef and translator teach you not only how to cook a delicious Moroccan meal, but also gave us a lot of useful information on how to make the best of our visit to Marrakech. We met some wonderful people at the workshop who were staying at a nearby hotel, and ended up having dinner with them several nights later...the tagine we had at the restaurant (considered one of the best in Marrakech) rivaled what we made for ourselves at the cooking class.

This will be the best tagine you have in Morroco. We did the La Maison Arabe cooking class at the very start of our trip to Morroco and after 8 days travelling around quickly discovered that you will taste a lot of tagines during your stay. However none will be as good as the one you make in this course. We made a preserved lemon chicken tagine with salads. It was all very easy to follow along with the Chef, and tasted great. I would highly recommend this as a great activity to do whilst in Marrakech

Outstanding. I had a wonderful learning to cook Moroccan food with Mr Mohammad. He was very genuine intelligent of the world and Moroccan food. As soon as I got home I put what I learned to used and whipped up some tagine! I highly recommend to anybody going to Marrakech!

Impressive !. Coming from someone who can only whip up a dozen eggs for omelette everyday and considers it gourmet cooking - signing up for this cooking class was a HUGE gamble. But encouraged by the reviews that I have read on tripadvisor - i chose a lamb tajine from the menu provided by my riad.And at 3 in the afternoon - after a 3hr walk around the old medina with a tour guide - all my five senses were geared up for some delicious moroccan cooking. But then again - can I cook? Greeted warmly by Mr. Mohammed at the door - one immediately "feels" the kitchen. Followed by an introduction to the history and sources of moroccan spices and seasoning. Then the actual cooking workshop begins. Mr. Mohammed thoroughly guides you thru the process. Explaining each addition of spice along the way. And while the food simmers on the hot stove - you get to sip tea and exchange pleasantries with Mr. Mohammed. But this wasn't just plain boring pleasantry believe me.Mr. Mohammed is someone who has a vast knowledge of the local cuisine. Speaks; breathe and talks food. Fluent in 4 languages. Travels extensively to further his field. And as you listen to him speak - you would feel his LOVE for food and cooking. And as to the lamb tajine? I licked the dinner plate clean !Is there hope for a hopeless miserable cook like me to whip up some lamb tajine by tomorrow? As Mr. Mohammed has said - there is always hope. AMEN.

What a wonderful time! Makes me want to live there!. 2 girlfriends and I went on a Morccan adventure and decided to throw in some tangine cooking classes for fun... and it delivered! Mohammed, the instructor, was easy to relate to, very knowledgeable, and fun to be around. He was filled with local knowledge and great tips on Marrakech! The cooking class was a ton of fun and delicious! It's highly recommended! Don't miss it if you are in town.

Great, must do experience!. My wife and I went to the cooking class in November 2011. It turned out we were the only people there for the class, which simply made the experience even better. Mohammed and Fatima (the staff that taught that day) were very experienced and knew a lot about the history, spices, and culture around Moroccan food preparation. After a detailed description of Moroccan cooking, we walked through the streets to see the local bread baking shop, which is a local who cooks all the bread for the neighborhood -- everyone brings their dough on pans to cook and pick it up later. Coming from New York, there's nothing to compare it to and it's hard to describe; this is something to see in person. Next we went to a spice shop which seemed to have higher quality spices than what we saw in the Souks. It was unclear whether prices were fixed or bargain-able here.After that we went back to the hotel where they had a very nice kitchen set up with multiple work stations -- one per person. Each step of the preparation was clearly described and explained, and help given if needed. We made a salad, Tajine, and dessert was provided. All were excellent (and not necessarily because of my cooking, but because of the help we were given)!I very highly recommend this as an excursion -- my wife and I almost cancelled other excursions we had already planned and paid for just to come back a second day!

I don't cook but I loved it. Top notch, very professional class in a well-equipped kitchen set up for appro. 12 students each with their own station. A wonderful tagine (the best we had in the 10 days in Marrakech), a basic dish so if you are more advanced book for a more challenging menu.Great fun and really enjoyed dining on the veranda with the people we met.

Morrocan cooking in three hours-theory and practice. If you go to the MAison Arabe cookery school you will probably be taught by Mohammed who is so passionate and knowledgeable about his subject that even my slightly cynical uninterested guest was caught up in the hearing about where foods came from ; how they are prepared and why they take on the flavours that they do. Our cookery class included the short walk to Planete des Epices which is run by another enthusiast who quickly talks his audience through the herbal and culinary qualities of the spices-all of which are of course on sale.And you leave either having eaten or having wrapped up a small feast. A really wonderful way to spend a day
Best experience!. Had the best time in Marrakesh here, made nice dishes, had really nice and funny tutors, an experience to remember!

Wonderful cooking class. Mohammed and Fathia ran a 3 hours cooking class for 9 people that was beautifully organized, visually stunning, appropriately clear, and tasty. They created for us a memory that can be revived in our own kitchens, and at the end, gave us each a tagine to cook it in. These were dear people who gave us a lovely experience. Highly recommended.

Fabulous experience- don't miss!. My husband and I went to the cooking class with 5 other couples as part of a Butterfield and Robinson bike trip through Morocco. The chef explained cultural influences on and techniques of Moroccan cuisine. We went with him to a wonderful spice store, a terrific experience in itself, where we were further entertained and educated. Returning to the kitchen, we prepared a traditional Moroccan meal with salads and chicken tagine under the direction of the chef and his lovely assistant, Fatima. We ate the delicious meal we prepared in a relaxing setting by the pool, and left reluctantly with recipes, spices, as well as the chef's gift of a tagine cooker.
Cooking Class at La Maison Arabe. Loved the class! The dada was great and we went home with a small tajine and the confidence to use it.

Great experience!. Wonderful, friendly staff, who speaks great English. They will help you cook an amazing meal, take you to the bakery and the spices shop, and answer all your questions. We brought a toddler, who was allowed to help us and also had a great time!
Terrific meal. We stayed at the Riad Knisa and this was just a short walk. The four of us enjoyed the ambiance, the service and, especially, the food. I would certainly recommend it.

A brilliant cooking experience that gave us a very simple insight into Moroccan food.. We were one of five couples doing the cookery course and I think everyone thoroughly enjoyed it.We started off around 10am and were met by our tutor / host and taken to meet the Dada (chef) in the kitchen - the next few hours were thoroughly entertaining, useful and educational. I can't quite remember the sequence but all in all we made some local traditional bread, made a pepper salad and an aubergine salad (my favourite) as well as being shown how to make a proper chicken and preserved lemon tagine.We went to a spice shop round the corner for a little talk about the main spices there, with the opportunity to buy some (though it didn't feel like there was any pressure to buy); we were also taken to a local bakery to see the local people bring their bread in to be baked - very fascinating. It didn't seem like we were very long in seeing both of them, maybe 45 minutes (not too sure).After some more cooking we sat down to enjoy the fruits of our labours and we felt that it had been a thoroughly worthwhile and enjoyable morning/lunchtime. Definitely recommended.

Delicious - a real highlight of our trip. There were 6 people on the course and 2 members of staff. In addition to the cooking, we were given a history or Moroccan cookery and visited a bakery and a spice shop.We kneaded bread, made an aubergine salad, a green pepper salad, a chicken and lemon tagine and watched a milk pastilla being made. All the participants then sat down and at the meal and we were given a tagine each as a gift. Really enjoyable and highly recommended.

Brilliant!!!!!. We did this on our first full day in Marrakech having booked before leaving the UK - We were very fortunate in that we were the only ones for the class that day so was very intimate, if a little shorter than we thought (I guess it takes longer with bigger groups)Taken to the bakery and spice shop - spices are really good quality although I suspect we paid a little more than in the souks - it wa our first day and we didnt really bargain hard - maybe we should haveMohammed very informative, interesting and a pleasure to be with.Made traditional tagine with preseved lemons and olives; bread; and an aubergine salad together with a roast pepper salad - All turned out so well - even my partners who never cooks!!!!Stunning surroundings, recipes and tagine to take away - Fantastic - Would recommend!!
great activity. really enjoyed finding out about how the dishes are cooked. hope to do this at home

Intimate, stunning setting...very informative. I could not have been happier with the experience. The setting was very luxurious, the instructor (Mohammed Nahir) was extremely accommodating, pleasant and informative. We made amazing dishes which included a presentation of making real Moroccan mint tea. I wish I could have filmed the entire event so i could relive it! of course I couldn't believe my eyes when the Real Housewives of NYC took the same class - I loved seeing the kitchen again, as well as Mohammed and his female assistant. I hope this publicity brings more business, they deserve it!!

Best part of my trip. Went a few weeks after the bombing in the square after assurances from friends that all was well. Loved the interpreter and the class. The class kitchen is beautifully equipped and opens to the inner courtyard of the ryad. A friend of the owner gave me an amazing tour of the place, and shared its history as the first restaurant owned by a foreigner (French) in the city. Churchill was one of the many names you would recognize that frequented the place. Very cool Came home telling my friends what a great experience it was. Turned on the television, only to see "Real Housewives of Orange County" episode filmed there in the cooking class. I think our class was much better!

La Maison Arabe Cooking School. My wife and I have recently returned from a wonderful trip to Marrakech. If you plan on going to Marrakech I would highly recommend that you plan on going to the Cooking School at La Maison Arabe. It is truly an experience that you will remember, particularly if you have Mohammed Nahir conducting the class. We learned how to cook Chicken Tagine, Peppers Salad and Zalouk Salad. After visiting a local spice shop to learn more about spices, Mohammed and his assistant took us through the preparation and cooking of the food. The nice part of having Mohammed was that he worked with you as if you were his close friend and gave information about the Moroccan culture and its relevance to the food. Very interesting.Following the cooking class, we went to an outside table in a beautiful setting where our food was served and Mohammed joined us. It was very enjoyable as we all talked about our experience and Mohammed continued to give us insight into the Moroccan culture.Since Mohammed is an instructor in English at the University, his English is excellent. He also speaks several other languages. If you are planning on a Moroccan Cooking experience, you should definitely consider La Maison Arabe and Mohammed. Be sure to request him. He is terrific and will add to your trip in a wonderful way. You should also know that he is in charge of classes during afternoons and on Sundays. My wife and I continue to correspond with Mohammed as have some of our friends who have taken his class. Once you meet him, you will be very fortunate to be able to say, “I have a friend in Marrakech.”

Fun and informative. I am not that interested in cooking, so at first was not that excited about doing this when my wife signed us up. We were a total of 6 in the cooking class. Everything was very clean and well organized. We had 2 people teaching us: the chef and a guy who explained a lot about Moroccan food and culture, and who also gave us some great tips on things to do in Marrakech during our stay. The class lasted around 3 hours. At the end of the class they gave each of us a small tagine to take with us, one more thing to carry home, but a fun souvenir of our holiday in Marrakech. Since returning home, my wife has made the tagine recipe we learned, delicious. Net net this was a fun way to learn a lot about Moroccan culture and would definitely recommend, even for people like me who tend to stay away from the kitchen. We did this on a rainy day in Marrakech and was a great way to keep ourselves occupied while staying indoors.

A real taste of Morocco. If you want an interesting experience and real taste of Moriccan life then the cookery course is for you. We booked an afternoon session for just the two of us. The session started by a very interesting brief from Mohammed, our interpreter, who made it all come alive. He also acted as our guide at the spice shop where we were introduced to the owner who gave a very interesting presentation of the different uses for spices, some of which were quite surprising. We bought quite a hoard to take home, whilst the prices were good and the quality high it is easy to spend more than you imagine!After the shopping trip it was back to the school to finish our dishes. The chef made the experience very worth while and added some humour and fun that made it very enjoyable. We sat down about 5:30 to dine on our endeavours, surprisingly very good. Since returning home we have received from Mohammed several interesting recipes which we have tries at home and hope to delight our friends with a Moroccan evening in the near future. Well worth the time spent in an educational and entertaining experience, highly recommended.

Our cooking course was a great experience in Marrakech. During our travels we decided to do a cooking course in Marrakech: just to do something more practical an relaxing during our trip. We made 2 very nice salads (that we have already made at home as well) and a lemon chicken tajine. Our instructor was very nice and helpful, he taught us a lot about Moroccan cuisine and even sent me extra recipes afterwards. Everyone who visits marrakech should do this!

Very informative and culturally enriching. My husband and I enjoyed very much the cooking class. Everyone was very informative and I believe I will actually be able to recreate these dishes back home. I agree with other reviewer on the knives being a bit difficult to chop with but that was my only complaint. I learned so much about the history of the cuisine and the influences of the different cultural groups of Morocco!

Fun for All. My husband asked "why not five stars?!"The course was fun for both of us. I've made this dish a number of times, the only reason why it did not rate 5 stars. My husband enjoys cooking but is not very experienced and the course was deserving of 5 stars for him.The Mason Arabe staff was extremely accommodating to my gluten allergy and all were friendly.

Lovely Insight into Moroccan Cookery. La Maison Arabe is a wonderful totally safe cookery experience. I went for one morning but would happily go every morning for 4/5 days to learn all the different menu's. It is so much better than trying to struggle with cookery book and you meet such nice people as well.

I am now able to cook Moroccan cuisine!. I attended the cooking class at La Maison Arabe and loved learning how to use the exotic spices and ingredients to cook Moroccan cuisine. The instructor was very clear and was helpful in showing us how to recreate the dishes once we got home. If you like the flavorful Moroccan Tagine (a dish of chicken or lamb with vegetables and spices), take the class! It's a fun way to explore the culture and learn a new dish.

Great Cooking Course with Added Extras. I did this course with 8 other people and was the only one not staying at the hotel but it made no difference. The course was superbly run by Mohammed and a lady helper . Mohammed was very helpful and informative and his helper who basically was there to teach the people that were doing the vegetarian tagine as the majority made the Chicken with preserved lemons and olives tagine. As well as the tagines we made two different salads and also had demonstrations of bread making and tea making. We also saw the bread being baked in the communal bakery and visited a spice shop where we had a very interesting talk about the different herbs and spices. I did feel that the Spice Shop was very expensive compared to other places I visited before and afterwards but there was no pressure on you to buy. Needless to say most of the group did buy things! Mohammed also gave us a talk about on Morroccan cookery and how to make Couscous - so different from what it tells you to do on the packet here!!! Since coming back I have contacted Mohammed and he has sent me the recipes for the Couscous and some others.If you are thinking about doing this course - do it. I am a very keen cook and I had such fun doing it and cannot wait to make the tagines at home. By the way not everyone on the course were keen cooks but they seem to enjoy it and especially eating what we had cooked afterwards. I know I should not say it but it was the best tagine I have ever tasted and the salads were also delicious. The hotel provided the pudding which was equally delicious and luckily quite light! It was also great value for money because you also are given a small tagine to take home as well as the recipes.

Exceeded my high expectations!. I had a pleasure of taking the cooking class at La Maison Arabe in March 2011. As I had planned for this class for a long time and researched La Maison Arabe and Moroccan kitchen before my trip my expectations were high – and I am glad to say, they were not only fulfilled but also in many ways exceeded. The people in La Maison Arabe are extremely nice – in addition to advising me on a proper class they provided me with tons of extra help and advice – up to helping me to arrange my logistics to Marrakech.The half day cooking class itself takes place in La Maison Arabes beautiful complex in the medina and it is worth mentioning that La Maison Arabe was the first restaurant opened in the old part of Marrakech, later frequently visited by celebrities like Winston Churchill. Cooking class is presented by Dada – a traditional Moroccan chef who has been working in LaMa for the last 10 years, and a translator. Our translator Mohammed was simply great – in addition of speaking perfect English (he is a university professor) and French he is also passionate about the cooking and Moroccan cuisine. Mohammed got as going with a short lecture on the origins and main characteristics of Moroccan cuisine. This was followed by a short walk to a local spice shop. Even though many people expected some heavy sales pitch, this was not the case at all. This was rather a short introduction to Moroccan spices, different spice mixes and about the ways to use them. And after that – if someone wanted to buy the spices –they where given a chance to do that. Many people did so, as being a partner of LaMa the quality of the goods in this shop can not be doubted. After getting back to the hotel we went into the cooking class where each of us had a cooking station prepared. Over the next hour and half we cooked the most delicious Moroccan dinner – two starters and a great chicken tajine with preserved lemons. We were also given hints on the presentation of the food what was great. Dada and Mohammed where there all the way discretely checking what we were doing and if needed – helping us. Once the dinner was cooked we where seated in the terrace right next to a beautiful swimming pool where the waiters served each one of us with our own dishes. My compliments to the chef – the food was great, as was the company! As a nice touch to a great afternoon Dada gave each one of us a small tajine pot to take home with us. You will also get a printout of all the recipes, so no need to take notes during the course. Most definitely recommended to anyone interested in Moroccan cuisine – this was a highlight of my 4 days in wonderful Marrakech!

La Maison Arabe Cooking Workshop. Our workshop took place at the main hotel, in a group of 10. The cookery school was well equipped, other than that the knives were a bit small for chopping and not quite as sharp as they might have been. There was a cook to demonstrate, and a leader who conducted the course in English and French, helping us with our cooking.Our workshop commenced with a talk about Moroccan food and its origins. In addition to the "hands on" food preparation and cooking, the day included a demonstration of bread-making, a visit to the nearby communal bakery, a visit to a spice shop, a tour of the hotel, and an explanation of how to prepare couscous.We prepared an aubergine salad, a tomato and courgette salad and a tagine of chicken with olives and preserved lemon, all of which we then ate for lunch by the pool along with bread and a dessert made for us.The workshop was pitched at beginners. At home I regularly prepare Moroccan salads, tagines, couscous, bread, etc., and didn't learn a great deal new. Nevertheless, it was great fun, good value at the price (which included a small tagine to take home though I suspect it was a second and not of good quality). Tthe others on the course seemed to get a lot from it, and I did find it helpful to have somebody to answer questions about the things I cook at home. I'd certainly recommend this as something a bit different to do on a stay in MarrakechPaul from London

A great cooking and cultural experience. My friend and I booked this cookery course over the internet so did not really know what to expect but we were not disappointed. The hotel is lovely as is the kitchen where you make your food. All the staff are friendly, helpful and professional.  When we arrived we were given the receipe we were to cook and were given an explaination of what the course entailed. We were then taken see a traditional bread oven and a herbalist where spices were explained to us.Returning to the hotel and our kitchen we prepared our meal, which we later ate. The staff were always on hand to help and the cooking was very hands on. It was very important to the staff that we not only prepared and cook the meal but that we learnt something about the culture of the country and the tradition of the food.I would not hesitate to recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning about Morroco and its food as well as learning how to cook.

Fantastic experience - an absolute must.. As it was just the 2 of us on the course we had their full attention the whole time. The visit to the local bakery and spice shop was very interesting and informative. The food we made was delicious - a chicken tagine and 2 cooked moroccan salads. Our tour round the hotel afterwards inspired us to stay for some mint tea by the pool - which turned out to be complimentary - and to return for dinner for valentines day. An excellent experience, and the instructions are so in depth it's suitable for any level of cooking ability.

A very enjoyable experience. We attended the La Maison Cooking workshop on a Sunday and had a great time. Mohammed was very knowledgeable and easy to understand and made the experience a very enjoyable one. We prepared a chicken tagine with preserved lemon and olives, an eggplant and tomato side dish and watched fresh bread being prepared. The trip to the spice shop was not as good as if you went to the spice souks yourself so make sure that you plan the cooking school before you buy your spices. The cost of the workshop is £50 per person and includes lunch (no wine) and a complimentary tagine. I would definitely recommend this to my friends who enjoy cooking and for a nice break from the exhausting nature of the main square and souks. On the back of the cooking workshop experience we also had dinner at La Maison Arabe. We would not recommend this hotel for dinner. The service was poor, it was very expensive (minimum £60 pp with wine) and the food was not as good as other restaurants we tried in Marrakech. In hindsight we should of asked Mohammed for his recommendation before booking.

Cooking with Mohammed and friends at La Maison Arabe-Fantastic!. Six of us joined our friend Tim for his birthday at this cooking class in Marrakech. Everyone loved the experience-cooks and non-cooks alike! The setting is beautiful and Mohammed was an excellent teacher. We learned about the foundations of Moroccan cooking, visited the local bakery and had a fabulous visit to the local spice shop. We each made three dishes and then sat down to enjoy them together. All of the women working with Mohammed were also really great and we had loads of fun with them.We all loved the experience and would recommend it enthusiastically!

Excellent course in lovely setting. Nestled by the swimming pool, half inside and half outside, this course was very relaxing. The kitchen was impeccably clean and clearly custom designed for the course. We combined a bit of theory and outings to the spice shop and bakery, with demonstrations and, of course, our own chicken tagine.
