My inefficiencies were amply covered up by quick intervention from the demonstrators. My friends back here in London are all now being bombarded with invites to my home-cooked tagines. Highly recommended. Lucy

Fantastic cook course. This excellent half day course starts with an introduction to moroccan cuisine followed by 45 mins out and about visiting a local bakery and spice store. You then go back to the kitchen and get hands on cooking a lemon chicken and olive tagine and two moroccan salads. Instruction is in French and English. When your dishes are ready you dine by the poolside. There were eight people on my course 6 female, 2 male, 4 English speakers and 4 french. We all had a wonderful time. The course started at 10am but we were still enjoying drinks by the pool at 3.00pm. This course is also a great way for solo travellers to make friends. Very professionally organised. Price varies depending on the number of participants but I paid 500dh ( about £40) and this included a lovely tagine dish to take home. Excellent value and a great day out.

All good cooks at La Maison Arabe!. This was a great day in which we learnt to cook Moroccan style and then eat the evidence. It was a treat on a hot sticky day to be in such clean surroundings with cool competent and clear instructions. Everything set out at the ready, recipes, ingrediants and lots of friendly advice provided as well as a trip to a nearby spice market - an unexpected bonus.

highly recommended experience. this cookery school was one of the highlights of our trip to Morocco. The staff were really helpful, their cooking knowledge and help is excellent. This is well worth doing

So enjoyed our cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe!!. The cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe was fun. Mohammed was great - he, along with the others did an excellent job with teaching us how to cook 3 yummy Moroccan dishes. He was not only explicit but also very humourous. The venue/kitchen was very well equipped and we got to take back with us recipes and also tagines. Rebecca, Australia

Must do. I attended the cookery school and found it well worth it. It was fun, visiting a spice shop where you do not fel pressurised to buy as you do in the souks, and cookings some lovely Moroccon food and gaining some understanding of their flavours.Would highly recommend it.

In two minds - but feels overrated. I'm not sure I quite understand why this attraction is rated quite so highly and I definitely feel a bit cheated.The plus points are pretty compelling. Wow, what a location the out of town grounds that La Maison Arabe has, which you are propelled to via air conditioned MPV. The secluded nature, huge swimming pool and sense of exclusivity are incredible. It was built recently in an old style and is owned by a rich Italian who lives nearby. The location is special. As is the translator, an English professor from the local university who has a wonderful social grace and rare but excellent linguistics.Plus a well air conditioned kitchen on a day where it was pushing the mid 40s in Marrakech made this a great place to be in the sweltering heat. I am vegetarian and I made by far the best veggie tagine that I have ever tasted, and learnt a lot.I left though feeling dissatisfied. Was it the cook, who spoke very few words and only then in Arabic? That she paid little or no attention to what we were cooking and offered no advice - the translator was the person who was teaching us to cook, with no input from her? That she seemed more intent in the food she was cooking (who for, I have idea, as we were the only guests there!).Or was it the waiter who brought us our deserts and asked us to leave within 15 minutes, whilst making sure we knew that for 1600dhm, service is not included?I'm not sure what left me with a bitter taste but whatever it was, La Maison Arabe should know better.

Even I can now cook a Tagine. My husband and I spent a pleasant few hours cooking with Mohammed. We were the only ones in the class so we got individual attention. Mohammed was really patient with me as cooking is usually 'not my thing' but I surprised myself and really enjoyed it. The kitchen is well equipped and spotless and the whole experience, including eating your own creation for lunch, really worth doing. Mohammed also volunteered information regarding where to buy spices and how to make the preserved lemons and I am determined to recreate the Tagine at home. Thank you Mohammed

Great fun even with teenagers. The cookery class in the Hotel was full but they offered to put on one for us in their Palmarie location. The class was very informative and well presented. The facilities here are excellent with individual work stations, sinks etc. There is a navette to bring you to and from the Palmerie and the setting is lovely around a beautiful pool. Our teenage children loved it as well. A great way of spending a relaxing half day. The day we were there we cooked a chicken tagine and a starter whereas in the Hotel the cooking class there was making a pastilla.

Great Class. This class was informative, well presented and in pleasant surroundings. I learnt a lot about spices and there uses in different dishes, and would recommend it to anyone – even those of you who think you cant cook! I’m a vegetarian, and they changed the menu for me immediately. It was absolutely delicious – even if I do say so myself Go. You won’t be disappointed.

La Maison Arabe Cookery School - a must do in Marrakech. We spent a morning learning to cook 3 moroccan dishes. Mohammed led us through the process; he is a most knowledgable cook and expert on all things moroccan. The facilities are first class and the hotel restaurant is a perfect place to enjoy the food you have prepared.A great experience.

Delightful Morning!. The cookery school at La Maison Arabe was fun, tasty, and educational! Mohammed the sous chef and teacher was delightful and knowledgeable about all things Marrakech. He not only made the class lots of fun, but was extremely helpful with additional planning! The hands-on demonstration school kitchen was purpose built and the prettiest and most user-friendly of any cooking school I have attended. Situated around the pool, the cooking and the eating were divine!

One of the highlights of our trip to Marrakech!. We inquired to the owners of the Riad Clementine (the lovely riad where we stayed) about cooking lessons in Marrakech, and they recommended the cooking course coordinated by La Maison Arabe (a beautiful hotel). We were in Marrakech during the Christmas holiday and were thrilled that they were able to fit us into a class on Christmas Day. When we arrived at La Maison Arabe the morning of our class, they treated us and the others waiting to the take the course, to complimentary tea and snacks in their beautiful courtyard. There were 9 of us in total (I believe that 10 is the maximum), and we road in two seperate mini vans to the location of the class. The class is held at the hotel's country club, which is a short drive away from the old city. Our interpreter Mohammed (and essentially the instructor), was perfectly fluent in both English and French. Upon arriving at the country club, he gave us a brief introduction to Moroccan cuisine that was very informative. We then went upstairs to the beautiful (and extremely clean!) kitchen, and began cooking. There was a local woman who demonstrated the techniques throughout the lesson while Mohammed explained everything. It was a wonderful experience, and we all enjoyed feasting on our delicious meal after it was prepared (we learned to make a chicken tajine, a warm salad, and a dessert). Mohammed does an excellent job and was kind to email the recipes to us after the class. We would highly recommend this to anyone visiting Marrakech!

Professional and fun. This workshop is properly set up and run: La Maison Arabe is a gorgeous setting in the medina, and they have converted a large room for the workshop with I think 10 workstations, each fully equipped with gas range, sink and all the spices and equipment you will need. It is run by a professor of english (who also speaks fluent french and probably other languages) with genuine knowledge and passion for moroccan cooking. The session starts with a general chat about moroccan cuisine, techniques and spices. We then cooked a lamb tagine and moroccan 'salad' (cooked augerines and tomatoes), and while it was cooking, we were taken on a stroll through local markets and to a spice shop. I didn't buy my spices then but I later wished I had, as I found that I couldn't beat the prices they were offering. Then we returned and ate our cooking, served properly at a table in the al fresco restaurant. I learnt a lot, I think, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I have read elsewhere that the lady that runs Souk Cuisine started out by attending this class. I would recommend it to anyone who actually wants to do the cooking rather than watching someone cook. 500d each if there are 3 people or more on the day.

Great time - exceeded expectations!. Four of us signed up for the La Maison Arabe cooking class. We were a little surprised that we were being bused to a different location from the hotel, but it turned out great. The facility is beautiful, with the nicest pool we saw in Marrakech - Take your bathing suit to relax after the class. We learned a lot, and their teaching facility is great. They have a translator who teaches English at the local university who has been doing the classes for a long time and is VERY knowledgeable about the food and Marrakech in general. I would definitely recommend this and I would do it again.

Highlight of our Moroccan Holiday. We recently spent 3 weeks touring around Morocco. After visiting the High Atlas Mountains and Riff Mountain areas, camping in the Western Sahara,as well as visiting various coastal areas, and all the imperial cities who would have thought the highlight of our holiday would be this cooking class. We joined three other people for this class and had the absolutely delightful experience, under the watchful eyes of our instructors Azizi (sorry if that spelling is incorrect) and Mohammed, of each cooking a pepper and tomato salad, a chicken and olive tagine, and cinnamon orange slices. An added bonus was that we then got to sit down with our new found friends and enjoy the fruits of our labours in the quiet, peaceful grounds of the site of the cooking school. All aspects of the school and the presentation of the ingredients and utensils with which we were to work was very professional. The assitance we received from the instructors was so fantastic that who would have thought cooking could be so much fun! We would not hesitate to recommend this cooking class experience to all who visit Morocco and we plan to use the tagine we just had to buy in Morocco after the class, and the recipes from the class, many times over now we have returned to Australia.

Fantastic foodie experience. The Maison Arabe is a fantastic haven from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh. I visited with my boyfriend to take part in the cookery workshop. The chef was extremely helpful and knowledgable about all aspects of Moroccan cookery. They adapt the level of the course to suit your experience and even seasoned cooks can learn a few tricks. We ate our meal afterwords in the poolside are of the hotel. This is a must while visiting Marrakesh. Don't be disheartened if you don't hear back from them when you email, as internet links are not always fantastic. We ended up turning up while we were over there and they did everything to could to accomodate us during our time.

Amazing experience !!!!. I stayed at La Maison Arabe in January 2009 and took a cooking lesson and I don't regret it. That was just fabulous !!! The people are really nice and the place is just magnificent. I really recommend it.Thank you again.

Delicious and informative. My husband and I took a cooking class at La Maison Arabe in June. Our experience was a bit unique in that we were actually at the hotel, not the off-site location, and it was just the two of us attending the class. The hotel is beautiful, but the best part was the discussion we had with Mohammed. He gave us a lot of information about Moroccan cuisine, but also great tips for the rest of our stay in Marrakech. OK, what about the food... delicious! We each made a tagine (I am a vegetarian, so I made a Berber tagine and my husband made a chicken one), plus a salad. This was one of the best meals we had in Morocco. We had a wonderful lunch and can now impress our friends and family with our fabulous new skills!

An Amazing Experience - Do Not Pass This Up. While on our honeymoon in March we decided to take this class. The class is held outside the Medina on property owned by the hotel, which itself is quite beautiful and relaxing. Mohammed was our instructor, and he was excellent. As an English professor, Mohammed was a natural when it came to teaching, and always made sure to explain the “why” behind the “what” and to give a little cultural background as well which made the day that much more enjoyable. We learned three dishes; green pepper salad, chicken tagine and oranges with cinnamon. The food we cooked was delicious, but there was really no way you could fail. We thoroughly enjoyed the day and would recommend it to others interested in cooking and culture.

An explosion of flavour!. I visited in April on the last day of my stay as a volunteer working in different orphanages. I was the only person there that morning so had 1:1 tuition. I made hot pepper salad, chicken tagine and orange salad. The chef spoke good English as he had worked in New York for a while and we got on well although he was somewhat concerned at my chopping technique! It was a very well equipped teaching kitchen with a number of workstations. It overlooked the terrace and swimming pool. When my food was ready I could not believe how good it looked and the taste - it was like an explosion of flavours in my mouth! Having had tagines in different restaurants I hadn't been able to see what the fuss was about but having made one with incredibly fresh spices I now see the difference. The chef told me that to make tagines in bulk in advance, as is done in many restaurants, can only lead to a reduction in flavour.I would recommend having this lesson to anyone who loves cooking. Some people I was with did an overnight trip to the Atlas mountains, some went to the coast - this was my treat to myself. I am still cooking from the recipes I was given and using the (well sealed) spices I bought in Marrakech.

You'll be hooked on Moroccan cookery. A fantastic introduction to Moroccan cookery and a great way to spend half a day. We were lucky to be the only people in the class so we had the chef and our guide Mohammed all to ourselves. The kitchen is beautifully laid out and maintained. Mohammed was easy company to be with and explained everything well. He is very knowledgable and didn't seem to mind answering any questions, both food and non-food related - even though he has probably answered them hundreds of times before! It was very satisying to sit and eat the fruits of our labour at the end of the course and I was particularly pleased with the way my tomato peel 'rose' came out.

Capturing the taste and fragances of an exotic cuisine.. Entering through perfumed gardens you are led to a beautiful building on the grounds of a private club. First, a drink of minted tea beside a pool- where Mohammed, our translator and guide, greeted us and gave us an introduction into the history of Moroccan cuisine. We were then taken to a breathtaking demonstration kitchen that rivals any kitchen on the Food Network . It lets you know immediately by its style and set-up that you are in for a remarkable experience. Our chef/instructor spoke no English, but with Mohammed at our side, she took us through the intricacies of a multi-layered phyllo- filled dish of chicken and almonds,p'astilla, and an elegant eggplant salad, both challenging to make. But every step of our hands-on prep and execution was patiently explained by Mohammed. Then, best of all, we got to eat our morning's endeavors back at poolside, under fragrent trees. A perfect ending to a perfect time. It was the highlight of our trip to Morocco.

Fantastic insight into Moroccan cuisine. We spent a great morning a few weeks back, on La Maison Arabe cooking course. Being aware of the exceptional reputation of La Maison Arabe, and keen to further our knowledge of Moroccan cuisine, 3 of us enroled on the course.We received a warm welcome on arrival at the Riad, and were able to have a walk around and relax in the ante rooms while waiting for our transport, which took us off to their country club.We were greeted by our tutor for the day, Mohammed Nadir, who sat us down for an overview of Moroccan cooking & its key principles/ingredients over a cup of mint tea. This served to further increase our excitement of the culinary task ahead.Moving up to the well laid out spacious kitchen area, we met head chef, Lazziza, and her assistant for the day. Each of us had our own work surface, together with necessary utensils and ingredients pre laid out. It was straight in to preparation of a lemon chicken tagine, Moroccan cooked salad and orange salad to finish. The whole process was thoroughly enjoyable, taking around 2 hours, with step by step demonstration and instruction.The grand finale, and most eagerly anticipated part of the day was sitting down at a table for 3, where we were served up our individual creations for a private lunch. Wine was an optional extra, and most welcome. I must admit, in my 10 days in Morocco that meal was the best I had!We thoroughly enjoyed our morning and all took away valuable tips, which will certainly be used in the future. Though on initial research not being sure of the slightly high price, none of us were disappointed by the service we received and the fantastic surroundings our morning was spent in. Moreover, our host Mohammed was vastly knowledgable gentleman who was not only an able cooking tutor, but was able to satisfactorily answer many of our other questions on Morocco.

fantastic way to spend an afternoon. my boyfriend and i have just returned from a great trip to Marrakech, the highlight of which was our afternoon spent at La Maison Arabe Cooking Workshop. Mohammed is a fantasic tutor and taught us so much about Moroccan culture as well as its cuisine.the kitchen is at la maison arabe's country club which is about 15 mins out of the city. the hotel put on a shuttle bus to take you out there. it is so refreshing to get away from the mayhem of the city and the gardens are a beautiful.we spent the afternoon making preserved lemon and olive tagine and morrocan salad and ate it under the huge fig tree in the gardens. truly gorgeous. i would recommend this to everyone.

Excellent introduction to Moroccon cuisine. As part of our culinary tour of Morocco, we wanted to learn a bit more about Moroccan cuisine, and spent an enjoyable morning taking this cooking class. The facility was spotless and beautiful, the instructor and her interpreter both very pleasant to work with, and the class was well-structured. Even though the dishes were extremely simple, the class was very well-structured, and served as a very good introduction. I would note that the knives were not as sharp as I had hoped, but that the instructor was very good at determining people’s levels of experience and helping them as needed.We prepared a salad (tomato and pepper), a chicken and lemon tagine, and simple orange dessert. All were very tasty, and this old chef learned a new technique or two. Wine and tea were offered with our meal, and the transport out to the facility from the medina was a mini-tour in its own right. We also enjoyed the pleasant company of our classmates!Later in the week, we attended another class in the souks: it pointed up how well-organized this class was, even if the dishes prepared were not as eloborate as some might hope. All-in-all, a sound introduction to Moroccan cuisine.

Great morning, great food. A great way to spend a morning if you have the time. It's held in a beautiful morrocan house / villa with a swimming pool in a tranquil setting away from the old town. Mohammed, who takes you through the cooking course is a really lovely and interesting guy who is fascinating to talk to about morocco and moroccan culture. We learned about a lot more than just cooking from him!We made a 3 course meal and like others my tagine really was the best one i had in morocco. It is quite expensive but when you consider that you pay about 500 Dhirams for a 3 course meal in a restaurant anyway it actually is pretty good value. And a lot of fun!

great experience. My husband and I recently did our very first cooking class at La Maison Arabe.Whilst it was quite expensive, it was worth it for the delicious food, tranquil respite from marrakesh and the pleasure of Mohammed's company (who hosts the cooking class). We cooked a delicious tagine and learnt a few tips and tricks along the way (including the simplest way to peel an orange).At the end of the class we were able to sit in the beautiful gardens at the cooking school and eat our meal and drink wine. It got chilly so they even bought my husband a blanket to wrap around himself.Spending a few hours in Mohammed's company was one of the highlights of this outing too. He was able to give us plenty of advice about the rest of our stay, and provided an insight into everyday Moroccan culture. Thank you Mohammed!

A great place to learn to cook Morrocan style. The whole trip was world class. We got picked up at the Maison Arabe and got whisked off with another family of 4 on a 30 min journey out of the old town to a secret hideqwqy. When we got dropped off , the 6 of us were met by a very friendly man named Mohammed, who led us down beautifully grown gardens with thick rosemary hedges to a poolside table. There we sat, soaked up the winter sun and furiously scribbled notes as to how to cook 'morrocan style'. We then went upstairs in the uge Maison to a purpose bulit kitchen with 6 stations for the pupils and the head chefs position in the middle so all can see. Everything was laid out the same for everyone and the 2 lady chefs demostrated everything that had to be done whist mohammed narrated the sequence all very calmly and simply. Inbetween history and cultural lessons on Morroco, we onjured up a masterpiece. The aromas and visual beauty was something to behold and soon the flashbulbs were going off as everyone marvelled their delights. We retired downstairs to the lounge, sat with a bottle of wine whilst our dishes were served to us in style.With full bellies and contentment, we returned t the MAison Arabe... All in all a very worthwhile and memorable experience. Very laid back, beautiful surroundings, and veryfriendly staff. The food was amazing ( if I do say so myself)! and I fully recommend it.

Delicious!. Just back from Marrakech - and missing the sunshine!Booked a cooking class at La Maison Arabe. I enjoyed it very much. Mohammed was most helpful and patient. The chicken tagine was delicious - turned out to be the best one we had during our holiday! Can't wait to recreate it......

A chance to learn the basics of Moroccan cuisine. Marrakesh: La Maison L'Arabe Cooking SchoolDate: 13 November, 2008.Reviewer: Suzanne - Melbourne, Australia.I travelled to Morocco in September with 7 very good friends. As the nominated travel planner, I included a cooking class at La Maison L'Arabe. We stayed downtown at "La Maison" and were transferred to the outskirts of town to the hotel's private annexe. This is a walled oasis of lush gardens with a swimming pool and the Cooking School. By the day of the class, we had some idea of the dishes that were the basis of Moroccan cuisine. We were given a choice of dishes for our class. We had also succumbed to the charms of the wonderful ceramics used to cook and serve these dishes. We were all set to learn the basics and transfer this knowledge to our own kitchens.Mohammed, who is a University professor of English, manages the school and accompanies the class. The kitchen is beautifully set up with individual stations for the students. The "dada", or traditional cook, guided us through the skills of preparing and cooking Moroccan salads, meats and fruits with the appropriate Moroccan spices, herbs and accompaniments. The dishes were not difficult, they were an introduction. More complex dishes involving the local pastries and dishes for festivities could be learned with additional classes. For our requirements (and skill levels) this class was ideal. Recipes are available by request on email, communication has been very efficient.While waiting for lunch to be served, we enjoyed the company of Mohammed who, in answer to a myriad of questions, gave us much information on the history and culture of this ancient, colourful country. I am sorry he will not be with us next weekend when we have our first Moroccan dinner party and serve our lemon chicken with olives in our gorgeous targine.

Highlight of our trip. Thoroughly enjoyed this cooking workshop. The facility is set up really well, everything is modern and clean, with a beautiful pool and garden to have lunch by. Mohammed was an excellent teacher, very friendly and professional. He catered well for the two in our group who were vegetarian. The recipes were delicious (the best we'd tasted during our 4 days in Marrakech) but also simple enough to recreate at home. Even for backpackers on a budget like us, it was worth every penny! It was also a nice way to get out of the hustle and bustle of Marrakech for a morning. Would highly recommend to anyone.

A Tasty Treat. My husband and I spent a great afternoon at the Maison Arabe cookery school. It was relaxing yet informative and very hands-on at the same time. Mohammed who runs the school was very friendly and took us through each stage of the ingredients and cooking at a nice pace. We made a lovely chicken and olive tagine with salad, which we later enjoyed in the beautiful gardens. I would recommend it to anyone who has an interest in food or cookery and wants to learn more about moroccan cuisine and culture. It was just the two of us which made it very personal as well.

Greatly over-rated. We recently attended the cooking workshop at La Maison Arabe with some anticipation having read the reviews. We were very disappointed. We were taught to cook a very simple Moroccan starter (took about 10 mins to prepare), an equally simple tagine and a dessert of oranges sliced and sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar. Hardly complex.For a half day cooking course (supposedly) at significant cost, and without written menus at the end, this was poor value and wasted time, particularly for anyone who has ever done any cooking. The food we had prepared was good and yes, a bottle of water was provided for four at the table "at no additional cost" joked the waiter - but only one - additional water was extra. We should have stayed in our riad and cooked with the staff as offered.

Moroccan Cooking. I enjoyed attending La Maison Arabe cooking workshop as it was a very small kitchen so we could get individual attention from the lovely staff. It was authentic, the food delicious, the surroundings superb. My only criticism is that the demonstration was very slow, we could have learnt more dishes in the time and we we had to write down the recipes instead of being given printed copies.Tricia Brown

Cook Swim Cook in mini-Eden. As guests at the Hotel Maison Arabe for an extended hen weekend, we were fully acquainted with the lush paradise in which the cooking school is situated as it also houses the pool - a peaceful oasis with sun and seamless poolside waiter service. The hotel (in the heart of the Medina) provides a shuttle out to this beautiful facility and boy did we make use of that.The cooking lesson on the last afternoon was a welcome respite from the sun. A short lecture on Moroccan cuisine followed by much hilarity in the kitchen making a chicken tagine with preserved lemons and olives, a cumin-laced side salad and an orange salad for desert.While it cooked, the dada (cook) kindly minded our tagines while we returned to the pool for a dip for 40 minutes, returning to the beautiful kitchen (I want one just like that) to plate our food and move outside to the shaded patio area to eat the fruits of our labour.Not too hard. Good fun. Mohammed who facilitated the event had lovely easy style and it really was the perfect end to a fabulous long weekend.

an oasis of quiet away from the buzz of the jemma elfna. Coming to the La Maison Arabe cooking classes every year with my travel group is always a highlight of our journey. Stepping into the walled organic gardens, brushing the scented hedges and quietly watching the turtles in the pond is one of my favourite sensory experiences of Morocco. The grounds are immaculately and lovingly kept and the school beautifully fitted with individual cooking stations, colourful ceramics and fresh organic ingredients. Mohamed is an intelligent and informative host and teacher. His knowledge is wide and diverse. He is always accompanied by 'dada' and although a quiet and gentle woman, holds a strong traditional presence in her kitchen. After the meal is cooked it is a great delight to sit with Mohamed and other travellers from all over the world to share a sumptuous meal by the shade of the palm trees overlooking the aqua pool. I will always highly recommend this great experience.

Sensational Food & a very knowledgeable teacher. My husband and I chose Morocco as a holiday destination after seeing a cooking show in Australia. Our ten day trip was finished off with a cooking class at La Maison Arabe. The location was so very beautiful, the kitchen was sensationally set up and Mohammed and his lovely assistant were great (and patient!) teachers. I found the class extremely helpful but my far more "competent in the kitchen" husband found it a bit simple and easy for his abilities. Mohammed was a wealth of knowledge and knew so much about Morocco and its culture, it was wonderful to sit down with him. On our return, my husband emailed Mohammed for more recipes which Mohammed promptly sent. I am definitely looking forward to the Moroccan dinner party my husband is planning. This class is certainly a great family class to do and the food we ate after the class was sensational, even if I do say so myself :)

Great Cooking Class. My daughter and I spent 2 1/2 weeks in April traveling throughout Morocco. One of the highlights of our trip was the cooking class sponsored by La Maison Arabe (which is also a wonderful place to stay while in Marrakech). We attended the class in a beautiful, tranquil setting on our last day in the fascinating city of Marrakech and learned how to prepare the lamb tagine with couscous and 7 vegetables. It was by far the best tagine that we had while on our trip! Mohammed was an excellent translator and provided us with lots of information throughout the lesson. The two cooks showed us how to prepare the meal step by step. After arriving home, I e-mailed Mohammed and asked for some recipes which I received that same day. This is an experience not to be missed!TeresaWilmington, NC

Good Cooking. My wife and I wanted to learn about cooking i Morroco after reading an article in a Norwegian newspaper.After arriving in Marrakech we were recomended the La Maison Arabe .Thanks to Mr. Mohammed Nahir it turned out to be a great experience.The cook (dada) was also a great help.

A relaxed and enjoyable cooking lesson!. My daughter and I thoroughly enjoyed our 6 day trip to Marrakech and the cooking lesson was definitely one of the best days we had. The environment was relaxed and the people we met on the course were good fun! It was a cultural experience well worth doing. Mohammed Nahir enhanced the experience with his stories and information on many aspects of not only the cooking, but also life in Marrakech today. Many thanks!Pandora and HollieKent, England.

A Hidden Paradise!!!!. Wonderful setting, tranquil gardens with lush folliage surround a peaceful bathing area with shaded seating and dinner table. Cooking experience was out of this world, chopping carrots has never been so much fun - expertly guided by our interpreter Mohammed and the morrocan ladies there - a fabulous day and I can only hope that the recipies can be recreated in my kitchen at home!! A wonderfully clean and cool kitchen given the outside temperatures - everything provided.

Tasty Morrocan cooking lessons!. During the last day of our Moroccan tour, we spent a lovely afternoon at the Maison arabe's garden estate, located just outside the old city of Marrakesh. The beautiful grounds and pool provide a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of the medina. Inside the spacious and gorgeous house, we had an enjoyable, hands-on Moroccan cooking lesson with Mohammed, our talented chef and teacher. Not only did we make a delicioius chicken with preserved lemon and olive dish, we got to eat it for lunch! It was certainly one of the more memorable moments of our trip. We left relaxed, with full bellies and recipes to take home. I would strongly recommend this experience to anyone interested in learning more about Moroccan cuisine and culture.

One of the highlights of my Moroccan holiday. We spent a beautiful afternoon learning how to cook Moroccan food from an authentic cook, in an immaculate kitchen, amidst stunning surroundings.
I've wowed my Australian friends by cooking the beautiful food on my return home.
As well as the dishes cooked in the session, participants can have more recipes emailed afterwards!
Excellent value, memorable and very worthwhile.

Chicken and Berber tagine. The cookery workshop is held a short car ride away from the main hotel in the most amazing location. The gardens and swimming pool are absolutely beautiful and very relaxing, unfortunately you can’t swim in the pool as it is for guests only.We were given a very informative explanation of Moroccan food, spices and ingredients by Mohammed before making our way up to the most amazing kitchen I have ever seen.My husband cooked Chicken tagine with preserved lemons and olives and as I am vegetarian I was shown how to cooked a vegetable (Berber) tagine. There are a maximum of 6 students in each class and the pace was very easy going.Once we had the salad and tagines prepared we had time to enjoy the grounds and explore the wonderful gardens before eating the lunches we had prepared.My husband who is a novice cook enjoyed the session and learning the different skills. I very much enjoyed learning about the different ingredients and meals but I am a much more adventurous cook and did feel that I would have liked to have learned more. One of the ladies peeled and chopped most of my vegetables for me so all I really had to do was put everything in the tagine and add the spices. I think this is an excellent session for beginners but maybe not for the more adventurous. However we did learn lots about what to look for in a tagine and have come home with 2 ready to amaze all our friends.

Flavour of Morocco. We spent a wonderful morning learning how to cook some real Moroccan food and enjoyed eating the results for lunch. We have now tried to cook it back in England, but it just doesn't taste quite the same when it is cold and wet outside. Overall this was one of the highlights of our holiday and the memories of it will live on every time we cook a tagine.

Must Do Activity in Marrakech. My husband and I took the Arabe cooking workshop on March 20, 2008. We had a fantastic experience. Mohammed was a great food instructor. His English is perfect (he is an English Professor) and he is very patient (great for novice cooks). This class was a wonderful break from the busy Medina and another wonderful way to immerse oneself into the culture of Morocco. I would highly recommend this activity.

a wonderfull, inspiring place. My friend and I took a cooking course given by Maison Arabe. We booked this on the site of the hotel (in which we did not stay, way above our budget!) and arrived at the hotel, where we met two other couples and were taken by shuttle to a very beautifull and luxurious villa outside of Marrakech (bring bathing gear, there is a wonderfull pool!). There, we met up with Mohammed, a very nice english teacher and translator for the local cook who showed us how to make a real Marocan tagine and salad. Though not very difficult to make, it was very, very tastefull and inspired us to buy a tagine in the medina and take it all the way home with us (heavy, but it arrived in one piece!)I would really recommend taking this course; it gives you a real 'taste' of Marrakech.

Wonderful Culinary Experience. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our cooking class at La Maison Arabe. Mohammed was a perfect guide/translator and the tagine class capped a wonderful week in Morocco. The chicken tagine we made was actually the best we had in Morocco. We'll try to duplicate it at home! I would highly recommend the class for anyone looking to learn a bit more about Moroccan culture/cuisine or just looking for a fun afternoon.

bring all the flavours of marrakech back home .... We met Mohammed Nahir, our cookery teacher for the morning and local expert on all things to do in Marrakech, in the beautiful gardens of La Maison Arabe on a sunny, hot morning just over a week ago. Mohammed gave us a background to Moroccan cooking (and gave us notepads and pencil to write it down if we wanted). Then we went up to the kitchens - amazing! - where he and his assistant Aziza showed us how to make a Moroccan salad and a tagine of lamb with figs and walnuts. The teaching was excellent - and so was our food - with the help of Mohammed and Aziza - which was served to us once ready on the terrace under the shade of a tree. I did the morning's course with a friend so it was great to have so much attention with just the two of us and feel able to ask lots of questions. Mohammed also told us where to buy all our spices in the covered spice market. I am definitely going back to learn to cook more things next time I'm in Marrakech!

Cooking class in Marrakech, Morocco. La Maison Arabe cookery class was superb. We spent an afternoon immersed in Moroccan culture in a gorgeous setting under the guidance of a University of Morocco English professor, Mohammed Nahir, who was acting as translator. Meeting Professor Nahir was the cultural highlight of our trip to Morocco. We discussed with him many aspects of Moroccan life including education, women's issues, and religion all the while preparing and then sharing a delicious meal.

Family fun. 8 of us went including two vegetarians, we now can't wait to cook tagine at home. It was a good laugh and very informative - beautiful setting where you can sit by the pool whilst you wait for your meal to cook. Mohammed Nahir is knowledgeable and interesting and happens to be a local expert for Marrakech - well worth contacting him in advance.

Tagine For Two. if you are in marrakech for a few days and have spent time in the souks, done the square and not been mown down by the mad mad traffic do yourself a real favour spend half a day with mohammed nahir. cost a few bob. 1200 for two.be transported to the outskirts of the town , to a beautiful house and garden and cook. it will be one of the highlights of your stay in morocco.mr nahir likes his job and he is great company and ready to help you in any way . what could be better than cooking a great moroccon dish and eating your own in idylic surroundings.give this cooking class a try. you wont regret it.

Reserve now....before it's too late!. Taking this class was one of the best decisions I've made in a long time! I signed up solo and was a bit shy about that. I got over it right away, after meeting Mohammed, our instructor, and the other two attendees, a fun couple from Michigan. To say we enjoyed ourselves was an understatement. From the stunning kitchen to the beautiful gardens, not to mention the absolutely delicious chicken tangine lunch....that we made ourselves....well, it was a perfect way to spend the day. Mohammed is a wealth of information on spices and "H"erbs, not only in Morroccan cooking but in many other ethnicities. We learned a lot and had a great time. Mohammed is the MAN!Sally

Great fun in Marrakech. My wife and I just returned from Marrakech, where a highlight of our trip was the Cooking Workshop run by Maison Arabe. (Reserve in advance. Elapsed time 9:30AM to 2:30PM. Cost for two was 1200 Dirhams.) Here, we each cooked a Moroccan feast under the expert guidance of a lead instructor and two chefs, who monitored our progress every step of the way. The potentially scary part was eating our creation for lunch (in a magnificient courtyard garden), which turned out to be less daunting and more exhilirating than we had imagined. I for one am not ready to give up my day job just yet, but I can see myself experimenting often with gourmet recipes and enjoying my labors in the kitchen as a result of my experience at the Workshop. Particularly noteworthy was our warm and gracious lead instructor, Mohammed Nahir, whose knowledge and stories of Moroccan cooking, spices, customs, history and the region kept us enthralled for hours. Thank you, Mohammed, more than we can say!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Compliments to the Chef. Agree with previous posters, this is a must do for vistors to Marrakech who are interested in the local cuisine. Mohammad's easy going style,immediately puts all at ease as he translates the actions of his lady chefs. His knowledge of Moroccan culture compliments the day and he is happy to answer any question about his native country, whilst the food is cooking. The location is idylic and the meal (cooked by outselves) was beautifully served. Great fun.

Great food - should be, i cooked it myself :-). Great introduction to Moroccan cooking and the tagine. If you've any reservations about making a hash of it - then don't have, Mohammed Nahir and the Moroccan cook are most helpful and the results worthwhile.In addition, Mohammed is a very interesting guy to talk with and an expert on all things Moroccan.Great setting, great facility, great fun.What are you waiting for??

Great even for the most reluctant of cooks.... We were a small group of 3 ladies, 2 of whom cooked and one a self-confessed biff in the kitchen. We joined 2 other couples at La Maison Arabe and were taken by minibus to a beautiful farmhouse in lovely gardens on the fringe of the city where we chatted, drank wine and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Oh yes! And we managed to learn how to cook a 2 course Moroccan meal which we enjoyed eating by the pool afterwards. Mohammed is a relaxed facilitator who can help you with guides and advice for the rest of your stay - do this early on in your trip. Do not worry about pens or notepaper, this is all provided, and Mohammed will email you recipes afterwards. Go on! Have a go.

Must do in Marrakech. A beautiful setting and a wonderful and educational class. Mohammed Nasir, who teaches the class, is a wealth of information about Moroccan food and many other things Moroccan. What a wonderful way to spend the morning.RSK

Great class and great host. I could not have imagine a better cooking class then the one provided by Mohammed Nahir at the La Maison Arabe Cooking Workshops. The location was gorgeous, all details thought of in advance and arranged, the product fresh, and the food produced one of the best meals we had while in the country.The real gem, however, was Mohammed Nahir, an interesting, well-spoken, and well-educated (he is also a professor) cook. He was informative about the cooking and about the country and culture in general. I wish I had known he served as a guide prior to my last day there as I believed he could have added a layer to Marrakesh that would have deepened the experience.Although our group thought the class was private class, we quickly forgot this concern because the quality of the class was so high and because Mohammed was such and interesting and great host.I would highly recommend.

Cooking Oasis. The review by 2BAnonymous gives a perfect account of what happens during the cooking class. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our time in the oasis that is La Maison Arabe. We only wished we had brough our swimming attire for a dip in the beautiful pool.We were amazed by the gardens, including the fact that rosemary, one of our favorite herbs, is used as shrubbery!Mohammed Nahir, who is also an English professor at the local university, provided us great insight into Morocco and its people as he taught us about its cuisine.The weak dollar made this activity rather pricey, especially since we were the only two in the class. However, it was a great treat!

learning to cook traditional dishes. booked onto this course on our last day. had a great time, with a flient spking teacher, followed y being able to eat our dish outside in the sun by the pool. beautiful surroundings, excelent location and stunning kitchen. definitaley recommend it!

Delicious and Interesting - a Must for Marrakech. We reserved the cooking course at La Maison Arabe on the recommendation of friends who had previously attended a class. Their review of the experience was glowing, and we were not disappointed.Roundtrip transportation from La Maison Arabe to their off-site location is easy (and included in the price of the course). After several twists and turns through the city, you find yourself in a beautiful garden setting. La Maision Arabe certainly spared no expense in the design and finish out of this property.We were met by Mohammed and commenced our day over mint tea with a general discussion of Moroccan cuisine and the spices used. Based on our interest, he walked us through the process (and dictated from memory the exact recipe) for making traditional couscous and seven vegatables. I cannot wait to try it out.Our class consisted of just my wife and me and focused on the preparation of taktuka, a "salad" of tomatoes and green peppers, and a tajine with chicken, preserved lemon and olives. (I understand that if you prefer to learn a particular dish, you can make arrangements in advance.) Ingredients are neatly laid out at your workstation when you arrive (although laid out nicely, nothing is pre-prepared - you chop, dice and slice everything yourself). After a brief introduction to what lay in store for us, Mohammed set us to work. Each step was explained clearly and we were given ample time to execute to task at hand. Given the differing preparation times, you bounce between the salad and the tajine. After the salad was complete and our tajines were cooking away, we went outside into the garden to take down the recipe for what we had just cooked. Mohammed is very interesting so I would encourage you to take the opportunity to chat with him about Morocco, Marrakech and life in general.Once everything is ready, you are taken to a table where a waiter serves you the meal you prepared. Since the weather was nice, we ate in the garden - just lovely.If you love to cook or just love to eat, this course is a fantastic way to spend half a day in Marrakech. (For those who fear the kitchen, there is no need to worry. The structure of the course is such that it moves at your pace. It is a pressure-free way to roll up your sleeves and to discover your "inner chef".)The cost of the course at MAD 1'600 (roughly EUR 140) for a two-person course is certainly not cheap, but well worth the cost for the quality of the experience and the food. Note that the per person cost declines with each person added to the course (I believe to as low as MAD 500 each). Beverages are not included in the price.

Learn to cook Moroccan dishes - tasty and fun!. Organized via the hotel La Maison Arabe - you can do one day or multi-day cooking workshops. Workshops run from approximately 9am - 2pm, including transportation, and you get to eat your work for lunch! Truly one of the most enjoyable things we did in Marrakech. Small class size, professional and beautiful cooking facility, very good explanation and demonstration. If you call ahead, you can also request to learn to make specific dishes.
